Bottled. Dark brown color with small head. Sweet, roasted caramel, some chocolate, faint hints of smoke and peat in aroma. Taste is similar, sweet caramel, dark fruits and a bit of booze.

Founders Dirty Bastard is a cloudy, red-brown ale topped with a thin, bubbly, yellowish film. It has a sweet, whiskey like aroma; malty and resiny. Its pretty full bodied and smooth with a dusty finish. Its sweet and syrupy. It tastes malty and resiny, just like the aroma.  There may be a hint of peat and lots of toffee.  This is a solid and well done Scotch ale.

Here in CT we have "Ten Penny Ale", which is also a flagship scotch ale, from a different brewery. But, Ten Penny is more of a session beer - not on the same level as this monster. Very strong flavor, lots of alcohol and smoked malt. A good choice for whisky drinkers. Lots of caramel sweetness and roasted malts as well. Resiny hops for balance. Very impressive.

Pours a lovely mahoghany red with an aroma full of malt and bread. The taste is heavy, much like one would expect from an excellent scotch ale. Drink one of these and you know you did...in a good way, of course. Tried this beer on reputation of the brewery alone and can guarantee other Founders libations will soon make their way to my home. Good job lads. Well done!

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2016 Bottle from Alko, Helsinki. A reddish dark brown color with a medium-sized white head that leaves lacing. The aroma features plenty of sweet, maltiness with a rich combination of dark fruits, nuts, fudge and caramel  delicious. The taste takes off with caramel sweetness that bends into a dryish, slightly bitter British-style finish. Flavours of raisin and caramel are accompanied by vanilla and sherryish notes usually found on oak-aged ales. Only a faint touch of alcohol in the finish. The palate is medium to full bodied with a low, soft carbonation. A good, refined Scotch ale for late-night tasting sessions.

Bottle (12 oz). Dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, smoke and hints of pepper. Taste is moderate sweet with caramel and earthy notes. Mouthfeel is almost watery. Slight alcohol warming. Less sugary than most of the Scotch Ale so its kind of drinkable. Not very complex. Im not impressed.

Tasted in a blind Scotch Ale tasting on october 13th 2012 (my ranking in parenthesis): Rank # 1: Le Bilboquet MacKroken fût de chêne (# 3) # 2: Alesmith Wee Heavy (# 1) # 3: Cigar City Big Sound (# 2) # 4: À la Fût Corne de Brume (# 5) # 5: Dieu du Ciel Équinoxe du Printemps (# 4) # 6: Founders Dirty Bastard (# 6) # 7: Glazen Toren Canaster Winterscotch (# 7)

Bottle. Dark mahogny w/good sized head. Nose is sweetish, caramel, sweetish aged malty - raisins, plums, syrupy- with even some yeast spicyness. Body is thickish and smooth. No signs of alc, but malts, some plums, some roasted tones, burnt sugar. A very flavorful drink. Bit, but smooth.-- bb/h

Bottle @ Kaisla. Pours an auburn-tinged dark brown with a small, dark latte head. Aroma is caramel malts mostly, some salty liquorice, light peat and grapefruity hoppines there. Taste is very much caramel, some smoke, a bit sweet, some salty liquorice, light grapefruit tones. Palate is full.

12 oz. bottle served in a shaker pint at Buffalo Wild Wings.

A: Pours a dark brown with a ruby tinted edges. A thin tan head forms on the pour and leaves some soapy lace down the glass.

S: The nose is mainly all malts, a touch of smokiness and a very faint hop presence at the backend.

T: Rich caramel and bready malts are the major players in the taste. There is a touch of peat and a very light smoke as well.

M: Full bodied beer with ample carbonation. There is a slight peaty finish to this that lingers around.

O: Very easy drinking and a solid scotch ale. The variety of malts used really give this beer different layers of flavor.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-08-2012

On the money for a scotch ale. Not my favorite stule but this is solid. Strong up front scotch flavor, but finishes nicely. These are generally sippers for me. A winner from Founders an very popular for a reason.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I love a scotch ale and this is a worthy one.  The bouquet is ripe with rich maltiness.  Its bold and chewy.  This is absolutely worth drinking and seeking out.

Bottled.  Pours a medium to deep amber with a head that starts out coppery, developing into a uniform light tan.  Sweet aroma of caramel and berries.  Bittersweet flavors up front, dark chocolate and tart fruit.  Pleasant, warm mix of hop bitterness and alcohol follows, leading to a finish that is just a bit too harsh.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied.  Good level of complexity and flavor in this one.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Founders Dirty Bastard Scotch Ale - Dark reddish-brown with minor head and good lacing.  Definite peaty, smoky aroma.  Big, complex malt flavor - very tasty, though the booziness seems higher than the 8.5% advertised.  This brewer consistently wows me more than any other - I never thought I would touch a Scotch Ale, let alone like one, and here I am, happy as can be.  Oddly enough, its their DIPA that I find the least impressive of the beers Ive had by them so far, but even that was still "pretty good."

nose: malts,peat,
taste: cocoa, warm, balanced, sweet, 
aftertaste: cocoa, soft well balanced


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown color, little carbonation.  Strong nutty flavor with hops.  Smooth finish.  Very good for the style.
Au nez, pas tres convaincant.  Une amertume plus prononcee qua lhabitude pour une scotch ale.  Le gout sucre habituel dune scotch ale nest pas present.  Leger gout metallique.
I love the dirty bastard. consistantly a favorite of mine. big malts, with some slight smokiness. this is a go-to for me when i cant decide what sounds delicious.

This is a unique and delicious brew.  The aroma has all the qualities of a good scotch including a nice malt scent.  I love the way this beer pours and looks in the glass.  Its a mahogany color with some cloudiness.  You cant see through it.  Very little head that quickly dissipates and leaves just slight lacing.  It feels medium to full bodied to me and has a thick almost oily mouth feel.  It has a long finish and you can really feel the alcohol hit you at 8.5% abv.  Taste is very rich and malty with a definite scotch flavoring that runs through it with some caramel and toffee flavor undercurrent.  Its an interesting style thats worth trying.  I also LOVE their Rye P.A.  One of my favs.

Being an avid scotch drinker I was interested in trying this brew. It has a very nice aroma with a hint of scotch. The pour is a gorgeous dark amber. The taste is sweet caramel like and has a finish with a little burn, more of a warming factor. Overall this beer is good in a 4 pack better as a single one or 2 bottle. I enjoyed this beer

Poured from the bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a thick dark amber-copper pour and color with light sediment and a smallish foamy white head that had short retention, modest cling, and average lacing.  The aroma featured floral and fruity hops notes along with some caramel malt and sugar, and touches of pine, grain, and a smoky effect.  It was a bitter-sour grainy and fruity blend in taste with an undertone of lightly sweet caramel malt.  The body was very thick and full mouthfeel with low-to-average carbonation and a wet character.

Bottle. Mahogany brown pour with neat tan head. Slightly alcohol aroma. Predominantly like prune juice with butterscotch notes. Rich peaty flavor of dark fruits with bitter chocolate (was not expecting that) and anise notes. Snappy mouthfeel. Lively on the tongue, but heavy on the lips. Warms the belly like a good Scotch ale should. This is a very smooth ale. I was a little surprised by the chocolate in the taste, but it really blended the other flavors beautifully. The finish was much more traditional and good. A very nice beer. My first from Founders. Must have more.

Aromas of caramel, licorice & wood smoke.A hop edge in the flavor, helped by the smoke sour & coffee keeps in balance the dark & raspy sweetness. Drinking it at the Pittsburgh airport (they also had arrogant bastard on tap), was trying to classify it, as it seemed verging on stout (without the dark roast in flavor) though more a deep burnt sienna, with a moderate dark khaki head. I like this take on scotch ale, with some more hop/smoke rasp, and no danger of cloying sweetness.
Nice! Smells like scotch with a little scotch flavor. A little strong alcohol taste at first but by the second drink you dont notice it.

Pours a dark mahogany deep brown with a small head. Nose is fruity with raisins and alcohol wafting as well. Taste is chocolate and coffee with some mild bitter sweetness. Taste is malty as well and very drinkable. Finish is sweet and dry. Delicious Scotch Ale. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours red brown with a tan head and aroma of fruit, malt, and caramel. Taste is sweet and toasty, of roasted malt, chocolate, fruit, caramel, and a slight bitter finish with some lingering alcohol. Good, complex beer from Founders.

Aroma - Lots of caramel and malt smells. Appearance - Nice deep brown/ redish. Taste - Not as much caramel tasting notes as expected lots of nice rounded malts though. Palate - Is lighter than expected. Overall - Not bad full of scotch flavor!

6/22/12 bottle to a pint glass. Pours a hazy mahogany brown with almost no head. Aroma is malts, caramel, and watered down scotch with a tad of smoke. Taste is bitter up front. It gives way to a malty sweetness with some toffee and caramel. There is a slight smokiness to the back with a strong roasted malt flavor. Mouthfeel is medium and alcohol is somewhat present. Good representation of the style.

Very delicious beer. Nice, complex aroma; with a thick, lacey head. Some sediment in the bottom of the glass was the only negative. Malty start with a smooth, tasty finish. A little boozy, but a great session sipper.

This is really everything i want in a beer.  Malty, yet has just enough crispness not to weigh it down.  And a nice gorgeous color.  Id drink this all night, if I could keep from falling off the barstool.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The beer itself is a deep, transparent ruby color with a small off-white head that froths up on the initial pour before fading to a ring around the glass.

Toasted bread, cocoa powder, a bit of peat, and some dark fruit notes create the aroma.

Each sip starts out a little bit sweet, with a touch of caramel and cocoa up front.  Toasted bread, dried cherries, and some nuts round out the flavor profile.  

The mouthfeel is fairly balanced, with carbonation that falls between creamy and crisp and a medium body.  A slight stickiness sits on my lips after each sip.

This is a well made beer from Founders.  The Scotch Ale style is not really for me, though.
Bottle. Dark ruby body with white cap of foam. Aroma Carmel and hint of hops. Taste Carmel,cherries and good hop character. Refreshingly good scotch ale.
Aroma is sweet, taste is the same, caramel and big hoppiness. Real impressed with this bold beer, very good.

Smell is lightly roasted caramel, some cherry sweetness, a hint of chocolate.  Not a whole lot of carbonation, but great color.  Nice carbonation that didnt stay around for too long.  Looks very clean thus far.  Mouthfeel is smooth, with a nice hit of roastyness.  A good bit of english hops make this one fairly drinkable.  Very smooth, and clean, but the complexities of bold flavor make this one great.  Enjoyability:  4.5/5.  If there was one weak spot, its not a whole lot different then other similar brewers on the market.

Bottle; dark caramel hue with minimal head; nose is boozy malt, hints of smoke and caramel; flavor is rich, sweet malts with light smoke, peat, and warming alcohol throughout, light bitterness to help balance, finishes slightly sweet and close to burning; thick texture, full body, low carbonation; overall, a very stiff/strong malt-forward scotch ale with plenty of malt tones to accentuate the over-riding alcohol presence.
Bottle. Deep brown, very little head. Smels of sugar, carmel and malt. Taste is boozy and sweet. Almost like a dark rum. Really good representation of the style

355 ml bottle shared with minderbender and czar. An opaque reddish brown ale with a short-lasting white head. Smells sweet, with barley dominating, and a touch of roast. Tastes very sweet, like caramel and candies, barley candies and a touch of chocolate. Herbal hoppy finish. Light bitterness. Medium bodied, not so thick, low level of carbonation. Pretty good!

Tap at the Royal Tavern, Philly - 26/05/12.
Dark amber with a small to medium tan head.
Big malt nose, fruit cake, bread.
Taste follows nose, sweet caramel, dark fruit, touch of cocoa.
Medium bodied with a little warming alcohol on the finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2012 I rerated this one (blind), with pretty much the same result, but with some caramel. I enjoyed it a tad less than first time.
[Former rating 8/4/8/3/14] Bottle 355ml.
Pours red/dark amber with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of malt, sweetness. Taste is of malt, sweet, sligth bitterness. Body is medium. Overall: very good. Easily drinkable for a Scotch Ale.

Bottle poured a cloudy light brown, medium tan foamy head, and minimal lacing.  Minimal aroma makes its way through the foam, but was able to distinguish hints of bready malt, caramel, and toast.  Taste is includes notes of raisins, caramel, and slight booziness.  Nice dry finish, but dont think scotch ale is my cup of tea.
On draft at lost dog cafe in arlington Virginia. Pours murky brown with a substantial creamy head. Bread rough aroma. Raisin and caramel with a long lasting bitter finish.

bottle shared with VT and minderbinder: thanks. pours light brown-reddish, almost clear, with a decent light beige head, some retention, little lacing. caramel malts, candi, lightly smoked and peppery, alcohol warmth, some sweetness, nerver cloying. soft carbonation, light to medium body - oily but not wee heavy, nice short but fairly present grassy-citrusy-lightly acidic finish. good.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 This is a nice thick earthy ale made hard to swallow by an understandable but unfortunate boozy tang. The finish is nice and smoky but its not something Id start off the night with.

Dark brown color, very little head that dissipates down to ring around glass. Smells of brown sugar, tomatoes, veggie. Plastic-like taste with bitter, very minimal sweet taste, alcohol, some sort of fruit in there too, can't peg it. Not my favorite style of beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Enjoyed at the Best of Milwaukee Beer Dinner last night at Roots in Milwaukee. Pours a mahogany with a large cream colored head. Smells of leather and plums. The taste is slightly bitter with caramel, figs and smoke with a dry finish.

The pour is dark ruby red with a thin tan head that leaves a touch of lacing.  The aroma is very malty with a hint of booze.  The taste is exploding with flavor.  While its primarily malty, theres some caramel chewiness to it as well as a nice hop finish.  There is a lot going on here and its all good!  Another outstanding effort from the micro kings they call founders!!!

Draft. Mahogony brown beer with a dark cream head. Caramel and light dark fruit aroma. Caramel and smoke flavor with light dark fruits. Medium-plus bodied. Toffee/caramel lingers with light smoke and light dark fruits.

Bottle at my dads in MI.  Cant believe Id never rated this before.  Go figure,  pours a rich ruby amber with lots of fizzy red velvet foam and bubbles racing up the sides of the glass.  Not much aroma cuts through the foam, just some solid malts and roastiness along with a touch of sweet butterscotch. Taste is strongly bittersweet at the front, followed by even more sweetness in the middle palate before evening out to a clean, bitter finish.  Sugary ABV qualities are noticeable in this brew, and again the ABV shows up in a nice burn at the finish.  Body is middling, but semi-thick for the style.  Mouthfeel is low-end creamy.  Good stuff.
Looks good; amber-brown with beige lacing.  Smells malty and hoppy.  Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel.  Good, not great.
A little bread, some brown sugar, molasses, and maybe some light coffee notes. Very good.
Puts a cloudy our hazy mahogany deep color with little head. Not much of an aroma. Hit flavor with maple syrup

Bottle. Pours clear deep reddish brown with a small brown head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel and toffee malts, with almost a peaty scotch note. Flavor is medium sweet caramel, brown sugar, roasted malt, slight smoky note. Warming and lightly bitter finish. A bit more watery than I expected.

Aroma is slight cooked vegetables. Has to be a byproduct of the yeast; gives off a horsey smell. I understand its probably the peat, but it doesnt quite work. Cereal grains and nuts. The broccoli-like sulfurs are nearly too much. 

Ruby reddish-brown. Not a ton of head, but a thin off-white layer of it. Hazy to look at.

Flavor is brown sugar malts, touch of boozy stuff going down. The taste is hazelnut, molasses and bourbon. Hints of chocolate and black coffee. 

Silky, milky feel; perfect for this style. A touch of chewy chunkiness. Its a shame that the aroma is so off, because the flavor actually top notch. Might be one of those rare craft beers thats better straight outta the bottle.

A hazy brownish amber on the pour with a very thin tan head. Aroma is fruity, yeast, caramel malt, some dark fruit notes and sweet alcohol esters fill the senses. Taste is dark fruit, caramel malt some yeast with some bitterness. The Palate is a full body with slightly smooth dry mouthfeel with good carbonation. Finish is sweet caramel malt, yeast, fruity followed by a some alcohol and slightly dry bitterness ending with a bit of lingering sweet nutty flavor. Aroma and flavor really come through as it warms up. Overall a good representation of the style
A smooth sweet caramel nose blended with just touch of smoke. The beer is brown with almost no head. The taste is sweet and malty. The beer is very smooth with a sweet but quick finish.

Sample, from a bottle, Mondial de la bière, savoured on June 8 2012; eye: dirty brown, opaque, tiny ring of beige head; nose: caramel, toffee, malt, light burnt, slight hops; mouth: toffee, caramel, slight burnt, light hops, light alcohol, finale in toffee with light presence of alcohol, medium-full body, below-average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, lightly harsh and lightly alcoholic texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, dune bouteille, Mondial de la Bière, savourée le 8 juin 2012; il : brun sale, opaque, très petit anneau de mousse beige; nez : toffee, caramel, malt, léger brûlé, très léger houblon; bouche : toffee, caramel, malt, très léger brûlé, léger houblon, léger alcool, finale en toffee avec légère présence dalcool, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement amère, légèrement sucrée, texture légèrement rugueuse et légèrement alcoolique; en résumé : bien

Delicious. Pours a dark brown with a moderate tan head. Mild aroma, slightly sweet bready aroma, some smokiness. The sweetness and smokiness is also apparent in the flavor. There is also a little spiciness. A little bitterness in the finish, but does not seem to come from hops, but more from the smoke.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

The beer appears dark brown, with crimson hues evident when held to the light. The beer arrives with a half inch of head that generates some decent lacing as it recedes. The beer is slightly smoky, with a sweet malt character evident in both the aroma and flavor. A subtle roast aspect contributes to the flavor profile, and a surprising hop bitterness in the back adds the finishing touch. The feel is medium bodied, with a healthy level of carbonation. A good, but not great, example of the style. Id drink it again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 02-21-2011
Pours a deep brown with a full finger head. Aroma is rich, malty sweet, caramel. Flavor is similar, light coffee, chocolate, malty sweet, caramel. Medium body with nice lacing. Very nice overall.

12oz bottle. Dark mahogany with a tan head that disappears fairly rapidly. Lots malts, a light peat that doesnt overwhelm, caramel. Low carbonation, moderate body, mild sweetness with lots more malt and some molasses. Becomes more bitter and "scotchy" on the finish - decent.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2012 Ar: Toasted caramel, dark fruits and some alcohol - dry red wine feel
Ap: Deep copper to brown at the bottom of a tulip glass, appears dark brown/black - head dissipates quickly and has very little retention 
T: Dried fruit, caramel malts, more sweet than bitter - intriguingly complex
P: Substantial but not too thick - soft carbonation as expected
O: Fantastic beer and incredibly drinkable.  Cannot wait until backwoods!

Aroma: Yeasty, quite malty, alcohol, nutty, berries. Appearance: Dark reddish-brown with a tan, frothy head. Taste: Dark fruit, somewhat sweet, somewhat bitter, strong malty. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, average carbonation, bitter finish.

Pours quite dark with a small brown foam head. Through light it looks a dark red with a lot of carbonation and definitely unfiltered plenty of sediment floating around. Smells sweet like toffee with plenty of complex malt flavors and some alcohol. Tastes of plenty of malts, walnuts, dark wood casks not very much smokiness. Pretty light in body easy to drink a lot of carbonation. Leaves a bad taste in my mouth but good for the style Im sure.

Poursbrown with a small head.  Aroma is roasted malt, nuts and a hint of caramel. Meduim in body with pretty light carbonation.  Flavor is lots of nuts, dark roast flavors, caramel and a touch of hops.  A perfectly balanced beer that just tatses great.

Pours wood brown with a yellow-tan head.
Scent is  sweet, heavy malt, nuts, caramel, dark fruit.
Taste is caramel/toffee.....nutty.
Alcohol and hop bitterness.
Big flavours everywhere. A little smoke thrown in as well.
Nice.....very nice.

On tap, Pours a brown amber color with a small tan head. Nose is rich malts, citrus, nutty. Taste is similar with a slight bitter finish. Slightly sweet, but still rich and hoppy. A good example of a scotch ale. I still like Oskar Blues Old Chub a little better though.

Bottle (cellared for two years). Full rich roofing tar with thick prune aroma. Muddy swamp water brown with some floaties and no head. Sweet toffeeish initial, mild sweet mid palate, a balanced final with alcohol very apparent. Medium-heavy body. Really tastes more like a restrained barley wine rather than a Scotch ale. Not a lot of complexity. Very straightforward stuff.
Dark, roast, malty flavors & aroma.  Chocolate, coffee notes.  Slightly bitter aftertaste.
Beautiful pour with a full head. On the palate caramel malt upfront, smoky on the finish. Not for the long haul but great for a beer or two.

Pretty ruby amber pour, orangeish head. Caramel drenched dark fruit on the nose, with a bit of malt syrup. Flavor doesnt bring the punch that the aroma does. More dilute, with a metallic bitter note, like overextracted hops. Good. Not great.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2015 Draft at Khyber Pass. Sept 2012. Dark orange amber with a fizzy head. Subdued aroma. Juicy malt flavors. Burnt orange peel. Chocolate caramel. Peat. Gummy bears on fire. Dense and complex but oddly crisp. Tad too sweet. Medium light body. Alcohol burn in the finish. Nice, but does not compare to a true wee heavy to me. UPDATE: Draft at Good Dog in June 2015. Appreciating it more now. Bumping it up. Great deep complex Stout notes balanced with a highly dry hoppy sharp edge. Nice sporadic lace. Heavy stuff. In balance feels like a deeply heavy Scotch Ale with some bright dry hop notes. Like a firing squad.
From a bottle from a friend. Good chocolatey flavor without being too heavy or sweet. good clean finish.
Mild tangy malt aroma. Clear dark orange color with a small white head. Mix of alcohol and hop bitterness that builds into the middle and last to the finish. A really good scotch ale.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2014 Deep brown pour with offwhite head. Scent is sweet and a little smokey. Great medium body. Very balanced scotch ale, not one flavor sticks out. Malty taste with a little bitter finish. Great beer and very unique scotch ale.

From a big trade. Pours darker brownish red, almost tea colored. Minimal head. Smells sweet malty, toffee caramel, like a less bitter english barleywine. Taste pretty sweet, caramel, bit of a bitterness to it, sticky. Very drinkable though bigger bodied. Nice.

Bottle 35.5 cl thanks to Tim. Pale red and rusty; aroma is intense vanilla, heavyily spiced like ginger or cinnamon, orange peel, dates, macaroon/ratafia. Taste - medium in body - is pure malt and ginger, with the typical dryness of scotch ales. An alright bitter of oranges in spirits, fortified by the peel... becomes a sorta of orange whiskey. Finish tends to strong drink dryness. Complex beer, not annoying and no session as well. I dont like scotch ales much, but you cant state prejudice in front of a good one. And Dirty Bastard it is.

12 oz. bottle- Pours a very nice dark hazy ruby red  with a thick light tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, peat, not really any smoke in the aroma unfortunately. The taste is so smooth, sweet yet fairly light malt, but intense flavor, hops are welcome here, but its all about the malt in this style, peat and moderate smoke, just really drinkable. Sweet and malty, but not overly so. Nice beer, but I would have preferred more of a smokey taste, dont be subtle on the smoke man, stoke it up.

Great, great scotch ale. Founders doesnt make anything half-hearted, and this is no exception. Great malt flavor, with a great hop balance to it. Never too bitter, never too anything...just a great representation of the style. Had a bottle of this back to back with 3 Floyds Robert The Bruce and loved them both for the differences they stand on, but the DB seems to be more of the standard to this style.

Poured from bottle into snifter. Pours deep ruby red in color with little head formation. I really had to aggressively pour it to create an inch of head. On the nose are aromas of dark fruits, malt, cherry, and some wine notes. Flavors are complex and intense with sweet malts combined with dark fruits and sherry/wine notes. Mouthfeel is lighter than expected with good carbonation and a boozy palate. Overall it's a big strong brew that's a pleasure to sip. 

--- Cheers
Very malty aroma.  Complex taste.  Sweet taste.  Medium to dark body.  Almost spicy finish.  Very good beer with many flavors.  Hard to pinpoint all of the flavors.
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2012 Currently my favorite drink. My introduction to wee heavy / scotch ale and I compare others to this.
Aroma of dark malt and feet.  Thick and dark, very malty with caramel roasty flavor.  Sweet finish with slight hop bite.  Lots of dark roasted caramel.   Very heavy.  Not outstanding.
Bottle. Color dark red with small white head. Aroma malt, caramel, sugar, berries. Taste sweet, alcohol, caramel.
Excellent beer! Pours dark amber with a light amber foamy head.  Smells of malt, and tastes of caramel.  Very smooth drink, with little bitterness, and a slightly sweet finish.

Aroma- caramel, malts, brown sugar, peat
Appearance- ruby red, crescent white head, murky
Taste- roasted malts, caramel, slight smoke, metallic aftertaste
Palate- decent body, smooth mouthfeel
Overall- Not bad but not anywhere near as good as its BA counterpart, Backwoods Bastard.

Bottle. Dark amber clear with dark tan creamy head. 60.6 degrees. Not very aromatic. Full thick body. Slight bitterness. Rich. Spicy. Long lasting on the palate. No lacing but small head remains. Awesome beer for the evening. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle (from... dont remember the store, damn!) served in shaker- poured an almost perfect non-transparent darkened maroon when held to a light source, whisps of white, several frog eyes, and a white ring for a head.  Aroma of malt, malt, and malt!  Hits the mouth with wide body, malt is very firm and thick, middle has some molasses sweetness to it, finish is warming and has a slight bitterness to it.

Pours a hazy amber-red color with a thin off-white head. The aroma is amber malts with a bit of the earth and peat. It has a great malt and earthy flavor up front with a sweeter finish and syrupy mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Excellent scotch ale.  Not too sweet or heavy, pours dark with medium tan head.  Tasted on tap at Brooklyn Waterfront Beer Festival, 6/16/2012.
This is one of my favorite beers.  The combination of aroma, color, and taste make this a great brew for any occasion.
Fra flaske på Cardinal: herlig aroma av svisker, dadler og gammel tokayer. Nydelig smak med stor munnfylde. Et koseøl som skal nytes i  små mengder (temperert) i godt lag f.eks med blåskimmelost.

Poured into a pint glass. A nice inch of dirty-white head formed. Color is copper and red when held to the light, almost transparent.

A rich malty smell. Dry barley.

Smell is matched by the sweet malt and candy flavor that takes over this beer. There is a slight bitterness at the end.

Syrupy with moderate carbonation. It feels like it is sticking to the sides of your mouth.

Great Scotch style beer. It is not my personal favorite style but they have done a great job with it. No surprises.
Bottle pour ruby nice head. Tastes smells of caramel spice woody malt. Semi sweet nice mix of flavors. Nice carb. Pretty damn good.
Big aroma of sweet breay, doughy malts, soe roasted nuts and touches of smoky peat. Medium mouthfeel, soft, light carb. Medium bitter finish, grassy hops, nd more bold robust malts.

Fantastic scent! Love the label on this bottle, as well the dark color of the beer. The taste is thick and somewhat bold. This is the kind of beer you should have around for special occasions. Very nice beer.

Bottle - 341ml. Hazy dark amber body with a good off-white foamy head. Well balanced malty/hoppy aroma with woody and caramel hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Its complex taste carries fruity and caramel notes. Ends with a robust, warming bittersweet finish. Very good Scotch Ale.

Pure a deep ruby red, almost brown.  Aromas of pete, smoked malts, amber randomness.  First sip reveals a nicely balanced beer, heavily malted, peaty, slightly roasty, very dry finish.  The dryness of this beer is what sets it apart from the others.  Very nice.  Top of the class in a style that I honestly dont much care for.

In bottle. Pours a dark amber colour with a fair beige head. Aroma of sweet malt, chocolate, caramel and alcohol. Similar flavours. Alcohol is fairly present with moderate carbonation and light CO2 prickle. Quite dry to finish and nicely bitter with an foamy mouth-feel. Not bad.

bottle at home .. copper ... thin tan head ... soft fruit ... dark malt nose ... little of that malt ... light fizz ... soft roast ... zezty fruits ... light hop ... soft roast malt ... light sweetness.. little too fizzy for me.

I usually dont like scotch ales but I love this beer.  Pours a dark amber copper color with a decent head that quickly fades.  Big caramel malt aroma with slight amount of earthy and spicy hops.  The taste has a pretty complex malt profile.  Not just straight caramel malt like most scotchs.  Seems like a nice mixture of different malts, fairly sweet, a little smoke, and some spicy hops help to balance out the malt.  Pretty smooth and slightly dry in the finish.  Definitely my favorite scotch ale Ive tried.

A tasty but mild scotch ale.   Caramel in color, with an average head.  The smell hints at apples, raisins, grains and slight alcohol.  Theres more of that in the taste, plus a little bitter hop bite.  Not a lot of "scotch" going on here, but it is a little dry, the slightly high ABV is present in the flavor.  This is one of the better Founders brews Ive had.

Pours into the glass a slightly cloudy dark reddish brown color without much of a head. The smell is one for the maltheads. Caramel and brown sugar coated cherries and raisins mixed with a hint of smoke and a touch of ethanol. The flavor is rich and malty with just enough smoke and burnt to keep it from being cloying. Lots of caramel and dark fruits abound. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet bubbly mouthfeel. Ive had this before and Im surprised I hadnt rated it yet. Great brew, now distribute to NH already!
an overly sweet scotch ale.  really syrupy on the tongue, which would be OK if the flavor wasnt that of an off flavored malt.  The finish never goes away
Det här var gott! Doft och smak av trä, karamell och en aning rök.  Välbalanserad och harmonisk från början till slut.

Pours a rich mahogany rust color with little tan foam around the edges.  Aromas are winey with full malt, oak and earth coming through.  On the palate its very earthy, hints of smoke, caramel and fig.  Nicely constructed and  pleasure to drink at 8.5%. YUM

Pours dark reddish brown with a small white head. Nose is caramel, brown sugar, cinnamon rolls and just a hint of hay straw. Flavor is mostly sweet but has a decent hop bitterness to balance it out. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth yet crisp. Heavy body with a long aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botella de 355ml. Copa de Vino. Saboreada en feb´12. Brota con color ámbar oscuro y tintes rubí a contraluz. Capa fina que se disipa con rapidez y color bronceado. En nariz aromas de maltas tostadas, maltas caramelo y azúcar. Chocolate chispeante, amargor seco, frutos oscuros e intenso malteado conforman el perfil de sabores. Cuerpo medio y carbonatación moderada. Final seco y astringente. Toque de ciruelas en el retrogusto. Fácil asimilación.
355ml bottle. Oversized glass. Enjoyed on feb´12. Pours dark amber in color, ruby to the light. Thin, quickly dissipated head, tan color. Toasted malts, caramel malts & sugar to the nose. Sparkling chocolate, dry bitterness, dark fruits & intense maltiness compound the flavor profile. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Dry astringent finish. Plum touch on the aftertaste. Easy drinkability.

First off, this is a SCOTTISH ale not a SCOTCH ale.  But, if you disregard the name, this is a fine beer.  Darker colored and very full flavored.  But be careful... with 8.5% alcohol, these beers will knock you for a loop if you drink them like a typical lager.

Draft at Sweegrass Dairy. Pours a very deep hazy amber almost brown with a tiny tan head. Aroma is rich roasted malts, brown sugar and a bit of earthiness. Flavor is sweet maltiness up front with nuts and brown sugar. Slightly sweet finish. Very nice beer.
Awesome brew.  Pours ruby red, with a lightly smoked caramel aroma.  Taste is full of peat, malt, and butterscotch.  Sweet finish, very little alcohol present.

Bottle at Jimmy's no 43. This is a really great scotch ale. Alcohol hides nicely, flavor is really malty and caramel. Can't go wrong with anything in the bastard series.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at urge. 1 of 8 on tap. Dark red-brown with mocha petri head. Nose light sweet of dark fruit and smooth malt. Taste is high and quick. Light compared to curmudgeon. Sharp dark malty tart. Clean quick finish. Bit of roastiness out back, buit not for long.
deep amber, one finger head. lots of caramel. very malty with slight hop finish. not exactly smooth, but id stillsy this is a sneaky strong beer.

Reddish brown, with a low head and moderate carbonation. Malty but not very sweet, and this works well. Balanced with some hop bitterness, nice. Alcohol very well hidden. Its a good beer. Wish it was bottle conditioned though.
Tulip glass. Dark amber with a dark tan head. Malty, roasty and peaty. Deceivingly high in alcohol. Pretty smooth.

From the bottle. Not much aroma but I do detect some caramel. Full bodied with a slick mouth feel, Complex malts on the palate, Caramel, biscuit, not sure if I get much peat like people have mentioned. Its sweet but certainly not cloying. Finishes clean and is very well rounded overall.

12 oz bottle pours a hazt brown/amber color with a small off-white head and good lacing. Not much to smell, but aroma is intersting with lots of caramel, some nuts, molasses, toast, and maybe even peat.  Taste is slightly bitter and chalky. Body is at least medium with average carbonation.Very enjoyable, and hides the ABV well.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a clear dark copper with minimal head. Aroma is mostly caramel and some citrus hops. Also, a good bit of dark fermented fruit, oak and some boozieness. Taste is light bitter and light sweet. Lots of caramel and citrus hops with dark fruit and oak. Full bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. I would love to drink this again.
Pours a clear and reddish brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel and notes of roasted malts. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel, nuts and fruit. Flavour is roasted caramel, fruit, alcohol and nuts.

Bottle at the Bridgeville Beer tasting on 04/27/12. An above average scotch ale. Tasty! Boozy scent over a pale copper pour. Pale muted hop fronted taste with a boozy finish that was more of an alcoholy booze than other scotch ales. Hints of candy and spice mixed in the aftertaste.

12 ounce bottle into snifter, bottled 2/15/2012.  Pours very hazy dark reddish brown color with a 1 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Some nice spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, raisin, molasses, plum, biscuit, toast, toffee, and light herbal.  Nice and well balanced aromas with good strength.  Taste of big caramel, toast, prune, biscuit, raisin, peat, molasses, light chocolate, toffee, and herbal spiciness.  Fair amount of herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, molasses, raisin, prune, peat, toasted biscuit, light chocolate, and herbal spiciness for a good bit.  Very nice balance of flavors with good complexity; and no cloying sweetness.  Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very nice creamy, lush, and slick mouthfeel as expected.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish noticed.  Overall this is a great scotch ale.  Nice flavor balance, with a good amount of robustness and complexity; and very smooth to sip on.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Bottled 3/27/12 so this one is very young.  Pours a clear dark mahogany color with beautiful red hues.  A small tan head dissipates very quickly.  Smells of peat, caramel, sugar, raisins, light alcohol, molasses, some banana and green apple.  Tastes of peat, molasses, raisins, dates, and green apple appears again.  It ends with some alcohol and a mouth puckering astringent sensation.  Very thick, very slick mouthfeel moderate carbonation for style.  Not a bad beer but it has some flaws.

Not a whole lot going on with the aroma except sweet caramel notes - which is to be expected with this style. Quite a pleasant taste - almost tastes like a Cadbury chocolate caramel egg I had at Easter. Good amount of hop punch with this but not overbearing or taking away from the style

A hazy brownish amber on the pour with a very thin tan head. Aroma is fruity, yeast, caramel malt, some dark fruit notes and sweet alcohol esters fill the senses. Taste is dark fruit, caramel malt some yeast with some bitterness. The Palate is a full body with slightly smooth dry mouthfeel with good carbonation. Finish is sweet caramel malt, yeast, fruity followed by a some alcohol and slightly dry bitterness ending with a bit of lingering sweet nutty flavor. Aroma and flavor really come through as it warms up. Overall a good representation of the style
The hoppiness of this one came through more than I expected. There is a high level of maltiness that is very pleasant. A good scotch ale.

Bottled. Sweet, somewhat spicy aroma. Full mouthfeel. Hints of vanilla and fruit. Very faint taste of alcohol in the background which remains in the mouth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a very nice beer.  It pours a very dark amber with some light tan head.  The aroma has nutty notes.  You can definitely get the caramel, chocolate, and coffee in the taste.  This is a really nice beer in a not so common style, I highly recommend it.

Originally reviewed: 2/25/09. Pours a deep mahogany with very little head and minimal lacing. Smells of strawberries, cherries, some banana, caramel malt, and hints of alcohol. Wonderful scent!

Very smooth and creamy brew. It coats my palate ever so softly. Drinks very well. Taste is of roasted caramel, hints of smokiness, slight fruitiness, and finishes just slightly bitter. No lingering bite, just enough bitterness to know its there. Its a heavy brew in my mind. I wouldnt see myself drinking more than 1 or 2 at a time. Well done. Recommend.

Deep amber with reddish highlights. The minimal head leaves some lacing as it settles. The aroma is boozy, caraway, blackberries, toast. Full bodied and viscous. Flavors of pumpernickel toast, molasses, leather, tobacco, black cherries. The finish is dry and hoppy, with a lingering metallic feel and some fruity aftertones.
Bottled. The aroma is pink and sweet with strong notes of red berries. Flavor is sweet malty, smoked caramel and chocolate. Aroma explotion but a bit sticky sweetness.
Beautiful deep red pour.  No head to speak of.  Tastes like 10 different malts having a party in your mouth.  Sweet, strong, delicious.

Dark amber pour with reddish highlights, about a finger of head.  Aroma of toffee, peet, Very malty, Raisin.  Taste of Molasses, raisin, Dark caramel, dark bread.  bitter and smokey finish.  medium boded.  Carbonation is right.  Cat believe I forgot to rate it earlier.

On draft at Founder's taproom. Deep amber color and lovely caramel and toast aroma. Taste was familiar malty Scotch ale taste but more balanced and mellow in a good way than bottle tastings.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at a tasting at Dagans. Pours deep orange with a beige head, aroma of honey, cherries, caramel, toffee and vanilla, flavor is smoky, with vanilla, dark bread, caramel, nice bitterness with some acidity, medium to full bodied, nice
(Bottle 21/03-2012) Low light brown head, clear amber color, malty aroma, fresh rounded hoppy taste.

Aroma is very rich. Strong caramel, plenty of fruit, maybe citrus, raisins and plenty of malt. Taste is beautiful. Very complex first impression. Perfectly sweet, very sweet without becoming cloying. Plenty of caramel, raisins, cherries and a slight smokey harshness. Maybe some vanilla in there too. Plenty of rich malt. Metallic hops in the finish with some alcohol burn. To be honest I hate when I taste any alcohol in a beer but this is integrated awesome. Actually there is a lot of what I hate in this beer, but it all blends  so awesomely you cant help but like it. Even some cinnamon as it warms. There is just way too much going on for me to even begin to comprehend all thats going on here. Palate is thick and syrupy. I love this beer, will definitely stock up before it sells out. One of my favorites thus far.
This is a great beer.  Saw at the store and just had to buy it and I am very happy that I did.
Tap at J Ryans. Initial hits of scotch with lots of good bitterness. Pours  redish colour. Pretty light in mouth with long bitter finish.
Light fruity scent, scotch appearance, dry nutty smoke infused with scotch follow up.  Medium body.
Grew on me. Didn't like it at first. Smelled fruity, tasted nutty. Smooth. Pretty decent once you get over the first drink.
TAP: Ruby/brown in color. Aroma of caramel, butter, slightly of hops. Taste is sweet with great malts and carmel. The smooth mouthfeel makes this bees seem like it is melting in your mouth.

Two things I have determined about Founders during recent beer shops: they dont make non-excellent beer, and their best stuff is always sold out in these parts. Complex aroma of smoke, wooden whiskey barrels, currants and spice. Looks like muddy water. No head to speak of. Deep flavor of bitter chocolate malt and raisins. The body is medium, but kind of syrupy. The winning streak continues.
Really good beer. Have not had too many Scottish ales so I dont know what to compare this to but a good beer I will drink in the future.

honeyish malts winelike aromas and scotch whisky in the aroma..dark red/brown color foamy off white head and lacing..tastes of caramel vanilla molasses and smoke..bit of raisiny dark fruit also very unusual,like a barleywine... sticky and a bit heavy though well carbonated I dont usually like scotch ales but this has enough malty foundation to justify the smoky flavor

A: Pours a very dark tawny color. Head is light cream colored with poor retention, but good lacing.

S: Quite complex smelling. Caramel, toffee, subtle dark fruit, biscuit, smoke, and light hints of nutmeg.

T: Taste follows the nose here, with quite a bit of caramel and biscuit on the opening. Dark fruits enter the picture slightly during the second part, while it has an herbal, green tea-esque finish. The caramel notes actually give it some finishing bitterness, too, along with an additional smoky sweetness on the exhale. Complex and interesting, perhaps a bit too much for its own good; but drinkability is surprisingly high.

M: Im surprised how crisp this finishes, which parallels its dryness very well. The body is a little slender - actually, I cant complain about that, because of how expertly it intertwines with the carbonation (high, but spot on) and the aforementioned finish.

O: Surely, Im no expert on what a wee heavy should taste like - but for what its worth, this is one of the most drinkable high(er) alcohol beers Ive ever had. Its amazing how the complexity doesnt hinder its drinkability, either. Big thumbs up.
Bottle @ Olympen. Transparent reddish brown, small creamy head that disappeared quickly. Malt and caramel, some toffee, yeast, and alcohol. Thin body, slick, not very drinkable.
Now this is a dark beer. That last beer I had was nothing compared to this. It is like eating a fancy cigar. Sweet smell. Complex taste. I like!
Simply the best american style scotch ale Ive tasted. Glad its finally avaliable in Iowa. This is certianly not a boring beer!

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans. Thanks Thanks zvikar.  Cloudy reddish brown with a little foam. Sweet wine-cherry aroma, sweet wine-alcoholic taste. Light body for what it is, alcoholic finish and soft carbonation. Not good.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours translucent crimson with small off-white head.  Little lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and caramel malt aroma.  Taste is rich malt and light bitter finish.  Complex, but not for me.
Dark brown with a creamy head. Nose has chocolate prunes and raisin and slight bourbon. Fruit and chocolate, malt forward. Raisin aftertaste. Noticable alcohol. Light carbonation.

Pours a dark-reddish brown, absolutely beautiful. Plenty of roasty malts, very sweet, with toffee and caramel. Tastes of alcohol, although not as much as one might expect. The flavor is less sweet than the aroma, with more leafy hops.
Amber brownish in color. Cloudy. Aroma of sweet malts, cinnamon, coffee and chocolate. Oaky taste and slightly bitter. Thin body. A bit harsh at the end.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2014 
35,5 cl bottle @ OHaras Freehouse. Rated on 09.03.2010
Red-brown colour, disappearing head. Aroma is fresh and sweet with some malt, fruits and hints of berries. Flavour is sweet with ripe fruits, some malt and berries. A Scotch Ale in American way  and too sweet.
7+3+7+3+15=3.5

35,5 cl bottle @ home
Aroma is sweet and malty with caramel, toffee and some hayish grain. Alcohol is also present. Flavour has toffee, caramel, sweet malty tones. Alcohol comes through and actually disturbs a bit.

7+4+7+3+15=3.6
nice beer-  Wish we could find this in Boise Idaho.  I got this beer in the mail which I was glad to get it.

Pours a deep burnt orange/amber with a finger of short-lived off-white/tannish head, sporadic beading.  The nose offers waves of toffee, toasted bread, consistent and somewhat pungent - the beer has already taken a distinct direction.  The taste highlights much of the aroma plus some peat and smoky wood.  Drinkability is pretty low but it doesnt detract from the beer.  Im not an avid scotch ale drinker, but from what little I know, this is a good example of the style.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2015 Thick and dark amber pour no head.  Can taste the alcohol in it but it is smooth anyway.  Carmel and nutty flavors pretty malty aftertaste.  Not bad

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Re-rate 4/18/2015
Draft pour at Stella barra. Copper color. Off white head. Super Earthy, sweet, malty, Carmel, and smooth. Expected some harshness. Nothing. - smooth sipper and tasty.  Glad I  re-rated. My taste buds are much different since 3 years ago when I gave it a much lower rating
Pours a deep red brown. Very little aroma. Malty taste with slight nuttty flavor. Another good founders beer.
Weird..at first i hated it..but since i cant dump a beer out i finished it... It grew on me in a good way... Malty bitter... Kinda fruity long lasting finish... Different

Simple aroma but a beautiful appearance and smooth scotch tones makes this an easy drinking beer with great mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle to a pint glass.  Aromas of caramel, burnt toffee, dark fruits.  Appearance, very little lacing, a small cream-tan head, the body has a dark amber color, with a faint Burgundy hue.  The taste is sweet, plum, fig, toffee, and alcohol.  The feel on the palate is a medium-carbonation, slightly oily, and dry.  Overall, this may be my favourite year round release from any brewery.  Im not a huge Scotch Ale fan even, so, that speaks to how great of a beer this is.  Its very balanced, yet, complex.
Tap at the Stags Head.  Pours nice reddish brown with thin head.  tastes very malty of barley, hops, toffee, prunes, caramel, and earth.  creamy mouthfeel a great scotch ale.

Bottle.  An amber brown coloured ale.  Mild plum and fig in the aroma, caramel and a distant earthiness.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  Toasted malt flavour comes through immediately.  Bitter hops, milk chocolate and fig lead to subtle and medicinal, herbal flavours.  There is a slight sweetness with hops in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Bottle from Founders brewery.  Pours clear dark brown.  Mild "scotch ale" aroma of brown sugar.  Very good taste of caramel and brown sugar, with some smooth chocolate,  and a nice bitter bite at the end.  Great stuff!

Pours an amber caramel color with hints of orange and a decent head. The aroma is strong toasted grains and malt. Taste is sickly sweet with a malty syrup, raisins, piney hops, and a slightly burnt caramel sweetness. Warm alcoholic burn similar from quads.

Great red brown color.  This is a great scotch ale!  Bit of a burn on the back end barley and heavy malt, no hop notes, but 50 IBU.  Tastes like Scotland.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark reddish mahogany with a thin, mostly dissipating light tan head. Nose is hops and toffee. Very creamy on the palate, the taste is of dark roasted malt, molasses, toffee and finishes with a light hops note. A touch of smokiness permeates. A robust beer that pairs well with brats off the grill.

Poured into a chalice. Reddish-brown color with a very minimal head. Had a slight metalic taste on the onset that dissipated afterwards. Detected some fruity notes on the palate. I am not a scotch-ale fanatic however, I still found this to be an enjoyable beer.
UPDATED: NOV 1, 2012 Nose of malts and sweetness. Taste is roasted malts with a nice hop presence. Nicely complex and a great brew.

12oz bottle.
Pours a dark ruby red, with a beige head.
Smells of caramel, prune, malt and hops.
Tastes gorgeous; a heavy sweetness, a medium bitter, and a sideways kick of a different bitterness, leading towards an interesting palate assault.
Texture is oily, carbonation is soft, body is medium. Finishes like a flachette to the tongue with bitterness. An excellent and interesting beer.

On tap.
Deep red pour with some bubbly head.  Aromas of smoke, dark fruit, and caramel.  Flavors of sweet grains, peated malt, and more caramel.
Local Belmont bottle. I have no idea why it too me this long to try this beer. Self-description includes "bold and powerful"...yes it is...that is all.

12oz. to snifter, yielding glorious falu like tone accompanied by modest tan froth with medium stay. Delicious vanilla/caramel swirl with dollops of molasses emerge summoning trademark smoked peat perfume. All continue to dazzle senses in further hops complexity with silken lasting mouthcoat. Tailed is warm with sweet n sour steeped in barrel char. Great example of a personally newly acquired and admired style.
Bottle, pour is red, aroma is sweet and hoppy. the taste is very nice, it is one of the better scotch ales

UPDATED: APR 5, 2015 Beautiful dark brown beer with a thin, short-lived lathery head. The aroma is sweet with molasses, caramel, dulce de leche, wood, and dark, ripe fruits. The taste is only very mildly bitter and somewhat sweet, with a dulce de leche finish. The mouthfeel is a bit thick and sticky, with almost no carbonation. Thank God I got a six pack. Didnt love the first two times I tried it, but it grew on me.

Bottle.  Sweet malty and both spicy & floral hop aroma.  Sweet taste and sticky texture gives way to drying bitterness, a metallic note, and earthy woodiness that makes it end a but rough.  Quite boozy. Not super quaffable.  Possibly not the best stored bottle from a bodega. Other than the heavy dose of hops this does exhibit the nice hallmarks of a scotch ale and is pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2016 Aroma is sweet malt, butterscotch. Appearance is dark cooper, almost red. Taste is complex, malty, butterscotch, toffee. Mouthfeel is perfect, soft carbonation and smooth. Overall, this is the beer that made me decide to never go back to Macros. Over time, I have found beers that far surpass this but this is still a staple of my beer diet.

Bottled 01.05.12.  Pours hazy, murky dark reddish brown with a 2-finger creamy orange and beige head.  Doily-like lacing remains.  The aroma is caramel, warm apple and pear, and brown sugar.  The flavor is sugar, sweet plum and pear jam, brown sugar, and caramel.  This trends to mocha and cocoa and brown sugar.  The finish is peaty and malty, with a touch of smokiness.  Low to medium carbonation with medium/full body, warming, and nearly slick and oily.  Nice stuff.  [974]
Bottle: pours a dark reddish copper, hazy thickness, a small tan head. Bread, and spiciness in the aroma. Great smoky malty taste.  Great beer, way better than I remember.

Pours darkest amber, with a dark cream head. Aroma is caramel, toast, vanilla. Taste is of raisins, caramel, some bitterness to finish. Full-bodied and warm. A very good beer. Although the sweetness is not really my thing, this definitely has its place.

Beautiful deep red brown color that pours a nice light tan head.  Has good alcohol legs and the scent is bursting with yeasty maltiness.  The taste is yeasty and bready with a touch of sweetness.  This is a smooth and mellow beer for its type.  Not my favorite style of beer this one is nonetheless very tasty and I would buy it again.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Archer Liquors by Midway-Chicago airport for $1.80 Very good!
Una cerveza estilo "ale" muy lograda. Muchisima carga de malta, se nota en toda su intensidad. Un gran descubrimiento

Aroma is malty with a undertone of fruit.  The flavor is malty and mildly fruity, with a sweetness but not cloyingly so.  A bit more sweetness than other Scotch Ales Ive had, pretty good as a whole, not too sweet in flavor that it overpowers the fruit in the flavor.
Soury smell, medium body. There is a metallic flavor that is somewhat part of the Scotch Ale character- but in this brew, it is not pleasant

Pours a dark amber color in the glass. It has a sweet roasted fruit aroma along with some cough syrup. Flavor is very smooth with raisins and licorice. The roasted malts they use definitely give it a unique flavor, maybe similar to a barleywine. Good finish.
Pours dark amber with a low head. Aroma is malts. Flavor is sweetish malts and some hops. A bit boring but decent.

Bottle pours red-brown with a tan head. Aroma shows roasted caramel, brown sugar, light smoke, and berry. Flavor shows sweet malt and earth with underlying notes of dried fruit. Overall body is moderate to full, and finishes with a touch of warming alc.
Good beer.  This beer is a nice medium of grain profile to hop flavor.  The complexity of grains are enjoyable.
Bottle: Part of beach tasting. Full bodied, complex, rich. Food Pairing: BBQ.

Bottle.  Pours reddish brown (opaque).  Smells of caramel and some hay.  Taste is lightly bitter with a bit of alcohol on the finish.  Mouthfeel is fairly thick.. but not quite chewy.  Scotch Ale is not a top style for me but this is pretty enjoyable.

Thanks zielinski. Tasted from bottle into nucleated pint glass. Poured a dark reddish-brown color with no foam, just a small film of beige bubbles. Vigorous swirling kicked up a small, mildly aromatic head which quickly subsided, leaving a little Belgian lace. Smelled a little like caramelized brown sugar, toffee, distant earthy and citrusy hops, light compost and smoke essences. Very hoppy flavor: tart, tangy, bitter orange rind, with a rich malt sweetness masked underneath. Much hoppier than a true-to-style Scotch Ale, but this is a remarkable enhancement. A well-crafted balance which is still reminiscent of a classic, dark and complex style. Medium body. Full, creamy mouthfeel, low carbonation. Long-lasting bittersweet aftertaste. I dont think they barrel-aged it, but somehow it seems that way, hints of toasted hardwood, peat, Scotland. Very tasty.

Pours a nice amber color with a small head that dissipates quickly. smells like alcohol and sweet red fruit. Taste strong and thick for an ale, warm alcohol, a little brown sugar. After taste was a little weak and funky. A good beer if you like this style.

Pours a hazy/granulated, dark amber with a small brown head.  The aroma is nothing to write home about.  It some hint of hops and malt and it smells a wee bit like scotch, and I like my scotch.  The taste is well balanced with the right amount of bitter and a hint of sweetness.  The palate shines through with a full body and creamy rich texture and a nice bitter finish that could be a bit stronger.  This is a fantastic beer at a fantastic price.  I will buy more sixers of this for sure.

12oz bottle.  Somehow this one has eluded my rating until now.  Deep unfiltered brown-red.  Nice steady chocolate and amber malt flavors, not much besides some faint balancing hops.  Really hides or incorporates the alcohol well, this could pass for 6%.  Smooth and clean, really well done.
This beer is just the best beer I have had had. It is a fantastic scotch style ale beer.

Pouts a murky brown with a 1/2 finger head. The aroma is crazy sweetness and small tangy bourbon. Taste is very clean with big dark fruits and crazy smooth maltyness. Just an amazing scotch ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: APR 18, 2012 Very dark amber, light will not pass through. Hops are still very bitter for such a dark colored drink. Tasted with a cold so favors not as evident. Smooth palate.

Bottle from pivoteka Zly casy, Prague. Reddishbrown color with small light pink head. Aroma of roasted malt, fruity syrup, honey, earthy hints. Taste, red fruits, malty sweetness, earthy hints, notes of smoke, nice bitterness in background.  Strong alcoholic feeling. Long bitter hops finish. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 Poured dark amber, with a big, creamy, off-white head that left lots of lacing.  Aroma is biscuit, clove and faint orange zest.  Taste is whole wheat bread and biscuit.  Dry, but smooth finish.
Another great beer from Founders, deep brown colour, great aroma and taste, a good example of this style.
Great caramelized smell.  Thick head.  Dark amber appearance.  Odd balance of malt and hops...slightly too malt.  Tastes like burnt wood, but its good.
Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Nice malt and roast flavor.  Decent amount of peat smoke and light hops flavor.  Big alcohol flavor. Dry finish this was a very tasty beer.

Bouteille de 12oz. Merci Patrick pour cette dégustation de Scotch Ale. Encore une bière brune acajou où la mousse est peu présente mais elle fait un petit rond au sommet. Le nez est peu complexe mais efficace avec ses notes de caramel fruitées. La bouche est bien charpenté, les goûts de sirop dérable carbonisé sont forts sympathique. Elle est bien sucrée mais nécure pas. Elle est longue et se termine sur des saveurs de houblons herbeux et de chocolat.
I have not had many scotch ales, however  it was my first. Vary deep amber color, no head and a vary strong alcohol smell, over all great ale.

355ml bottle. Deep mahagoni with almost no head, a thin film remains though. Toffee aroma, alcoholic efflorescence. Taste is basically toffee, accompanied by hints of dark chocolate and Schwarzbrot. Well balanced sweetness. Alcohol becomes noticable after a while.

(Courtoisie de JulienHuxley)  Une robe brune acajou plutôt opaque.  Une mousse foncée plus ou moins durable.  Un nez riche et appétissant de caramel et de tire dérable avec des parfums fruités et liquoreux.  Des saveurs décadentes de malts grillés.  Des houblons qui émergent en douceur.  Des notes rôties qui transportent une légère fumée.  Des petits fruits qui roulent sur les papilles.  Un corps dans la moyenne avec un pétillement modéré et une texture huileuse.  Une finale qui permet à de timides notes amères de franchir le mur malté.

Bottle no. AULFE-05/03/11-15:45.  The stamp was a bit faded.  The pour is a dark amber with a short burst of head that settles quickly. The aroma is pungent and powerfully malty, sweet, bitterly hopped.  The body is medium to bold.  The taste is strong and bold like a Scotch Ale should be.
Recently had this one and it pours a nice amber color, but I wasnt to fond of the taste, guess I am not a fan of scotch ales...

355 ml bottle (bottle size makes more sense in heathen measuring units) @ Delirium Hoppy loft: looking forward to this one, appearance is just lovely, raspberry hued amber with a tanned non-lasting head, smell is sweet caramel malts, very malt heavy, sticky, sugary blond malts, touch molasses & yeast, fruity, non-bitter hops, taste is definitely heavy on the sweetness candy sugar, caramel malts (lots of them mashed together), sticky, strong toffee, hint molasses, touch vanilla, same sticky fruity hops in the finish, leading to a touch of bitterness beneath the malt layer, touch floral & herbal, hints of camomile, strangely I am getting some almost bourbon (almost there but not really) & barrel (somewhat there) like characteristics in the finish, wouldnt really call them peat or smoke as the description claims, body is oily & sticky, I have been here before, starts out pretty nice but the combination of new world hops & handful of hops outstays its welcome pretty quickly & doesnt quite work for me, ok but not mightily impressive
12 ounce bottle. The aroma is toffee, sweet breads, fruits, and malts. The flavor is sweet as well, with fruity notes, toffee, and malts. A great beer to end the night on.

Enjoying a Founders Dirty Bastard...an outstanding scotch style ale! At the pour it begins with an 1/8 off white head and has a deep ruby color in glass. The nose is of dark fruits, caramel maltiness, and the traditional scotch/peet smoke aromas. The taste in the front is of fresh pineapples, raisins, and plums. This moves into a solid, well rounded maltiness highlighted by caramel and toffee flavors. The finish is of smoke and a well balanced hop bitterness. The mouthfeel is a perfect balance between thick and thin making this an ale that can be sipped over time or one that can be enjoyed in mas. I am looking forward to this one warming up a bit, as it should gain in the flavor profile...particularly additional boozy qualities.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle dated 5/14/2011 into a tulip glass.

A: Deep red/maroon/brown beer with a tan foamy head that retains its shape and size. Nice looking beer.

S: Mostly malty and bready, not much picked up here through the nose.

T: Big malty flavor up front with hints of fruits and fruits coming through.

M: Medium carbonation with a rather thick body. 

O: A decent beer, I remember it tasting a little better than this, but its not a bad beer just not as complex and interesting as I remember.

Bottle.  Pours an amber brown with a thin tan head.  Mild aroma of malts typical of those youd expect in a Scotch ale.  The flavor is richly malty, and opens up nicely as the beer warms up.  A bit of smoke on the finish.  Nice mouthfeel.  A solid beer, but a bit dull - would be better with more hops to balance it out.

A gift from my little sister, poured to a snifter.
Pours a deep brown with some red shining through. A one finger tan head recedes quickly leaving a thin whispy film with almost no lacing. 
The nose is dark fruit with an earthy background, I defiantly get a nice round roasted malt and some caramel sweetness. 
First sip I get sweet dark fruit and an earthy dirt flavor, same as the aroma it is backed up with a little caramel, no alcohol detected. 
Big medium body with a silky feel, fairly low carbonation, almost powdery on the finish.
Overall a very nice beer.

Poured 12 oz bottle in a snifter. Very cloudy dark iced tea color with very light head.  This beer really needs to be served warm!  Poured it cold and it had no aroma and very harsh flavor.  As I let it warm up the flavors and body began to show up along with some aroma.  As expected a malty aroma, very sugary caramel and some bread notes.  Heavy sweet taste with slight bitterness.  Medium body with a bit thin creamy texture; flat carbonation and long finish.  Im not sure I really like this style of beer based on this selection.

Pour dark ruby, with a medium sized off white creamy head. 
Aroma of dark fruits like figs, raisins and plums. Brown sugar, vanilla and plenty of fugde/caramel is also present, with s little bit of wood. Big malty flacours, with a hint of doughy yeast, nice balanced.
Medium bodied, and medium to flat carbonated.

I know that Ive had this about four or five times before (I had a bottle on a shelf in my old house). Anyway, bottle thanks to SS. Pours with a hazy bronze hued body with a small but retentive head that is pro lace. Aromas are super malty, brown sugar, caramelization, melanoidin, dark fruits, medium to light smoke, pretty clean yeast wise. Crackery and a bit biscuity on the malt. Flavors seem to be a touch on the older side, light oxidation (cardboard), and a bit of an odd bitterness (style wise). Dark fruits, raisins, melanoidin, brown sugar. Clean. Light smoke. Drier than I remember this beer. Lighter carbonation. Medium to full bodied, oddly bitter in the lasting duration. Quite bitter for a scotch ale. Minimal alcohol presence felt.

This is such a good beer. The malt character is perfect, and the peat notes are very subtle and dont overpower the hop favors. Even the alcohol is subdued by the flavor--youd never know it is over 8%!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle/12oz - Pours a dark reddish amber in color with ruby highlights when held to the light and a very small off-white head that faded to almost nothing.  Low carbonation.  Aroma is slightly sweet with a fair amount of dark fruits, some caramel/toffee and just a bit of alcohol as the beer warms.  Flavor is slightly sweet with some hop bitterness and a bit of floral hop flavor.  Dark fruits and slightly smokey.  Medium palate.  Really good...

Color of dark ice tea when poured with little or no head. Slight aroma of pineapple. Very good palate, smooth drink ability. Can taste the hops, but not over powering. Slight taste of chocolate. Alcohol well hidden, but starts to creep up with you after one bottle. Overall, good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The label on this one was in red plaid with a menacing looking Scots Man wearing a newsboy cap and sneering. The label stated it had 50 IBUs and 8.5% alcohol and was bottled on 12-9-2009. After an agressive pour I only managed the single finger of pale beige head that faded to minimal lacing. The beer itself was a deep mohagany color and very inviting looking. The aroma was quite muted but did impart some slight pineapple smell. The flavors on this one truely set it off. There was the afore mentioned pineapple from the nose, some dark cherry, banana, and the scotch/peet smoke that is typical of this style. There also was just enough hops to balance out the malt back bone and lend a little bitterness. The alcohol was very well hidden but started to warm after 2-3 gulps. Mouthfeel was virtually perfect. Not to thick or thin which made for excellent drinkability. Overall this is a very nice example of scotch ale, but the high alcohol content catches up after only 2 beers.
Pours a nice ruby red color with hardly any head. Smells of sweet malts and dark fruits. Taste was dead on for the style. Caramel and Peated malt, with a slight hop bitterness. Acceptional beer.
36cl, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, very complex Scotch, sweet/bitter and slightly smoked/fruity, not to heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive

From bottle. Pours deep red/brown with short lasting head. Aroma has lots of toffe, some chocolate and decent wiff of alcohol. Taste is more balanced, very delicious, lots of toffee, some vanilla and chocolate. Id prefer a bit more carbonation and less alcohol burn

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy amber color, beautiful in the light.  Aroma is subtle, with hops up front, and peat notes.  Flavor is very complex, with malt up front, a subtle peat flavor in the middle, and a surprising aftertaste of bitter hops.  Kind of an abrupt finish, but not unpleasant.  After a couple of these, I feel like Piltdown Man, ready to relax in a bog.

On tap at the Cleveland Pub. Pours brownish brown with some red tints. And brown. About a 1/2 inch head which, amazingly I thought, stuck around throughout most of the glass. Aroma has caramel and berries and toffee. Very strongly malt smell. Taste brings brown sugar and caramel and berries and a bit of malted milk. Quite sweet but with a lot of body. Very sticky. Finishes fairly long and sweet with some alcohol. Founders seldom lets one down!
very nice balance of malts, high alcohol, and had enough hops for a hop lover like myself.  Didnt love it at first, but I keep it in rotation from a great beer company with reasonable prices.

Taste over Aroma. 
 Dirty Bastard pours deep brown with slight amber. Has slim head.
 Has a light scent, mostly of malts. 
 After observing the avarage appearance and aroma, the flavor was a kick in the mouth!!!! Fantastic, flavorful roasted malts, cocoa.
 Oh, man! What a pleasant suprise!
cloudy, copper in color/ slight malt aroma/ very boozy strong malt flavor slight smoke

Founders continues to impress me. Dirty Bastard is the best Scotch Style Ales i have ever had. Very Very smooth with a great taste. Outstanding 
Beer!!!

Murky blood-brown color. Slim off-white head with no lacing left behind its rapid demise. Huge bread, caramel, and malt aroma. Hints of raisin. Malty rich flavor. Sweet mouthfeel and aftertaste. Much of the aroma is present in the mouth, minus the raisin. Very good beer.

1i2 oz bottle pours a dark ruby color with a thin off white head.  Aromas of
caramel, sweet malt, earthy.  Medium bodied, light carbonation, smokey finish

Draft in a pint glass. Pours dark and clear amber with tan foam and good lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, alcohol, hops, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is sweet and ends quite dry and bitter. Hoppier than I like for the style.
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 On tap at G Michaels. Pours a reddish brown with an inch of head. Hoppy for a scotch ale but still super malty. Overall very well balanced.
This is a tasty beer if you like scotch. It is a good mix of a beer taste with a hint of scotch.

Hazy brown in the glass with a thin tan head.  Aroma of nutty, earthy, chocolate malt.  Not much hop aroma but a nice bitterness backing the malt on the palate.  Maybe a slight smokiness, but nothing very strong, which is a positive for me as I usually dont appreciate much smokiness to my beer.

On tap at Pizza Luce. Poured a deep medium brown, with a rapidly disolving head. Just the right amount of malts to make it both delicious and easily drinkable. Smoky with sweet highlights. Soft finish, easy to drink. Perfect for the stout lover whenever they dont feel like having a stout.

Poured a dark amber brown with a good ruby red tint. The tan head was thin and reduced quickly to just a film. The aroma was complex with losts of different scents from molasses, earhty peat, some alcohol, chocolate and some brandy. The beer had a creamy texture and lots of various sweet malt flavors. The first of which was chocolate and a light alcohol flavor of brandy or bourbon. There was also some molasses and some light smoke. The finish has a little bite from hops and alcohol along with a good bit of alcohol warmth. Excellent!!!!!!!

12 oz bottle. Clear brownish/red with a small beige head. Aroma is toffee, bread dough, caramel and some smoke. Flavor is very malty with a medium sweetness, light acidic smoke and no noticeable hop bitterness. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a thick, slightly syrupy mouth feel. Another great beer from Founders, solid example of the style.

Bottle.  A dark red unclear beer with a thin frothy off-white head.  Sweet aroma of caramel, alcohol, chocolate.  Taste is very sweet, with notes of brown sugar, overripe fruit, cocoa, wood.  Sweet and bitter on the finish.  Very smooth, creamy, full bodied, with little carbonation.

bottled 8/8/11 consumed on ratings date. pours a deep red thats a touch brown. small dense foam cap that is tinted brown. the smell is intense dark carmel malt with a hint of roast and light bitterness. taste is much the the smell, super rich carmel malt with a bit of roasty chocolate. sweet but a moderate bitter hop bite. mouthfeel is rich and smooth. moderate carbonation creamy feeling. overall very enjoyable.

Poured from a bottle purchased at Good Beer in New York. Comes out a beautiful dark brown. Has a nice thick almost syrup-like density. Aroma consists of caramel, vanilla, and alcohol. Very dense and complex beer, lots to love. Recommended.

Unclear reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet malty, lots of caramel and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. Smooth and soft with a good balance. 241011

Pours a beautiful red with brown head, aroma is nice hints of caramel and smoke. Very tasty beer, caramel with a smoky end and just the right amount of bitterness. Packs quite a punch as I began to feel warm after a short while. Recommended beer.

Wow.. 12oz bottle pours red with a khaki brown head. Aromas of toffee molasses brown sugar and a woodsy pine.  Flavor comes in sweet with a heavy pancake syrup taste and acut with a woodsy smoked pine bitterness. Body is on the fuller side with alcohol warmth. Heavy brew

(355 cl bottle @ Café Langebro) Pours a clear, copper brown with medium off-white head and lace. Weak retention. Aroma intensely malty like a doppelbock with notes of nuts and grain. Taste is very sweet. A bit too much for my hophappy buds. Also it didnt help that the bottle had been refrigerated at a rather low temperature and I didnt have the proper time to let it heat up a bit. Full-bodied, oily texture, softly carbonated with a sweet finish.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 Tout dabord, jaimerais rendre hommage au spectaculairement confortable col qui sest formé en la versant. Un amalgame de minuscules perles et de vigoureuses grosses bulles saccumulent au dessus dun corps presque rouge sang totalement translucide. Une fois la tête disparu, je suis en mesure dapprécier larôme: caramel brûlé, fruits confits et une touche de bois. Au goût cest le chocolat, caramel avec un kick de fumée sur le bout de la langue. Lamertume se manifeste beaucoup plus que dans les autres scotch ale que jai goûté, sans être déplacé. Founders frappe fort encore une fois.
This is a strong, relaxing beverage.  It has a spicy, clove-packed barnyard kick that will warm you up.
Pours a scotch color with a white head.  Smells of brown sugar and molasses.  I like these flavors.  Not a hug fan of scotch ales but still pretty tasty.

12oz bottle dark brown with an off white almost yellow color that lingers with decent lacing. medium bodied scottish ale sweet malty flavor that lingers on the tongue. well balanced hop. the warmer the beer got the better the flavor.

Truly monstrous.  An earthy and boozy aroma gives you the clue that youre in for a big punch from this ale. Theres hint of sweetness that carries through to a long finish. I didnt get much of a hop bite, but, really, dont we have enough of those types anyway? A solid entry from Founders and yes, Id like another.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2012 Strong malt profile, good drinkin beer
appearence, dark amber in color
taste, malty, I did taste a toostie roll type flavor, sweet, hardly and Hop flavor
smell again a faint toostie roll aroma, nice
overall, a nice Scotch Ale, I would like a alittle smoke flavor added to this, from smoked peat.
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: Sampled this at ABR this fall.  Wonderful scotch ale, pretty much exactly as it should be done.  Very nice!
Bottle, as pictured.  Pours a deep brown and has a very creamy mouthfeel.  Caramel, chocolate, toffee all throughout.  Really a good beer.  Not sure if I like the backwoods better or not.

Pours a lovely dark amber with a tan head that quickly dissipates.  Sugary, fruity aroma, caramel as well.  Flavor is mostly warm malts, with hints of smoke and tart, a deliciously clean overall effect with barely any lingering bitterness.  Nice full mouth-feel.

A soild beer, not really on the scotch ale train myself, but I did find this beer to be well balanced, and very drinkable. Solid hop profile, big smoked earthy malt flavor. If its a style you enjoy seek this beer out its very enjoyable.

Bottle looks simple but really good. Beer in the glass dark brown, small head. Starts soft-malty, fine roasty-rusty, not too dry. Some sweet hints in the background. Finish well balanced, wonderful spicy-malty, also a little bit fruity like berries. Nice aftertaste. A great beer!

pours a nice mahogany color with a good and thick foamy head

rich and deep nose of caramel, dark chocolate, some malt tones and bits of spice

full bodied with a real richness to it. Fuller bodied with well balanced flavors of dark roast coffee, caramel, malts and spice tones
