while this is a bigger beer it holds it very well. On the fuller and richer side, but well balanced with some power behind it

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2014 
Tap @ Konttori.
A lot creamier palate on this one, maybe a bit sweeter too. Spices on the background, lots of caramel, very bready. Very tasty and pleasant.
355 ml bottle @ OHaras.
Originally rated on 20100808. (8+3+8+4+15)
Pours clear dark red with small head. Aroma of old ripe fruits, plum and lots of raisins, spices, dark malts and yeast. Flavour of dark malts, spices, ripe fruits, caramel malts, toffee and raisins. Palate is sweet and slick, medium carbonation.
5324
Bottle 330ml. Pours dark amber with a minimal head.  Aroma and taste overwhelmed with raisins. Amercan hop swetness. Not Bad.

12 oz bottle poured at home. Beautiful translucent ruby color around the edges, becomes mahogany through chocolate brown in the center. A gorgeous beer. Aroma is smoked and roasted malts, peat, robust caramel, and a touch of vanilla. Rich, smokey, peaty malts form the body of the beers taste. Some caramel and vanilla swirls on the edges. Its held together by a bit of floral hops. The best touch of barnyard flavor floats in, too. Wonderful palate -- the beer briefly sits heavy and robust, then slides away, cleansed by the touch of hops. Nicely done.

pours dark brown with a lasting white head and some lacing.  creamy aroma with notes of brown sugar, toffee and a hint of citrus.  taste is sweet with a bit of birch, maple and hoppiness.  finish is a bit syrupy and sticky with a nice burn.

A: The beer pours a dark amber color with a creamy khaki colored head.

S: Quite a bit more fruity than many other Scotch ales.  Sweet toffee and caramel with some toasted bread and malt aromas.  Just a little bit of peat and smoke.

T: Sweet malt and bread with lots of peat.  A bit of caramel and toffee and a maybe a weird savory and salty flavor, almost like seaweed.  Theres a bit of a strange bitterness, too.

M: Medium bodied with a medium carbonation.

O: One of the few Founders beers Ive had that didnt do much for me.

Bottle. The pour was a murky medium brown with a copper hue and had an average sized (1-2 finger) light brown rocky head that dissipated quickly but left a thin layer of foam that created some fair lacing.

The aroma was a bit on the sweet side with roasted bread malts, an herbal hop and a sweet doughy yeast with notes of raisons, molasses and a mild alcohol scent.

The taste was sweet and malty with a hint of molasses in the beginning and finished a bit bitter, with a touch of raisons and a mild alcohol tinge at the end that left the flavor to linger for a nice long while.

Mouthfeel was somewhere between medium and full in body and was rather dry in texture with a soft carbonation.

Overall an extremely tasty brew with the alcohol flavor kept to a minimum, yet still allowing for a nice warming sensation after the swallow.

12-oz bottle from 9th Ave Vintner (6-pk). Erica had one, too. Pour is dark, syrupy and with a tinge of red. Medium to large light brown head which vanished pretty quickly, leaving almost no lacing. Aroma is not bad but very subdued: some chocolate and light alcohol. More of the same on the palate with a sweet, somewhat bitter finish. Heavy but smooth mouthfeel. Porter-esque.

Bottle. Pours dark copper brown color with a kahki head that settles to a thin film and collar. Aroma is roasted malt and licorice and some caramel. Taste is more malty roasted caramel and light anise with some woodiness as well. Palate is full slick and a little creamy that finishes dry. One of the better Scotch ales Ive had, even though I am not a huge fan of the style!

(bottle 7/7/10). Dark amber color with light cloudiness. Medium off white head. Strong sweet bready malt aroma. Flavor of the same, with moderate alcohol. Avg duration. Moderate dry, alcohol finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

It pours a light brown color, almost like the darkest iced tea youve ever had. The flavor is very complex with a ton of different malt flavors going on. There is roastedness, piney, hoppy, a little bit of not very sweet maple, even a hint of scotch. Its very bold and has a long bitter, but not acrid, finish.
Bottle @ home. Dark brown / red colored beer. Smell chocolate and burned malts. Taste a lot of chocolate and malts. Nice carbonation, medium body.

12oz bottle:  This one pours a cloudy, coppery amber color.  There was a very small light brown had on it that didnt linger or leave much lacing at all.  Big nose of roasted caramel.  Definitely raisins and a hint of smoke in there also.  Very nice taste.  It is smokey and a little bitter.  Then you get some of that roasted caramel with a bit of sweetness popping thru.  Faint dark fruits to the taste also.  Nice.
Nice beer. Doesnt have that maple syrup taste that I hate (present in a lot of scotch ales and barley winws). Fruity ans smokey as well; although not terribly complex.
real good beer. lots of caramel with a nice hopiness to it. real heavy with some welcome alcohol burn.
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Red/brown color with a tight tan head. Pleasing nose.  Smoky malt and toffee flavor with a nice finish. Good stuff.

Bottles from the local market. Pours a deep, red black brown with a thin, evanescent head.  Aroma is a complex mix of raisin, coffee, and toast, balanced by a nice bitterness. The mouth is medium,  with a slight carbonation.  Really nice.

Pours medium red-brown with a quick light brown head. Nose is strong and a mix of sugar, herbs, wood, and good ol funkiness....and a little hops. Flavor hits with alcohol and oak hard on the front, without much of a change as it tapers off. Some peatiness is left after the swallow, but theres no stickiness or bitterness. Very smooth for a Scotch but it doesnt have the depth I expected.

This beer is surprisingly FANTASTIC!
Aroma is of sweet burnt caramel with a hint of toffee.
Appearance is a reddish/tan color, with a creamy tan thick head that makes me want to guzzle this beer. 
The taste is absolutely delicious and has a butterscotch caramel coffee taste that is smooth as he** for a scotch ale.
Overall, its great.. It is a thick, syruppy, caramel, sweet beer that is pleasing to drink.  I didnt think I would like this big beer, because I am normally not a fan of strong big ales.. But this is really good.  A must try..

Bottle.
Pours redbrown with a yellow head when given a whirl.
Buttery aroma. Smooth mouthfeel with a taste of butter scotch and some hops.
Dark brown light tan; peat aromas; hopped up palate for a scotch ale; nice.
Bottle. Pours beautifully red-brown with a small golden head. The aroma is too buttery to be really enjoyable. Taste is sweet of toffee and has got a warming finish. Smooth.

Now this is one hell of a nice beer. Just sitting there it has this kind of dark stained wood appearance, but then you hold it up to the light and it magically transforms into this beautiful crimson. It has a quickly settling mocha head that leaves little smiley faces for lacing. Aroma is caramel and bread with hints of dark fruit. Taste is very sweet, yet theres a bitter hop element back there keeping it together. Palate is full and rich with a wonderful finish. Just what these old creaky bones needed.
Poured a dark red/amber color with a nice maly, chocolate, boozy aroma that blends well when you drink it.  Each sip left me wanting more.

A dark reddish brown beer with a small tan head.  The aroma is very malty with hints of chocolate, pine,  and butterscotch.  The flavor is equally malty, with a strong smokiness, earthiness, and a growing bitterness in the finish.  The alcohol is a bit pronounced and it is overall just okay, but scotch ales have never really been my thing.

5 Aug 2011, bottle. nose is cerealy malt, raisiny alcohol but not a big nose. med body, slightly fizzy, a little watery consistency. taste is much bolder than aroma. rye bread, raisins, alcohol. bigger than most scottish ales but very nice.

12oz bottle - Dark brown ruby red pour.  Aroma of malt, chocolate, and cherries.  Full body beer.  Tastes hoppy and sugary.  Warms you up pretty good.  Wonderful beer.  You can taste the booze pretty well, but thats not a bad thing.  Everything seems to blend well.  This beer is perfect for sitting in your basement while your wife cooks dinner.

Instant gratification. Better than I had expected. A bit bitter at first... that brings out the very slight hint of chocolate and strong coffee. A very bold beer! If you like malts and hops you need to try this beer.

Poured into a pint tumbler.  The aroma was rather neutral.  Perhaps a hint of hops but that may be a subjective decision on my part.  Nice deep reddish brown color.  Complex blend of rich sweet malts.   No strong alcohol taste despite the high 8. 5% A.B.V.  Quite smooth with a full palate feel.  Light carbonation.  Overall this beer is a must have keeper.

Poured a reddish brown hue with a tan head with nice retention.  Aroma had big malt notes caramel mainly but there was some biscuit notes. Smoky peat and alcohol balanced it out.  Flavor was initially sweet, sweetness gave way to some dark bread notes and a smoky finish.  Alcohol was a warming presence through out.  Finish was slightly dry and the palate was rich.
Bottle @ Pannuhuone, Kuopio. Originally rated on 8.10.2010. Great, well balanced scotch ale.

Pours a deep mahogany color with a light tan head that leaves some pretty good lacing. Smells of caramel and chocolate malts with some dark fruits and a faint hoppiness. Taste follows the nose with the sweetness of the malts and fruit, the beer is medium bodied and smooth. Overall this is a good beer I can get at a reasonable price.

Pours a dark amber with a off white head.  Smells of caramel malts, a little coffee and some ripened fruit/berries with a nice bit of hops.  The taste is caramel, ripe berries, a bit of alcohol and a bit of charred malts.  Very nice and will certainly be revisiting this one.

On tap at Founders. Dark brown pour, with some off white head. Aroma of toasted malt, something chocolaty and a lot of hops. Taste is sweet at first, with a long bitter hop finish. Palate was average on carbonation and pretty full bodied. I didnt like the hoppiness in this beer at all, out of style according to me.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark copper with a very thin beige head. The aroma is roasted malts, caramel, vanilla, licorice, and faint earthy hops. The flavor is very malty and sweet up front, with a growing bitterness in the middle. The finish is dry, smoky, and bitter. The palate is medium, a little acidic, and clean. Well balanced and subtly smoked. Very nice.
Poured a thick dark red color with aroma of caramel and roast. Great taste and mouthfeel with the amount of alcohol, it was impressive. One of the best Scotch beers Ive had yet.
Very dark brownish red pour. Aroma is chocolate and berries. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, toffee, alcohol and more fruit. Sweet, interesting and delicious.

Date: June 28, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Founders, Grand Rapids, MI Appearance: Dark brownish red with slight amount of head Aroma: Sweet/malty Flavor: consistent with aroma with some bitter Other: A good beer, but was nothing special....possibly because I had the Cashew Mountain right before it and any beer after that one would be a let down.
Draft in Bowling Green, OH.  Dark brown-reddish pour, small head. Sweet dark caramel and roasty aroma. Medium thick body, dark almost smoky flavor of aged liquor and malt. Fairly sticky finish.

Kaffeemalziger, röstiger Duft mit spürbaren Fruchteinschlägen. Leicht fruchtige Tendenzen denn auch im ersten Antrunk, süßlich-malzig und angenehm weich. Im Mittel schokoladig-röstig und trotz der immerhin fünfzig Bittereinheiten, eher bedeckt bitter abklingend. Wärmender Nachhall. Ein ausgezeichnetes Bier.Test vom 6.9.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche
Bottle from Cavie.  Brown orange pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is chocolate, moss, steamed veggies, and smoke.  Taste is bitter, nice hops, great spice, a little smoke, and more chocolate.
A fantastic scotch ale.  Full of body, great malt profile.  Very complex flavors.  I could drink this all day.
This beer has a frothy brown head. There is a big alcohol bite on top of an earthy peat flavor. It has a thick body and a lingering aftertaste.

0.355l bottle from Barley Wine. Pours a cloudy unfiltered dark ruby body with a small quickly fading tanned caramel head. Aroma is full of sweet dried fruits, roasted caramel and quite malty. Full-bodied, average carbonated and has a near sticky to oily mouthfeeling. Tastes are mainly dominated by good roasted caramel, malts and sweet and warming alcohol. Its kinda sweet with notes of dark dried fruits. There is also a nice light roasted chocolate-malty hint in the finish. Ends with a nicely sweet and light bitter warming aftertaste. Good stuff!
Burnt wood and caramel taste.  Subtle alcohol kick.  One of the better scotch ales on the market.

Much, much better than I expected.  Poured from a 12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy brown.  Has a sweet, roasted smell...almost honey roasted peanuts (minus the nuts) if that makes sense.  Creamy, smooth finish.  I dont like Scotch Ales...or so I thought.  But, this is a good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2013 On tap. Pours dark brownish red, little to no head. Smells of lightly burnt wood, chocolate malt and sugary alcohol, tastes up front much the same. A lot more flavor comes out in the finish and once it warms a bit. Some fruit a weird mix of green apple (without tartness) plum or something but still that lightly burnt attribute. Murky spice-full hop flavor adds to the quirky complexity. Big body, not for the light at heart, smooth malty finish.

pours a dark ruby, very dark ruby, with a tan head aroma is roasty caramel, not amelling any hop presence, taste is sweet rich and slightly smoky, small bitterness comes through at the end but without a hop taste seems to be nothin but malt here full bodied but still very drinkable and th 8.5 abv is hardly noticed

Pours a dark brownish-red with a thick tan head. Sweet aroma filled with caramel, roasted malt, honey and a bit of smoke. Tastes of roasted malt, fruit and butterscotch, with a bit of hops, smoke and peat in the finish. Full-bodied but sessionable.
Bottle w sweet malt nose & dark brown pour...tiny head. Big malt taste with caramel plus a tad of  smoke.

Würzig-hefiger Antrunk, angenehm malzig. Weich herb und nussig, der nicht unerhebliche Alkoholgehalt zeigt sich meist unterstützend, wirkt im hinteren mittelteil aber zwischenzeitlich stechend. Aromen von Pflaumeund Orange, trocken mit seichter Whiskynote. Anschließend trocken und süß, stimmig. Zum Ende auch röstmalzern unter der Süße, Kaffeebohnen, herb-bitter. 9/10/9/12/12/11

(bottle)  Founders always represents well.  Even though this is not one of my favored styles, I must credit this beer for its attributes.  Rich roasted malts, peaty, dark molasses and some smoke & alcohol noted.  Nice palate.  A nice choice for cold days or a night cap.

bottle - pours a deep mahogany with a khaki head. Aroma is aggressive; scents include caramel, smoke, spruce, and hay. Taste is smokey and lightly bitter. Medium bodied with a creamy texture and lively carbonation. The bitter finish lingers nicely.
En härlig skotsk ale med massor av malt, smörkola, torv och liten lätt rökighet. Sammantaget en lätt whiskeykänsla. En bra välavvägd beska håller ihop det hela så att det inte blir för sött.
Very pleasant. Smoky,malty and scotchey. A perfect first step in the direction of imperial stout to imperial IPA, didnt want to make the full leap just yet, its still spring!

Poured into a snifter. Appearance is a dense mahogany with a creamy head of beige foam floating merrily atop the beer. Head dissipates at a fair rate leaving nice rings and webs of lacing as it goes. Nice carbonation bubbles. Aroma is sweet fruits, smoky malt notes, a touch of cream loaded coffee is in there too. Taste is where this one shines the brightest. Slightly smoked malt and peat coats the tongue and mellows to a wonderful woody note. Hop bitterness comes through slightly towards the end and lingers until a slight alcohol burn wraps things up. Mighty tasty beverage if I do say so myself. Creamy, fully bodied mouthfeel, but yet supremely drinkable.

Reddish brown color, relatively clear, small and quickly fading tan head. Kind of a sweet taste, very nice. Does not taste alcoholic, the scotch aroma is very well done. Easy to drink, but brief aftertaste, which is probably approriate for the flavor. Something more complex to the aroma that I cant quite figure that has me coming back for more. Certainly feels like a classy drink.

12 oz bottle from Chevy Chase Wine & Spirits in Washington DC, served in a tulip. Pours clear mahogany with a small tan head. The head fades to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big aromas of toasted malts, smoke and earth, along with a touch of chocolate and a faint whiff of pepper. The flavour is quite malty sweet, very complex with caramel, chocolate and a toasted, smokey character and just a touch of earthy and resinous hops for balance. The finish is long and malty, with alcohol and roasted notes. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, an excellent scotch ale with a complex roasted, smokey malt character. A delicious brew. 2011-05-12

Appearance:  ruddy, reddish-orange brown with an ochre head of about a finger; syrupy legs coat the sides, and leave occasional bubbles of shimmering lace.  Aroma: boozy caramel, like a butterscotch sauce freshly made, notes of toffee and smoke.  Taste: caramel, molasses, raisins, prunes, toffee, rich brown sugar, butterscotch, and a good underlying note of smoked meat (maybe some peat) and chocolate.  Finish: syrupy sweet flavors quickly surrender to a solid, meaty and smokey dryness, which in turn gives way to a lovely whiskey-like warming.   Notes: Wonderful scotch ale.  Reminded me very much of the Grand Teton Sheepeater, only with a little less smoke.  Flavors are rich, sweet and syrupy, but the palate stays smooth and dry enough to keep it from getting cloying.

A dark mahogny coloured body and a nice smooth head. It gives an explosion of malt-taste in your mouth. Caramel malt blends perfectly with some chocolate, taste of bread and a hint of smoke. Super well balanced. Very easy to drink with its low carbonation. The aftertaste hints of dark syrap, without beeing sticky.

Draught at Jerrys Sandwiches in Chicago.  Appearance is dark ruby or mahogany color with slight tan head.  Aroma is caramel, bread, and some slight resin and earthy hops, over all present but not overly powerful.  Taste is rich in caramel, bread, smoke with a earthy hint in the background.  The palate on this beer is amazing - medium-bodied, smooth, creamy, mild carbonation making it very drinkable.

A deep crimson pour with a tan head with excellent lacing.  The aroma is a little woody, but with a touch of sweet caramel and some bread.  The medium body has creamy texture with soft carbonation.  The taste begins sweet and is closely followed by a smokey finish with a slight alcohol flavor.

Pours a dark reddish brown with off-white head a above average lacing.  Aromas of caramel, chocolate, smoke, burnt sugars, and notes of some fruit, maybe black cherry.   Taste is sweet for sure, but not overbearing as the hops steps in quickly and are noticeable with this full bodied beer.   Very little carbonation leads to a creamy, long, dry finish.  Overall, I am a big fan of this one.  Great combination of malts, sugars, hops, anything else they threw in there. Another great one from Founders.

ottle 12 oz. Dark brown with a ruby red glow and off-white head of medium length.Aroma of dark fruit, heavy roasted malt, brown sugar and spice. The taste is more sweet, but slightly bitter with hints of spice. The aftertaste is slightly bitter
Pours cloudy red-orange with off-white lacing. Malty aroma with notes of cherry and fresh bread...like fruit cake. Full-bodied with nice malt feel. Think fruit cake in beer form.

Bottle. Deep red copper color thats slightly hazy and a thinner tan head. Sweet candied sugar, plums, dark fruits, toffee and light roast in the aroma. Vanilla, dark fruits, prunes, toffee and a slight bit of peat for the flavor. Medium body with soft carbonation. Nice sipper.

2010 bottle cellared July 10 consumed 23 April 2011.  Dark reddish brown color, tiny bubbles in the head hint at the superb quality of this brew.  The nose has subsided substantially in the cellar but still has notes of caramel and roasted grain.  Full bodied and viscous on the palate, this beer displays chocolate and heavy caramel notes with hops being mildly spicy and just enough to balance the sweetnes of the brew.  Has always been one of my faves.

Appearance: Beautiful dark red hue, mostly hazy but some transparency to it. No noticeable carbonation. Forms a small, yellowish, soapy head. Decent retention and lacing.Smell: Red apple and caramel syrup. Touch of alcohol.Taste: This is the liquid equivalent of a candy apple. Rich caramel sweetness on the outside with a juicy red apple on the inside. Strange, but pleasing mix of fruit and sugar. Leaves a distinct bittersweet chocolate aftertaste as well to impart a touch of bitterness as well as round out the sweet aspect of the palate. Finishes with a slightly smoky flavor, but it seems to fade away after one a few swigs. Initially, a very delectable palate, but the beer doesnt finish as strong as it starts as it begins to become overtly milder and alcohol begins to distract from the main palate. Still very tasty and pleasing from first to last drop, though.Mouthfeel: Thick, soft, slightly stick, no noticeable carbonation. Thins out and becomes slightly watery towards the end.Drinkability: For an 8.5% ABV beer, Dirty Bastard most definitely does not drink or feel like it. While the palate is robust, the soft mouthfeel makes for a smooth, easy-drinking beer. Not refreshing per se, but fun to drink. Ideal to pair with a pie - especially pecan, rhubarb, or minced meat. Overall, one of the best American Scotch-style ales. Those with a taste for the style will love it, but others will simply like it as I did.

Poured a very hazy reddish-brown with almost no head.  Aroma has lots of molasses and sweet malts.  Lots of dark fruit as well with some scotch, great aroma overall.  Taste is sweet and fruity at first.  Transitions into a roasted and malty finish with scotch.  There are also flavors of bread that go along nicely with the fruit flavors.  Overall its pretty complex.  A good amount of hops helps the taste finish off.  The body is a tiny bit thin, but there is a good amount of flavor so I like it.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle.  Pours a amber red color with thin beige head.  Nose is smoked peat, some alcohol and toffee.  Taste follows the nose.  There is some biting hoppiness in the back end of this one.  It lacks the sweetness that I really love in this style and the hop profile is more pronounced than is typical for this style.  I love Backwoods Bastard...the aging kills the bitterness of the hops.
All Founders beers have so much flavor and this is no different. Not much of an aroma, This has an interesting mix of hops; good selection but not one of the top from Founders.
Pours mid brown with dried fruit notes.  this then drives to a more caramel malt base which then finished with a light spiced hop lingering finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with off white head. Aroma consists of dark fruit, little malt sweetness, and a little roasted nuttiness. The taste is very good for a scotch ale I can get yea round. It is malty with hints of caramel and toffee, roast, hop bitterness, and toasted bread. Good beer and aregular in my fridge.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2011 Pours a deep reddish brown with minimal head.  Nice roasted malt aroma.  The taste is very slightly sweet and decently malty.  A little chewy.  Has a nice mild hoppy finish.  The alcohol does shine through a little bit, but not too harsh.  Overall a solid brew.
12oz bottle. Dark reddish pour with very little head. Sugary aroma, sweet malt taste. Dark fruits.

Bottle.  Deep copper color, thin white head.  Powerful malt aroma a little sweet and smoky. Balanced palate, medium and smooth with some carbonation.  Full bitter finish that sticks around.   Solid all around for complex, full flavored scoth ale.  Good beer.

Bottle pour into globe glass. Bottle from refrigerated section at local store.

The beer pours with an almost garnet color and a thin white head that doesnt last long. Very low carbonation, as expected from a scotch ale, makes for a smooth drinking beer that goes down fast at 8.5%. While cold in the glass the beer has a mostly malt aroma with a hint of alcohol but as the beer warms it smells almost entirely of alcohol. The beer has a slight scotch character and a very dry finish due in part to the hop bite, but nothing special. The beer was undoubtedly swayed towards the sweet with only 50 IBU. I love scotch ales but this one missed with the overwhelming alcohol and cloyingly sweet notes.

Bottle thanks to Phaleslu. Pours muddy amber brown, creamy tan head. Aroma of toffee, citrus, roasty malt, molasses, raisin, earthy things in general. Taste is much the same, lots of roast malt, nut, dark fruit, some citrus, some bitter chocolate/coffee finish. Lots of flavor. Medium thick texture, soft carbonation. Alcohol is mildly noticeable.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2014 This was purchased at Whole Foods for tasting.  The ale poured a deep reddish brown and not much of a head.  The ale was a surprise.  It had an unexpected taste of malts and some bitterness.  The higher alcohol was well balanced and contributed to this ale being worth trying again. Another gift in December 2014.  The ale has medium body with soft carbonation. The ale ended with  a malty sweet finish.

deep mahogany pour with little head.  brown sugar aroma.  bold taste, dark fruit, brown sugar or caramel...maybe some biscuits. powerfully malty.  strong alcohol warming feel.  very good...my favorite so far of this style.

12oz bottle poured into my De Struise glass... As it pours into the glass it looks like a bright copper, but this settles a deep mahogany. A light tan head rises a few fingers at first then settles to full finger cap. Im skeptical of this retention as the head looks very watery and light, not full enough for me. Very light lacing... The aroma is really too light, toffee on the front mostly, some light scotch notes on the back, not much going on. As it warms lots of peat comes through. Actually, this needs to warm quite bit out the fridge, really starts to open up and is very pleasant...The taste is a bit of let down for me. There is a scotch backbone that really dominates, too spirit like. Very chewy. Malt characters is gone. 

This is so-so, get if youre a scotch ale fan, but Id pass in the future.
Sampler at the pub.  It poured a reddish brown and had a white head. The aroma was malty and a bit smoky. The taste was malty, chocolatey, some grass and a little bittereness.  A decent Scotch Ale.
This is good. Had this on tap at the public house in peoria. Sweet and tasty. I think I like alittle more Smokey malts. Slight bourbonisque thing going on.

Bottle @ Flying Saucer. Dark brown appearance with a creamy tan head. Nice caramel Scottish malty nose. Very sweet malty caramel malty beer. Very sweet flavor with bit of nuttiness. Strong alcoholic and sugary finish.
A rich copper pour with little head. It started off sweet with a nice smokey finish.

A - Pours a slightly clear ruby-amber color with about a finger of off-white head. The head fairly quickly reduces to a nice ring with some nice lacing.

S - The aroma is a very pungent sweet carmel malt. There are also some brown sugar and roasted elements also. There is also some booze in the nose.

T - Starts off with some deep dark fruit flavors and some of the malty carmel sweetness. Through the middle the carmel malt flavor gets a bit stronger and is joined by just a bit of hop flavor also. The finish is a mix of the carmel sweetness, the dark fruit flavors, and just a touch of booze, brown sugar, and bitterness that lingers. Nicely balanced.

M - Medium to heavy bodied with fairly low carbonation. Fairly think and almost creamy overall, but still smooth. Finish is just a tad dry and a tad syrupy.

D - Fairly drinkable. Very rich beer and a lot of flavors going on. Thankfully, the flavors are well balanced are work very well together. Not a beer to gulp down, and with the high abv (8.5 %) it is a very enjoyable beer at a bit of a slower pace.

Morning, just another day
Founders beer will pass my way
Looking in my glass
I see a Dirty Bastard
I never realized
the Scotch style you mastered, oh Founders
Well you came and you gave without taking
but I drank you away, oh Founders
well you filled me and stopped me from thirsting
I need you today, oh Founders

Pours rosy brown with a quickly-dissipating off-white head. Sweet and malty on the nose, with booze-soaked bread and a touch of smokiness. A little sharp. Interesting taste. Starts off same as the nose--sweet and malty, with some sour nuttiness. Kind of watery though, and not nearly as pungent as Id expect. Finishes with a hop bite thats quickly overtaken by a rubbing alcohol/nail polish note thats neither warming nor smooth. It really ruins the beer, even though it was fairly unimpressive up to that point. Really missing the boat on this one.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2013 12 oz bottle. Pours auburn-brown with a substantial head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is smoky, caramel, malty. Taste is medium sweet. Body is medium, with good mouthfeel-- slightly thick, but not too much. Finish is mild with slight taste of alcohol. A hearty beer. Overall enjoyable, but not a beer Id seek out again. (Or maybe I just dont like Scotch Ales. Need to try more in this style and then re-rate.)

Pours a dark and rich copper color with very little head. Smells like sweet roasted malts and honey and caramel. Taste is noticeably sweet and malty with a little yeasty bite. Alcohol esters become more apparent as beer warms up a bit. Beer finishes with a smoky caramel flavor.

Charred malt aroma with a hint of hops and brambles. Taste is a little tannic rather than bitter on the start, probably from wet hopping, then fades into a sweet roasted malt flavor followed by a nice oaky, and somewhat smoky Scotch presence, followed by a lingering but mellow hop bitterness. This brews texture is very nice, not syrupy or watery, somewhere in the middle with some enjoyable fizz and a silky feeling finish. The taste lingers for a while, a very good sipping beer. Very nice reddish/dark brown color, with awesome lacing, looks very appetizing. Very nice brew.

Bottle. Poured a murky orange brown. Nose is big and sweet hops. But the flavor although it is hoppy is way more complex. The hops blast you then the intense malt backbone kicks It in High gear. Butterscotch and hops. Sweet and bitter. Very nice.
Pours a reddish brown body. Deep and dark. Sweet with dark fruits, toffee, a rum-like alcohol burn. I didnt really get the advertised hop in the close, but it was good without.
Sweet malty body with deep fruity flavors on the palate, complex aroma, very nice yearly offering, recommended

The nose was smoky, dusty, fruity with additional hints of caramel and spice. The taste was spicy and fruity with the malt as more of an undertone. A smoky. lightly salty and almost acidic character shows on the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is lush for the style and there is a minor alcohol presence detected during the swallow, but not overpowering.

Generally not a fan of Scotch Ales, but this is one of the better ones Ive had. Still a bit too much sweetness and alcohol presence as is par for the course for this style (pun intended). Yet in spite of that, this beer is very drinkable, not syrupy, and has a good hop presence.
Catching up on ratings. One of my favorite Scotch Ales, and Founders never makes a crappy beer.

Reminds me of an old smoke filled cabin in northern Michigan. This beer will bite you in the ass if youre not paying attention, it has a great life, full body, smoke like presence, and beautiful pour to it. Love this beer.

Bottle. Dark brown with small pale brown head. Aroma sweet, malt and whisky notes. Taste initial strong alcohol burn, mellow sweet malts, sugar, finish with notes of whisky and a little bitterness. A nice beer.
Pours dark brown with a one finger head light tan head.  Nose is heavy peat and smoke.  Taste is mostly smoke and malt.  A fairly bitter finish for a scotch ale.  Good but not one of my favorites.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2012 19-02-11 Bouteille: Brune très foncée avec reflets rougeatres. Mousse épaisse couleur crème caramel qui disparait rapidement. Faibles aromes de caramel et de noix avec une touche de chocolat. Pas trop sucrée avec une petite amertume. En bouche, elle est très pateuse et farineuse avec de petites note caramel-chocolat. Texture mince et légèrement crémeuse. Très ordinaire.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 Red brown in color and smooth and full bodied. It was pretty to look at and I will another. 8.3% and loving it. A nice change. There is some smoke in there.
On tap at Zenos. Dark amber with a quarter inch tan head. Aroma is caramel. Flavor is caramel with some smokiness and nuttiness. Nice.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2016 Bottle at Colletts Cafe, may 4th 2016. Dark red to brown body with a small beige head. Aroma is malty with chocolate, toast and hazelnut. Taste is sweet with herbs, burned caramel, mild bitterness. Light boozy finish with a strong malty aftertaste.
Pours ruby brown with a thin offwhite head. SMell is sweet malt maple and hops. Taste is similar with added peat roastyness and a chocolatey lingering aftertaste.
This is one of my less-liked Founders offerings. IT is a bit sweet and a bit blunt imo. When they trow it in the bourbon barrels it comes alive.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark red with a thick, long lasting, frothy reddish head and good amount of lacing.  Aroma is of bready malt and cherry.  Medium, creamy, smooth body.  Bready, caramel malt is balanced on the palate by some earthy hops and dark chocolate.  Long, dry finish.  Delicious brew.

growler from whole foods...  pours a healthy amber with toffee colored head.. hearty, earthy notes permeate above the brim.. initial hit to the palate is breaded almost toasty with a sligt resinous hop flavor on the back end.. complexity of malts are apparent as a syupy thickness envelops the taste buds.  the alcohol is masked beautifully and this truly is a grown mans ale.. well constructed from start to finish..
Bottle, pours reddish brown, aroma of diacetyl, molasses, malt, dough, caramel, taste follows the nose but has way too much diacetyl for my liking, very sweet as well.

Pours a dark amber.  Sweet malt and dark fruit aroma.  Taste is very rich...toffee, dates, figs, whiskey, roasted malt, vanilla, and some alcohol. Full body, oily texture.  This was good, but a bit too rich for my liking.
Bottle at Olympen Oslo. Ruby red with a light nonlasting head. Smells of smoke and malts. Taste is the same. Much whisky cask influence here. The hops and finish is more reserved.

Strong Scotch ale, very bitter and potent, dark color, complex flavor, heavy malt flavor evident, almost a barrel aged smoked flavor to it as well, definitely a sipper, but excellent cold weather beer, worthy of praise.

Deep aroma of plums, dates, ripe cherries, and aged caramel. Dark fruits, molasses, toffee, and caramel for flavors. Roasted, chewy finish. Hearty and warming. I only wish there had been a peat presence... that would have indeed uped the score.

Bottle. Deep brown, copper-glinting at the edges. Slim cappuccino foam, aerated like its been whisked and diminishing by the second. Rich, buttery shortbread nose studded with milk-chocolate coated raisins and M+Ms. Sweet, chalky and heavily raisin-accented with notes of brown Smartie, M+M, muscovado sugar and a whiff of the annoying peach air freshener of the Centennial IPA. Zero smoke, peat, hop...who needs it? A seductive, sugary, Belgian-aping, doppelbockesque morass of dark fruits and sugars so sweet you dont notice the sledgehammer of booze swinging squarely down on the back of your skull. Good session beer.

Shared bottle at Cardinal. Pours clear mahogany with a finger thick, creamy brown-orange head. Sweet dried fruits, wood and prune in the aroma and a whiff of smoke. First flavor impression has sweet dried fruits wrapped around alcohol that reveals itself in the finish along with the bitterness. Full bodied, syrupy and gently carbonated.

355 ml bottle @ Cardinal. Dark reddish brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of dark, roasted malt, caramel, dry fruit and alcohol. Flavor is sweet and light roasted malt, caramel, dry fruit, balanced bitter and warming alcohol. Bitter and alcoholic warming aftertaste. Very nice.

bottle from bierkompass!!!
A dark orange-brown beer pours with a good, fine, flat head. The smell is malty sweet, subtle caramel. Starts malty sweet, barely alcoholic for 8.5%. The further course remains dominant sweet malty with mild roasted flavor and a touch of berry fruits. The aftertaste appears to be relatively neutral, also sweet malty with good roasted notes. To finish it gets a little bitter, the hops come through more and more.

12oz bottle, ruby red pour, little lacing, nothing much of an aroma, a little caramel and burnt malts, Im not sure, the brew doesnt have any of the caramel sweetness Im used to in a scotch, interesting.

(bottle - 12 oz) Hazy ruby pour with a thin tan head. Malty and smoky aroma at the start with some caramel hiding behind it. Flavor begins with a sweet and smoky flavor that gives way to a lightly sweet caramel malt middle and then a rather aggressively hopped finish. Bitter and smoky on the aftertaste.
Bottle. Copper colour with a beige head. Aroma is peat, caramel, alcohol. Flavour is alcohol, hop, smoked, malt, peat, caramel. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

12oz bottle pours a deep redish brown beer that almost appears purple under light, with a very slight off white head. Aroma is somewhat sweet upfront with slight notes of yeast and bread. Taste is somewhat sweet upfront but is very well balanced with hops and a slight bitterness that round out this beer. A very complex beer that works, a great beer.
12 oz Bottle. Hazy caramel color with a tan head. Toffee and caramel nose, toast, alcohol as it warms. Roasty malt flavor, brown sugar, tiny bit of smoke and chocolate.  Easy drinking for ABV.
Pour is a translucent mahogany with nearly no head. Nose has hints of dark fruit but is dominated by molasses and scotch. Taste is of scotch and vanilla  with some burnt brown sugar notes as well.

Pours a deep red-brown with thin off-white head. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, butterscotch, hints of whiskey. Flavor is bittersweet with some whiskey kick; lots of brown sugar flavor and a little vanilla also.

Bottle. Pours hazy ruby brown with a small and diminishing beige head. Quite sweet aroma with notes of dried fruits and bread. Remote overtone of alcohol. Cloying. Notes of damp basement as it warms. Flavour is sweet and a bit tart with dried fruits and malt. Tart, sweet and quite bitter finish. Lingering grassy notes. Overall a fine beer, but too cloying for my taste. 04.01.11.

Bottle. Caramel hops. Butterscotch. Toffee. Dryness. I let it warm in my mouth.  Enormous body.  Expands on the palate.  Big soft carbonation.
Amazing.

Bottle.

Dark ruby with a small head. Nice aroma and taste of malt, caramel, dark fruits, some wood. I liked the sweet and very malty taste of this beer.

Bottle- Pours a slightly hazy chestnut color with a very small off-white head that fades to lacing. Has a dark fruit and malt aroma with traces of spice and sweetness. Very subtle hint of alcohol, not overpowering. Taste is a mixture of dark fruit and alcohol with some malt and a touch of spicy sweetness. Medium body, very smooth and quite creamy. Has a pleasant warming feeling. Great sipping brew on a cold winter night. Good example of the style.

Bottled. Pours deep amber with a creamy, beige, short lasting head. Weak lacings. Soft carbonation. Nose of caramel, bread and notes of berries. Sweet flavour with bread, caramel and berries. Medium bodied. Slightly bitter finish with alcohol notes. OK and well balanced.

Bottle.
Brown/amber with some off white head. Aroma is of malt, caramel, light earthy note. Taste has light sweetness, malty, bit of a woody note. Finishes dry. Solid.

Pours a reddish brown, with little head, and not much lacing.  Smells faintly of whiskey, or scotch, and beer.  Has a dry scotch taste, mixed with some maltiness.  Not much hops going on.  Pretty good.  Leaves a kinda watery mouthfeel.

Bottle @ EODT10

Pours a rich murky brown, opaque body with a creamy, light brown head.
Intense aroma of pine, strong hops, liquor and potent dark malts. Very promising.
Taste is incredible, the aromas above return in the taste but are quickly overpowered by a rich, broad palate of medium bitter hops, caramel, toffee, cream. Like a brown variety of imperial stout. Great balance between smoothness, piney hops and bitterness.

Bottle @ EODT10:
Light yellow beige foamy head on top of a cloudy dark orange to brown beer.
Smell is a very balanced mix of oatmeal, caramel, toffee, liquorice, milk chocolate, liquor, malts and cookie.
Taste is a big wow! A very well bitter sweet balanced mix of toasted/roasted malts, hints of coffee and liquorice, caramel, brown sugars, toffee and hints of dark fruit and hops. Light grassy, full spiced dark fruity malt mix in the aftertaste.
Low carbo, full body and soft mouthfeel.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle.  Pours dark ruby with thin head.  Aroma of berries.  Strong alcohol sweeps into the nostrils upon first sip.  Taste of malt and some licorice.  Smoke evident.   Delicious offering and another winner from Founders.
Aroma is a rich sweetness with a hop presence. Pours a deep, rich dark red. Taste is sweet at first but finishes up with a cloying bitterness. Very chewy body. Pretty tasty/

(12oz bottle courtesy of guyinchicago.  Thanks Chuck!).  Pours cloudy mahogany with huge tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of marachino cherry (?), some smoke and caramel. Taste is sweet with noticeable alcohol.  Full bodied with slick texture.  Very nice beer.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark ruby-brown color with a medium off-white head. Good lacing and mostly lasting foam. Aroma is intense coffee and chocolate, with lots of roasted notes. A decise hops presence is there too. Hints of alcohol, vanilla and wood too. Taste is similar but more inclined towards the roasted-woody side. Finish is hoppy, dry and smokey. Palate is medium/full with a good amount of carbonation.

Bottle at home. Dark brown clear pour, thin creamy off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, candi sugar and some spicy hops. Flavor is somewhat bitter, mostly sweet and quite spicy with some fresh bread, a hint of peat and decent roasty malts. Very nice balance and thick body. Nice brew.

Extremely dark brown pour with a half finger beige head. The aroma holds nutty roasted malts, caramel, raisin, fig, date, plum, caramelized brown sugar, chocolate, and a slight hint of grapefruit hops. The flavor is peaty caramel and cocoa nib with a powerful dark fruit back drop that leaves the slightest roast on the tongue. The palate is rich and full with a silky body, low carbonation, and a dry finish.

pours a deep red with a foamy tan head.  Aroma chocolate licorice.  Amazing.  I could smell this for hours.  flavor is amazingly malty.  the licorice comes through in the flavor amazingly well.  The sweetness is slightly counterbalanced by a smoky alcohol flavor at the finish.  I love scotch ales and this is now my favorite.  Salud.

Hazy amber with burnt orange/yellow highlights around the bottom.  Moderate tan head with modest retention and nice lacing.  Looks pretty good in the glass.  Very delightful malty aroma of bread and caramel.  Very, very well balanced.  Both really stand out and are very alluring.  Lightly roasted and somewhat fruity.  Peachy smelling.  Rich malt in the taste with some light caramel.  Actually has a walnut dryness in the taste.  Very nice.  Some alcohol warmth invades the flavor in a very welcoming way.  Full bodied mouthfeel that is extremely dry and leaves a wealth on the palate.  Some alcohol is left on the tongue and the roof of the mouth.  Feels wonderful.  Chewy even.  This is a great brew, however I probably wouldnt be able to have more than 2 at a time due to the high ABV.  It was very nice on this cold December night.  This is also a nice after dinner brew in my opinion.  The alcohol comes in nicely and exits easily.

Thin beige head. Hazy deep red body is just barely translucent because of all the small particles. Fruity dusty caramelly aroma with earthy licorice and toffee notes. Dry-sweet delicate roasty earthy chocolate taste with caramelly toffee and dust notes. Fullish body. Mild mouthfeel. Dry roasty resiny caramel aftertaste with chocolatey coffee, raisins, and creme brulee notes. Absolutely outstanding. Lovely malt character. (0.355l bottle, Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)
I dont really love scotch ales, but this was from Founders so I gave it a shot. Not bad. From bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at Rustico in September 2009.

Pours a dark chestnut brown with a nice beige head and plenty of lacing as it goes down. The smell is quite enticing with overpowering roasted malts, toffee, caramel, a little bit of wood and vanilla, and a bit of brown sugar sweetness. The taste is all the same with the malts dominating. Medium-bodied and smooth, this one was very, very drinkable.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-05-2009

Bottle: Pour is dark brown with amber highlights - very modest off white head that retains fairly poorly, really.  Nice sweet toffee, peat aroma on the nose. Unfortunately I keep thinking to myself ; why cant this be backwoods bastard. (long gone from the shelves) - But let me continue; Medium bodied, fairly sweet - flavors are toffee and caramel malts, a hint of peat, a touch roastiness, finishing with a creamy feel in spite of the hop bitterness. Its really an excellent beer. Unfortunately - its second tier.

12oz bottle. This is a nice style. Pours a deep copper color with a thin light tan head. Has a sweet malt aroma. Flavor is malty sweet with the bitterness to back it. A liitle dry but smooth. A medium to full body beer. A good beer.
Pours a dark cloudy amber. Aroma of thick molasses and malt. Taste is medium bodied with complex malt and molasses.

Its dark, red amber with a creamy, golden head and the aroma has loads of malt, caramel, light candy-sugar, licorice and fruits. The flavour is sweet with heavily malted notes of caramel, candy-sugar, licorice, alcohol and fruit, and the finish is dry with a light bitterness.

Dark, viscous looking reddish brown pour with a thin cappuccino head. Loads of sweet malt aroma. Chocolate, caramel. Its faint, but I think Im getting just a trace of hops. Hits your mouth almost like an imperial stout. Full body coats your mouth with roasted malt flavor. The vague smoky profile becomes a little more evident after a few sips. Nice bitter finish that stays for about 10 seconds.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. Pours a hazy, deep mahogany brown body with a creamy, medium off-white head. Aroma is smooth, deep toffee and caramel, with some vanilla and hints of chocolate and berries in the back. Taste is as smooth as the mouthfeel; a pure toffee pleasure trip gently streaming down my throat. This is good. A regular malt-fest going on here; some toffee, some sweet caramel appearing mid-palate and some roastiness towards the end. Very pleasant drinking, and though the alcohol is warming it is still very well integrated. A pleasure to drink, and the excellently crafted, creamy mouthfeel makes for EITHER a sipper or a faster-drinking beer. This is one dirty bastard ye jees gottu luv! :-D

Notes from Wednesday, September 15 2010

Ar: Caramel, dried fruit, malt.
Ap: Pours a deep brown-red with a 1/2" light cinnamon head that fades quickly and leaves little lace.
F: Very complex up front - dried figs, smoke, and a bit of chocolate.  It finishes with a bourbon-like bite.  However, I find the sweetness to be a bit cloying, even with the hop bitterness on the finish.
P: Thick, chewy body with semi-high carbonation.
O: Not a style I have that often, but this is quite good.

Bottle. Golden brown with white head. Aromas of peat, toffee, leather, tobacco. Flavors of toffee, toast, tobacco, roasted nuts, butterscotch. Malty but slightly bitter and attenuated finish. Medium body with creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation.

Bottle Pours a dark auburn with a medium light tan head that fades. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, alcohol, Great soft, frothy mouthfeel. Taste is buttery, malty, and sweet. Finish becomes bitter,Has almost a butter toffee lingering taste. Very nice example of the style.

Thanks to Tony from OTH for the share.  Pours deep amber-brown with a white head.  Nose is malt, maple, sweetness, slight raisin, and brown sugar.  Flavor is similar with maple, dark malt, and a clean finish.  Very enjoyable scotch ale.

Bottle. Pours a nice deep dark amber color with a frothy tan head. Aroma is like a malt bomb filled with sweet, bready and caramelly malts, i also get some dark fruit and a slight hint of wood. Flavor is of the sweet, bready and caramelly malts along with alot of dark fruit and wood. I also get some alcohol and a slight amount of roast. The body is medium to full with a sliky smooth mouthfeel. Overall a really nice beer from Founders, its a real Autumn beer!
Reddish brown in color with a malty aroma. Sweet, malty, but with a pine and earthy flavor. Full bodied and balanced.
Very sweet, has a slightly sickly sweet aroma. Good auburn color. Strong and big and malty.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Chestnut pour with a light tan head which soon goes. Very enticing nose. Plenty of caramel, raisins and toffee. Has a sweet and fruity feel too. Flavours of toffee, licorice, some coffee, dark fruits and a little sweet spice. Dry, bitter-sweet finish. Nice.
Bottle. Pours ruby-brown with thin camel head; decent lace. Nose of malt, smoke, and plum.  Hot taste of burnt caramel, maple and booze. Metallic finish. Alcohol is very prevelant.

Bottled. A reddish brown beer with a creamy but small beige head. Aroma is malty and fruity, notes of dried fruits, caramel and burnt sugar. Taste is also malty and bittersweet, strong caramel notes, raisins and plums. Sweet after taste. Nice texture. Very good beer

12 oz. bottle.  Pours deep brown with tan head.  Initial taste was bearable but the after taste was to smokey.  Not to knowledgeable about beers but i dont think scotch ales are for me.  Pricey to boot, so this one gets the boot!

Rich malty flavors are nice: slight figs, caramel, with a finishing bit of citrusy hop bitterness.  The thing that takes this one a bit off the rails is the alcohol, which is omnipresent.  In the nose, I get a slight quiver of the nostrils from the overwhelming alcohol.  The palate notices it too and even burns a bit for it.  A good option if you like boozier, sweeter beers.  In spite of my review for BT, I will claim neutrality.

Poured a dark amber ruby color and cloudy.  Minimal head.  Malty aroma (nuts caramel).  Aroma has a strong presence.   Light to med sweetness.  Starts off sweet and malty on the tongue.  Finished smokey alchohol taste with nice blend of hop.  Complex.  Light bitterness at end.  Medium body, soft carbonation.  Long finish.  Good sipping style beer.  Would get again.

Dark red ale with just a litte of head. Aroma of dark berries, caramel and sweet malts.Some smoke there too.Just a little bitter but sweet taste. Soft carbonation. Flows smoothly through your mouth without leaving you cold.

Pours very dark red with a minimal head that tends to disappear. Amazing extra sweet aroma with hints of dry fruits like raisins or plums, some smokiness also but soft. Round malty and sweet taste with a smokey note, dark honey. Full body, creamy feeling, soft carbonation and medium after taste with dry finish.
Bottle, beermerchants.com. Sweet and malty, with tobacco and rum flavours. A beer that is thick and chewy, rich and definitely best drunk in small doses. Did become a little bit cloying.

Bottle. Beautiful deep red-orange, thick golden head. Sponge-toffee, breadcrusts, and light smoke aroma. Barley candy sweetness, chewy dark toffee, toast, light smoke, light spice in the finish. No hint of the ABV. Fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Bottle from beermerchants.
Very dark ruby, fluffy head.
Fruit, smoke and soot in the nose.
Compact mal which is supplemented by smoke and hops to make a lovely beer for sipping rather than gulping. Bacon, spearmint, campfires. 
Very well crafted, well balanced.

From a bottle thanks to Jay (fear025). Pours a dark redish brown with medium head and a good amount of lacing. Aroma is malty, caramel and brown sugar. Flavor is sweet and malty. Medium bodied with a smooth finish.

On tap at Sugar Maple.  Deep red, amber, brown mix.  Malt, smoke, and roasted aroma.  Flavor is brief sweet malt then roasted malt, peet, wood, earthy.  Finishes with mild hopping.  Good medium body with light carbonation.

Bottle, tasted alongside a Saint Arnold DR#8 and an Old Chub. Ive kept this one for over a year. Its the middle range of color for the three, a fairly clear amber-orange with some small yeast floaties and a small head with good retention. Nose is packed with caramel/syrupy malt, along with a little woody smoke and grapes. The flavor is predominantly sweet and rich, tasting a bit like grape juice at times, interestingly. Some light grassy/peaty tones, particularly in the finish, and no hops to speak of. Carbonation is average, making the palate a little heavy and sticky - definitely some presence to this one. I havent had it fresh, but its very nice after some age.

Dark brown, and Ruby highlights with a medium, light-tan head. Aroma very malty, a touch of caramel, dark fruits. Flavor also very malty; brown sugar, fruits, Caramel and lightly sour.Nice smooth velvety texture. Almost too sweet, but I keep buying it.
The taste is that good.

I first had this beer at dinner for my sisters college graduation from Michigan State. It being her graduation dinner, I had a few. However, being that it has an 8.5% ABV, my actual acknowledgement of what I was tasting diminished about midway through my second beer. This is a very good, full bodied Scotch Ale with a strong malty finish. It is a little thick to drink more than one or two and is very filling. It can probably replace a meal if you have more than one. The beer has a very malty aroma and somewhat of a black licorice aftertaste. Overall very excellent, but a little too thick to drink often.

poured from 12oz bottle - Not usually a fan of anything "Scottish," but this little Dirty Bastard won me over.  Nice malty profile with plenty of great-tasting hops.  Giving props to a Scotch Ale that I would normally not buy.
Deep brown with a light tan head. Banana, caramel aroma. After taste strongly of alcohol that sticks with you. Burps smell strongly fused with alcohol even after only one.
Had on draft at founders brewpub.  Ive had this numerous times, but first time rating.  Im not generally into scottish ales, but this is very enjoyable.

355 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone.
Pours a dark reddish brown colour with a minimal white head. Aroma of caramel malts, oak and fruits. Flavour of dark fruits, syrup, caramel malts and oak. Medium bodied, oily mouthfeel. Tasty.
caramel, bread, nuts, toast, dark amber, light brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish. nice beer.
Dark brown, and clear. Has a light yellow head, fully lasting. Faint hoppy aroma, notes of malty chocolate, faint citrus too. Heavy sweet flavor, finish moderate bitter. Dry, creamy texture.

Bottle.Pours dark amber with ruby notes and an off-white head.Big malt aroma with caramel ,grains hops,,a little smoke/peat and berries.Flavor is warming alcohol,berries ,sweet malt, grains and caramel.Nice firm bitterness, long lasting sweet finish, average carbonation.Nice malty brew.

Bottle. Its an unclear, copper-colored beer topped by a small, beige head. Malty, peated nose with caramel and dried fruits, a touch of alcohol blends in, and theres also some chocolate and dms. The flavor is sweet, with a good bitterness, as well as chocolate, peat, alcohol and some dried fruits. Peppery notes too. Full-bodied and warming. Hop-bitter finish with dried fruits, caramel, some dried fruits, peaty notes and sugary sweetness. The first sips of this beer was a bit disappointing, but then it turned out to be a beer thats really tasteful, pleasant and good for an hour of joy. 101006

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter.

Appearance: Pours a dark cola brown with a 1/2 finger white head which dissipates quickly.

Smell: Caramel malt with chocolate, dried fruit and a hint of alcohol.

Taste: Caramel and chocolate malt up front followed by a faint hoppy bitterness in the middle then a complex array of malt flavors that I cant quite describe at the finish. Alcohol flavor comes through at the end. Aftertaste is somewhat bitter but not overly so.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. This isnt a beer thats meant to be sessioned. Drink a couple slowly throughout the evening.

Overall: Very solid Wee Heavy. Founders puts out a good product and this is another fine example.

Bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 8.5%, 50 IBUs. Dark reddish brown colour, big to moderate beige head.  Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, peat smoke and over-ripe red berries, also vinous notes with hints of oak. The flavour has loads of malty sweetness and caramel, peat and oak, with a distinct hoppy bitterness in the finish and aftertaste.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a snifter and the small head dissipated almost immediately. As it vanished, it left behind a thick yeasty aroma with hints of prune. This evoked a Belgian-style quadrupel ale, as did the beers ruby-russet color. Despite these hints of the abbey, the beer drank fairly American, especially in its dry finish that transformed the stone fruit to black grapes. Overall, I think its safe to conclude that they know what theyre doing up in Grand Rapids.

12 fl oz [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */&Cigar, Oslo. A low beige head upon a slighly unclear, deep mahogny colored body. Strong malt aroma. Sweet, rich and grainy, almost like an American style BW. Notes of ripe fruits and caramel, and a vague smell of wood and peat. Strong malt body. Medium sweet and grainy with faint pepper and ash, and a note of rum&raisin. Fruit notes too. Distinct bitternes, earth and spice. Well-bodied and quite thick in the mouth. A complex and tasty beer, very likeable.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 190910.
Amber with white head. Aroma of malt with alcohol note. Flavor with fruit and some caramel
Very solid offering from Founders. Definitely has a raisin-like undertone. Didnt get any skunk in the flavor, but wonderfully complex. Makes me happy.

Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival on September 16, 2010.  Glowing, translucent brown body with a fine light-brown head.  Aroma is... at first hard to describe, but very good - great, even.  Malty, but lightly and sweet.  It has a really wet mouth feel.  Flavor isnt all that - its actually very, very light and smooth and very punchy on the palate.  There is some aluminum-like bitterness in the back.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2010 Aromas of alcohol, toffee, and bread.  Color is a cloudy dark red with a nice tan head.  A really nice looking beer.  Taste is very malty...complex with alcohol noted up front, and cocoa and toffee coming in later on.  A dense palate with a heavy body.  Very nice long finish that keeps changing.  This is a very nice, complex brew.  Love it.

Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark red-amber colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Prune and plumb notes. Heavy bitter very nice flavor. Long spicey great finish. Creamy palate. Really nice beer.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown color with a tan head that quickly disappears.  Aroma is caramel, sweet, and a little bit of a roasty character.  Taste follows the aroma with a little bit of a bready aspect that doesnt come through on the nose.
Deep, dark red pour with a medium foamy brown head. Aroma is caramel, sugars, bread, very sticky. Flavor is brown sugar, bread, sugar, caramel. Nice thick mouthfeel.
Brown pour, thin white head.  Remarkable aroma of scotch which is also mildly present in the flavor.  Also present was a combo of hops, spices, and caramel.  Mild carbonation, medium body.
Dark red brown pour. Brown head. Sweet aroma of caramel and spice. Flavor is complex. Starts bitter and alcoholic and finishes sweet with a hint of chocolate.
Poured into a snifter from a bottle.  Aroma is malty with some dark fruits.  Taste is fairly bready with some nice fruits and sweetness.  Full-bodies, goes down really smooth.  A very good brew!

Mmmm.  Pours red with a tan head, aroma of cookie dough,, vanilla, distant scotch or bourbon, and a twinge of alcohol.  Flavor is inially very warm, toast, molasses, wood esters, black pepper, and tobacco, followed by a bit of earthiness.  Very good.
Had tried all Lunar beers on tap at Lunar Brewing Company that day so on to the guest taps. Strong, rich, bold. Smoky, peaty, and malty.  Tasty. Serving: Tap
355 ml bottle from Voldby. Dark brown/ruby with tiny off-white head. Flavour is caramel, fruit, alcohol, sweet and nuts.

This is quite a heavy bodied deep reddish brown brew. On the sweet side in aroma and flavor with all of those malts. However, the alcohol is certainly held in check by the sweetness. I would have liked a bit more smoke on the back side. I wish I had some smoky cheese or oysters to go with this.

On tap at the University Roadhouse. Deep dark brew, sweet aroma with dark fruit and malty overtones. Taste is sweet, dominated iby malt, molassas and dark figgy fruit overtones, more than a little bitter and  sour hoppiness in the finish, but the overall impression remains that of sweetness. An ethanol whooze in the after taste and ethanolic sweetness ala malt liquor permeate the flavor. Very satisfying palate and mouthfeel. very nice brew on the first cool day of late summer, would be great to warm up with after a long winters day outdoors.

A: snifter. opaque mahogany color. light tan head. good retention rate with a very nice amount of lacing.

S: rich malts, with some huge peat aromas. some hops in the back of the aroma.

T: some caramel and toffee, with a big peat flavor. some nutty tones. very nice scotch ale flavors.

M: big bold body, perfect mild carbonation. very small and has a great palate.

D: very nice scotch ale. perfect flavors for my palate. really enjoyable.
ambrata nocciola buona schiuma media persistenza naso maltato con tostaure e caramello in bocca buon amaltatura caramello e decise note amare

Draught @ Churchkey - Pours dark, dark, dark, with a thick and creamy head that persists and laces the glass.  Fantastic aroma of breadk, chocollate, coffee.Sweet and malty with a hint of bitterness. classic Scotch Ale.  Founders is fantastic.

Bottle from VBS.  Deep brown ruby color with a pale foamy white head.  Aroma has some hints of scotch with a little chocolate and some hops.  Some interesting funk mellows out into a sweet roastiness that lingers.  A little rough on the palate.  Im a big fan of this beer.  Everything I want out of a scotch ale.
bottle.  A classic scotch ale with sweet malt, carmel, and cola flavors.  The nose is basically the same as the taste.  Maybe my second favorite scotch ale.
Draught at Churchkey.  Toward the end of the night, after my tastebuds were in shock and very sleepy.  I remember this one being on the sweet side, lots of malt, and a decent butterscotch tome.

Bottle.  Pours a nice brownish ruby with average head.  Weak aroma of roasted malts and piney hops.  Tastes like peat with a boozy, bitter finish.  Definitely not founders best, but still pretty nice.

from Erzbierschof - cloudy ruby-brown colour with no head left; solid aroma of prune and caramel, a fair piney hop presence; full-bodied and gently sticky, a sweet and solid malt backbone, a respectable bitterness before a long aftertaste of dark fruits, piney hops and licorice
Poured from bottle, pours very dark ruby/red color, has aroma of malt and booze to it, a little alcohol to the finish of it but this is one fine brew from Founders.
Bottle - from sampler pack. Dark copper color - barely translucent. Very little aroma. Taste is really good - very malty with some roastiness and a bit of peat smoke.
Can smell the high alcohol - nice ruby read appearance.  Very smooth tasting for an 8.3 beer, but a metallic finish.  Very good, but not Founders best (Porter and Red Rye).
Draft at Founders during RBSG. Pours ruby red, thin white head, poor lacing. Nose is caramel, brandy beans, fruit. Flavours are chocolate, brandy, spice, toffee. Solid.

Bottle pours dark brown color with brief tan head.  Malty aroma with a little alcohol.  Taste molasses, caramel, malts.  Palate medium and smooth.  Long mildly hoppy finish, A little too bitter to be pleasant.

Not bad, was hoping for a little better from Founders.
A good beer, nothing outstandingly special about it, but it does the trick (at 8.3& alc. it should).

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Cloudy dark reddish-brown. Aroma was semi-sweet, caramel malts and fruit. Flavor is malty, sweet and smoky with a touch of hops tang for balance. Hides the alcohol very well. Full and round with a clean and smooth finish.

Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours ruby brown with a tan head.  Aroma mainly of malts, but some hints of hops and coffee as well.  A nice coffee finish on this beer.  Thick texture, very good. Definitely worth trying.

Sweet caramel and malt aroma, with a bit of pine and smoke.  Pour is dark brown with a bit of red.  Small tan head that didnt stick around.   Taste of sweet molasses with maybe a bit of vanilla and a bit of smoke.  Earthy and grassy malts finish.   Love the finish on this one.  Love me some Scottish Ale, and this is a nice example.
Lovely, rich and smooth. Smells like a strong brown ale, with a flirty burnt malt addition. It goes smooth and clean with a harsh aftertaste that gives the dirty bastard its name.

Had this on draft at a local Unos.  It was Founders night there so was able to have KBS as well as Centennial IPA and their Pale Ale.  I liked this one the best although KBS and Centennial were both incredible as well and Pale Ale was a nice session beer.
Enjoyed from bottle at Fountainhead in Chicago.  Aroma is lightly boozy.  Appearance is very dark brown not much head.  Taste is malty and strong, can taste the alcohol.  Good stuff.
Bottle. Sweet caramel aroma. Deep copper with a small off white head. Sweet caramel, hops, and a light roasted malt finish. I really like this one, it was very easy to drink.
Poured from a 12 oz. bottle. Pours a beautiful brown color. Light white head. Smells of malt and some hints of hops. Taste is slightly bitter. Good beer.

Bottle 355 ml from www.erzbierschof.ch. Smell malted, smoked, undergrowth and a pinch of hops. The malt flavor is full, sustained a shade of hoppy bitterness. Earthy flavor, moshrooms, touch of wood and peaty, nuances of scotch, buttertoffee, toast. The texture is a little oily. Final drier, sappy, sweetened, smoked, heating.

Brown-red pour with a thick and lasting tan head.  Sweet malty aroma with some chocolate and caramel.  Flavor hits you fast with a lot of malty sweetness.  This one is clearly high gravity as its pretty hot on the palette.  Chocolate, raisin, plum, molasses maybe even some oakey flavors.  Lingering bitterness. Strong, sweet aftertaste, lingering booziness.  As advertised, its really malty and the hops were not anywhere on stage other than to provide bittering and perhaps a slight bit of citrus in the aftertaste.  Overall, a pretty good scotch ale and pretty true to the style.

Served at 45 degrees, poured into a pint glass.Deep copper in color with slight head after aggressive pour. Darker than I anticipated.  Smells sweet and carmel like. Sweet taste moving to bitter on the tongue. Lingers on the bitter side. Rich and smooth mouthfeel. 
Overall, I really liked this beer.
Tap @ Blind Tiger - Love me some scotch ale. Dark pour, white foamy head. Toffee, piney, smooth and creamy. Roasted malts. finishes dry with a touch of astringency.
Good Scotch Ale. Brings everything to the table that it should. I prefer backwoods bastard though for its added complexities.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany with ruby tints when held up to the light. Small, light tan head, minimal lacing. Nose is nearly all malts, with smoke and peat hitting the sinuses. Taste is heavily smoked, with some burnt caramel and peat moss cutting through. Finish is lingering; dense, black wheat bread. Very subtle, very complex brew, and immensely drinkable for the ABV.
Bottle.  Pours dark red amber with minimal head.  Aroma is sweet, lots of malt, caramel.  Tastes sweet, malty, some alcohol, caramel, toffee.  The alcohol is apparent in the finish but not too much.

Deep mahogany complexion with ruby highlights and a creamy head. Smells primarily malty with traces of maple sugar and caramel. Expected a bit stronger aroma. Well deserving of the wee-heavy label as it is bursting with layers of robust malt characteristics. Behind the roasted malt flavors are earthy hops creating a long lingering finish. Wait for it to warm a bit and it suggests raisons and caramel. Full bodied mouth feel, a tad chewy. High carbonation hides its strength as it does not come close to feeling 8.5%. Ill crank out a few of these and get smacked in the face before I realize it. For a style I am not usually impressed by this is a really good representation of a Scottish Strong Ale. Founders never seems to disappoint!
Bottle. Sweet caramel aroma. Deep copper with a small off white head. Sweet caramel, hops, and a light roasted malt finish. I really like this one, it was very easy to drink.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 Draft. Pours a dark syrupy brown. White jead.  Some malts and such. Not too much alco to taste.

Draught at Blind Tiger. Clear dark brown to black with nice off white head. Aroma of dried fruit (raisins, etc), sweet fruit (melon), molasses syrup malts. Taste is sweet molasses syrupy at start and goes big bitter fig/dried fruit in finish. Really tasty! Booze is hidden well, finish is short and abrupt.

He poured murky browns and faded mahogany into my glass where he settled under a small layer of khaki foam. Lace sticks to the sides of my glass like nobodys business, and a thin ringlet is his only decoration. But then, anything more would get in the way of his massive nose which just hit mine. Caramel and red apples galore followed by sprinklings of cinnamon and nutmeg, finishing with a flourish of toffee and a whiff of chocolate. Hm... Im having candy bar flashbacks, and I dont know why Alcohol nips at the back of my nose, tingling and teasing with spice, warmth, and dry wood read for the fire pit. Despite a straightforward nose, his palate is surprisingly more subtle and subdued, choosing the slow and supple path versus the in-your-face path. Slick, smooth, and mouthcoating, I am left once more smacking my lips in thirsty satisfaction, each lick a candied apple delight. A generous helping of dry brown spices permeates each quaff, enhancing and accentuating the immediate glow of warmth in the back of my throat creeping its way into my chest. Sweet, crunchy, woody, and spiced, cinnamon mingles with crisp fall red apples while esters of caramel and toffee crunchies waft on by. Closing my eyes, I am transported to a small cabin amidst the rolling hills of Scotland. A chill permeates the air, matched only by the crackling fire before me as I settle deep into a cushy chair, glass of Founders Dirty Bastard Scotch-style Ale in hand, and absolutely no where else I want to be.

<rb>
Romantic? A bit maybe, but like most things, romanticism got its start in reality. I prefer a mingling mix of the two, and Founders heartily delivered. I wasnt always fond of scotch ales, but the more I open my palate and mind to all beery possibilities, the more I appreciate their malty gifts. If you are ever somewhere where Founders beers can be found, grab a cart and have at it.
courtesy of badnewsberrs, thanks! pours a nice orange amber, really smooth, a nice brew for sure. lots of bready, caramel and buttery notes throughout, easy drinker, wouldnt mind trying it on tap.
Big time malty beer with some hop taste coming through in the finish. Somewhat of a dry finish as well. It hides the 8.3% very well.
Drank from a pint class from the tap at Rattle N Hum.  Sweet, carmely, just a bit of roasted flavor and a nice lasting finish.  Just a great beer all around.
Cola colored pour in the glass. Very sweet resin and spruce nose and taste. Rated 8/27/08
this stuff is pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty, pretty, goood

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 On tap at the 2010 Microfest in St. Louis.  Pours a ruby red color with a substantial off white head that diminishes but remains.  Taste is sweet roasted malt, and an earthy smokiness.
Bottled 355ml. Ordered from bierkompass.de. Malt accented, fruity with a strong alcohol presence. Not the best example of the style.

Very malty scotch-style ale with a medium brown to amber hue.  I love the body on this beer, it has a bit of thickness to it.  Very smooth on the palate with a nice aroma.  If you do not like malty, thicker brews, you probably would not like this.  Found all over, if a pub has this beer available, I will default to it if there are no other beers of interest available (malty, darks, stouts, porters, or browns).  This could be an everyday beer for me (if I drank everyday).

Bottle. Dark ruby with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel and roasted malt, alcohol and hint of hops. The flavour is very malty with sweet caramel, smoke, notes of liquorice and bitterness. Smooth and medium-bodied.

Pours a deep ruby red color with a thin head that gathers on the edges. In the nose there is caramel, bread, smoke, pine and light alcohol. The palate is medium in body, softly carbonated with a long finish. The taste is lightly sweet with malt and finishes dry and leafy with a touch of alcohol. This beer is nicely balanced, not overly sweet, complex and rewarding sip after sip.

thanks to thenewguy for sharing!  Hints of smoke and molasses with vanilla and hints of roasted malts.  Pours a dark reddish amber with a thin white head that dissipates.  Tobacco with molasses and caramel with an earthy bitterness, very malty with earthy grassy hop notes.  Very nice Scotch Ale.

A- Body is a rich dark mahogany hue. Pours with a 2 finger creamy tan head that eventually tapers off into a thick collar and plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass. Body is translucent and lots of particles can be seen floating throughout.

S-Deep, rich, and syrupy with chocolate malt dominating. Caramel malt and alcohol also make a strong presence.

T- Flavor pretty consistent throughout. Roasted chocolate and caramel malts are the main characters here and they make a strong presence throughout. The taste sweetens for the finish but a big roasted bitterness lingers along with a medium alcohol burn.

P- Big, thick, syrupy mouthfeel characteristic for the style. Carbonation is medium and does not get in the way of the smoothness of the mouthfeel.

O- Ive only sampled a few from this style and this seems to be a solid example. ABV is normal for the style and alcohol presence plays a big role in this brew. Sweet caramel and roasted bitter chocolate mix well and leave behind a nice warmth. Decent overall-but I am confident I can find other examples of this style I enjoy more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2007 20:05:45

Red-amber color with off-white head. Complex malt profile - caramel, bread, biscuits -  fruity hops, hints of vanilla and peat. Flavor malt dominated with a nip of fruity-op bitterness. Body is creamy with a smooth sweet finish.

First of all, this is not my favorite style of beer; I am an IPA drinker. That being said, I really enjoyed this. Pours a dark ruby brown with a tan head. Aromas of caramel, bread, and a little alcohol. Flavor is rich, sweet, smokey, and a nice bit of hops. Alcohol is evident. Very nice for a Scotch ale; really like the hops in this. Excellent.

Pours ruby-tinged brown, moderate tan head that fades to thin and sparse lacing.  Aroma of smoke, peat, and very malty. Thinner mouthfeel, kind of slick, moderate carbonation. Slightly sweet, a bit bitter, with some saltiness.  Very complex and rewarding beer to drink.

Pours a mahogany with standard white head. Aroma is of honey complemented by notes of pine and yeast. The honey/caramel sweetness takes a backseat to the pine hops (but only by a bit) in the flavor department. Slightly thin body with more a more hoppy finish than I expected or wanted. I expected more considering how much I love Backwoods Bastard.

Tap sample at New Beer Dist. Pours a dark ruby with moderate, off-white head. Nose of sweet malt, caramel, some heavy booze. Flavor is rich, plenty of sweetness, more caramel and some toffee, warm notes of scotch. Tail holds has some dark chocolate, coffee and some smoke. Sticky finish. Pretty nice.
Breadish aroma, like new baked bread and with a taste of strong alcohol and good hop, nice red colour but cloudy, I am going to drink this beer again.

Dark ruby/brown pour with nice tan head light lacing ..... aroma of caramel and bready malts tastes just the same with some thickness, light smokiness and hop bitterness in the finish ..... smooth and mellow a tasty brew with a nice bitter bite at the end
12 ounce bottled sample.  Founders could be my new favorite brewery.  Liked the boldness of this beer.  Nice combination of malt and hops.

Burgundy / ruby, clear w/ off-white head.  Subdued aroma.  Very malty / sweet at first, finishes with quite a bit of hops bitterness.  Medium-bodied w/ velvety mouthfeel.  High alcohol content is masked well by generous malt and hops additions.  Pretty good.

Pint at Rattle n Hum.  Directly after pints of Founders Porter & Double Trouble.  I have to say, this doesnt really compete with those hard hitters.
