Pour is a brown with a red/maroon hint... no head is retained.  Lots of sweet malts, rich and supple.  Body is medium and a bit slick.  Does hide the alc well.
Draft.  Clear, dark amber, small off-white head, minimal lacing.  Almost no aroma.  Sweet and malty up front, earthy hops on finish.  Well balanced.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2010 Aroma is caramel, earthy, light smoke. The appearance is an amber color, white head.  The flavor is malt forward, caramel, expected for the style and notes of earth, smoke.  The finish is piney hops.  Medium body.  Nothing out of the ordinary, just a good representation of the style.
Bottle. Poured a darker amber color with a light white head. Aroma was malts, caramel, and other fruits. I am not a huge fan of this style but this was was very good. Love this beer, and Founders.

Pours a ruby red color with tiny head.  Aroma is of crystal malts which impart some sweetness.  Taste is somewhat of a malty sweetness with little to no hop bitterness.  Alcohol is hidden well making it very drinkable.  Not too shabby.
Pours a medium brown color with a minimal tan head. Aroma of dark fruits with some underlying sweetness.  Flavor of toffee, caramel and dark fruits with a bitter finish.
Thanks to MOTORTODDHEAD.  Beautiful mahagany color with a creamy tan head.  Nice malt and caramel with smoke.  Kinda dry and bitter aftertaste.  Nice beer.  Thanks Todd.

Bottle: A dark reddish brown beer with a fairly large dense tan head with lacing. Rich aroma of toffee, dark ripe fruits, brown sugar, and caramel. Flavor is of dark fruits and toffee with a moderately bitter finish. Very well done.
12 ounce bottle reddish prown pour . taste of caramel, smoke, fruit .great beer nicley balanced good hop finish

A:  Pours a nice shade of amber with red highlights showing through.  No real head but it does have some legs.

S:  Nice sweet aromas.  Caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, and light dark fruits.

T:  Raisin and caramel lead the way.  Light chocolate, hints of earthy hops in the finish with a bit of boozy burn.

M:  On the ligher side of full in body, bold, smooth, with a perfect level of boozy burn in the finish.
A lot of complex flavors.  Rich and full of body, this beer makes me want to break into a scottish brogue.  Beg bdrew weth ah gdrate mault bach bohne!
12oz - Chocolate nose, bitter finish, some malt without being sweet.  Hides the 8.3% well.  Nice Scotch, not great.

This Dirty Bastard is in my opinion more similar to a Stout than Scotch Ales that Im used to.  It lends a caramel and toffee like taste along with a lingering mouthfeel.  Very drinkable and a personal favorite both by name and taste.
Bottle, small. light brown and almost clear with small head. Aroma was malty and choco Flavours malty, smoke, chocolate, sweetness, caramel. Aftertaste was chocolate too sweet.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are rich caramel, chocolate, malt and notes of fruits.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured reddish brown and almost clear with small and white head. Aroma was malty and smoky. Flavours were malts, smoke, chocolate, sweetness, hops, grass and bittereness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter.

355 ml bottle. Brown tanned head, dark body. Very sweet caramel aroma, lots of dark fruits, plum and date. Some aroma goes towards belgian ale. Sweet and burned candy flavour with high bitterness. Although flavour is less overwhelming than aroma.
Tap.  Pours brown with a tanish head.  Smell of malt.  No description of the type of beer this was on the list so I thought it was a weak brown.  Pretty nice tame flavor in my opionion.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 Pours a medium dark brown with hues of red.  Aroma of molasses and roasted malt.  Taste is sweet.  Flavors of molasses, peat, and grass.  An oily, creamy texture.  Nicely balanced with sweet malt coming through.

Pours a dark red almost brown color with a small bold white head.Nose is bready with a hint of toast.Taste is ALL MALT...maybe a little hops on the backend..The mouthfeel is smooth and luscious throughout.The alcohol is masked due to the heavy malts.Pretty good beer.Not my fave from Founders but a pretty good brew.I can see why many people would enjoy this beer.

Had from the bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a hint of red, also had off-white head, not alot though.  Aroma sweet, with hint of fruit and caramel.  Tasted malty, with hints of licorice and sweet fruit.  Finishes strong with a lingering sweetness.  This beer was a great experience.

355 ml bottle. From København, Denmark.
Dark reddish brown colour with tiny white head and some floaters.
Yeast, dried fruits and caramel in aroma.
Dark bitter hops and yeast in flavour.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours reddish brown color with light tan head. Aroma of toasted malts and peat with a hint of smokiness. Sweet malty flavor with some peat, earthiness and some mild smoke. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Thanks Peter.

Appearance is a dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is somewhat sweet, with some licorice. Flavor is malty with that same bittersweet flavor noticeable in the aroma. Finish is smooth with a slight sweetness that sticks to the tongue. Quite pleasant, would definitely recommend.

33cl Bottle at Beer Temple. Hazy reddish amber colour, off white head. Aroma of caramel, some yeast, lots of malts, dried fruits. Resembles Great Divide Hibernation Ale, but lacks some hops. Flavour is sweet, malty, dried fruits, light spicy, yeasty, light bitter hoppy finish, bitterness lingers a bit. Medium to fullbodied, soft carbonation.

Im surprised I have not rated this yet.  Pours a dark brown/red.  The aroma is woody and doughy.  The flavor has a lot going on.  Rich with chocolates, caramel, and some spiciness. Has a smokey finish with some bitterness.  A real tasteful beer that you can tell was crafted with great care.

Pours a deep opaque chocolate-coffee brown with a fine-bubbled beige head. Aroma is malty with a chocolaty undertone and a hint of caramel. Flavor is lively, malty and spicy with an undertone of cinnamon candy and just a whisper of sweetness. Texture is edgy, tingly and sassy - it seems to dance on your tongue.
Distinguished by a rich, full body with sufficient hops to balance its malty sweetness.  I like this beer ... alot.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Vinny. Pours deep amber ruby with a thin, silky off-white head. Aroma of chocolate, malt, scotch, roasted barley, rye, and hints of raisins. Body is mild, approachable and tasty; palate is warm and smooth. Finishes with a classic bit of scotch warming. Great scotch ale.

Nice scotch ale that isnt overly smokey, but will still remind you which style it belongs to.  I felt like the alcohol was presented a bit too strongly, but thats not too major a problem.  Overall, a good scotch ale, but there are others Id rather be drinking, most notably the Dark Horse Scotty Karate.

bottle, dark amber-brown with medium brownish head. aroma contains caramel sweet chocolate and coffee, also some alcohol. its a decent beer, although its not very complex and unfortunately doesnt have a long finish.

Pours ruby red with a tan head.  Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and hints of dark fruits.  Flavor is nice caramel, slightly nutty malty flavor, with a little bit of smoke, metal, and a slight bitterness that balances out the malty sweetness.  Good stuff.

(Bottled) Hazy dark ruby color with a small, but firm and reasonably lasting, creamy and lacy head. Very nice, grainy-malty, soft and sweetish aroma with lots of dried fruit and some strawberries. Flavor is berryish, sweet and dark-fruity with a tiniest ashy roastiness underneath. Quite full-bodied, very smooth and creamy palate. A beautifully balanced and enjoyable Scotch Ale.

On tap at the bierstube in Moline Iowa. Pours reddish light brown with a very thick off-white head. A butterscotch aroma. Great lacing. This beer is super thick, like drinking a glass of pancake syrup. At first I thought I could smell a bit of diacetyl, but I think its just an intense caramel aroma. Anything this big oughta have a stewardess on it serving drinks.

Founders proves that the West Coast doesnt have a lock on great beers.  On the pour, a hazy reddish amber hue glows from the pint when lit.  While a weak aroma is present, Im sure it will improve with some warmth.  Now down to business!  Sweet Jesus, theres a lot of malt in here.  Sweet and a little smokey up front followed by a great hop bite with hints of peat and booze.  A very nice thick  smooth palate akin to finer stouts.  To the Brewers at Founders, cheers and thank you!
Bottle, pours brown with nice head/lacing. Flavor is very malty with caramel, cocoa, and spice. Tastes like Christmas, very good.

Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a medium head.  Lots of sweet malt, floral hops in both the aroma and flavor.  Maybe some peat as well, but that might just be the influence of the alcohol and the "Scotch" in the name.  A tasty ale.

A tasty brew.  Pours a very thick head, with a light to medium brown haze.  Even with a delicate pour almost had an overflow.  A weak malty, caramel smell.  But this beer packs a punch in flavor.  You get hit with the sweet on the front of the tongue and then the bitters and creamy malt surround the mouth quickly.  Has a malty-smoky finish.  Really enjoying this beer.  The aroma and color knock it down on the score, but you will enjoy the complex taste.

340ml bottle (Utobeer, London)
Sweet cakey aroma - caramel, some cocoa and cakey spices. Similar taste, a bit dead. Covers the alcohol well, bit still a bit heady. finish pleasantly grainy and malty.

12oz bottle.  pours a clear, deep brownish ruby with a medium sized tan head.  malty and sweet aroma with notes of toffee, toast, and a bit of chocolate on a shortbread cookie.  the aromas carry into the flavor with the added hint of peat but its definitely not a focal point.  finishes dry  and a bit chalky with a wash of floral accents.  tasty little number.
Pours ruby red with white head, aroma is full of caramel malt.  Taste up front is really sweet with some caramel and toffee moving into an earthy spiciness and ends with bitterness and smoky flavor.
Pours amber red with a thin fully receding tan head. Notes of toffee, plum, peat, caramelized wort, pit fruits. Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown, no head. Pretty mild aroma that is mainly malts with a slightly hoppy twinge.  Flavor is big on malt sweetness, dark fruits that finishes with a bite of hops.  Also has a faint metallic flavor underneath everything.  Alcohol fairly well hidden.

( 12oz bottle) Pours red with nice oily bubbles, spare head and great lacing. Nose of bread, light cholorine hops, smoky malt. Taste of peat, toasted grains, smoke, caramel with a nicely carbonated finish and perfect body.

Tom Ace. Pleasure to meet you Mr. Camp, and congratulations on all your success. You smell terrific! I was just telling Melissa that one of the first things we learned back at... Stanford Law... was the modern proliferation of food poisoning claims against wealthy private homeowners. In fact, if one were so inclined, one could make quite a lucrative law practice with little else. How is everyone feeling tonight?

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a small creamy tan head. Malty aroma of caramel, brown sugar and some fruitness. Flavor was lightly sweet with burnt caramel, dark fruit, toffee, brown sugar and had a touch of chocolate with a sticky oily texture and a dry finish

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2010 12oz bottled in Dec 2009.  Pours brown/copper, with strong red highlights, nice fluffy tan head, sheets of lacing to start.  Aroma is pretty quiet on this one, some caramel malts, which is then immediately contrasted with the huge flavor, immensly malty to start, lots of caramel, brown sugar, molasses, toffee with a nice grassy bitter hop finish.  Overall very malty impression, but a noticeable hop presence, more than other Scotch Ales Ive tried.  Mouthfeel is quite rich and creamy, medium carbonation.  My first night ever with Founders, Breakfast Stout equaled expectations, Dirty Bastard exceeded expectations.

Dark brown with a good amount of sediment at the bottom of the glass and no head at all. The smell is quite nice and consists of caramel malts, molasses, hops, and a bready note that I cant quite figure out. The taste is initial alcohol with a strong earthly and molasses finish. It tastes a little like scotch but not as strong as I would have thought, overall it is very good an interesting.
Bottle.  Pours a good shade of garnet.  Smells of malt and smoke.  Bold with hints of whiskey.  Medium bodied with a sweetness in contrast to the name.
0.355 l bottle at Monks Cafe Wallingatan, Stockholm. Slightly hazy chestnut color. Sweet, malty, toffeish and nutty aroma. Sweet malty, toffeish and berryish flavor with chocolate and nuts.

The aroma is an interesting one of a dark chocolate champagne formation.  It doesnt exist for sure, but that is the sort of aroma I perceive.  The bouquet is full of dark berry alcohol.  The sugary alcohols add to the nice fragrances.  The appearance is very dark ruby colorerd a bit hazy with almost no head whatsoever.  The head is only a thin collar of white fluff.  The taste is a moderate to heavy sweetness, but reserved not overly abundant as this style has a tendency towards.  There are slight alcohol notes, but only sort of like a dark chocolate pinot noir (if there were such a thing) nothing overpowering.  Its most akin to The palate has underlying notes of bitterness that has light to moderate effervescence with an interesting dark chocolate feel on the center of the tongue.  A sort of parallel of astringent sweetness.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-whit ehead. Has a fruity malty caramel and chocolate aroma with some hints of dark fruit. Sweetish malty caramel and chocoalte flavor. Has a sweetish roasted malty finish with hints of carame land chocolate in the aftertaste.

Very smooth for such a dark strong ale(8.3%).  Have had on tap and from the bottle, both times I was very impressed with how easy it goes down. Pours a reddish brown with thick creamy head.  Nice aroma and has a coffee like bitter aftertaste.  All around a great beer.

Pours dark reddish-brown with a minimal off-white head. Aroma is lots of caramel, dark fruit and some alcohol. Not much peet smoke in the aroma. The flavor is very fruity and sweet. Not too much smoke. You get a little roasted malt and the alcohol is present and warming. Medium mouthfeel and pretty drinkable for a beer of this strength.
Pours a translucent dark tea with a mocha head. Faint nose of sweet malts. Nice sweet flavor with a slight toffee note. Great mouthfeel and nice clean finish.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
A fabolous deep red with some slight brownish edges. Beautiful, creamy, yellow to off-white creamy head. Great duration. A definite 5 on the looks. Sweet caramel aroma, lightly toasted, some fruity hops, light raisin, red currants and strawbeeries. Medium to high carbonation, rather prickly. Fine, creamy and dry mouthfeel. Flavour is nice, sweet, caramel, a bit of roasted malts and chocolate. Some berries and a lovely fruity bitterness. Really lovely, actually.

Bottle (8,5% ABV). A ligtly hazy dark red beer with a medium sized, mostly diminishing, beige head. The aroma is powerful and very malty and quite hoppy. There are notes of toasted grains, caramel, grapefruit, sugar, peat and some alcohol. The flavour is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. lightly bitter. Lightly sticky, but enjoyable. Medium to full body, soft to lively carbonation, quite long finish with medium bitterness, lightly alcoholic. A cross between a Scotch ale and an American Strong ale, because of its overhopping for the style (but not so much). Interesting.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a thin beige head.  Malty with some toast and caramel notes, and just barely a feint hint of alcohol.  Smooth, medium bodied, lots of malty caramel flavors.  Light warming alcohol with some toast and hop bitterness.

Bottled [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */
Deep ruby color, small steady beige head. Nutty and bready aroma. Toffeish, rye-bready, some chocolate. Aftertaste is strongly hopped and spicey (chili). Interesting spicey-toffeish Scotch ale.

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint. Aroma is similar to what youd expect from a porter, instead of a scotch ale. Smallish tan head. Taste is great. Chocolate was most noticeable for me, with a slightly fruity aftertaste. Delicious.
Excellent U S Scotch Ale... Nice follow up to last weeks Double Bock. Not for the timid.

Bottle. Brown color, hazy. Malty caramelly buttery aroma with a hint of cinnamon. Malty sweet buttery flavor with licorice and cinnamon. Caramelly. Cookie dough. Pear. Alcoholic and a sticky mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was deep ruby with a half inch of tan colored foam on top.  Nose is peat, caramel, malt, earth, molasses, and a hint of hops.  Taste was molasses at first, followed by the characteristic scotch ale blast and a light hop bouquet.  Wow!! For me, it doesnt get much better than this brew.  Every phase, even through the finish, is simply delicious.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark maroon with some slight brownish head. No lacing.

The smell is malty with some nice dark bread flavor, some great butterscotch flavor as well.

The taste is caramel and toffee. Some dry dark fruit mixed with some hop bitterness with a nice warm alcohol flavor.

The feel of this beer is medium bodied and is easy going down. It is high an ABV but still pleasant and not overpowering.

This is a great looking beer. Copper pour, light haze, thick flourish of tan head, generous lacing. Generic malty aroma. Rich malt ball of flavor, cracker, bread, toffee, fig, offset by generous bittering hops. Medium to full body, zesty palate, some alcohol warmth.

12 oz. bottle.  Clear amber mahogony ruby pour with tan beige frothy head.  Smells of malt, caramel, smoke, bourbon, vanilla.  Tastes of rich roast malt.  One of my favorite beer styles, and a good take on it.  Excellent.

Bottle. Cloudy, red-brownish liquid with an almost yellow head. Aroma is rich with some sweetness and notes of caramel, dried fruits and banana. Taste is sweet and rich with some fruitiness and hoppiness. Thick mouthfeel and notes of banana. Really nice brew.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/6/09 


Aroma: Nose of dark berries, caramel, toast, sugar, wood, and some earthy hops

Appearance: A deep, dark reddish-brown color with a small head

Flavor: Big sweet flavor up-front, fruits/sugar/bread, and a nice hop presence in the later palate

Palate: This beer has a smooth mouthfeel, medium-full body, and long duration

Overall Impression: 
I found this beer to be really enjoyable.  In fact, Ive found pretty much everything Ive had from this brewery to be pretty darn enjoyable.  They just make a lot of really quality beers.  This one was quite good, a great flavor profile, nice looking, nice throughout the full palate.  Well done by Founders with this one.  I picked up a bunch of Founders at Wine and Beer Westpark, and Im glad I did, because they make some really nice brews.

Pours a deep, dark, brown with little to no head. Whatever head there was laced nicely as it went down. Aroma, is caramel, chocolate, and maybe a hint of peat. Mouth feel is medium and a bit chewy with minimal carbonation. Taste is fairly sweet. Lots of caramel and chocolate notes. I could pick out a few notes of smoke and peat, however, would have enjoyed more. Malt is offset by a nice hoppy bite at the end that helps avoid it becoming cloying.  For the abv, this is easy to drink and can creep up on you.  Id definitely would let this warm a bit, as the complexities come out the longer it sits.  Im not very well versed in the style, but from the scotch ales that Ive tried, this would rank up there pretty high.
12 oz bottle, Waldos, Kalamazoo. Dark red-brown colour, tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, nuts, some roastiness. Flavour of roasted malts, dark fruits, caramel and brown sugar. Well drinkable.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of carmel, brown sugar, light earthiness and a hint of fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, brown sugar, pepper and light earthiness with a smooth warming lingering carmel finish.
Bottle 0,355ltr: Hazy dark brown brew from Michican, with an dark fruit, caramel taste.

12oz bottle brought down by inlaws from Andersons in Toledo.  Red brown pour with a smallish off-white head and some spotty stick.  Aromas of caramelized sugar, earthy roasted malts and a light bourbon vibe.  Full toffee malt and dried fruit taste.  Little to no carbonation on the tongue.

355 ml bottle. Hazy dark mahogany. Medium-sized thick creamy light beige head that clings to the glass. Feels thick and rich. Carbonation level is fairly low and the beer has high viscosity. Rich caramel flavours with toffee and chocolate. Thick and oily texture. Notes of paper and candy sugar. Sweet, but not really that sweet given the otherwise rich and viscous beer. Very tasty.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.Clear medium to dark red brown orange color with a small, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, hay, caramel, overripped fruit, burnt brown sugar, smoke - vomiting notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, and malt dusty. Body is medium full to medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091020]

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2014 On tap. Poured a clear dark reddish brown with a thin light brown head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma was full of sweet grains with a bit of darkness and toffee underlying. Flavor begins with sweet grains and toffee and has some dark bread in the finish.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a hazy dark red with a nice tan head.  Aroma is nice, toffee, dried fruits, some roasted nuts and maybe some brown sugar.  Flavor is full and smooth. Malty, a bit sweet (but I like that), caramel, toffee and fruit. Very good.

Bottled. Pours out in a hazy mahogany colour with a small creamy off-white head. Fat and rich malt aroma of fudge, peat, burnt caramel and butter. Full-bodied with notes of burnt caramel, fudge, licorice, peat caramalized sugar and grass with touches of peppery alcohol. Long chewy and malty finish of fudge, peat, prunes, caramel and black pepper.

Dark amber with a small off-white head that settles fast. Minimal lacings.

The smell is malty with notes of caramel, toffee and vanilla. Quite a lot of fruity notes reminiscent of fruit candy.

The taste is very balanced. Its not very complex, but its rich and round in character. Malts dominate with notes of caramel and dark bread. Lots of fruit aromas. Its fairly sweet, but nowhere near cloying. Notes of leafy hops and vanilla. The finish is somewhat bitter with notes of leafy hops, malts and subtle alcohol.

Medium body, smooth mouthfeel. Very easy to drink.

A balanced and tasty beer. Despite the sweet and malty character, its very easy to drink. I like the subtle complementary hop notes and how they add a little something to the overall character.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

A hazy red/brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of caramel with chocolate and fruits like cherries, The taste is sweet moving over to bitter. There is chocolate. Its dry and has some fruits. The aftertaste is dry bitter with a little sweet.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2010 From a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.  Bottled on 9/9/9 Pours a beautiful dark ruby with little head, turning to no head quickly.  No lacing whatsoever.  Aroma is of alcohol, plum and smoke.  Taste is of burning, burning alcohol!  Some other flavors are, dark fruit, smoke, pine (but not a hoppy pine really), slight bubblegum and dark malt.  Mouthfeel is very substantial but its a little too carbonated for my taste, just slightly so.  Overall, this would be a great beer if it wasnt for the burning alcohol flavor which consumes the whole taste and turns it into cherry NyQuil.  I really felt it on the way down.  It isnt even that high an abv beer.  Im going to let a few of these sit for about six months and see if they mellow out.

Update 12/27/10:  Indeed this Bastard has mellowed out a lot.  Much less alcohol a year and a third out.  Plenty of peet, smoke and scotch.  Still not my favorite but at least its drinkable now.
26th May 2008. Like an old aged ale. Lots of chocolately malt and a fair hop finish. Low carbonation and not much bitterness.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 12 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber brown with a small creamy tan froth. Aroma is very nicely blended with chocolate and spiciness, along with an earthy peat character. Very inviting on the nose, sweet but some citric hops, chocolate covered oranges. Flavor starts with a tasty dark fruit character overlying a nice complex chocolate maltiness and just a hint of smoke. Definitely a nice hop kick in the finish, but not overly bitter or harsh. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Really tasty scotch ale, I dig.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Deep ruby colour with some sediment and a small, tan head. Rich caramel and chocolate aroma. In the mouth raisins and citrussy hops, hints of nuts. Tastes actually more like a barley wine. Dryish finish. Sirupy. Solid bastard.

Nice rich red colour with a lingering cream coloured head. Aroma is malty, sweet, and boozy, you can already tell this beer is serious business by  the smell of it. Thick and syrupy, lots of malt and lots of hops to balance it out. Great beer, very smooth and extremely easy to drink. My favourite beer to start a heavy drinking session as it goes down smoothly and packs an 8.5% punch.

355mL into thistle (yeah right). Pours a clear, deep, beautiful ruby with a two-finger yellow, rocky head with good retention. leaves good sheety lacing. Aroma is pears, strawberries, burnt sugar, tannins, leather, caramel, a bit of booze. Taste is metallic, fairly bitter with a plethora of balancing English hops. A bit astringent on the palate. Chewy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Long, bitter aftertaste.

From a trade with coyotehunter.  Poured somewhere between ruby and copper.  Clear with a scant off-white head.  The aroma is fruitier than I anticipated.  Citrus and tropical fruits over a hefty dose of malt and some alcohol.  The flavor also had what I thought was mango along with citrus hops, plenty of malt and some booze.  A lighter mouthfeel than I anticipated.  Ive had the Backwoods Bastard and I think its miles ahead of this.
A good sloid Scotch Ale that is smooth and slightly sweet. A great beer one comes to expect from Founders.

Aroma of scotch, brown sugar, currant and roasted caramel. Appearance was cloudy brown with creamy tan head. Flavor is similar to the nose, with most of the scotch elements most prominent. Palate is creamy. Very solid, well made brew.

Bottle. Moderate aromas of roasted and caramel for the malt, herbs for the hops, with hints of date and brown sugar. Head is small, wispy, off-white with fair lacing and good legs, and is mostly diminishing. Color is dark brownish red. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and acidic, then the long finish is lightly sweet and acidic, and moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, oily, with a lively carbonation and a moderately astringent and very dry finish. The flavor in this Scotch Ale leans towards dry and bitter unlike others Ive had, which is why I like this so much. Thanks Hopscotch.

Bottle. Hazy amber body with a small off white head. Lovely malty aroma with some spice, lots of caramel and fruity barley notes. Powerful and deep malty flavour which contains lots of light burned caramel, light alcohol, dark ripe fruit, biscuits and light chocolate. Complex and smooth brew.

Poured from bottle into Imperial Pint.

Cloudy orangish-brown with small head and minimal lacing. Turns lava red if held in the light just right. Great color but lack of head hurts slightly.

Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, peat, slight English hops. Smell definitely improves as it warms.

A malt bomb. Loads of caramel, dark fruit and toffee. However, some smokey peat and English hops keep the malt in-check. While sweet, the bitter finish prevents the beer from becoming cloying.

Thick and full-bodied with low carbonation. Almost chewy but the beer is too drinkable for that.

Seems lower than 8.5% abv. Very nice Wee Heavy overall. Just make sure to let this Bastard warm up some as I almost gave a couple lower scores because I was impatient to drink it right out of the fridge.

Botella. Cloudy golden deep amber brown colour. Beige small head leaving some lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, yeast, alcohol malt and caramel. Sticky mouthfeel. Sweet, deep malty, alco, caramel, bitter dry, woody and spiced flavour with a little chocolate Dry malty caramel hoppy sweet light chocolate finish. Too sweet and too much alcohol appearance but pleasant.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a copper hue and a thin light beige head.  Aroma is mostly caramel malt with a little spice.   Flavors of caramel, malt, molasses and brown sugar.  Medium body with a smooth creamy mouthfeel.
Had on tap at the brew pub mahogany pour with some nice beige head, nose is malty with a touch of smoke and some booze. flavor follows suit very smooth loved this beer and this brewery.

24-OCT-2009, bottle @home.
Dark amber with nice head.
Very efficient malt based nose. Nice alcohol and bitterness balances the malts.
Quite complex malt taste, but the winner for this beer is the long aftertasted.
I am in no way an expert on the style, but this seems a bit "American" for a Scotch ale? Any way, I like it a lot.
It is in no way an "easy drink". Each sip reveals more and more. Mayby it just benefits from the increasing temperature?
Actually the higher the temperature, the more the hops kick in. I have experienced that a few times. Is that a well-known secret? In any way, I like it more the warmer it gets.
My second Founders, and I will definately still seek out available Founders beers in Copenhagen. Really well-made beer.
Bottle in Beer Temple, Adam. Amber body with slight head. Malty nose and sticky head. Quite sweet with lots of caramel and malt taste. Sticky. With a smooth finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Full, thick, syrupy. Thats what first comes to mind. Besides that rather bitter and malty. But the main thing with this beer is sweetness. Very sweet! Luckily the bitterness hides it a bit. Flavourful but not complex.

Bottle. Pours cloudy amber with thick tan head. Aroma of malt, some smoke. Body is thick and creamy. Taste of caramel malts, oak and spice, not too sweet. Very well balanced, finish and smooth and warming.

Wonderful sipping beer for fall. Dark in appearance, aroma, and taste--malty with enough hops for balance, resulting in a smoky flavor conveyed in a creamy thick palate. The greater than 8 percent ABV is well-hidden.
Pours a clear reddish amber.  Caramel malt, must grass, fruit, toffee, bread, and a bit of oak.  Some bitter hops at the back.  Nice beer well made, but Im not a big fan of the style.
Bottle.Dark brownish colour with small white head.Aroma is rosted and sweet malty,good powerfull mouthfeels and flavor of dried fruits,wood and caramel.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2009 Nice color for scotch ale.  It has a simple head and good carbonation.  The aroma is the best attribute of the beer with the smell of Carmel, the smoked malts, and hops.  This aroma creates the scotch smell.  The finishing hops are excellent.  It is very bitter, but well balanced.  The overall beer trys to have a creamy texture like a Belhavens Scottish ale but I think the beer is too bit thick.  It is a great sipping beer.  I would not recommend drinking it fast.  Very nice alcohol level.  If you hold some beer on your tongue and behind you bottom teeth while breathing in, you get a nice spicy tingle.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Brown colour with brief, frothy, beige head. Malty nose with dark fruit, prunes, raisins, dark rye bread and caramel. Malty taste with notes of dark fruit, dark bread, raisins, wort, toasty caramel and spicy hops in a nicely balanced finish. Slightly more than medium body, smooth rounded mouthfeel. Lovely balance. Very nice beer.

clear amber/red, small white head.
mild sweet malty red berries aroma.
flavor is sweet malty, faint woody, sweet fruity, nice balance, swet barley wine type flavor.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a medium brown with just the slightest tan head that is gone within about 45 seconds.  My sample is an unapologetic ode to all things malt.  The aroma brings a malt aroma that, if one closes his eyes, leads him to think that he is in the boiling room of Briess.  Almost doppelbock-like notes of Munich come through.  Some middle crystal notes are also noticeable, giving a strong scent of caramel and toffee.

The malt character found in the palate nearly penetrates to the soul.  Rich toffee comes through first, almost as if they had bought a palate of hard-tack caramels, and then dumped them into the boil.  Again, Crystal 60 thru 80 seems to evidence itself here.  Interestingly (and slightly out of style), there is a moderate hop bitterness that runs through the mid-palate to the finish.  While it is surprising, I think it is quite pleasant, and helps the beer from being cloying.  The finish is a balance between sweet and bitter, and lasts forever.  Overall, one of the best Scotch ales Ive had.
12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Dark brown pour with a tan head.  Very nice lacing.  Smokey, malty aroma.  Smokey, hoppy flavor, the peat is noticeable too.  Nice lingering finish.
Pours a dark brown color with just a little white head. Has a malty caramel smell to it. The taste is just about the same way it smells. Has a slight bitter finish to it

bottle poured a dark ruby brown in color with a foamy white head with a brisk pour. aroma has mostly malts, some dark fruit, and caramel. medium mouth feel with just enough carbonation. flavor gets a little richer, roasted malt, light bitterness, toffee, and a touch of sweetness. good beer overall but not as nice as many of there others.

12oz bottle. tawny red brown color with a khaki colored one finger head. dried fruits like dates and golden raisin on the nose with an obvious big roasted malt character. very rich sweet and malty but not unbalanced. hops play second fiddle, but are found from start to finish, providing a good counterpart to the malt. well crafted scotch style ale.
Bottle thanks to Butters.  Brown-red with a thick tan head.  Lightly sticky lacing.  Plummy, raisin, melty aroma.  Taste is very fruity, plums, raisins, cherries, very sweet and malty.
Red chestnut with a creamy and lasting off-white head. Rich malty aroma with biscuit and dried fruit. Sweet and fruity flavour with a hint of smoke. The sweetness to some degree balanced by alcohol

Bottle shared by DuffmanSW.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a yellowish tan head.  Aroma is caramel, pears, and honey.  Flavor is sweet with some burnt roastiness, fresh fruit, and salty caramel.  Medium to full bodied, medium carb, would have liked it a bit thicker.

12oz bottle at the Winking Lizard Crosswoods location. Pours clear red with a medium tan head. Malty caramel aroma that is sort of metallic with a hint of booze. Caramel malt flavor with a dry, earthy hop finish.
Bottle. Brown/ruby pour with smallish off white head. Smells like an English ESB. Malty, hoppy, slightly sweet. I really like Founders but this one is not really my thing to be honest.

Deeeeep reddish brown with a creamy off-white head. Nice malty nose. Deep mouthfeel with a nice creamy palate. Very complex on the tongue with a bit of sweet (honey?). So much malt but combined very well. Ive had a lot of poorly done scotch ales and they turned me off of the style. Im glad this one is around to help redeem scotch ales for me!

Pours a deep reddish-brownish color with a small head. Whoa! this actually smells like scotch! Smoky and peaty with some mild honey notes, dammit this smells good Flavor has good notes of scotch whisky with some very good hoppiness, some apple, some cherry, and some pronounced but delicious alcohol notes.
Dark brown with hints of red in color, little head.  Hints of malt in the aroma.  Sweet, rich malt flavor, hints of caramel.  Medium-heavy body, dry finish.  I prefer this beer on tap.

Bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours unclear dark amber with a small creamy and lasting head. Nose is sweet of toffee, caramel and dark fruits with alcohol and chewing gum in the back. Smooth and sticky palate. Warmth and has a good level of vinousness. Nice.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Ruby red colour, small brown head. Aroma is caramel malts, some alcohol, plum and some slight grassyness. Flavour is sweet malts, alcohol, some mild raisins and plummy notes. Aftertaste is very sweet along with some mild toasted notes.
Bottled. Brownish color, short head. Aroma of caramel malt, some butterscotch, bit hop. Sweetish taste, very malty, caramel. Very nicely balanced.
Bottle. Pours dark ruby with a small white head.Aroma of caramel. Taste of dark fruits, caramel and some smoked character as well, sweet overall, finishes bitter and better.

Bottled. Aroma has caramel, butterscotch, raisins. Hazy, brown coloured beer with a lasting, off-white head. The taste is sweet, caramel malty with butterscotch. Sweetness is not too overwhelming. Balance is okay. Just a little siruppy. Has some hoppiness. Enjoyable brew.
Reddish-brown in appearance. Sweet, but not syrupy. A little anise and caramel malts. Slight whiskey or scotch on the palate. Very nice!

The aroma is strong, like a brown ale with boozy undertones. It is like a thick dark syrup in appearance with red hughes. Tastes delicious from a strong ale perspective in the tradition of a scotch ale. I know people who are scared to drink this style - ask Sean.

(Sample Date: 8/25/2009   Source:Capital Ale House - Downtown)   Caramel and a light fruitiness in the aroma. Hazy amber brown. Big caramel maltiness with dark fruit notes and peat smoke. Dry moderately bitter finish.

Malty molasses nose with faint hints of wood, chestnut, and whiskey. Cloudy brown with a thick yellow head, good lacing, constant streams of carbonation. Well balanced blend of whiskey, malt, and oak. Bark finish. Medium mouthfeel. Hearty and well crafted.

Bottle. Medium high and lasting creamy off-white head leaving nice lacings. Hazy orange red body. Powerful barley malt aroma with caramel and choccolate and vague hint of vanilla. Mild malty creamy and hoppy choccolate flavor with a bit of sour berries. Low carbonation. Long malty aftertaste. Would not have guessed on such a high alcohol level.

Floral, meadow-like aroma, that is a touch tangy and blossomy.  Starndard brown pour and weird drawing on label.  The flavor is great - malty and sweet, but not syrupy, with notes of grassy hops and a bitter, herbal undertone (fifty IBU).  A touch of yeast and bit of bourbon in the flavor as well.  This is as complex and tasty a scotch ale as I can name.  Bravo, Founders, for another excellent release.
Canals purchase. Pretty good beer. I remeber a good blend of sweet malt and raisins. Very dry finish. Quite enjoyable. AYE!
Great beer. Wish I wouldve bought more. Good balance. Not way to mlaty like I was afraid of. Has a good spicy bite to it also. Cant believe its 8.3%.
Pours clear deep amber with tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel. brown sugar.  Similar taste, bitter finish.

12oz bottle. cloudy caramel color, thin tan head. nice sweet caramel aroma. very sweet caramel taste with a little spicy background. smoky and smooth, i didnt get a lot of the hops in the finish. nice but a little sweet for more than one a night for me.

2005 Bottle at the RB Rochester Gathering, Aug. 30/ 09. Thanks, JB!  Reddish-brown in color with a medium beige head and good retention. Earthy, malty aroma with caramel and wood. Flavor is lots of caramel malt with woody notes, brown sugar, and a hint of smoke. Creamy with a full palate. A very good scotch ale.

Bottle at home. Pours a clearish amber with an off-white head. Sweet with some bitter malt aromas. Very malty with aromas of caramel. Also aromas of marzipan. Hints of alcohol. Medium to full bodied. Medium carbonation.Long bitter and somewhat sweet finish.

Flaske: Rødlig brun øl med et fint skumhoved. Duft af frugt og masser af malt. Alkoholen er en kende for dominerende i smagen, hvor den eneste humle man kan ane er bitterhumlen, forholdsvis bitter af en så sød øl.

Bottle at Dayton Ale Fest.  Pours a rich, dark brown with a very small tan head.  Aroma is toaseted malts and caramel.  Notes of oak, spices, and brown sugar come out.  On the palate it is dry.  The taste brings out a bit of the spices and it finishes dry.  Overall, this is an alright Scotch Ale.

12 oz bottle courtesy of the Craig 12 pack. Pours a medium deep flat brown with some small moving bubbles. Flavors of spiced scotch, cramel malts, barrel flavors. Mouth is a little flat. A decent beer.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2010 On my second try of this beer, I found big, sweet, rich, cake-like malts and spices in the nose, and sweet flavors of spices, cake, chocolate, and caramel, which then finish hard, dry, dirty and bitter. Lovely how sweet turns to punishing hop and roast. Smooth, silky, lovely body. 
Bottle at the RB Rochester Gathering, Sept. 09. Thanks, JB. Red-orange tinted amber. Nose or caramel and fruits. Dry, hoppy, and roasted with good caramel. Rich and tasty, smooth, fruity. Good bitter finish. Lovely stuff. 8/3/8/3/15

What an amazingly balanced beer this is. Its complex and thick, and the alcohol is well-disguised but with just enough presence that it subtly enhances the flavor. The hop content is pitch-perfect. Color is beautiful, and it tastes much better than it smells. Awesome brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber with a small, lasting tan head. Nice, pervasive aromas of clover honey and caramel. Has a wonderfully thick, mouth feel. Strong tastes of sweet malt, caramel, allspice, and vanilla. Lighter on the hops, but enough to balance the sweetness well. Finishes with a nice bitterness and a sweet alcohol burn--comparable to the taste of scotch. I love it.
Dark amber with with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, caramel and hops and overripe fruits. Sweet flavour with toasted malt, caramel, ripe fruits, hops and pine. Finished bitter.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy brown and amber with a small off-white head. Roasted caramel malty aroma with a distinct fruity hops note, light wooden. Fruity, light metallic, roasted caramel and prune flavoured. Growing bitterness into a overripe fruity flavoured finish.

Nice deep red colour with a small off-white head that leaves some great lazing on my tulip. Aroma is subtile malty with notes of carmelized sugar, malty fruit and some yeast. Flavour is similar but more with a fairly big fruity, sweet malt flavour hitting you right away. The brew finishes sweet and malty with candy like fruit notes and some almost burnt sugar alongside a good back bitterness. The body is smooth and fairly full.

12 oz bottle thanks to kryptic. Pours a awesome ruby color with a thick beige head and lots of lacing. The aroma is pure Scotch Ale; rich fruity malts, dusty and full with some caramel as well. A sweet fruity flavor with loads of dry dustiness, light caramel and smoky berries. Very nice and drinkable. A good bit of alcohol warmth in the flavor- which is fine with me.
rich red pour with a quickly diminishing offwhite head, great lacing...nose is of sweet dried fruits... flavor is malty, sweetness, and a lingering hop finish
12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Had this awhile back and dont remember specifics, but a nice brew.

12oz bottle from Archer.   Brown color with some red highlights and a small head.   Malty aroma with caramel and sweet dried fruit that gets brighter as the beer warms up.   The flavor is much of the same, with dried fruit and caramel, but with a surprising amount of hop flavor and bitterness that is just a bit musty and dull.   Medium-full body with lower carbonation.   Nice overall, but the hops just didnt work very well for me.

Not sure if this is courtesy photomike or SamGamgee. Pours a ruddy rusty brown with a pinkish ecru head. Smokey aroma with some acidity, dark bready malts, light prunes, scotch. Flavor is light on peat but still with a nice smoked character. Dark breads make up the heft of the beer with accents of prunes and alcohol. Some mild hop bitterness in the finish. Nice medium full body.

A dark copper/red ale with just a hint of tan head, leaves nice lace.  Aroma is very malty with a whiff of the alcohol breaking through.  All of that malt in the aroma comes through in the flavor, along with an unexpected shot of hop bitterness in the finish.  A nice take on the style and sure to be a regular in my fridge from now on!

Pours a hazy copper color with nice layer of offwhite head.  Aroma is caramel, dark fruits and some boozy ruminess to it.  Flavor is nice strong caramel sweetness mixed with sweet dark fruit flavors.  Reminds me of some raspberry caramel chocolates Ive had before.  Finish is bitter, dry and roasty with a hint of boozy warmth.  Very nice beer.
Bottle. Pours a dark, hazy reddish brown. RUST is the color. Aroma is sweet malt. The flavor is smooth, sweet malt, sugar, and a touch of alcohol.
Muddy brown, cinnamon aroma, great sweetness.  More spice, dirty spice and earth.  Did someone say spice?
Pours copper with a white head.  Smells of sweet malt, some spice, some fruity hints.  Tastes of toffee, dark fruit, some bread pudding.  Well rounded.

bottle thanks to dmschefke.  poured a deep amber with a beige head and spotted lacing.  aroma of caramel malt, plum, and raisin.  flavor was caramel, plum, raisin, and some alcohol.  medium body with medium carbonation.
Pours a hazy ruby with a small off white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, bread, and dark fruit. Flavor sweet malt, nuttiness, light fruit, and a bit of bitterness.

1/2 a shared 12oz. Pours a murky dark brown with abundant haze. Nose is sweet, dark malt with some slight bourbon notes, and some faint dark, dried fruits. Taste is smooth and creamy, dark malts, undertones of bourbon/scotch, and the taste of dry, dark fruits (fig, plum, etc) comes through slightly in the background. Alcohol is not overpowering, and finish is rewarding. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a nice complex palate going on. WoW! This one is a Winner!

Malty caramel and toffee in the aroma.  Extremely small off white head that is fully diminishing.  Murky dark amber/brown color.  Sweet initial flavor ending in a moderately bitter back end.  Dry texture with an extremely flat carbonation.  Was expecting a little more.

12oz bottle. Pours a mahogany brown body with a reddish tint to it. Finger-width, brownish beige, creamy head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of sticky lacing. Aroma has barley wine style sweet fruity toffees with a nice earthy hop blend. Some deeper caramels, berries, prunes, citrus, a touch of roast, a just a hint of sweet scotchy booze. Flavor is sweet, malty caramels and more fruity toffees. Citrusy, berry, and pruney earthy bitterness goes nicely with the malts. A touch of smokey roast towards the finish as well as a sweet booze keeping this similar to a barley wine. Finishes semi-dry with a moderate duration of everything. Full bodied with a really nice, rounded sweetness and balancing hops/roasty smoke. Overall, a very tasty beer. I like the barley wine qualities a lot in this one. Solid stuff.
Pours copperry red with little to no head. Smells light citrus. Stunning complex flavor, hops are blended well and not overpowering. First scotch ale for me and will not be the last!
(bottle) clear reddish brown colour; virtually no head; aroma of mats, molasses, fruit; taste of malts, bit of alcohol; light initial sweet tones giving way to a moderately bitter finish

(bottle) Dark chestnut brown ale with disappearing tan head. Aroma of crystallized malt sugars, strong ripe berries. Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, caramel, nuts; earthy, fruity but not so much as the aroma. Medium  to full bodied, sticky.

Clear mahogany pour with a small beige cap. Aroma of toffee, maple syrup, earthy hops and a hint of roast. Taste mirrors aroma but with an added smoky note and some nuttiness. One of my favorite American brewed Scotch ales.
A ruby red pour. Aroma of caramel malt and fresh bread with a hint of deep fruit. Flavor is similar: bready and caramel malt but with some toffee character. Finish is very alcoholic. Very tasty.

Bottle from Ludlow Wines in Cincinnati.  Pours deep red with medium light tan head that fades and laces the glass.  Medium body.  Aroma of malt, hops, toffee, smoke.  Flavor is more of the same, but also has some sweetness and fruit to go along with the smoky malt and hops.  The alcohol lingers on the palate for a potent, bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy of ericandersnavy.  Clear ruby pour.  Aged aroma notes with a strong amount of alcohol.  Caramel elements as well.  Pretty solid taste.  Bready and sweet that tingles over the tongue.  Leaves a dryness that does not disappoint.

Soon as I started pouring this I knew I was in for a treat.  Poured out really thick and really hazy, and brown tinged orange with a thick tan head.  Fastly faded though.  A bit sour in the nose, very fruity and malty.  Palate is smoky, and a bit gritty from the hops.   Lots of toffee, caramel, that sort of thing.  Lots going on in the nose and the palate.  This one will take some more tastings to really appreciate.   Thanks for the trade Zach!  And so glad now that you threw in a few extras!
UPDATED: APR 10, 2012 BOTTLE: dark red/brown pour, aroma of smoke, maybe some caramel. Taste is terrific - lots of sweet caramel, just a touch of hop.

This and the Moylans Kilt Lifter I find to be highly comparable, with this being slightly superior.  Similarities: big malty sweetness, brown ale characteristics, smokiness.  Differences:  Dirty bastard just has more of all of the above.

Bottle.  Poured a muddy brown with a reddish tinge and a creamy head.  The aroma is pretty restrained, and I struggle to extract much of one at all.  The drink has more to it ... predominately bitter toffee and wood bark, with a bitter bite.  Creamy mouthfeel but a relatively thin body.  (#3607, 14 July 2009)

Pours a dark, reddish amber with a thin, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts and hints of smoke and scotch. Flavor also contains a lot of roasted caramel malts with hints of toffee, smoke, wood, nuts, scotch, and some light, bitter hops. Body is medium-heavy with some carbonation. A pleasure to drink.

Pours a cloudy dark red/brown with minimal head. Almost looks like a iced sun tea but just a tad darker. Swirling it creates a thin off-white creamy head that doesnt stick around. Nose is sweet with a nice fruitiness and a fleeting hint of vanilla? Initial sweet flavor that becomes slightly bitter and tea-like in the finish.. Good medium-thick mouth feel. Malty and fruity. Complex, with slightly different flavors with every sip, especially as it warms a bit. Overall very good. The first Scottish Ale I really enjoyed.

Poured a heavy dark brown color with a light toffee aroma.  A small smoke taste starts this bad boy off,but it disappears quickly behind the huge caramel finish.  I feel like a licked caramel off a spoon.  Another bold one by Founders.

dark red brown with tan head.  moderate carbonation.  sweet malt nose with a hint of floral english hops.  some hop bitterness that is quickly replaced by a lot of malt sweetness, likely low crystal and some upper crystal and a hint of roasted malt. for a scotch ale i would prefer some smokey and peated flavors, but this version doesnt really open up to reveal those.  honestly, tastes more like an irish red ale, with sweetness and roastiness.  not impressed

Pours a deep reddish color with some amber hues and a creamy off-white head.  The aroma was musty brown sugar and caramel with a touch of fruit and spice.  The flavor is very similar, but not too sweet as I find some Scotch ales.  Very creamy body with some noticeable alcohol in the finish.  A solid beer from a solid brewery.

Bought a six pack at Giant Eagle, then bought another. Pours a very impressive reddish gold with a fine head, but not very much of a scent. Nice powerful taste, I swear theres a punch of liquor after the nice malt taste. Ill probably be buying more soon.

Bottle. Bought att the brewpub. Very special tanks to Freddie!
Pours very dark red, almoust brown. No head on this.
I expected a more destinct aroma from this than I found. Aroma is mild from malt, butter, wood and burn sugar. Flavor has roasted malt, little spicey peppery from the alcohol. I also find some tar. Palte is medium.

This beer pours a muddy brown with a creamy.  Smells amazingly of booze and rich caramel malts.  The flavor follows the nose on this beer.  Strong boozey flavor up front with a deep rich caramelly malt background.  This is a fairly complex beer, with a very minimal hop presence.  Im glad it isnt overly sweet, yet the malt background is rather thick and actually.  I enjoyed this one.

A beautiful amber color with just a little head, deep amber color. The malty and smoke flavors compliment each other very well. Medium body little carbonation. One of the best scotch ales I have yet to try

Tap, from growler filled at Party Mart.  Dark rich clear amber brown color that, when held to light, reveals  a great ruby red hue.  Khaki head with descent retention. Roasty caramel, oak, nuts, and hops on the aroma.  Favor had all of the same characteristics but a bit more potent on the whole. Sturdy hop profile.  On the palate - turn the keg pressure down please.  Overall: a solid beer that I wouldnt call sessionable but would call interesting.
Very bold! Not usually a fan of the smoke flavor but this beer had just the right amount  .  Aroma was of bourbon and scotch. Flavor was carmel and malts.

Source:  12 oz bottle purchased at Bruisin Ales in Asheville. Glass: Tulip. Appearance: Poured a dark red/brown with a one finger beige head.  Aroma:  Sweet malts and dark fruits.  Caramel dominates. Flavor: Caramel malt base with dark fruits on the end. Palate:  Medium/full body with mild carbonation.Overall:  Solid Founders offering.  I dont crave the Scotch Ale style, but this was a particularly good one.

Bottle at 33 Wine bar in St. Louis. Deep mahogany with a thin, quickly disappearing white head. There is a dark rum quality to this with lots of fruit to it, and a bit of smoke. Its very tasty but the sweetness overpowers a bit as it goes on.

Bottle from Giant Eagle in Canton.  Last time I had a scotch ale it tasted like bandaids so this was a pleasant reversal of my first run-in with this style.  Dark copper/light ruby pour with light tan non-existent head (no I did not have a thistle glass, Ive never even seen one).  Light carbonation with an undeniable scotch aroma.  Flavor is much the same but super subtle and cut by an equally subtle hop profile with a dry finish.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Tap. Not too much as per i remember about this beer besides it was a full bodied beer with lots of flavor.

Edit saw this early rating and laughed. Dont object to the score however. Flavor ends with butterscotch finish? Fruit and woody aroma. Fruit and spice front of flavor. Tap.

12 oz bottle from a trade with dmschefke. pours burgundy with an everlasting tan head. malty aroma of caramel and dark fruit. the flavour is very malt forward but the finish is to hoppy for the style. i think more of the sublety would come through if it was as hopped. still a great beer though. thanks dave!
Brownish hued body with a thin head.  Aromas of rich caramel, raisin, fig, plum, vanilla, and a bit of smoke.  Rich malty flavor, and a good beer for the style.

Bottle from Wegmans in Princeton, NJ.  Reddish-brown in color with a medium beige head and good retention.  Earthy, malty aroma with caramel and wood.  Flavor is lots of caramel malt with earthy/woody notes, brown sugar, and a hint of smoke.  Creamy, fairly full palate.  A very good scotch ale.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy, deep red with a small, foamy, light tan head.  Big boozy nose with hints of earth and wood.  Pine, ripe stone fruit, alcohol, earth, oak, and a touch of mineral on the palate.  A slight medicinal and peat note in there too.  Reminds me of scotch in a way.  Medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Lots of alcohol and lots of hops in this one.  Low viscosity for the style, but almost too much hops in my mind.  A bit on the raw side.

Had to drink this 2 bottles at a time  out of a 22oz hurricane glass 
: p
Pours reddish brown with a thick foamy tan head. 
Aroma is earthy/ woody, caramelized sugar and roasted malt..
Flavour is  bourbon alc and woody, light earthy smoke and a subtle hop finish.

Really nice beer.  Smells of bourbon,  burnt brown sugar and green apples, same on the flavor but with an unpleasant ashtray-like finish.  Great looking, almost like murky river water.  Good beer but not great.  Thanks Founders.  2009 12 oz.
Bottle - This is a very hearty beer with loads of roasted malt flavor.  The alcohol is present but a nice complement to the beer.  I cant put my finger on it, but something seems to be missing.

Dark Copper in color, very slightly cloudy, no head but nice lacing.  This ia a big beer with Malt and alcohol prevalent in the taste.  Certainly some subtile notes of caramel and burnt suger but the alcohol overrides the flavors a lot.

So, I was incredibly perplexed with this beer.  I was told that I might not like it so much, but thats certainly not the case.  I dont love it or want to go out and purchase a case, however, its not all too bad.  It poured a light brown - rust color and was very cloudy.  I simply couldnt put my finger what I was smelling and tasting.  At first it seemed like I was smelling caramel, but then it went into an apple smell, reminding me of Fall, and trips to the cider mill.  Taste was the most strange thing - after thinking about it for a while, it reminded me of breakfast...some sort of combination of bacon, pancakes, and maple syrup, all along with the fall (cider and caramel)...Just very odd.  I liked it overall.

Pours a shiny ruby to amber color with thin tan head. Aroma is a bit weak with sweet sweet malt and a slight roastiness. The flavour starts off with some hop bitterness and slight roasted maltiness.  Not a fan of scotch ales, however, this brings a nice change in my mind of the type.  Tasty beer.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark, ruby red color. Small, lasting light brown head. Lightly sweet malty aroma. Full mouthfeel. Fruity, malty sweetness with just a bit of hops in the finish. Good scotch ale.

Bottle thanks to Daknole. Rusty orange-brown color, and aroma is also rusty hop, burnt sugar, the crust of fruit bread. Very smooth beer with great hop profile matched by delightfully fruity malts. Nice brew that is not as chewy as it smelled.

Another good one from Founders.  Has a deep reddish brown color with a little bit of a yellow head.  Smells is a little bit complex.  Has malts, caramel, hops, and grain.  Has very little carbonation.  Tastes has a lot of hops and very smooth malts.  Simply a great experience.

Bottle.  Good stuff herr folkds!  Red/brown pour.  Aroma is really nice. Toffee, dried fruits, some roasted nuts and maybe some brown sugar.  Flavor is full and smooth.  Malty, a bit sweet, caramel, toffee and fruit.  Very good.
Pours a dark reddish-brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts, toffee.  Taste is toffee, caramel, earthy malts and a little smokiness.  Seems like something is missing, however.

From a 12 oz bottle obtained in a trade from Eric in Indiana, the poured a hazy dark red with a nice tan head and moderate lacing. Nose of caramel malts, molasses, and some coffee notes. Very rich mouthfeel. Flavor is kind of classic for its style with lots malt tastes, and a dry finish. An excellent scotch ale.

A pretty, ruddy red in the glass with a good amount of lacing.  Aromas of toffee, caramel, and a sticky, clinging palate to match those sticky aromas and flavors.  The best thing here is the underlying earthy notes on the tongue.  Plenty of grit to go along with the burnt sugar of toffee and caramel.  Made somewhat hot by the high alcohol.

12 oz. bottle in a thistle glass. Ar: Unremarkable Scotch, whiskey, some grapefruit, liquorish. Ap: Amber, ruby color. Wasnt poured well, so cant judge the head. Fl: Malty, caramel, burnt sugar, whiskey, liquorish. Pa: Finished well-balanced, full body. I suppose its true to style, but one of my least favorite styles anyway.

Sampled at Rustico.  Pours a ruby color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is caramels, malts, touch of nuts.  Flavor is caramel, sweet, smooth, malty, scotch.  Extremely easy to drink and the alcohol is extremely well hidden. Me likes!
This is one of my favorites.  A sensational scotch ale with a hint of peat that is not overwhelming to the overall malt character.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark red color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of caramel, scotch, malt, and molasses. Taste is of malt, chocolate, cheap scotch, and brown sugar. Has a large presence of molasses, that tends to envelope the other flavors. Each sip ends in a lot of scotch and molasses. Lingering breadiness. Medium bodied, with a decent amount of carbonation. Mouthfeel is thick but goes down easy. The alcohol content is well masked. Easy to drink with a nice flavor.

Pours a deep reddish nut brown with a light tan head that looks good, but is short lived. Aroma is of sweet bread, toasted malt, and is slightly nutty. Flavor is similar, but slightly smokey and a little nuttier. Mouthfeel is nice and thick with mild carbonation, and the alcohol is well hidden. All in all a decent scotch ale, but not my favorite.
12oz bottle. Pours copper in color with a thin tan head which does not last long. Aroma roasted malt and peat. Taste roasted malt, bitter and nutty with bitter and peat finish.

Amber/brown color, fizzy tan head, mild lacing. Aroma of roasty malt / molasses. Flavor is chocolate and roasty malt. The chocolate is not overly sweet. There is a minor bitterness in the flavor. Medium bodied with a sryupy, dry finish. A good one, or two, or three...
Dark Brownish red color.  A nice smokey caramel smell.  Peat is all over the place, and nice hoppiness.  Doesnt taste like 8.3%.  The scotch ales tend to hide alcohol very well.

12oz. Bottle.  Deep mahogany color with a thin layer of foam.  Nose is full of peat and toasted malts.  Shows lots of malt flavors that lend a nutty sweetness to the front half of the beer.  Some smoky and dried fruit character as well.  These flavors tend to drop off quickly as the hops emerge. Bitterness is more prevalent than in other beers of this style.  Doesnt really show until the finish.  Texture is somewhat chewy with a medium carbonation.  Finish is short, bitter and somewhat disappointing.  This beer starts out great, but tapers off a bit at the end. Still a very drinkable Scotch ale.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2010 re-rate on 5/15/10... bottle... pours a solid deep red with a 1 finger off white head... subtle, yet pleasant dark fruit notes across the nose with some sweet malts.  medium smooth body with some dark cherry notes, a touch of smoke, raisins, light hops and lots of malt.  the finish is a more bitter with rich sweet malts.  very nice scotch ale... I would like a bit more depth, but overall it feels wonderful over the tongue and has a nice dark fruit / malt character that drinks very well.
Very good aromas and flavors of peat and butterscotch.  Nice full mouthfeel.  Overall a very good scotch ale.

12 oz bottle. Ah, one of my favorite scotch ales (only topped by Backwoods Bastard). Pours a dark brown (with hints of red) color with a tiny off white head the disappears immediately. Smells of light smoky hops, some caramel malt, a little dried fruit, and a bit of alcohol. Tastes of light hops, though the smoke was more prevalent, a bit of malt, the fruit kind of disappeared, and the alcohol was masked. Very smooth going down, and is my definition of what a scotch ale should be.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2009 On tap at Coasters (poured into a Duvel glass).  Pours dark reddish-brown with a 1/4 inch white head.  Sweet aroma with very light hops.  Flavor is sweet with moderate hop bitterness.  Extremely well balanced.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Not my favorite style but a very good Scotch Ale.

Reddish-brown pour with a tan head that ended up leaving a nice lace. Slight smoke and malt aroma. Flavors go well together- smokiness, malt, and then sweetness at the end. Leaves a nice refreshing aftertaste. Alcohol is not noticeable.

Beautiful ruby red color.  Nice head on there as well with some beautiful lacing down the glass.  A bit of hops in there as well as a sweet malty flavor.  Medium bodied.  Just what I woulid expect from an American scotch ale.

12 oz bottle.... possibly the best scotch ale i have ever had... very dark pour... dark head also...is that a little lowland scotch flavor in there? overall a must buy and great one from founders... 

i wish my notes were more detailed on this one, cause it deserves more

Nice pour... murky mahogany with a light orange-hued tan cap that leaves ring lace down the glass.  The nose is thick with sweet molasses notes, with other dark fruits, figs and malts.  Interesting flavor palate.... it comes off first as dry, just shy of roasted, with a twinge of alcohol to keep the bitters upfront.  The effervescence of sweetness is never really lost, though, and the integration of the two contrasts is nice.  The peat shows up in the finish, complementing the linear feel of the pull.  Good brew overall, with the ABV well-integrated, and a medium-lively mouthfeel.  As the body feels toward the medium to medium-soft side, this brew really exploits the contrasts and differences that end up complementing one another so well.

pours a reddish brown with a small tan head. heavy aroma of roasted malts and some earthy notes that i cant quite place. nice rich malt sweetness pushes through the smokey earth tones to give a nice complex scotch style.

Pours ruby brown, with a creamy tan head. Malt heavy aroma, sweet  toffee with some hops and alcohol in the background. Good complex flavor, toffee, molasses, dates, smoky peat and some hoppiness on the finish. Nice chewy and sticky palate. Overall a tasty beer.

Hazy red-mahogany with a small beige head. Earthy, woody, alcoholic nose, some peat and caramel malt. Some peat and alcohol in the flavor, also a little dry bitterness. Bitter finish. Good stuff, not very complex but rather coherent.
Great scotch ale.  i really liked this beer.  tried it at the 1st beer drinking meeting
Great old ale aroma and flavor.  Perfect amount of bitter hop aftertaste.  I never think to pick up scotch ales, but when I do I like them.  I need to chase down some of the more highly rated ones.
Poured brown with a beige head. Aroma of caramel candy. Sweet caramel flavor with some spice.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 Sampled on draft at Smokin Joes in Pittsburgh PA this beer poured a dark brown color with red highlights and a small khaki head. The aroma was tangy, fruity and malty. The flavor was full of bitter and fruity hops with light undercurrents of roasty molasses, caramel and chocolate. The finish was long with fruity, malty and molasses notes. Very nice.

12 oz bottle from daknole. Pours a murky brown with a medium off-white head that slowly dissipates to a film and has some lacing. The aroma is mild with toffee, sawdust, roasted barley and dough. The flavor was a bit like that of a slightly hoppy barley-wine with some smoked peat and a bit of alcohol. The mouthfeel is full and malty. The finish is long with a bit of lingering alcohol. Overall: A very tasty brew, thanks dakine.

Bottle served to a Czech pils glass. A walnut color pour with ruby tones. The head was a "quickly diminishing to a small ring" tan tone with light lacing. The aroma was malty caramel, a little earthiness, with a touch of vanilla. The flavor had a roasty/nuttiness, with dark molasses and caramel taste. A good alcohol presence and a pleasant bitterness was evident in the finish. A benchmark Scotch for me.

12 oz. bottle - Poured murky brownish red color with medium beige head.
Aroma - dark fruits, sweet caramel malt with hint of smoke.
Flavor - tasted plum, light chocolate, vanilla and some smoke.
Palate - medium bodied with average carbonation. Finish is slightly bitter and has earthy aftertaste.
Overall - excellent Scotch Ale!! Extremely easy to drink and higher ABV. is well hidden.

pours an amber color with a thin head
nutty aroma
Taste strong of alcohol without much depth to it
12 oz. bottle

Not to sweet and surprisingly drinkable for the style. Lightly sweet caramel malt flavor. Some plum and raisin flavors as well. Light smokiness. Long finish with some notes of alcohol. Very light carbonation and almost no head.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2016 Poured from bottle.  Aroma of big malt and molasses.  Cloudy mahogany, lacing tan head.   Roasted malt, brown sugar, molasses, vegetable.  Earthy and sweet.  Finished ok, but a bit sticky.  I like this a lot better than last time I rated.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: VERY sweet malt aroma. Has a slight red hue. Dark brown in color with very little head. Subtle alcohol aroma. Nice malty complex aroma. Wish it had more of a smoke aroma, but still nice. Nice smoke malt taste. This beer has a straightforward malt and smoke taste. A lot of sweet flavors. Nice smooth palate. A very good scotch ale. Not a huge fan of scotch ales, but this is nice. Purchased at Bruisin Ales in North Carolina.

wonderfully thick pour with a slight tan head. Deep brown color....just like the meanest scotch you have ever saw. unbeliveable sweet aroma. Caramel, vanilla, sweet fruits and maybe a ever so subtle hint of cinniamon....yeah I might be crazy. The flavor is very different fom the aroma. Very grainy....huge malts. Slightly smokey and a clean finish!!!! very good and easy drinking.
Dark mahogany pour.  Light peaty, heavily malty aroma.  Dark roasted nuts in the flavor with a peaty smokiness on the finish and aftertaste.  Nice.

Bottle, poured deep garnet with ruby edges with a creamy tan head. Aroma was strong sweet roasted barley, chocolatey caramel, and dark fruits. Flavor was oaky sweet roast barley, scotchy bite, chocolate, caramel, and licorice blending into bitter hops. I love to session with this.

Bottle.  Pours deep dark marroon with small off white head.  Aroma is burnt wood, malt and a touch of hoppiness.  Flavor is bitter at first with smoke, malt, and dried red fruit, finishes bittersweet with honey, barbeque, and a touch of hops.  Medium mouthfeel with medium carbonation, alcohol may be a little to present.  I like this though, one of the better scotch ales I have had.

Pours a murky copper-brown color with a 1/4 inch tan head and low carbonation.  Aroma is sweet with lots of toasted malt, some darker fruit notes mixed with a light chocolate and fruity hops scent.  The beer has a sweet flavor up of Maris Otter and some caramel malts, light dark fruity taste moving into a sweet, earthy bitterness in the middle and finishes with an almost gritty smoke and peat ending.  Alcohol is there but not a dominate factor in this fairly strong brew.  I love the ending to this beer and is exactly what I would expect for a scotch ale, that gritty smoke/peat ending which lingers around afterword and compliments the early malty sweetness.
Bottle.  Dark golden amber, thin white head. Tastes stronger malts, good touch of bitter hops. Notes of the booziness. Not a huge fan of this beer type.

Bottle into red wine glass.

Pours murky dark red-brown, with a thin, soapy off-white head. 

Nose is caramel, a bit of cocoa, big hit of fruity esters.

Taste is caramel, some toasty malt, bit of molasses; lot sof fruity esters, almost to the point of dominating the flavor. Buttery diacetyl comes out as well, stronger after a few sips. Light, earthy bitterness towards the finish. 

Mouthfeel is very lightly carbonated, with a full, slick body.

Disappointing effort by a great brewery. Esters are over the top, and the diacetyl that pokes through just adds to the distraction.

Pours a dark brown almost black with some translucence around the edges. Almost no head.

 Nice malty aroma with dark toffee and yeast. A bit of bourbon and raisin also show up.

 Starts heavy and ends watery. The carbonation is almost non-extistant.

 Heavy on the malt with a yeasty aftertaste. There is a whiskey bit in the middle but doesnt overwhelm.

 Not bad, didnt like the mouth feel on this one. Drinkable under the right pairing or mood. Not something I would seek out unless I had a specific itch to scratch.

12 oz. bottle from the Binnys Singles Rack from the back of the cellar (Orland Park, IL). Finally getting around to it. Pours a very nice fiery brownish hue, lots of red notes dance throughout with khaki moderate head that dissipates to a decent amount, well hazed brew. Aromas are  very nice with caramel, toffee, and biscuits heavy on the nose with a faint peat and smoke element. Initial is very nice, complex, with caramel and toffee taking the forefront, mixing in some nice vanilla and touches of peat, alcohol, light toaste, and subtle fruitiness. Largely a malt bomb, but under the layers takes a deeper complexity. Finishes with some malty lingers and a subtle bitterness beneath serving for balance. A beer Im sure to come back to. Cheers!

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy mahogany with a tiny tan ring of head, a bit of bubbly lacing sticks to the glass. Big caramel and toffee maltiness on the nose, perhaps a hint of smoke, but faint. Medium sweetness, caramel malt, some fig fruit flavor, again slight smoke, just the tiniest touch of bitterness rounds out the flavor quite nicely. Med-to-heavy mouthfeel with low carb.

208 Bottle - Thanks tjthresh - Pours a beautiful coppery ruby with a small orange head...aroma is mossy and bready, malt...flavour is "unique"...weird malt on the front flavour-wise, almost dirty, finishes the same way...not my fav, but great to try...
Shared with the boys for Cellar Reduction #3. Well masked abv.  Malty biscuit aroma and flavor with alcohol flavors.  Massively malty and good for style.

Bottle with Butters and sixfootsix at the 3rd Cellar Reduction.  Pours a light tan head with some orange to it.  Body is deep amber with some ruby highlights.  Smells of toasted malts and brown sugar.  Tastes the same with a nice bitterness on the finish.  I really enjoy the toasty nuttiness of this beer.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2009 Very nice. Kind of an old ale. Dark hazy copper. A touch fruity in the nose but it moves on to a chocolate/caramel flavor. I was hoping for a dark rummy raisiny flavor but it wasnt there. Still It was nice. Very smooth mouthfeel, rounded with light carbonation. Nicely heavy without overwhelming the palate. Plenty malt forward, with just a touch of leafy hop, without being overly sweet.
Deep red color with a tan head.  Scottish malts, maple, and caramel in the aroma.  Strong alcoholic taste with a sweet malt and caramel in the finish.

Hmmm...maybe Founders should get a new flagship. I found this beer to be too sweet for a Scotch Ale, and the number of malts used left the flavor muddled and unclear. The only good thing about this beer is its color.

ruby brown pour with a khaki thick head.  aroma of peat, fruit and smoke.  very nice on the palate with a great smoked peat flavor, caramel and sugared fruit in the finish.  pretty solid scotch ale though.

Nearly cloudy brown pour with an even light brown head that fads nicely. Sweet whiskey aroma with spice and fermented fruit. Strong sweet scotch with solid bittering present a well balanced, if somewhat rough punch. This is one of my favorite beers and it nee it fails t astoond ye! The finish is long and contains all the above as they slowly cave in on one abnother

Has a bitter aftertaste that of a stout. The color is very dark brown but not quite as dark as a dark stout. Claims to be scotch style ale but again the aroma is very stout like; which is not a bad thing. The head is very creamy in color but dissipates fast. While not one of the best beers I have had, it is still quite good.

Pours a murky scab brown with a tall, creamy peachy tan head that has great retention. Aroma is sweet grain, earthy hops, fresh cut wood, roast, slightly nutty. Flavor is peat smoke up front, lots of roast, maple, char, a touch of soghum, earthy and herbal hops, finishes char and bitter hops. A real Dirty Bastard of a brew.

Deep copper color with a thin white head.  Sweet hoppy aroma, nice.  In the mouth the taste was refreshing and smooth, hoppy and dry.  This flavor continued into the throat, but didnt leave a bitter aftertaste.  

n truth my original rating (written on the back of an envelope) finished here with a quick statement about this being a decent beer, but lacking something to make it memorable.  However, ten minutes after I finished the first bottle I realized a warm sensation in my stomach and a fuzzy glowing feeling like I had just taken a stiff snifter of cognac.  It was wonderful and calming.  I sat for 30 minutes in this comfortably numb state of euphoria, leaving it and heading straight to bed, where I slept like a Cheshire cat.   

This is definitely an interesting and wonderful concoction from the folks at Founders.  Drink with caution and enjoy the mellowing effects.  Cheers.
