Pours a dark hazy ruby with a thin tan/white head that leaves nice lacing... Aroma of sweet malts with slight notes of peat or smoke... Taste of roasted/smokey malts with nice complexity of fruits and a hint of drying hops... Finish is medium to full bodied with a lingering smokiness that builds throughout the sip til the finish... Excellent beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours slightly hazy copper with a small light tan head that dissipates rather quickly.  Nice malty aroma; sweet and figgy with some peaty notes when it warms.  Complex malty flavor profile, with lots of dark fruit along with some peat/light smoke.  Finishes somewhat dry, providing nice balance.  Medium-full mouthfeel, with moderately high carbonation, and some assertive but not hot warming.  Good strong scotch ale - a sipper in strength, but quite drinkable.

Bottle.  Spicy caramel malt aroma.  Cloudy reddish amber body, small light tan head.  Flavor is very assertively malty, with a definite alcohol kick, and a somewhat bitter finish.  Not a glass one can easily ignore; does not fail to make an impression.

Reddish-amber body with a clinging tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, brown sugar, and just a hint of smoke.  Formadible, silky palate.  Very nice flavor consisting of malty sweet goodness up front with brown sugar and butterscotch notes.  Some nice dark fruit flavor mixes in right before the smoke and whiskey warming.  Quite nice finish...a delicious and easy to drink beer.

pours a deep caramel to ruby color with a creamy light tan head.  aroma is slightly sweet with hints of vanilla and smoke.  mouthfeel is slightly heavy and silky.  flavor is very complex with a touch of fruit (maybe fig?) and some scotch and smoke ending in a lingering dry finish that leaves smoke and oak flavors behind.  excellent beer!

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with moejuck.  Pours a deep red-tinted amber with a moderate off-white head that lasted until about mid-glass and left partial lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt and brown sugar with just a hint of earthy peat.  The flavor is very nice with malt, brown sugar, dates, and a stronger dose of smoke and peat than the aroma suggests.  Some mild alcohol warming towards the finish, especially as the beer sits for a bit.  Enjoyable!
bottle, rich mahogany color, initial foamy head, aroma is scotchy, flavors of butterscotch, smoke, whiskey and some fruit, finish is smokey and viscous
Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is of malty sweetness, fruits, some liquor and plenty of hops. Flavor is similar, with a bit of peet and grapefruit. Slight bitter finish. Very good.

Dark amber color with a big tan head.  Aromas of malts, caramel, surprisingly strong on the hops, and whiff of woody scotch.  Flavor is pretty similar.  Again, a surprising amount of hops.  I thought the scotch flavor left me with a very dry mouth.
Good Scotch ale.  Pours amber with a thin head.  Aroma is mainly malt.  Flavor of malt, caramel, dark fruit, and some sugar.  Had a lot more body than a normal scotch ale.  Good stuff.

courtesy of frampin.
Pours amber - ruby with mahogany head.
Aroma is biscuity and malty with light roastiness.
Taste, caramel malts, grainy mouthfeel, light chocolate and dark fruits.
Very enjoyable like all Founders beers, and fits the style very well.

almost no head into amber body.  aromas of moderate caramel and moderate citrus and a touch of soap.  flavor is light bittersweet throughout.  long finish duration.  slightly stickly mouthfeel.  pretty darn good.

draft at barleys in greenville. pours a dark red/ruby color with a bubbly tan head and decent lacing. aroma us definitely malt dominated with chestnuts, caramel malt, coffee, and dark fruit. flavors of rye bread, cinnamon, dark malts, and brown sugar that finished with a touch of hops. a very complex beer with a heavy mouthfeel that has a rich flavor. good for a winter night by the fire.

Bottle.  Rough.  I have never had a Scotch Ale quite this burly before.  Almost a tartness to the charcoal and peat that is likely a result of the too-bright red color.  Lacks the velvety texture usually found.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 12 oz bottle, pours dark brown, cannot see through it.  Frothy tan head.  Aroma of brown sugar, malt, and figs, with some slight smoke.  Taste of roasted malt, dark fruit, and brown sugar, with slight hop finish.  Medium to heavy body, with nice carbonation.  Overall, a very nice scotch ale, I would drink more of this!

Update: I got a 1/2 barrel of this for my kegerator, and tapped it tonight.  On draft, I am enjoying this even more!

Clear brown with a thick off-white head. Chocolate and roasty aroma with burnt sugar, toffee and caramel. Super sweet cocoa and chocolate taste. Coffee and roasted malts abound. Pretty damned good, but not really a Scotch Ale.
Clear brown, no head. Smoky, grapey aroma. Fruity flavor at first, then smokey, earthy notes. Stay woodsy and rustic throughout. Nice stuff, very tasty.

Taste 12/8 Bottle. Looks... Dark and clear with a little lacing of the head. Aroma: Malt peat  smoke and a little dark fruit. Taste: MMMM..Really good. Mostly malts. Some smoke  earthy and a little fruit. Can not taste the alcohol.
Pretty durn good.  Finished the last bottle from my sixer last night, and it was even better than the first five.  Creamy, malty, and flavorful.  Scottsmen, light your fires.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Re-rate 4/2/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks zvikar. Reddish deep amber color. Malty, caramelly, alcoholic aroma. Sweet and caramelly malty flavor with some fruits and alcohol. Medium-bodied. 5/3/5/3/10=2.6

(10/20/08) Bottle at Tria in Philadelphia. Dark brown color with a beige head, Aroma of rather smoky malt, some dark fruit notes, some nutty hints and caramel. Sweet flavor, slightly smoky, with artichoke notes, some fruits and a bit of toastiness. Medium to full-bodied. A nice Scotch Ale. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

(11.22.08) 12 oz. bottle: Pours a dark amber with very little light brown head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts and alcohol. Flavor is malty and sweet, with some caramel. Rich, creamy mouthfeel. Solid Scotch ale.

12 oz bottle. Poured fairly clear dark amber in color with a very nice brown head that left no lacing on the glass. Aroma of white bread toast, lightly sweet malt. Tastes of light toffee, chocolate, dark fruits.  Alcohol seemed to be hidden quite well. Not bad.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep brown with gorgeous, ruby-red highlights and a thin, brown head that leaves persistent swirls over the beer and light lacing on the glass. The aroma is bready, toasty, and biscuity with subtle toffee and cocoa, fruity and earthy hops, and dark fruit. The flavor starts big and malty with a delectable malt sweetness that is laden with caramel, toffee, and biscuits. There is a slight dryness and roastiness - subtle coffee and roasted barley. The roasted grain flavors take on a slightly ashy note at mid-palate, and hops and esters enter to form a very nice, complex fruitiness. The bitterness is wonderfully balancing - a little hoppy in the end with a big, sweet, slightly roasty, toasty malt finish. The mouthfeel starts crisp with carbonation and thick. As the CO2 is released (from swirling in the mouth), the texture thickens into a rich and luxurious silk - full-bodied but not syrupy. Overall - a marvelous beer - well-balanced and drinkable. Perfect for cool weather but not so rich, strong, or sweet as to be a "nip bottle only" kind of beer. I don’t think it fits the label of Scotch Ale perfectly - a bit hoppier than one might expect. But it is really, really nice.

deep brown color, fluffy tan head, mild lacing.  aroma of roasty malt.  flavor is chocolate and roasty malt.  the chocolate is not overly sweet.  there is a minor bitterness in the flavor.  medium bodied, dry finish.  quite enjoyable.  luckily, i was forced to buy a 6-pack at ’liquor depot’ in monee.

I was expecting something a little bolder from a beer named Dirty Bastard.  Moderately sweet upfront, with a dry, lingering finish, and a hint of warmth and smokiness closing the show.  Not as complex as I was hoping for.  Less sweet than the Duck Rabbit Scotch Ale, but not as rich.  Good but not upper echelon.

12 oz bottle - Pours a hazy deep amber/red color with tiny, almost non-existant light tan head. Aroma has red grapes, lightly toasted caramel, light chocolate, oak. Flavor is full of chewy malts, caramel, hint of cherry, with a mildly sweet finish. Overall a decent wee heavy style brew.
Smells sweet, malty, and dark fruit maybe raisins. Taste is a little sweet, hops, dark fruits and some alcohol. Would definately drink again.

Bottled, at least a year of age.  Sweet malty nose.  Flavor of sweet caramel malt, dark fruits, raisin, a bit of smoke..mellow.  Reminds me of a sweeter version of an older bigfoot.  First 6 oz were better than the last...

Sweet boozy aroma.  Deep amber-red with about a centimeter of tan head with moderate lacing.
Boozy sweet malty flavor with a slightly bitter bourbon feeling.  
Feels nice in the mouth, not thin, not thick.

Pours deep opaque brown with red on the edge.   No head to speak of.  Aroma of dark caramel and bourbon.  A little frothy, full feel. Bitter heavy malt, warming alcohol.  Trace of piny hops, and acidic grapefruit. Bitter finish.  It’s definitely good, but not totally remarkable in the scheme of things.

nice mahogany pour...thin head. Kind of a woodsy earthy aroma. theres something in the flavor I cant quite pin down. faint licorice flavor. smooth and warming.  The first time I had this I poured half the bottle out. But as someone else has pointed out, your tastes change to amazing degrees.
another fine beer from Founders.

A dark reddish brown ale with a thin creamy reddish moka head. In aroma, a woody vinous aroma, licorice, lactic acids and butterscotch, rich and pleasant. In mouth, a sweet caramel, licorice, raisins, alcohol warmth. This bastard is classy, rich and complex. Early 2007.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Cloudy copper/amber color with a medium tan head. Sweet malty aroma, a nice rich and roasted taste with a hint of caramel and a trace of chocolate in the finish. A nice representation of the style.
[Bottle] shared by lawstudent09. Pours amber/copper with a smallish tan head. Aroma is malty and raisiny, and the flavor matches.

A decent brew...Pour is a cloudy, hazy, brown red that has almost no head.  Aroma is faint in fruits and citrus hops.  Pretty pleasant.  Flavor is malty, caramel and lightly hopped.  Palate is kinda sweet but smooth and a bitter finish.  Not bad but nothing great.

Now that I think about it, this was probably the first craft beer I ever had. I remember one of my bandmembers brought this stuff home, just based on it’s name, and we all hated it. Now after a year of trying new beers, and being turned on to craft brews, I decided to buy another six pack. Well it’s amazing how much change can happen to your palate in a year. This stuff is epic. It pours a very dark reddish brown, and has a small beige head. It’s aroma is strong, with hints of caramel, and apricot. The flavor is deep as well with hints of raisin and licorice. Very good brew from a very good brewer. Cheers!
bottle. has a smokey chocolate aroma. pours a dark brown color with a thin tan head. has a bitter chocolate taste with a hint of coffee. very good aftertaste.

Pours a dark ruby color with a nice tan head. Thick malty and slightly smoky aroma. It is a nice and creamy beer with coffee at the finish and loads of roasted malts in between. It has a sort of burnt flavor to it, but not in excess. Alcohol content is covered up really well. Really good.
Bottle.  Pours a ruby brown body with a tan head.  Big malty beer sweet with caramel malt and raisins.  Some etoh warming, with a nice smokiness.  Lightly hopped and sweet the whole way.
12 oz bottle pour. Nice amber color with a light head. Smoky, almost peaty aroma. Very malty flavor with a hint of smokiness. Fantastic brew.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2008 12 oz. Clear, dark brown with a thin head that tries to last and leaves some spotty lace. Aroma of earthy caramel and light smoke. Flavors of toffee, metallic brown sugar, toast, nuts, light candied apple and earthy smoke. Near-medium body is mostly smooth, a little to the dry side, and lightly warming on the finish.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2009 Bottle. Dark mahogany color, with a thin light tan head. Sweet woody,earthy aroma.Taste changes as it warmes,Caramel,smoke,sweet fruit "like peeches" and a hint of grain. Smooth mouthfeel,nice lacing, sometimes I get a little boozy hint on the finish,but in a good way. Very Solid.

Cloudy reddish amber with little to no head.  The nose is all malty, smoky and sweet with just a hint of hops.  A lot of flavor going on.  Sweet toffee, smoke, nuts, bitter chocolate and caramel.  Nice hop bitterness on the finish.  Covers the entire mouth and the finish stays with you.  Nice beer.

(Bottle, thanks to hopscotch) Pours cloudy, deep reddish brown with nougat colored head. The aroma is rather fruity, hoppy and berry-like with notes of resin, soap, strawberries, oranges, apricots and pineapples alongside malty tones of caramel, toffee, nuts as well as light hints of cookies and milk chocolate. Light smoky and earthy. Bit brown sugary. Some alcohol. The flavour is robust malty with notes of caramel and cookie alongside well balanced tones of fruits and hops. Light smoky, resiny, citric, soapy and earthy. The mouthfeel is soft, almost velvety with a light sticky touch. The finish is peppery and a bit numbing. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium bodied. Nice.

Bottle poured into glass; Pours out dark, thick, with very minimal head that lasts throughout the beers entirety.  I get a strong sense of caramel malt from the beers aroma.  Flavor of malted caramel with a little toffee.  Finishes bitter with a very nice hint of scotch.  Good beer.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: Draft from the Federal.  Deep, hazy amber pour... dark but nice orange/brown color; lovely light yellow/tan head.  Creamy and thick on top of the beer with good lacing throughout.  Great balance of hops and malt throughout.  Caramel, toffee, and bitter hops on the nose.  Definitely more malt up front.  A little bit of peat and not as much smoke or peat as I hoped, but a vague spiciness, possibly from the hops.  Good crisp bitter finish.  Remembered liking this more last time I had it.  Still, quite solid, though.
bottle.  a nice tasting ale.  great flavor and some kick  - rudy/amber color with a smooth finish

Draft at Flying Saucer. Cloudy, mostly opaque beer, like a hazy maple syrup. Sweet boozy nose with some nice nuttiness and a lot of malt. Really complex flavors of caramel, toffee, smoke, alcohol. It’s far from refreshing, more of a slow drinking beer worth complemplating. Tasty stuff.

Bottle.  A beautiful walnut brown pour with a decent tan head.  Aroma of bitter dark chocolate with toffee and coffee.  Peat, smoke, dark chocolate and roasted malt in the falvor, and some hoppiness.  Good mouthfeel.  Short finish.  Excellent brew from the fine folks at Founders.

Hazy opaque red brown pour with a thin white head.  Nutty malt aroma.  Some roast as well.  Bitter chocolate and caramel malt flavor with almost a smokiness and lots of bitter hops to finish.  Very dry without any sweetness, but balanced.  Alcohol lingers a bit on tongue.

12oz bottle:  Pours cloudy brown with an orangish-tint.  Slight to no-head.  Sweet roasted aroma with hints of caramel and toffee.  Lots of caramel and some smokiness initially.  Finishes hoppy and slightly dry.  Medium body and good carbonation...this beer is well balanced and goes down very smoothly.  I’ll definitely pick this one up again.

Bottle acquired through Sparky27...ERIC, you da man!!!  Butterscotch candy color with a nice 1/2 inch pale yellow head.  Smell is quite sweet and sugary.  Caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and even a touch of hops.  Flavor is roasted malt and all of the flavors that accompany it...the mild citrus bite is evident in the finish.  Syrupy and good...great on pancakes and waffles!!!

Pours a reddish brown in color.  Theres a nice half inch of beige head sitting atop after the pour.  It quickly recedes to a ring of froth.  Smell is wonderful.  Very incredible malts and a nice scotch like, peaty scent.  Taste is more velvety smooth malt.  Some toffee and some liquor like qualities.  Very smooth with just a hint of hop bite at the end.  Incredible beer.  No hint of the ABV while drinking.  I could drink this all the time.

Bottle.  Hazy caramel  color with a tan head.  Toffee and caramel nose, toast, alcohol as it warms.  Roasty malt flavor, brown sugar, tiny bit of smoke and chocolate.  Light bitter hops.  Slightly metallic finish.  Easy drinking for ABV.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy dark amber with a 2 finger light tan head and spotty lacing.  Nose is caramel, brown sugar and alcohol.  Taste is smoke, roasted malt, caramelized sugar, bitter dark chocolate and some hoppy alcohol bite in the finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Not bad at all.

(bottle) I’ve had samples of this beer at tastings before, but didn’t rate it because I didn’t think I could give it an honest rating.  Pours chestnut brown with a thin beige head and sticky lacing.  The aroma is incredibly complex, with each sniff producing a new scent.  Scents of chocolate, peat, banana, bubblegum, light mint, bread, vanilla,  and some toasty malt as well.  The aroma becomes increasingly peaty as the beer warms.  The taste is very malty sweet with toffee, peat, chocolate, banana,and bread. The sweet flavors then switch to a smoky, lightly bitter finish that reminds me of some bittersweet dark chocolate.  The palate is incredibly smooth and rich with a perfect amount of carbonation.  I’m glad I bought a bottle of this, and could see myself purchasing more in the future.

On tap at the crunkleton in chapel hill. Pours a dark brownish red with a small off-white head. Nose is sweet with a bit of chocolate, roast, coffee, toffee, hops,  and a bit of peat. Flavor is similar with a bit of alcohol showing.  This beer was nice but overall a bit too sweet for my tastes.  Not a huge fan of the style to begin with.

Dense and breadlike, almost reminiscent of kvass. Wonderful notes of chocolate, coffee, and mocha dominate with a smooth, surprisingly short finish that leaves the palate with a distinctly anise flavor. Wonderful on a cool autumn evening!
Poured cloudy dark brown. Aroma - Malty, smokey. Taste - sweet roast malt, peat smoke and caramel. Some bitterness as it warms.

bottle .. deep amber pour, small off white head ,no lace. aroma of caramel,
roasted malt and a touch of peat.very malty .caramel ,brown sugar, toffee and smoke flavors. light bitterness ,medium bodied ,slick and sweet

Pours brown with a tan head.  Lots of caremel malt in the aroma and taste.  The hops show up right off the bat with some flowery bitterness, but fade and the sweetness comes through in the end.   Good stuff.

On tap at the Fed. in Durham, NC. Dark red color with a finger’s worth of tan head. Very malty in the aroma department with a bit of peatiness and brown sugar. Tons of caramel flavor and brown sugar. Light smoke in the finish. Very very very sweet. Thick mouthfeel. Good beer.

very dark amber pour with a smooth head.  Aroma was nice.. first taste was not what I expected.  Very nice - I have had some Scottish Ales and didn’t expect much here.  Very complex taste with new flavors in every sip.  Aftertaste is good as well.. nice carbonation gives it a full feel in the mouth

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 My first Founders courtesy Alraomon. 12 oz. bottle. Thank you Sean! Red pour with a small head and floaties. Caramel aroma with brown sugar, toffee and subtle bitter notes. Taste is toffee, slight bitterness and subtle peat notes. Medium bodied. Awesome beer.

20080830  12oz bottle RB Spirits. Cola brown with lasting tan head.  Aroma is earthy, dirty, mulch...okay peat.  It’s a bit of a turnoff but it’s rated highly enough I fiugured I should give it a shot.  Sweet with sticky malts, chocolate notes, more detritus.  Pretty hot.  Meh...I could do without scotch ales.
A great scotch ale and pours with little head. Bitterness in the aftertaste with little hint of the alcohol content. Great with food or as an evening treat.
12oz bottle. Pours dark ruby brown with a moderate-sized mocha head. Has an aroma and flavor of malts with dark fruits and bittersweet chocolate. Alcohol is well hidden.

When you talk about hop bombs this isn’t it. but if you want to talk about a malt bomb you came to the right place. pours ruby brown with barely any head to speak of. Aromas of roasted malts lots of different malts 10 in fact,also aromas of alcohol and smoke, taste is of alcohol, malts, toffee, and peat. the harsness of the alcohol tames as beer warms and relaxes to a warm caramel  sweetness but laddie be careful cause this brew has a kick with 8.3 ABV content

12oz bottle. This is a nice style. Pours a deep copper color with a thin light tan head. Has a sweet malt aroma. Flavor is malty sweet with the bitterness to back it. A liitle dry but smooth. A medium to full body beer. A good beer.

12oz bottle. Pours murky, dark, caramelly brown with a thin light brown head. Smells malty fruity sweet, some alcohol, some dish towel. Tastes malty and less sweet than it smells. A bit of cereal malt flavor as well. Medium body, subdued carbonation.
lots of deep roasted malty aroma flavor is of malt bittersweet chocolate nice balance of earthy hops very great tasting wish it was available in florida

This is pretty much the best american Scotch Ale you’re going to find. Gorgeous dark red pour. Big nose, Huge, malty, smokey flavor. Especially pleasing if you love scotch whiskey. Alcohol is nicely hidden. A staple for the style.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Dark ruby, hazy, with almost no head, slight ring.  Peaty grass, earthy brown sugar aroma.  Brown sugar dark fruit mild peat and grass flavor with mild underlying bitterness and some lingering fruity sweetness.  Medium-full body and too little carbo.  Something happened that killed the carbo on this.  Too bad.  Otherwise an excellent beer.

Poured from bottle to English pint glass.
Reddish-brown in color with thin head.
Aroma of malt and peat.  Good, solid
taste of malt with a little hoppy bite to it
as well.  Not as much peat in the taste
as other Scotch ales I’ve had...not a 
complaint, but an observation.  A very
good beer worth seeking out.
poured from the bottle.  wonderful dark fruit, primarily plum and raisin.  very, very smooth palate.  a truly awesome american beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a thin mocha-colored head.  Aroma is sweet and malty, with scents of dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, roasted malt, and a bit of wood and smoke.  Taste is medium-bodied, with initial flavors of caramel and roasted malt giving way to a long, sweet finish of molasses, syrupy hops, and warming alcohol.  A solid scotch ale -- strong in flavor, but not overwhelming.

Poured a ruddy brown with a thin, quickly dissipating cream head.  Aroma is peat, caramelized sugar, and dark roasted malt.  Flavor is light and citrusy, like the first icy lemonade of summer.  No, not really.  More like the concentrated essence of a wood paneled den full of leather, scotch, cigar smoke and academic one-upmanship.  Smooth malt, peat, molasses sweetness, with a surprisingly hoppy finish.  Alcohol only shows up as it warms, and is remarkably well-hidden. Medium mouthfeel, but very drinkable despite its complexities. High-larious brewers notes alone makes it worth seeking out a bottle.

Bottle courtesy Gillard. Pours a dark amber brown with a small light tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, sweet malt, caramel, and a hint of smoke. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness and smooth alcohol. Very good.
Pours deep brown with moderate foamy head that holds.  Fruity aroma and similar taste and sweet.  Nice velvety mouthfeel and complex taste.  Very enjoyable.

Lakewood, Oh. - Rozis Fine Wines - 12 oz bottle, Murky dark brown pour with a quickly fading off-white head. Heavy aroma of figs, toffee, a hint of chocolate. Flavor is hearty with raisins. toffee, figs, a hint of chocolate in the back end. Very tasty, chewy, complex, but deceptively drinkable. Mouthfeel is thick, creamy and coats your mouth. Excellent, as is most from this brewer.
Deep dark redish pour.  peaty sweet aroma.    Tastes of peat, bitter hops, and subtle sweet malts.  a little odd.  but not bad.

deep garnet and brown pour with a small head. aroma is malty, with some sweet hints and a touch of smoke. flavor has some peat, not too complex, but also has the malt, plus a little hop bitterness. Palate is nice, smooth with a nice intriguing aftertaste. Interesting for a scotch ale, but a nice brew.

12-oz. Thanks, Ben! Crystal clear dark brown with ruby highlights. Thin gray rim and swirls. No lace but shows some legs. Rich roasted peat mid-palate. Brown sugar and notes of cream. Long, spicy, peppery finish. This is the most complex of a fairly serious lineup of scotch ales tonight. Great stuff. Wish I could get it all the time.
Pours like an ale from the tap, but tastes almost creamy, like a stout, on the palate with the distinct taste of peat.  Finishes with the bitterness of hops.  Very unique beer.

Tap.  Dark burgundy with an off-white head.  I got some hops in the nose but balanced firmly malt.  Full bodied with a lot of sweetness then a slight bitterness and alcohol.  Not my favorite style but I liked  it.

THOUGHTS: Nice beer, but nothing really special. Hid alcohol well. I still prefer real scotch ales since they don’t have the smokiness since it wasn’t true to the country’s style. Surprised a beer with this high of an ABV is their flagship.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark orangey red with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was light to moderate caramel malt, light milk chocolate, cherry and smoke. The initial flavor was moderately sweet, and lightly acidic and bitter; while the finish was lightly sweet and acidic, and moderately bitter with and average duration. It was very smokey with some caramel malt. The medium body was sorta syrupy with soft to tingly carbonation and light astringent finish. When it warmed there was also a light alcoholic finish.
On tap in NJ. An almost perfect example of a Scotch Ale.  Big alcohol number, but not overwhelming to taste.  Huge malt arooma and taste.  A classic.
Poured brown with red highlights and a dense tan head.  Aroma was all about the malt.  Flavor was caramel and chocolate with nice mouthfeel.

Just as the commercial description states this beer definitely has "hints of smoke and peat paired with a malty richness". I didn’t notice the "good bit of hop attidude" though. Nevertheless, this beer was VERY good - definitely one of the best scotch ales I’ve ever had.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 12 oz. bottle - thanks to kyrptic for the trade; pours dark brown with reddish glow; clear along the edges with thin tan head and minor lacing; dirty, musky aromas with sugary malts and zesty lemon; almost a sour touch to it; light texture and slightly light on the flavors, but very tasty nevertheless; strong, but drinkable

Scotland conquers Belgium and the Netherlands. There is a lot to offer here. The malts taste Dutch, the yeast Belgium and the Scotch, Scotch. Pours an amber red with a mustard head. A little smokey and bold hops.  All around pretty special.

its easy to become so jaded that one thinks that entire styles are not for their personal pallete, until you encounter something that blasts those preconceptions to smithereens and you realize the sky is the limit! the aroma on this clobbers you over the head, the stench of ingrediients that have been painstakingly worked into something nearly ambrosia like.  still, this beer makes no bones about its strength, its certainly detectable and to me seems even underrated but i can easily envision the pallete of another having trouble with the booze factor in this one (typical for the style in my experience).  wonderful dark ruby color gives way to coffee and other porter like characteristics but without the outright roast of that style.  smoke comes up front in the finish which is what steers this away from the stout category, mouthfeel and aftertaste linger seemingly forever.  this is very intense and pretty impressive!

12 oz bottle that pours ruddy brown with a tan head...mild sweet malts and a tinge of floral hops on the nose...also a metallic earthy scent...a slight stickiness left on the lips--bitter and smooth at the same time..its got some metal in the mouth as well...bitter citrus finish---and some flavor left in my mouth that tastes like warm milk...as it sits, some bitter toffee shows up in the finish mostly....it packs a sweet buzz, and it really creeps up on you..:)

I have to rate this one again. Good body with a layer of rather ashy cigarette smokiness which dissipates within a rich malty mix that has a chewable texture to it. Some dark fruits in here and overall a very drinkable andwell balanced beer. I didnt like scotch ales before this one hit me.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2016 Rerate June 2, 2016.  12 oz bottle.  A deep ruby red pour with sparse fine particles and an off-white head.  Sweet red and green grape/raisin aroma, ripe dark fruit, molasses.  Raisin and dark fruit flavor, molasses, anise, earthy peated malt.  This is a huge part of my regular rotation these days, so it must be doing something right, and Ive meant to do a rerate for quite some time, so here it is.  Really, really good stuff.  Available, affordable, high quality, and it adds some good variety to my routine.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark red brown with lots of tan foam and a bit of debris. Aroma is sweet, raisin or grape, caramel, bready. Flavor is sweet caramel, raisiny, a bit of dark chocolate, with a little pleasant alcohol bite. A very nice and interesting beer. Flavor seems slightly out of balance, which is what stops this beer from hitting the 4.0 mark for me. 8/3/8/4/16/3.9
Sexy name.  Sexy color.  Sexy brew.  Molasses up front, but a dry hoppy finish balances this beautifully.  Havent had much luck with Scotch Ales in the past, but this one rocks.

Bottle from Canals in Princeton.  Pours a clear deep mahogany with a relatively small medium beige head.  Aroma of toffee, cocoa and malt.  Similar flavors with some caramel, vanilla and just a touch of smoke.  Watery and flat texture and not much of a finish.  Maybe Im being a little harsh on this one - its a good beer, well-balanced and drinkable but I was expecting something special (and Im still longing for another Three Floyds Robert The Bruce).

ABV: 8.3%
RateBeer rating: 94
Calories: estimated at 175 C
Volume: 12 fl oz.
Glass: thistle, shaker
Purchased at: Canals Discount Liquors, Burlington, NJ (Thanks, Mike!)
Price: $1.89
Consumed at: home

Tanka: Chocolate surprise

mellow red white wisps
deep cocoa and caramel
long bitter and burnt
chocolate on whole wheat toast
when can I have another?

aroma 10 out of 10
visuals 4 out of 5
taste 10 out of 10
palate 5 out of 5
overall 18 out of 20
Mild hop and malt aroma. Clean dark brown with a slight red tint.  Very little tan head.  A very good Scothch ale with just a tad more hop than I prefer.

Finally in NJ. Bottle. 

Pours a dark, red that looks like a cedar water in a creek. Can definitely get a whiff of alcohol by the smell. Surprisingly smooth drinking (but felt heavy), with some very sweet notes. Finish can get a bit edgy for my tastes.

!2 oz bottle
Coupled with the main course was this release.  After a few starters it was hard to get through this one.  Despite taking it easy a beer this heavy can sink in the stomach.  I would love to try it again on its own and on a fairly empty stomach to fully appreciate it.  This is a solid beer instead of just one with a earcatching name.
Aroma / Appearance - The deep ruby red body swirled around the glass leaving a slight layer of film along the sides.  Black cherries, peat, wet earth and dark malts formed a thick grouping that almost choked the senses.  While not the richest beer I could have spent plenty of time admiring it.
Flavor / Palate - A slight bitterness washes along with warmth and chocolately tones.  Peat and earth come next.  The dry finish leaves one refreshed and full.  A little heavy for a warm day this might be nice on a cool fall evening.

Draught at Circa 6/6/08. I dont see this beer as red or ruby at all, I held it up to the light and got a pure brown for sure.  A beautiful brown, but not the scarlet red of a porter in front of a light bulb.

Definitely can taste the heat of the alcohol, some smoke and peat, would make a perfect chaser for a big snifter of Lagavulin 16.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 12oz bottle.  Weak tan head that dicipated rather quickly.  Deep ruby amber red when held up to the light, though more like motor oil sitting in my glass.  Almost as thick as oil too.  Malty and earthy aroma, as is the taste.  Very rich and thick feel, with high toasted and roasted flavors with caramel sweetening the hops.  Im not a big fan of scotish ales, too thick and gooey for me.
A heavy dark chocolate colored beer, with a light brown head.very rich and a creamy mouthfeel. This beer had a whiskey taste in the finish. Lots of sweet malted flavors.

12oz bottle.  Pours deep brown with a ruby hue.  Some light lacing came with the small beige head.  The nose reminded me of a lighter version of Angels Share (not sure why).  Lots of chocolate and toasted malt on the palate, creamy finish.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 12 ounce bottle. I have had this one before but was really excited to try it again. Pours a beautiful deep mahogany color with a small off-white color head. The aroma consists of a LOT of caramel malts with hints of dried fruits, and hops. The taste was a wonderful mix of caramel, dried fruits, and mild hops with a slight lingering of alcohol. It was medium bodied and stuck to my mouth making me want more. Finished very smooth with a good lingering taste. I really enjoyed this beer! I wish I could have this one on a daily basis...

Dark red and brown color - short creamy head - mild aroma - slightly smokey and coffee flavor. Smooth finish for a Scottish Ale. I gave it extra points for the alcohol content because it is hard to believe that it is 8.3 ABV for such a smooth Ale.

Deep red pur with thinnish off white head. Looks a bit like unfiltered cranberry juice, which is kinda unique. Nose is a little faint, but definately had some nice malt characteristics along with a touch of smoke. Flavor is nice caramel sweetness, though not overpowering, along with a mild fruit and smoke combo. Hops add enough bitterness to be balancing but not dominating. Very nice beer.

Pours coke caramel with a smallish white head.  Aroma of toffee, coffee, and whisky.  Flavor a woody mix of sweet and whisky alcohol.  Fairly warming on the finish.  A nice beer, but Im not blown away. Doesnt hold up with Old Chub or Wee Heavy.

Aroma: Dark malts, vodka-like alcohol, and some deep, slightly obscured estery hops. Sweetness of brown sugar or molasses.

Appearance: Dark red wine to coffee color, glows sunny crimson along the bottom edge. Coffee-stained peachy head; volatile with poor retention.

Flavor: Lots of coffee, woody and floral hops, quite nicely bittered, actually. Toasty flavors. Not as buttery or peaty as Id expect from a Scotch ale... a unique take on the style. Alcohol sweetness is very present, like dark rum.

Palate: Cloying at times. Not full-bodied enough to warrant the stickiness - it should be a little more crisp or else a little less light.

Overall: Not my favorite Scotch ale, but pretty drinkable. Id rather have a Belhaven.
Lots of smooth, chocalaty malts. A little thin on the pallate. Didnt seem to quite as balanced as say, Old Chub. Still a decent scotch ale for sure.

One of the better Scotch Ales Ive had. Pours a dark ruby reddish brown with a good amount of frothy head. Notes of smoke, wood (seems to be oak) and ends on a dry note. Very good - I would get this again.

Malty and grainy. Quite a lot of bitter without the chocolate malt. A good bit of hop bitterness without a lot of the citrus and herbal aromas. Lots of crystal malts. A bit smoky and peaty. Very heavy mouthfeel. A very formidable beer but a bit overrated on this site in my opinion.

Great Beer, Usually not a scotch ale fan, because they tend to be too sweet. Yet this Ale was very Nice, Smooth, and a pleasant scotch flavor.
Hints of chocolate, coffee, not sweet, yet not overly hoppy.
Had a slight alcohol finish, probably just the scotch flavor coming more full at the end.

Overall: Really good Scotch Ale, would have another again soon.

Founders is quickly becoming my favorite brewery. My only complaint about this one is it didnt pour much of a head. This is not the usual cloyingly sweet scotch ale that you find. Many layers of flavor here with mocha, caramel, and especially molasses dominating the palate. Theres some rich earthiness too, and enough bittering hops to balance out the sweet malt without making it too bitter or detracting from the malt.

Found this on tap thanks to Vinatage in Boardman, Ohio.

A deep chestnut brown with a nice tan head, the lace clinging to the glass as it was consumed.

Smelled of coffe and toasted malts.

Tasted of the toasted malts and coffee, as well as some hops.

Great carbonation level, not to much or too little, smooth going down with no negative after taste.

Went down smooth, a very drinkable brew that Im glad I tried.

Serving type: on-tap

Nice peaty earthy malt flavor.  Not a big hop presence in the back, but something there to balance and contribute a nice mossy earthy flavor.  Toffee is big.  Lots of malt but not too sweet.  Very well balanced.  The flavors are pretty big and strong.  Palate is pretty good, carbonation gives it a little creaminess, but a little more weight on the tongue couldnt hurt.  I might like a little more complexity in here, but the flavors are nice.  Well made for the style.
Very good! The best beer of this style i have ever had. Alot going on in the flavor and aroma of this one. Well done. Thanks mark.

cherry and beer and alcohol. clean old and pleasant -dirty bastard- uuhhh ok! beautiful ruby amber color. light beige head malt and hop with a clean finish. this brew is candy sweet. quite good! nice considerably consistancy.

Bottle.  Pours a deep caramely brown, hazy, with a thin offwhite head.  The aroma was sweet and caramely with notes of brown sugar.  Taste is sweet, thick caramel with a touch of alcohol at the back of the throat.  Thick on the palate.

Pours transparently; body of volcanic, glowing burgundy with wispy lacing.  Aroma of burly pit fruits and strawberry candies; a pure and decadent but still soft note of scotch whiskey dripping with peat smoke and pillowy tobacco character.  So rich, generous, and simple.  Flavor is not especially dark but very deep, giving hints of peat, charred raisins, and raspberries to speckle the body of viscous maple, dark honey, scotch, and milk chocolate.  A tower of carefully polished malt complexity.  Medium to full palate is luxuriously silky with a distant sparkle of carbonation; finish is semisweet chocolate and caramel before turning tannic and bitter like a blend of a muscley shiraz and dry citrusy hops.  First rate example; just immaculately made.

A fine example of scotch ale.  Strong, complex, but clean.

The pour is a deep amber with very little head.  The aroma is intense--caramel, hops, and smoke.  The flavor follow suit, with a very noteable earthiness and an apparent, but not overpowering sweetness.  Finished bitter and quite clean.

Excellent, excellent brew.

Powerful roasted malt jumps out at in the first sip.  It is also full of dark fruit, coffee, smoke, and a hint of tart hop as a nice undertone.  This is a complex and thoroughly enjoyable beer.   You have got to love the attitude!

Dirty Bastard is complex in the finish with hints of smoke and peat paired with a malty richness, finalized with a good bit of hop attitude.
Sneaky at 8.5% ABV.
Tasty with a andouille sausage and greens dinner.
Shared a bottle with a neighbor.
From the tap poured dark brown with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.
Bottle:  Poured a dark brown with not a lot of head.  The aroma malty, very malty.  The flavor was sweet malty caramel with some dry hopped smoke added.  Overall, this beer was ok.

From Bottle @ The Drafting Room. Poured dark caramel. Light brown fizzy head. Aroma of grass. Flavor sweet caramel, roasty, and grassy.  Nice sugar cane lingering aftertaste.  Smooth mouth feel. Medium bodied.
Tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee. Reddish brown with a thin head, caramelized malty flavors, rich, earthy, somewhat sweet
At Three Cellars tasting Founders Brewery night.  Reddish brown with a thin head.  Sweet malty aroma.  Sweet malty taste to go with dry hop finish.  A little on the sweet side but still pretty good.

Caramelized malt aromas.  Amber brown colors.  Good bitter caramelized malty flavors, rich, earthy, somewhat sweet to balance.  Fairly strong and solid palate.  Bittersweet duration with a woody finish.  Good.
Pours a dark amber with a small dark tan head. Aroma of caramel, smoke, and some brown sugar. Starts out with a nice sweetness, but there is a lingering bitterness that I dont care for.
Poured a dark auburn color with a very small head that disappeared quickly. Mild aroma. Sweet carmel taste, but sweetness did not linger. Very smooth, belying strength.
Poured a brick color with a sweet nose of malts, caramel, peat and wood.The flavor was sweet and smoky. A very good Scotch Ale.Finishes of sweet.

Reddish brown body, dark, slightly cloudy at the end, almost no head.  Nose of dark roasted malts, peat smoke, and warming alcohol.  Taste of dark malts, an almost Bourbon like alcohol warmth, toffee, espresso, smoke, and more hops than I would expect in a Scotch ale.  Mouth a little syrupy ... maybe more lively carbonation would help.  But a good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2008 Bottle pours a deep garnet color with very little head or lace.  The aroma is powerful malt, brown sugar, chocolate, vanilla, peat, and just plain excellent.  The flavor is really is so well rounded from the sweet malt and peat notes.  Some mild pear notes in the finish with the peat.  The palate is fairly rich, but does not at all become sticky like ales like this can tend to do.  Carbonation survives pretty well and is quite lively in fact.  Overall, this is an awesome beer.  I need to get more of this.

12oz bottle shared by robert. Nice brown rustic color, small head. Aroma was really sweet: it had sugar, malt, smoke, and some raison maybe. Flavor was really good: Smoke, sugar, a little vanilla, malt and some hops thrown in. All blended very well. Texture was medium and went down smoothly. This is one of the better scoth ales out there.
Pours dark crimson with a quickly receding orange head. Smokey malt aroma. Smokey, vanilla, black licorice, and a little chocolate note. Very complex, good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 The body is a dark chestnut color with crimson hues.  A small, foamy, light tan head settles to a thin film with a small edge.  Soapy lacing mostly rejoins the body.  Aromas are rich and malty, with a strong bourbon presence, tons of oaky vanilla, dark caramel, chocolate, and smoked peat.  It smells truly fantastic, and the flavor follows right behind.  Warming, peaty scotch notes blend well with the rich caramel and chocolate.  Theres a moderate earthy hoppiness that works together with the peat as well.  Vanilla is a primary highlight flavor.  Medium-full bodied, this one goes down just a little hot and finishes sweet and sticky.  This is a great scotch ale that, might even top its big brother, the Backwoods Bastard.  Great brew.
A great scotchy malty aroma with a little smoke. Has a nice flavor, a bit of graininess in the finish. Quite nice.
Founders is fast becoming one of my favorite breweries. This beer is very nice. Beautiful color with a small head. Sweet taste with a bitter finish leaves you wanting another.

Vinous, chocolatey, malty aromas. Color is sort of ruby or raisin, depending on thickness. Not much head at all. Some smokiness comes out. Near full bodied with creamy carbonation. Some heat, some toffee, and swear theres a chocolate note. Some dark fruit aspects. Theres a fair amount going on with this. The finish is a mite malty, but there is some helpful hop. Damn impressive drink.

one of my all time favorites...finally got around to rating it...

really malty, but lacks that sticky sweetness that can be there...good hop bitterness to balance out...
Pours a hazy brown color. Aroma of of sweet malts and some nuts? Tastes very sweet hiding the alcohol very well.
Poured a  ruby plum color. Smokey malt aroma. very pronounced alcohol.,was ok but a bit disappointing as a Scottish Ale. Tough finish. Will try again

Finally got around to trying this one.  What a mistake I should have much earlier.  Do not be scared by the high alcohol.  It has a great balance with alcohol and sweetness which make it dangerously drinkable.

Pours brownish red with a thick off white head. Aroma is thick and smoky malt with some sweetness. Taste has a little peat smoke in it with lots of malt. A sneaky strong beer, too. Somewhat like an 80 or 90 shilling style ale, but with a bit more carbonation. Finishes a little thick, but overall pretty nice.

nice dark brown color but the thin tan head only lasted a few seconds. smells very sweet and slightly smoky, sort of like a good bock. taste is sickly sweet and cloying. feels smooth and sticky going down. finishes a little bitter and some of that smoke finally emerges in the flavor. not terrible but if you are going to call it a Scotch ale it should at least have some earthy/smoky complexity.

Small but dense beige-brown head over hazy, opaque chestnut beer. Sweet, maltsyrup nose, but with touches of both hops and alcohol. Sweet rum cake, laced with hops and raisins. Quite roasted, too. Hopped & roasted, as a cake that has been thouroughly baked on the outside, becoming bitter-burnt, hiding the sweetness inside. A bit syrupy, affirmed by the MF. It is pulling a bit in two directions, ending a bit irresolute. Well bodied. Again undecided syrupy - thinner. Alcohol obvious, even some fusels. Especially the aftertaste betrays resins, whilst the smokiness spoken of, is very tardy in coming in the open. Nice, if undecided beer.  Thanks to Eric from BA!

In short: A nice easy to drink hoppy scotch ale.
How: Bottle 12oz, 6+ months old
The look: Cloudy dark burgundy body with a short-lived tan head.
In long: Nose of barley candy and tobacco.  Taste has lots barley candy, some residual sugar, some kind of spicy liquorice and a light berry flavour.  Very little fruity flavours.  Pleasant body but certainly not a thick decadent scotch ale.  A bit oily.  A lot more hoppy than average for the style but Im in the minority who prefers hoppy scotch ales.  Tasty resinous oily citrusy hops makes it highly drinkable.  Alcohol is apparent but doesnt detract from the drinkability.  This is like a session scotch ale.  Not often that I come across a dirty bastard that I find very sweet.

Sept. 2006 - I have to say, I did actually enjoy this beer more than the rating indicates.  However, for style, this was a stinker.  Beer poured with dark brown color with next to a little head and small lacing.  The aroma was smoky...a lot more so than the flavor.  The flavor was curiously devoid of smoke and earthiness, but abounding in candy flavor and caramel.  Rich creamy mouthfeel was the highlight of this one. Some hops were definitely noticeable.  If you are hankering for a scottish ale, this isnt your beer, though...and for that, it gets a big BOOOO!

Poured a thick dark golden with a small off-white head.  Had a ton of malt in taste including a sweet toffee character.  There was also a bit of hop character in the taste which confused me a little.  Just seemed like a bit of hops for a scotch ale.  Dont get me wrong, it still tasted great and Id probably buy it again.

This has a distinct smooth flavor for the people that prefer ales over I.PA.s .  Does have a sharp after taste from the hops, however it does hold down quite well.  Great for a social drinker wanting to experiment with new measures, but drink wisely. The 8.3% alcohol leaves more than to be desired.

This is one of my favorite Scottish Ales, and theyre my favorite.  The aroma is caramely, malty, slightly toasty and slightly alcoholic.  It has a wonderful Scotch Ale color.  The flavor matches the style while still incorporating hops more than many other Scotch Ales.  The palate is smoother though still retains a gritty heaviness.  Overall.......YEAH!!!  I LOVE IT.  GREAT JOB FOUNDERS.
Clear garnet with a thin head. Nice smell of smoked and peat malts. Med/heavy body. Good malty sweet, smoked, earthy flavor with a mild hop flaver to finish. Very good scotch ale here. 32606
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Listen kids. Do as I say and not as I do. Do not pour firmly with this one unless you want a six inch head. 

Pours dark brown with a tan head that is massive from way too firm a pour. Nose is a mass of complexity. Definite malts here. Caramel, wood tones, and just a good amount of things to take in. Flavor is pretty meaty with a consistent wood character going on. Thick caramel sweetness is there as well. Nice and robust. It seems like I am getting a small amount of alcohol on the flavor though. Feel has a decent carbonation and a smooth liquid feel. Overall pretty good. Nice and hearty and pretty rustic. I cant say it is really lacking, but I cant say it is the smoothest of the style I have ever had.
Aroma is pretty solid. A lot of resiny scents, sweet and a hint of smoke. Taste is clean and smooth, sweet, no bitterness but has that smoke to balance it nicely. Very good.

Pours very dark ruby with less than a finger of rapidly dissipating head.  Smell is sweet, honey and raisin.  Taste is really rich and complex, with raisin, oatmeal, and just a hint of smoke accompanying the slight hop bitterness of the aftertaste.  This is a beer that lingers- I really like it.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 I was really let down by this one. Ive been wanting some Founders, because they are rated highly and some of their brews sound delicious...but this one wasnt it. Very nice and complex aroma and appearance, full of roasty malts, carmel, hops, and smoke. But taste wise is where this one fell apart for me. Tastes thick in some places, thin in others. Very sticky and syrupy on the back end, and the alcohol seemed to get int he way of the flavor. Almost tasted like someone threw several different brews into a blender, topped off with orange juice, vodka, and maple syrup, mixed and served.  Not my cup of tea, but I cant wait to try some of Founders other brews.
Had on draft at the Brew Kettle. Poured a dark ruby. Beautiful! Smelled a bit like smokey honey. Taste was sweet roasted caramel, malts and grass. I enjoyed this one immensely.
Bottle. Good hop aroma, quite sweet, hint of dust and a fruity spiciness. Dark red brown colour, very small head. Roasted flavour, also quite sweet. Good dustiness.
12oz bottle.  Reddish- brown color.  Aroma of malt.   Flavor is of bitterness and malt.  Slight smoke, nice toasty malt.  Smooth.  Creamy.  Lingering bitterness.
Pours a brown with a hint of red.  Small head that continues with a ring around the glass.  No lacing.  Deep malt aroma.  Nothing but malt.  Hint of tobacco and a almost barleywine character.
Delicious. One of the tastiest and sweetest scotch ales ive ever tasted. Dark and rich. Smells like sweet coffee and a fruity hint. Not very heavy. Alcohol is not prevelent in the taste.
Tastes like a waterdown black coffee.  Good beer if planning on drinking a whole six pack.  Not flavorful enough for me.  No aftertaste.  Texture was watery.
Nice!  Dark amber color with a nice head.  Complex malty flavor with a hint of alcohol and toffee/caramel.  From the bottle.
Bottle.  Sweet barley malt aroma.  Cloudy orange-brown color with small head.  Sweet malt and light alcohol/bitter finish.  A very smooth and easy drinking scotch ale.
Shared a bottle with 3 others.  Nice reddish brown color.  Tastes a bit like a Heath bar, only not as sweet or chocolatey.

Ruby red color with a cream colored head leaving spotty lacing around the glass. Toffee, brown sugar, malted milk balls in the nose. Malted milk balls up front followed by toffee in the finish, only a bit of hop presence. Average carbonation and medium bodied. Wasnt very drinkable, split the bottle. Perhaps I will try it again to see if I got a bad bottle or if I will like it better.
Liquid GHB, clear your schedule if you plan to drink more than one or two.  Im not a lightweight just something about this beer knocks you out.

Really beautiful pour- brown with amber highlights and two fingers of tan head.  Strong grainy aroma with notes of smoke, peat, caramel, and molasses.  Flavor is also grain and peat, with hints of sweet caramel, floral hops, strawberry, and some nice nuttiness and smoke in the finish.  Thick sticky palate.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2008 Deep chestnut in color with minimal white head. Banana bread aroma gets solventy as it warms, and carries through into the flavor.  Roasty and bitter with a burnt caramel edge.  Biterness lingers after finish.  $2.5/12oz
12 oz bottle. Pours a dark red with a tan head. ksmells of smoke, dark fruits and alcohol. Taste of alcohol, malts, carmels and toffe.Finsih is alcohol. Definitly a sipper.

Bottle pours a dark garnet with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, smokey peat and a wiff of alcohol.  Flavor long on that rich smokey note with a mix of caramel/toffee /brown sugar, earthy finish with a warming alcohol influence.
Very dark brown body with a very small head.  Lots of chocolate malt and a bit of booze on the bouquet.  Tons of chocolate flavor as well.

Thanks dra19!  The color was a deep ruby.  The head was thin, off-white, and creamy.  The aroma was sweet malt, dark fruit, and alcohol.  The flavor was alcohol, sweet malt, dark fruit, some hopps, and some spice.  The palate was medium/thick bodied.  The finish was warm and long-lasting

Thanks to kryptic for this bottle. Red pour with thick tan head. Great lacing. Smoked malts with coffee and bittering hops. Taste is rich with nice malts and peaty flavors. Finish is clean and slightly bitter.

12oz bottle- pours a hazy reddish brown color with a creamy tan head. Lacing lingers on the glass. Some alcohol noted in the taste along with caramel and malts. Pretty easy to drink and could have another. My first Scotch ale and it will not be my last. Very well done Founders.

This scotch ale poured a deep red colour with a big smooth creamy light brown head. Scents include caramel, chocolate, ripe fruit and spice just name a few. First taste was creamy and sweet with flavours of burnt malts, strawberry jam, mineral water, ripe fruits...this could go on forever. The finish is slightly bitter with a grassy flavour and a almost oily mouthfeel. The palate is bitter with a flavour of Vermouth???

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy deep mahogany color with a small disappearing tan head.  The aroma is sweet caramel malt goodness with a hint of earthy peat and a whiff of alcohol.  The flavor is heavy on the sweet caramel malt, a touch of fruitiness, very light smoke, earthy peat, and a touch of alcohol.  There is a bit of bitterness in the finish.  Medium to full bodied.  Smooth and easy to drink.

Bottle at Hop Leaf, ChicagoDark chestnut color. Good aroma of caramel, malt, hop. Full bodied, with a sweet flavor, mix of malt, caramel, some toffee, very good hopping, but powerful and aromatic; in the end there is some roasted malt too. Excellent American Strong Ale.
Pours a dark brown color. Small head that turns into just a green ring quickly. Tastes like coffee and malt and brown sugar and smoke. Good brew hard to down.

Pours deep garnet into a snifter.  Thick tan head with excellent retention leaves sheet lacing as it slowly recedes. Smoky sweet aromas.  Upfront caramel and full with a lasting sweet/sour/smoked hop finish.

Had on tap at Perlys Bakery in Easton, PA. Pours a clear golden copper color with not much head (not sure the guy pouring the pints knew what he was doing). Smells lightly of sugar and yeast and a slight cutting citrus, lemon maybe. Tastes like a golden ale with German hops. Not too exciting.

Pours a dark ruby brown with a brighter white head.  The aroma is very malt heavy with notes of toffee/caramel and honey.  The flavor is rich and sweet with a tangy smokiness to it that gives it a nice balance.  Overall, there isnt anything wrong with this beer, but its far from the most interesting thing that I have had recently.

On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  A nice tasting scotch ale.  I personally thought it tasted a bit thin in the body-- wouldnt mind it a little more chewy.  Found the roast/smoke flavors as well as the hops to be very subdued.  Nicely balanced, but wouldnt mind tasting a little more aggressive version of this beer.  Lets take the gloves off this guy!

Bottle. Poured a very dark brown with garnet highlights when held to the light. Good head with decent lacing. Wonderful aroma of the malts with a hint of smoke and coffee. Great flavor of the dark malt with coffee, smoke and the taste of earth. Good mouthfeel and very smooth. You would never guess it is over 8% alcohol. Very, very tasty.

Poured a dark copper color with a thin white head that receded quickly. The aroma was of sweet dark malts and caramel. It had the typical smell of a scotch ale. The taste is really nice with the sweet malts really coming through. It had a nice sweet flavor of candy sugar to go with the malts and caramel. The finish was nice and sweet with some hops in the background to balance things out. I didnt get any of the smoke in there like the description says, but it was very enjoyable anyway.

pours a hazy dark, nearly opaque, reddish brown, with a thin light tan head that quickly gets out of the way.  big fruity estery and malty smell with spicy apricot and pear notes dominating hints of strawberries and plum, and maybe a bit of anise on the finish.  great complex smell.  taste is of fresh floral hops, with a dark fruity malt backing it up.  lots of bitter on the finish, which is well-backed by a decent malt sweetness.  good astringent mouthfeel and quite bubbly, emphasizing the tongue tingle, making for a great finish.  this beer is quite different from what i usually drink, and i like it quite a bit.
Bottle. Reddish body, small tan head, caramel nose with portish notes. Sweet, caramel, raisins, vinous, yum.

On tap at the Great Lakes Brewfest.  Pours a reddish orange brown color with a beige head.  Aroma of licorice, malts, chocolate, and caramel.  Caramel, burnt malts, licorice, earthy and peaty flavors.  Nicely bitter with licorice in the finish.

Bottle. Pours a reddish brown color with a small off white head. Aroma of malt, hops and spices. Has a bit of fermented fruit as well. Taste is bitter and a bit odd like prunes. I cant say I enjoyed it at all. Bitter, stale finish.
12 oz bottle at Quenchers, Chicago.  Dark ruby color with beige head.  Aroma is very doughy malt.  Flacor is caramel, brown sugar, alc, very nice.  Medium body and creamy.  Very nice overall.

Poured an attractive dark ruby color that was very inviting.  Had a good head that lasted a while.  Aroma was very malty and sweet.  Flavor was of malt, caramel, peat and brown sugar.  Nicely balanced with a bit of a bitter hop finish.  Lacing was really good and the mouthfeel was pleasant.  Hid the 8.3% abv very well.  Good stuff.

Bottle: Pours a reddish brown. Has some visible floaties, and is topped by a creamy tan head. The aroma is creamy chocolate, dark caramel, toasted bread, along with a slight alcohol touch. When its first opened and sipped it has an almost minty character upfront, maybe from the hops. As it breathes it evens out to a nice roasted earthiness from the malt profile. Its not too sweet at all. Theres some chocolate, peat along with a consistent bitterness (almost piney earthiness) throughout the flavor scale. The finish continues the earthy undertones displaying a hint of smoke and tobacco in the late palate. Nice and earthy, which is what I look for in Scotch Ales. Its also pretty dry overall, which I enjoyed. A pretty good Scotch Ale.
Too sweet for me.  It has a bittery-raisin finish that reminds me of Belgians.  Alcohol is hidden, but I really didnt find this one enjoyable.
Deep red color with a tan head.  Scottish malts, maple, and caramel in the aroma.  Strong alcoholic taste with a sweet malt and caramel in the finish.

Received this beer in a trade from someone, but its been awhile (and 20 trades later) so I forgot who sent it to me. While Founders seems to have a huge repetoire of beers, Ive only had a smattering of them, and they seem garner either a really good or average reviews. Since Ive always really had a soft spot for Scotch ales, I was pretty excited to finally pop the top on this one. 

So the beer pours out a dark brown color, mostly opaque but it started to clear on the end, with red highlights on the edges. A huge 4 finger thick khaki head erputed from my glass. It had some serious staying power and the head kept true thru the entire beer. Aroma was semi-sweet, malty, caramel, subtle run and smoke notes run along side a peaty note. Flavor is more sweetness, caramel covered raisins with a slightly over-carbonated finish. Would have received a bit higher scores from me if it was a little smoother. Still, a very nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 Thanks dra19! Finally got a bottle of this to re-rate since Ive only had it at a festival. Pours a nice dark burgundy brown. Little to no tan head. The aroma is malty, sweet, raisins, nice aroma. The flavor is sweet, alcohol, malty, caramel, raisins, rich, nice flavor profile. Warm dry palate and nice sweet finish.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Acknud. Pours a reddish caramel color with offwhite head. Nose is a little smoky with malts. Mouthfeel is a bit on the heavy side. Taste is of roasted malt, smoky peat, some caramel and brown sugar. Alcohol is well hidden until the end. When the brew is warm, the alcohol comes out to play. The finish is a bit on the hoppy side. Bitter aftertaste.
Old Dirty Bastard! Pours a deep ruby color with nice airy head and lacing.  Thick mouthfeel consiting of a nice malty flavor.  Notable hop presence on the finish

Bottle, courtesy HogtownHarry. Attractive deep ruby colour. Big woody, oxidised soy sauce aroma - not really my thing. The generous complement of tangy, resinous hops in the flavour was something of a surprise. The powerful, chewy malt presence was not. The two elements were beautifully balanced. Firm, weighty mouthfeel. Maybe a touch thick, with slightly volatile alcohol but those would just be very minor quibbles. Such a tasty and accomplished beer that my initial reservations about the aroma (which admittedly were more question of personal taste than anything else)  were entirely vanquished.

bottle to glass.  full nose, very little head, little lingering head around the outside of the glass. the body is dark reddish brown. Scotch drinkers beer! you can taste the smoke, coffee, a touch hoppy, pleasantly complex, best @ room temp. 
been drinkin dirty bastard since i was 19 and it will always be one of my top choices.
This dark brown ale poured with a tiny beige head. There is a delicious sweet toasted malt flavor and a carbonated mouthfeel. Tastes like an authentic scotch ale.
Bottle at Chris_Os, thanks to Harry. Deep amber with an off white head. Sweet malts, hops and alcohol in the nose. Hops, roasted malts and whiskey in the flavour. Not bad.
Bottle: Pours dark with a very small head.  Very sweet aroma and flavor.  Very good.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 Draft: Had this at the Sippin By the River fest in Philly.   Pour is a redish brown with a malty aroma with a hint of some chocolate, taste is malty, roasted and dry.  A very good brew.
Overall a good ale.  Dark brown pour.  Smoky aroma.  I dont detect much of the hops in the aroma but they do come through in the taste.  Smoky malt taste with a mild hop bitter finish.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at Chris_Os HogTownHarry minifest. Thanks to Harry. Very dark thick amber colour with a thin tan film. Resinous hoppy aroma with some sweet malt and slight alcohol. Burnt and roasty notes too. Flavour is more of the same but much better and really nicely balanced. Tasty.

Bottle from HogTownHarry drunk at Chris_os HogTownHarry meet up.  Hazy deep chestnut with lasting tan head.  Soy sauce all over it.  Bit too thick, tastes like thick black bean sauce.  Its ok, but oddly a tad bland.  Too soy saucey.

Poured from the bottle.  Produced a cloudy, nut brown body (with slight redness) with a medium tan head. Sweet smoky aroma with hints of chocolate.  First taste produced no sensation, quickly followed by strong bitter melding into sweetness (quite complex).  This was smooth drinking ale with a strong flavor.  Medium to heavy bodied and coated the tongue with a smoky sweetness.  I liked this Scotch Ale very much and will purchase again.

12oz bottle my friend Liz picked up on the road.  Drank from a dogfish snifter.  Pours dark brown with a ruby tinge.  The head is about pinky width and pretty nicely  colored, a pale cream.  The nose is sweet, robust and pretty damn enticing.  Tasty, sweet, rich, malty, but a tiny bit thin.  Founders has yet to let me down, and this is pretty solid, could be better of course, but pretty damn tasty.

pours a brown ruby color with a one finger bubbly off white head that quickly disappeared. aroma is roasted caramel malt with a touch of hops. has a medium body, descent lacing and ok carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma with a hint of alcohol. not bad of a scotch ale i guess. is a little sticky on the lips and a little syrupy.
on tap. i found this to be a delicously malty and nicely hopped scotch ale. not sure if i could drink several bottles at a time but this pretty tasty.

A so so Scotch ale. Aroma was weak but had hints of dark and roasted malt. Pour was a breathtaking dark ruby with a nice 2 finger off white head that appeared a couple seconds after the pour. Taste was smoky and sweet with a bitterness in the aftertaste. The sweet came from caramel, syrup and butterscotch. The bitterness resembled dark roasted malt in the end. I would have rated this a lot higher had it had decent carbonation.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dark brownish/ruby color - big aroma of roasted and sweet dark malts.  Flavor is sweet and rich, with notes of brown sugar, syrup, licorice and a slight hint of smokiness.  Finish is a little dry and sticky.  All in all a nice, bold scotch ale.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2009 On tap at Capital Ale House - Downtown on 08/25/2009. Mostly clear reddish amber body with ruby highlights and a bit of chill haze and a medium frothy dark tan head. Toasty molasses and faint smoke aroma. Grainy molasses and dry smoke flavor. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation. 8/4/7/3/15 - 3.7

Shared with Kinz for an impromptu tasting. Dark ruby body with a small off-white head. Sweet caramel and molassas aroma. Sweet malty caramel flavor with a butterscotch ending. 8/4/8/3/16 - 3.9

12oz bottle.  Pours an ugly red brown with a small off white head that quickly settles to a tiny film.  Sweet aroma, malty, maybe a touch of smoke, raisins, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, wood, maple syrup.  Some piney hops. Taste is smooth, a little bitter, with the dark fruits being the main thing here.  Sweetness is surprisingly low, which is a good thing I think.  Drinkability is higher than the aroma and ABV would lead you to believe.  One of the better Scotch ales Ive had.

Bottle from monks in philly.  Pours a deep dark brown.  Requisite sweetness and massive malt flavors.  Subtle candi sugar in the flavor as well.  Paired nicely with the cheese and sausage platter with got as an app.  Definiitely enjoyed this onen but I am pretty partial to this style.
Thanks to maniac for this one.  Deep amber, floaties, little head.  Deep caramel aroma, hints of molasses.  Flavor is fantastic, deep caramel.  There isnt much else to this, it is simple, but great.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of markgugs. Clear, reddish brown with a yellowish brown head. Fairly complex aroma of rum and overripe fruit. Has a nice, full body with notes of nuts, overripe fruit and a rather hoppy finish. Complex and very interesting. 230807

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 
Date: September 03, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade
Appearance: dark clear red, whispy tan head, rich sweet carmel malt aroma with a hint of earthy peat and a whisp of alcohol
Flavor: good rich earthy malt flavor, great carmel sweetness that dries out over time, picks up some nice smokey peat, only a hint of bitterness to keep the balance
Overall: the new benchmark in scotch ales

Date: June 03, 2006
Mode: bottle
nothing to add

Date: November 09, 2010
Mode: draft
Words: mac mcgee
Appearance: clear dark brown, fine beige head, streaks of lace
Aroma: sweet malty aroma, light smokeyness along with a dry earthyness, touch of caramel sweetness
Flavor:  rich deep caramel flavor, touch of earthy peat

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4
When I lived in Michigan, I didnt buy this too often, but would have it at the Beer Fest each year. Very heavy alcohol taste that will sit with you for awhile. A complex, intense beer.

(Bottle) Pours a brown color with a nice looking tan head. Rich, smoky taste (which I really like) is balanced with some light spicy hops and a good dose of alcohol. Subtle notes of dark fruit and sweet earth as well. This is one of the better beers Ive had from the style.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 12oz bottle from EithCubes - thanks, Mike! Now this is my kinda Scotch ale. Big and bold, with malts just pouring out and a big peaty aroma. Very rich and smooth, with a strong butterscotch note in the middle, balanced by a bit of dry spice towards the very end. Quite fine.

Bottle: Dark amber, mahogany, light head and lacing. Nose of bright alcohol and earthy hops overshooting the sweet caramelly malts. Some chewy toffee. The flavor is nice and chewy, rich raisin and plum notes. Thick mouthfeel, creamy sweet, bright and fruit. Light hops, nice scotch.

Bottle.  Poured a cloudy purplish-brown color with a medium light-brown head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is very malty with a sweet fruitiness to it.  Very nice mouthfeel.  Flavor is very strong, with malt, alcohol, caramel, and an almost smoke flavor to it.  Interesting and tasty beer.  Strong Scottish Ale for fans of the style.

How could you not like the name of this brew?  Short stubby 12 oz bottle that is certainly not a long neck.  Has a twist off cap. No head. Cloudy root beer appearance. Chocolate rubbing alcohol aroma, really attractive.   OOOH, smoothness makes you take a big swig then the malt alky impact whacks you in the palate. A rather strong alky brew and it tells you. It is so easy to confuse scotch ale with the milder Scottish ales. Simply just buzz making.  What a brew, like somebody spiked this beer with whiskey. Strong, numbs up the old tase buds rather quickly. Yes, the taste is somewhat like the aroma; big bold and intoxicating.  Really coats the back of your throat. Finish is medium long and malty alcohol bitter.  Barely acceptable as a beer because of its style but it is on par with 	McEwans Scotch Ale, OB Chubb and 3Fs the bruce. Really is powerful as stated in the description. Quite an exceptional rude alky experience, these scotch ales.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle from Gregis (via Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL).  Pour is a clear reddish brown with a one inch off-white head.  Aroma is caramel sweet malt and some hoppiness.  Taste has a medium to full body with a really nice full bodied sweetness.  Rounds out to a citrus hop finish.  Very smooth and drinkable, I was quite surprised to see the ABV.

dark copper/brown colored with mild head.  it smells like a Scoth ale, for sure.... touches of roasted malts  with sour/soft echoes of vanilla and toffee.  An ample bodied selection, but  one that features a raisiny/malty quality, syrupy caramel malted, and a fruity smooth touch, with a touch of biting sour/dry hops.  A nice offering

12oz Bottle Pours out a cloudy rust brown topped with a small head. A nice sweet aroma and tast. This was pretty tasty. I was thinking maybe A BW.
Thanks Jake

Bottle:  Auburn pour with a smaller beige head.  Nose is sweet and malty with oak, caramel, and fruity tones.  Syrupy and thick feel.  Malty and dry, there is a bit of oak present with a little citrus and hints of the alcohol content.  Enjoyable.  Thanks Eithcubes.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2007 Received in a bottle from a friend! :) Ive heard a lot about this local small brewery and finally get to sample one of their beer. Rich,  strong aroma.  Poured a deep red-brown. Creamy small  tan head that remained a very thin cap to the end., Left nice lacing. Rich, robust, slightly smoky flavor with very malty, chocolate. roasted malt and earthy taste. Very full body, thick texture, very soft carbonation with a very nice flavorful finish.  This beer is one of the best ones Ive ever enjoyed.  Founders has done a great job with Dirty Bastard. I tried this in a tulip.  I will definitely add this to my normal rotation of favorite beer.  If you like beer dark, rich, thick and full of great flavor this is the beer for you!  To me it is excellent!!
On tap at the Oasis.  Have tried several times before , but this time it was in a sampler.   Very nice scotch ale flavor, good sweetness in the malt with roasted and alcohol flavors.

Bottle purchased at Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a clear burgundy/brown with a creamy tan head that diminishes to a thin cap and laces nicely. Sweet caramel malts are strong on the nose, backed by notes of raisin, plum and a light alcohol. Full-bodied, creamy and soft, it finishes with a lightly burnt/bitter end. The flavor is a sweet, creamy roasted malt front with smoked/burnt notes and a clean, dry finish. A bitter aftertaste lingers at the back of the tongue. Quite nice, I can see why its referred to as "Founders flagship beer".
On tap at Founders.  Aroma of malts, earth, smoke, and hints of dark fruit.  Strong beginning taste of sweet malt, chocolate, and smoke finishing with good alcohol taste.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours brown with a very minimal head.  The aroma is heavy on the malt side, some roasted malts with molasses and coffee.  The flavor is of roasted malts with molasses along with oak and also smoke.  There is a alcohol burn.  The body is medium to full with a oily texture and soft carbonation.

I typically like Scotch Ales so when I saw this in the local beer store I picked up a 6 to try.  It has a bit of a smoke aroma, a nice dark brown color and a dry finish.  Overall I think it was a good find that Ill be sure to try again in the future.

12 oz bottle from Julios.  Pours a deep caramel/brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is very fruity, fresh berries, loads of caramel and some peat smoke.  Taste is alot of caramel, touches of chocolate, a moderate amount of fruit-sweet cherries/apple with some hints of smoke.  very nice.

12 oz bottle.  Clear, dark burgundy brown with a foamy tan head.  Lacy arcs.  Cocoa, light vinous, cola and peat.  Rich and chewy caramel and toffee.  Dried figs and a burnt sugar bite end with light grassy drying.  Another winner from Founders.

bottle from billvane: pours a brown colour with a tan head that leaves a thin line with some small amounts of lacing. aroma of caramel malts, earthy hops and a small amount of dark fruit and roastedness. flavour is roated, chocolate, caramel malt to start with dried fruit and some chewy bread. a very little amount of hops in the finish. this is a very thick and creamy on the palate, but most enjoyable.

Poured a lightly hazy, reddish brown color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of peat smoke, caramel malts, light roast, earth, and a bit of alcohol as well.  Taste of roast, chocolate, smoke, with some caramel, light dried fruits, with a dry, smoky, alcoholic finish.

bottle....apearance: dark-amber reddish brown which poured with a one inch off-white head....aroma: dark fruits, pretty malty albeit with some hope bitterness to it as well....taste: caramel malt sweetness, smokey with a bit of roasted bitterness that cuts through in the finish. a medium bodied beer that definitely is satisfying.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 Deep brown beer with a light amber-red tint to it.  Sweet toasty aroma, light berry fruitiness behind heavy brown sugar, light molasses and a sweet plumminess as well.  Deep caramelized malt with a touch of burnt sugar character as well.  Very rich tasting.  Flavour shows a bit of peppery ethanol behind the sweet toffee and caramel.  Slight salty with a hint of smoke on the back.  Nice stuff.
Pours a nice brown color with a beige head.  Hints of malt, alcohol, and hops in the aroma.  Has a very earthy taste in which the hops nicley balance out the maltiness.  Nice beer!
Poured dark red almost brown with tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, hops, and spice. Strong flavor of sweet malt to start followed up by hints of spice and caramel.
I had this yesterday for my first beer on tap for founders 10th anniversary.  Pours out a little thicker and darker than i remember the bottle, but the same great taste is there.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.(I must have misplaced my thistle?)  This Scotch Ale poured a hazy, dark reddish brown color with visible carbonation when held up to light.  Virtually no head or lace to speak of.  The aroma of this beer was made up of sweet caramel malts, light yeast notes, and a bit of wood.  The flavor is dominated by smokey malt richness.  Some sweet caramel notes followed by a big roasted, smokey malt flavor.  A touch of hop bitterness is present at the end.  The mouthfeel is medium-bodied with light carbonation, leaving a lasting smokey taste on your tongue.  Towards the bottom of the glass, it reminds me of drinking a Scotch and water.  The flavor seems to become a bit muted by the smoke.  I enjoyed the aroma and flavors that this beer presented, but the smokey finish seemed to detract from the overall experience.  Made my mouth feel like I had sat next to a campfire for a few hours, directly in the line of the smoke eminating from the flame.  A decent beer, but maybe just not my cup of tea.  It was definately a Dirty Bastard!!!
Pours a Deep, Dark Red. Aromas of caramel and some roasted malts. Some fruits and roasted malts that fill the palate. Nicely Balanced. I love this beer.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, light mahogany color with a light beige head. No doubt, its one of the prettiest hues of the Beer Rainbow.

Smell: Mild nutty aroma charged with a heaping helping of berries and other various dried fruits.
