Taste: Light toasted grains and caramel sweetness with just a slight bitterness that comes across as dull and unimaginative. Im not picking up any smoke or peat flavors either - just those bizarre fruity undertones. Sour cherries, figs, and more berries.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a slick mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Is it me, or is this the fruitiness non-fruit beer to date?
Pours a semi clear dark ruby red brown with a medium brownish beige head.  Aroma of caramel malts and toffee.  Taste is malty with hints of toffee and caramel.  Very good .

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of caramel malts, floral hops, and some cherries and strawberries.  Poured ruby in color with a medium tan head that diminished.  Clear.  Tastes of malts, alcohol, toffee, and chocolate.  Tastes like chocolate milk with alcohol in it.  Medium body.  Soft carbonation.  Slightly dry, malty, sweet finish.

bottle pours a hazy brown with a frothy head.  Glass laces nicely as I drink.  Aroma is of sweet malt with some spice.  The flavor is sweet and rich with hints of caramel.  It finishes with some spicy bitterness and a bit of bite from the alcohol.  Outstanding!

Nice brown color with a sm-med head.  Aroma is filled with thick malts, peat, and a small amount of hop aroma.  Flavor was sweet with some dark fruits, dark bread. and smoky/peat tastes.  Enough hops in there to keep things interesting.  Ive been drinking alot of Old Chub lately and this is just a tad better.
Chicago trip. Monday 17:30+. On tap at The Map Room. Black with ruby highlights. Peaty malt aroma. Rich thick black malt peat taste. Rich malty sugary and funky.

12 oz bottle. Poured a clear reddish/brown with a small off white head. Aroma of earth, hay, cobwebs, smoke, peat and slight chocolate. Flavor of smoke, peat, chocolate and a slight alcohol warming at the very back of my throat. Creamy full mouthfeel with just enought carbonation. Really good beer.
Roasted malt aroma.  The beer is too thin and lacks fruit, alcohol, or vinous qualities.  Not really bad, but it is just too thin and light for the style.

From a 12-oz bottle, shared by brewfiend, this pours a clear dark bown brew with a fast dissolving off white head. Aroma is earthy with hints of molasses, pitted fruit, peat and soy sauce. Taste is heavy roasted malt, medium body and more soy sauce. Finish is smooth, sweet and no bitterness. Lacking the alcohol sting at the end but very enjoyable.

Rated 9/23/06:  Killer Scotch Ale, plenty of bite coupled with a great smoothness. Heavy malt aroma, bitter-sweet. Solid pour, good head and lacing but too many floaties detract from the overall visuals. Smooth on the palate with a calm alcohol burn, just how I like it. Impressive flavor with lots of sweet malts, molasses & brown sugar mixed with a slight bitterness. Powerful and inviting, oh my this is a nice cool weather brew.

12oz bottle, $1.79.  Aroma is of heavy caramel malt with some prune and alcohol.  Small off-white head left virtually no lace and mostly diminished.  Body is a murky dark reddish brown with and average amount of varied particles.  Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter with a moderate finish.  Some alcohol on the finish as well.  Full bodied, oily, flat palate with a mild alcohol burn.  Bottle was shaken during shipping so the particles are probably not common.  As thick as a good Imp stout but without the complexity.  Good but not one Ill buy again.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 Pours dark red. medium thickness. Has a great malt and caramal aroma. Its very smooth and transitional beer leaving you with a great aftertaste. Alcohol is noticeable. Overall it was something I will buy again. Re rate it is amazing how your taste changes. I remember this beer to be pretty powerful when i began to taste and rate beers and now I find it to be not as bold, but still one of my fav.
Picked this up at the coffee grounds in Eau Claire.  Brown with sediment and faint head.  Malt carob nose with noticeable alcohol.  Dry chocolate and coffee taste.
4 oz sample, World Expo of Beer. Frankenmuth, MI. May 19th 2007. 28th brew of the festival.
on tap at the oasis in rockford.  tan head, very light body that was very well balanced. A very smooth dark ale  with no biterness.  Excellent caramel taste.
kinda a redish colour.  bit of a syrupy body, has a bit of a sweet fruity aroma, has a hop presence in the taste along with a bit of smoke.  McGraths Pub.

12oz bottle, courtesy of someone from a while back.  Pours a murky brown color; minimal head formation with a thin perimeter of small bubbles.  Dense, caramel and dried fruits in the aroma.  Medium, chewy mouthfeel: caramel and bubble gum upfront (slightly fruity, a bit syrupy), with some smoke and roasted malts; hides its alcohol reasonably well.  Decent scotch ale.  Lengthy, sugary and roasted malt finish.
Fruity, slightly diacetyl aroma.  Ruby brown.  Plummy, almost barleywine.  Slightly chalky mouth.  Very light cocoa. On tap, McNivens, Indianapolis.

Bottle. Pours a clear red body with nice head. Aroma is smokey malt, bubblegum, caramel. Flavor is a dry sweet malt, caramel, light bubblegum and a lot of smokiness. Nice full bodied brew. Very enjoyable.

This is a great beer.  Pours a toffee-brown color with a small white head.  Has a nice malty, caramel aroma and the mouth feel on this is great; smooth, fairly thick and just overall wonderful.  Starts out fairly tame with some roasted malt, caramel, and toffee notes and finishes with a decent smoky bite.  Will definitely seek out again.

This is what an American Scotch style Ale should taste like

AMERICAN

This is one of the best scotch ales ive had 
smooth - malty - a hint of hops and bitterness

great beer
Poured a deep reddish brown with little head. Tastes of chocolate, malt, and a nice smooth finish. Very tasty.

Pours a deep, dark reddish brown color with a fat tan head.  The smell is of rasisins, malt and some spices.  Great refreshing taste with a little alcohol kick to it.  The finish in smooth with some carmel and malt doing the job in the end.

12 oz bottle. great malt smell. Beautiful deep red-brown color. Strong,sweet malt flavor puctuated by caramel flavor that this style is famous for. Subdues alcohol bite. Just enough hops to balnce the alcohol and malt flavors. I will be drinking more of this

Draft - Dark copper color with average head and nice lacing.  You can really taste the carmel and peat in this one.  Nice after taste that sticks with you for a while.  Will drink this one again.  My wife didnt appreciate, but she only likes the fruity beers.  On tap at Cascarellis in Homer, MI.

I keep coming back to this beer.  It is my go to when I want something solid.  Pours a nice deep bronze color.  great smell.  Taste is caramel, spices, nice hope backbone, dark fruits.  Very nicely balanced and extremely drinkable.

Pours pretty cloudy and settles out into a medium tan head that faded pretty quick. Smell is pretty goo, a little light, but the fruits and sweetness are there again. Taste is damn good. I guess I love me some scotch ales.

On draft at Capones for the Pliny tasting. Pours deerp bronze with red hues, and a decent size off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, spices, toffee, and fruit. The flavor is sweet, fruit, very smooth, caramel, spices. Very Nice.

Bottle. clear ruby/copper color with a small head. Aroma of toffee and brown sugar. Taste is teeth hurting  sweet; toffee, caramel, nutty with some spicy hops. Medium to heavy body.  Sticky with alcohol texture. Long, sweet finish.

Cloudy reddish brown color with decent off-white head.  Sweet, malty aroma of molasses, toffee and dark fruits.  Flavor similar to aroma with some added dry nuttiness.  Alcohol is slightly more apparent than I would expect.
a smoky, roasted, nutty head with a deep amber color and white head.  smells great, looks great, tastes great.  a fine scotch ale.

Unfiltered, dark brown with big fluffy head. Aroma is malt and alcohol. Taste is caramel, toffee, alcohol, and mainly sweet maltiness. Good carbonation, with a somewhat dry aftertaste. Pretty good altogether.
Pours a nice red color with a minimal head.  Sweet nose, nothing largely noticable.  Highly malted and smooth, sweet, hoppy finish.  Small amount of roasted malts detectable.  A nice brew.

Bottle, poured a dark brown with a thin off white head.  I honestly think that Scotch ales just arent my thing.  They seem so bland and boring.  No aroma, simple malty taste, medium mouthfeel and a sweet finish.  I just dont get this style...
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle.  Reddish brown pour.  No head.  Icy, carbonated froth on top.  Looks a lot like a Birch beer.  Chocolate, malty, nutty aroma.  Overwhelming flavor to tongue and roof of mouth.  Malty, wooden taste.  More like a brown ale than a scottish ale

On tap.  Very dark brown chestnut color with a thin loose white head.  Aroma is malt-dominated with a general maple/brown sugar sweetness.  Some milder oak and plum-like aromas present.  Medium to thick palate, well-carbonated.  Sweet, dark, candied fruit taste with some alcohol discernible, but not obtrustive.  Dry finish.  A very good Scotch, but overall it lacked some characteristics I prefer in Scotch Ales (peat, a little smoke).

Had it both in bottle and in Founders on draft.  Aroma of caramel and coffee, and sometimes alcohol.  The flavor opens with a huge malty kick.  The beer finishes with a moderate amount of hop flavor and alcohol (though the alcohol is by no means overwhelming).  It feels heavier than most ales Ive sampled, but not as heavy as most microbrewed stouts.  Overall a very good beer!
Draft.  An interesting beer, with a nice palate (somewhat heavy carbonation but still smooth).  Flavor of sweet malt and some dark fruit.
Great and unique flavor; aroma is malty and not too smokey.  Flavor was caramel, sweet malt, some dark fruit, and maybe a hint of some peat.  Great mouthfeel; smooth and enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a nice copper color with some reddish hues.  Moderate white head that dies down fairly quickly.  Aroma is very malty with a slight smokey quality.  Flavor is also very malty, with some caramel and some earthy qualities.  Flavor lingers on the tongue.  Medium mouthfeel.  Drinkable and enjoyable.

Courtesy Solan.  Pours a cloudy copper with a very thin white head.  Smells of caramel, and sweet dark malts.  Pretty typical of scotch ales.  Taste is pretty unique for this style.  Pretty sweet, with a touch of candy sugar.  malts are pretty big, but get a touch of hops in the finish which helps balance this brew.  The finish is really smooth, and I get some nice caramel characters that accompany it which make it very enjoyable.

12oz. Bottle

Dirty Bastard poured clear mahogany. When held to the light you can see sediment floating throughout. Sitting on top of the body s a fingers worth of creamy beige head that sticks around. Looks good.

When I opened the bottle I immediately smelled scotch. When poured and held to my nose I smelled toasted grains up front. Followed by a sweetness of candied dark fruits. The toasted grains remain throughout with hints of the fruits, a hint of wood, and vanilla. There even seems to be a little mustiness.

Fairly complex beer. Up front I pick up a very mild toasted malt but its quickly overtaken by a wave of roasted malts and caramel at mid-palate.The wave settles with a deep roastines and caramel flavor. An earthy quality follows all the big flavors in the finish. A slight lingering bitterness shows up just before the swallow and lingers for just a few seconds. 

The mouthfeel accompanies the taste very well. It is a little on the heavy side of medium bodied. Nice and creamy like the way it should be.

Drinkability is good if you drink this how it should be drunk. Its a sipper in every sense of the word. That drops the drinkability just because of all the big dark flavors. 

Sampled 10/20/06

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2012 Draft at Jerrys. Clear dark mahogany with good, creamy, tan head / Sweet, rich nose of toffee, coffee, chocolate, and dark fruit / Medium to full body, chewy, sweet & syrupy but with excellent hopping, and good bitterness,  and some heat, on the long finish / Rich, complex flavors of coffee, chocolate, caramel, nut, and peet / One of the greats.
I am a fan of scotch ales and this one is good. Good flavor to it. Very smooth. Balanced.

Bottle. Reddish brown with a moderate tan head that fades rapidly. Sweet malt and caramel aroma. Big roasted malt flavor, with some peaty smoky flavor. Some hops become evident at the end. Fairly full bodied. Very nice.
Bottle. Pours opaque dark ruby brown with minimal off white head. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, toffee, pine. Flavor is molasses, caramel, pine, malt, chocolate, coffee.
Cant seem to get out of the party store without taking a 6 pack of this beer with me.  Its nice, warming with a bit of a carmally sweetness.  Nice representation of my favorite style.
pours dark brown/red with small creamy head. smokey, earthy flavors and some dark fruits. very nice creamy feel...its a wee heavie and I like it IN MY BELLY!

Extremely dark ruby color.  Fairly nice malt nose.  Really complex hints of peat and smoke on the palate, with additional notes of caramel, toffee and fruit as well.  Very nice body.  Nice flavor.  A very nice beer.  I would love to buy this beer in a 6er.
Bottle. Thanks to BillVanE. Poured a dark black thin like water. Aroma of malt and jack danials. Taste is smooth and frothy has a coffe hint to it.

Very Dark red almost black pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is malts, caramel, and a grain aspect to it.  Almost candy like in the aroma.  Very smooth caramel malt taste, but the graininess is subdued in the taste but brings something subtle nuances into the mix.  Palate is short, somewhat lively and carbonated, and light.  Overall, Very nice Scotch ale better than most of the Wee Heavies.  Cheers!

Founders has been a mixed bag with me.  I have had some good beers from them, and some pretty awful ones as well.  This one is a winner.  It pours a lovely dark brown color and smells like a delicious malty beverage.  Palate is nice and full, and the flavor is awesome:  Lots of smoke and roasted malts.  The smoke is definitely there, but its far from over powering.    I detect some brown sugar and fruits too -- maybe some raisin -- hard to tell.  Excellent beer.

Dark brown/amber in color. Poured a big cream colored head, very frothy that slowly diminished and created a nice lacing. Very very sweet & sour aroma. Flavor was rich and malty to start with some roasty, smoky notes with shots of sweetness. Alcohol appeared as it warmed & pinched the back of the the throat just slightly. Excellent

bottle - Pours dark ruby with a half inch head of thick foam that left some decent lacing.  The aroma is all malt and dark fruit tones.  Strong malt and fruit notes are balanced by a significant hops kick that comes through more in this full bodied brews finish.
bottle. murky amber color. aroma is barky. taste of wood and barly winy. dark fruits. raisons. quite strong alcohollic. lots of power.

Bottle from Sprinkle. Dark maroonish/brown color upon pouring. Aroma is burnt and malty. Some raisins and a woody scotch character. Bitter malty flavorings. Pretty nice bitterness from the hops as well. A little bit of everything in there. Strong malts and hops. Alcohol is well hidden.

Pours a delightful cloudy, dark coppery brown with a small head that leaves excellent lacing.  Aroma of cherries, caramel, and some tobacco.  Taste fruity and dirty at the same time with some cherry, plum,  caramel, tobacco, dirt and coffee flavors.  Tastes as involved as it sounds.  I like the way this beer finishes pretty light, but noticably dry, dirty and woody.  Its not meant to be a hopbomb, and the finish, while bitter, is not really a "hoppy" bitter.  The mouthfeel has a way of feeling thick without being heavy at all.  Wonderfully creamy and low carbonation.  It has some sweetness with no cloying factor at all.  I cant think of anything else Id want a scotch ale to do that this beer doesnt already accomplish....

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 A very fruity, Carmel flavor and aroma. No surprises between smell and taste. Poured and dark brown with a tan head.  Again the fruitiness stood out. When I bought this,, my beer gus said it was a very good example of Scotch ale.

If youre looking for something a little off the beaten path, give this a try.

12 oz bottle. Poured a lovely clear garnet color. Head was light tan with an orange tint. Aroma is of roasty malt, cocoa, and a hint of anise. Tastes even better than it smells. A mix of chocolate covered cherry, subtle peated malt, and alcohol flavors. Full bodied. Malty molasses comes out at the end along with a pleasant lingering bitterness. Well put together beer.

Thanks to decaturstevo for sharing this bottle with me! Poured brown in color with a yellowish tan head. Nice fruity aroma mixed with caramel malts and a hint of roast. Great fruity flavor (cherry stood out in particular) backed with some chocolate. Full body with a creamy texture. Hints of sweetness and fruity aftertaste. Thanks Stevo!
Solid in most aspects. Nice and malty, yet a nice and surprising dry finish. Yum yum.

A rich raisiny aroma with sweet malt kicker. An almost mahogony pour with almost no head and a nice gooey lacing. A rich malty fruity flavor with a nice bitter finish that is not a harshness that makes the beer unpleasant. It is almost an espresso bitter. A full palate but just a tad over carbonated for me. A very complex flavor and palate make this an interestingly good beer.

Surprise. This was a great beer! The downfall of this beer was that there wasnt another one only a  Beer Lao.... damn..

Dark cloudy brown. Large tan head. Malty aroma. Very malty flavour. With light bitters. Hints of chocolate and light roastedness. Palate was clean with light carbonaton.

Reddish brown with a big firm tan head.  Deep roasted, nutty malt aroma.  Flavor is another huge load of malt, Bittersweet chocolate, nutty, with a roasted bitterness in the middle.  Dry, earthy hops bite at the finish wraps it up really nicely.  Nice medium body with good carbonation.  Fantastic.
12 oz Bottle @ Coles, Buffalo, NY. Thanks Metzger. Dark amber color & very malty & nice alcohol bite. A good scotch ale.

Pours a reddish brown color topped by a large sudsy head of tan foam. Some lacing with great head retention. Sweet malty aroma with a hint of peat.

Very malty brew - lots of sweet chocolate malt and a little tofffee. A bit drier in the end, but not a whole lot. Hopped for balance, not for flavor. Medium to full body, light but adequate carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 I was a little disappointed by this Scotch Ale. I am generally an advocate of this style. It is unfortunate that they are few in variety for the most part, as not many Scotch Ales are distributed in Rhode Island. However, this beer all caramel malt, with a sheer whiskey mouthfeel. The bourbon taste is all well and good, but there is a very weak hop balance that makes this brew one dimensional...Old Chubb is much better.

Bottle.  Pours a copper brown with ruby notes; white-tan head is creamy and signifcantly lasting considering the ABV.  Aroma is dominated by maltiness, with some sweetness evident.  Smokiness is there along with some roast.  Flavor is more of the same....sweet, heavy malt, some smoke, hops balance, with a touch of lingering bitterness.  Really good balance.  Medium-full body, hints of alcohol warmth.  Overall, not one of my favorite styles, but this is really a solid beer....highly recommend for scottish beer fans.

12 oz bottle. Poured a shiny ruby to amber color with thin tan head. Aroma is a bit weak with sweet sweet malt and a slight roastiness. The flavor starts off with some hop bitterness and slight roasted maltiness. Then deeper roasted malt sweetness, sort of molasses, and a bit of dark fruit come out of hiding. Tough to pin down the flavor any more than that. Maybe there is a touch of brown sugar in there too. I also get a slight sense of the ABV. This beer really begins to shine when it is the third or fourth beer being consumed. The malts, hops and slight Barleywine taste really hits the spot.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a mahogony red/brown with a dense multi toned brown head.  Aromas of caramel and toffee, along with some smoke and molasses.  Rich malty flavor.  lightly peated.  Milk chocolaty caramels.  Huge palate.
12 oz bottle courtesy of wheninhell. Mahogany with a thin light brown head. Toasty, roasty malt nose, some molasses. Sweet malty flavor, peaty, very mild on the alcohol. Nice scotch ale!

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Bottle. Dark brown in color with no head and minimal carbonation. Malty and rich aroma. The taste was of figs, maple sugar,and caramel malty. Very good beer. Chewy smooth texture that ends with a bitter/sweet finish.
Dark rust colored beer... smells like smoked chocolate... also tastes very malty with hint of smoke....

Bottle.  Did the guy before me seriously rate this brew 1.5?  I think the average 3.7 is low.  This is a marvelous beer.  Deep crimson color with an beautiful tan head.  Intense natural, smoky aroma.  Thick, perfectly balanced mouthfeel -creamy.  A great malty blend with a hoppy kick.  A very solid Ale and a must try.  My full rec.

Deep brown with ruby notes, significant amount of yeast even with a careful pour.  Looks like hot and sour soup.  Aroma is rich with malt and smoke.  Flavor is liquid smoke with some roastiness and thin malt in the background.  Body on the thin side for the style.  This is one of my favorite beer styles, and I find this beer to be significantly lacking particularly from such a great brewery. Yuk!

Tap.   Pours a clear orange-amber color with a smallish yellow-tan colored head.   Aroma is malt, fruit, caramel.   Flavor is dried fruit, malt, caramel, alcohol.   Palate is medium-full, medium carbonation, bitter, warm finish.   Grrreat!

I have been "sampling" ;-) beers for many years....This one stopped me in my tracks. Now instead of always trying something new, I will get a 6 of this and something else new! Havent tired of the taste in over a year. 3 thumbs up!
Bursting with malty flavor. Nice dark body with reddish hue. Smooth, malty flavor with a nice kick from the hops. Im still trying to pick out all of the flavors. Great beer.
Pours a deep brown hue with armaos of caramels and apples.  Flavors of caramel, toffee, raisins, and figs. with a becent alcohol  finish.

Had this on tap at Barleys Smokehouse.Aroma of caramel and malts.Poured alight color with a long lasting head.Good sweetness stood out in the flavors.Finished sweet with a hint of alcohol in the finish.

Orange/amber color with tan head.  Scent of raisin, honey, nuts.  Rich, full beginning with smoky raisin, caramel, alcohol taste and a hint of cinnamon.  The sweetness keeps it smooth through the finish with a little more alcohol lingering.  More rainsiny-Scoth taste than a beer taste.

Poured a lovely shade of garnet with a longer-lasting creamy tan head... but there was significant unattractive chunkage resting at the bottom.  Nose was of smoked up darker fruit, caramel, alcohol, and some dried herbal hops.  Flavor was definitely complex from a malt perspective... overriding aire of smoked peat with pulled caramel, toffee, darker fruits, and herbal notes well-blended in there.  Smooth, creamy middle that had a bit of alcohol slide off toward the edges.  Warm smoked peat, dried plums, and herbal hops leave a lasting impression.  Another solid brew from these guys!
Bottle. Deep red - white edges. Red berries, a lot of bread, sweet, lovely hopped, caramel. A bit like a barley wine. Very nice.
A light, orange colour with a scent of dried fruits and a smokey aftertaste, generally a nice beer and if available around my parts, a deffinate buy.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with a small off white ehad.
Aroma of caramel, prunes and dried fruits
Flavour of dried fruits, caramel and liquorice with notes of alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2016 Poured dark with little head that ran away quickly, dark ale resembles a stout but has red, good lacing on the glass, smelled malty sweet, hints of coffee, some carmel, remnants of stout, taste of coffee, toffee, hint of licorice, dark malts, stout, a thick, full mouth feel, heavy on the palate Old Rating 8-5-7-5-16 - 4.1- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - -- - - -- - - New Rating 10-17-07 - pours a dark ruby with brown, looks brown black in the glass but is a dark ruby, with a layer of tan bubbles that disappeared to a ring, 
aroma of earth, chewy dark or cooked caramel, molasses, delicious malt sweetness in the nostrils, lots of malt fragrances, vanilla and choclate cake mix, 
I notice a faint smoke aroma here and there after the ale warmed up a bit,
a sip presents flavors of brown sugar, chocolate, toffee and little bits of coffee, a mix of dark malt flavors, roasted malt, 
thick mouth feel, coats the tongue, has a faint stickiness on the palate, little bitterness but the sweet flavor rides on top to subside at the finish and 
has a small bite from the alcohol to wash away the malt sweetness, there is faint alcohol warming in the background, this could be served as a wonderful Winter Warmer, 
I still love this brew!
Cheers to Founders for making my tastebuds so happy!
Bottle thanks to Bager. Amber colour with a tan head. Heavy sweet caramel malty, raisin aroma and taste. Medium body with a sweet raisin finish. Almost a barley wine.
Bottled. Brown reddish coloured with a small head. Very nice aroma of raisins. Malty and sweet with notes of dark fruit and caramel and spices. Well balanced - a bit like a mild barley wine.

Pours a murky brown with some burgundy hues under a thin tan head. Head quickly settles to a slick film which persists throughout the glass.  The initial aroma is of assertive peat smoked malts, followed by faint notes of burnt caramel candy, dark wheat bread, raisins, black cherries and a touch of herbal hops. Carbonation is appropriately subtle resulting in a smooth, slightly oily and slick moutfeel. Just right for this style. Initial flavor leans toward the sweet side presenting burnt caramel, brown sugar, raisins and figs with a hint of chocolate. The hops and alcohol eventually emerge in the late palate and finish with a fairly crisp, dry bitterness and ethanol warmth. Kind of an "Amercanized" hoppy version of the style, reminiscent of old Bert Grants Scotch Ale, but a nice winter season beer.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 Bottle.  Deep red body supports a creamy, frothy, lovely light brown head.  Sweet and richly malty aroma with notes of peat and roast and toffee and a hint of smoke.  Very, very malty taste with healthy woody/peaty bitterness, thick toffee and dark caramel, light roast, red berry, and very light alcohol more towards the end.  Very full-bodied with a wonderful hops/malt balance, no small feat considering the massive malt levels.  Also a nice balance struck between sweet/bitter.  Hoppy grit begins the aftertaste.  This is almost sticky, but not quite, and thick to the point of being sludgy - about as full-tasting as a beer can be.  Complex and mature, a really nice Scotch Ale! [2006.11.02: 4.0]  Had many of these over the years, but none in the last few; this bottle from 08/18/2014  Not as many hops this time, much more in the way of dark and complex malt, though, even a bit too much, though, as the strong candy bar currents come to dominate.  Really like the bitterness here without a peat overload, and the alcohol provides big heft without burn.  I need to drink this more, a satisfying big boy thats never at a premium price. [2014.12.02: 3.7]

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Chocolate and coffee taste, deep deep roasted flavors.  Good but one per sitting is enough.  [need to rerate] 9.5.7.5.16

[rerate 2/19/09 maybe 6 month old bottle] This is a still a great beer.  Very flavorful, more so than the new oaked arrogant bastard I just had.   Some dusty chocolate, hops are a bit oxidized but it really adds the character of the peated malt.  Great mouthful, this is nice with a touch of age.  Reminds quite a bit of Great Divides Hibernation Ale.  9.4.8.4.17

Caramel and coffee scent.  Beer is opaque brown and cloudy with practically no head.  GREAT flavor, sweet but not overpowering with plenty of caramel and chocoalte and a bit of coffee.  Body is medium heavy and compliments the flavor well.  Great beer, one of my favorites.

A bottle purchased from Breeze-Thru liquor in Milwaukee.

The best Scotch Ale Ive had in recent memory, although I am not a frequent consumer of Scotch Ales (I drank a Belle Haven and a McEwans recently and had some others at a recent festival). While I liked it, I didnt find Dirty Bastard very sessionable, which may have involved the ABV.

Appearance was a reddish-black, with a non-persistant tan head.  Odor was of bourbon/caramel, which I liked.  Flavor was also that of bourbon and caramel.  I didnt feel that the bourbon flavor was overpowering and thought the aroma and flavor of the beer was quite pleasant.

Aroma of plums over malt.  Appears a hazy brown with a small orange head that dissipates.  Flavor is vinous and intensely malty, with definite notes of roast coffee accentuated by an unexpected hop bite.  Palate is thick and chewy.  Overall an excellent beer, though not quite to style.

Pours mahagony with a tiny patchy off-white head.  Aroma is caramel malt (cookie, biscuit), yeast (sweat, dough), flowers and brown sugar.  Medium sweet caramel malt and yeast flavor, medium acidity and bitterness, alcohol at the end.  Medium bodied and smooth but dry palate.

Bottled. Beer is hazy, medium-red brown color with a small, white, rapidly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with light notes of toasted grain, moderate note of caramel; Hoppy with a light note of herbal thyme; Yeasty with a trace of basement; Moderate oxidation.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with a long, warm, lightly bittersweet finish. Slight grippyness.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is soft.

(Bottle via trade with OhioDad, thanks Scott!) Found this to be decent but not great with an unexpected note of pineapple...Pours sort of hazy dark reddish brown with two fingers of reddish-brown biege head. Aroma lightly caramel, candy malt and fruity pineapple. Mouthfeel pretty smooth, a little thin, a little sticky. Webby lacing. Flavor of mild sugar candy maltiness, bit of caramel and that pineapple note that prevailed. No hints of peat or Scotch or smokiness. Pretty bitter. Nice but kind of unremarkable for Founders.

Wow, one of the best looking beers I think Ive seen in a long time.  Dark, dark amber color with a small tan head.  Earthy, malty aromas.  Flavor was also very earthy and a bit smokey with a slightly hoppy and slightly hot finish from the alcohol.  This is some good stuff, espcially for a flagship beer thats very reasonably priced.

Pours red-brown, with nice ruby highlights and a tan head. Nose is malt, caramel, raisins, smoke, and alcohol. Flavor is malty caramel and smoke with a hin of alcohol. A firm mouthfeel and a nicely dry finish. An excellent ale!
Draft at Dilly Deli: Dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma was quite roasty with some chocolate. Flavor chocolate, caramel, nice and rich. Medium bodied. Quite enjoyable.
I liked everything about this one, very rich and complex, nice dark color, and the bitterness was rounded off with a spicy caramel/chocolate-type finish.

Deep brown pour, with a lighter brown head.  The aroma is a nice rich hoppy aroma with a malty highlights.  Flavor and body arent quite up to the caliber of the aroma.  The flavor is lighter sweet hops and a much more mellow malt.  Ther are lots of flavors in there, from citrus and pine to mollasses.  Very interesing beer.
Very sexy beer.  Quite strong.  Bitter, very malty, very complicated.  Deep red brown.  Excellent beer from draught AND bottle.

12 oz. bottle. Frothy tan head showing some good lace and durabulity bursts forth from a deep reddish amber pour. Malt sominated aroma with some bourbon , roasted nuts, and sweet dried fuit. Medium body with a rich mouthfeel. Sweet burnt caramel, molasses, and peppery spice are all part of a complex flavor. In spite of all the malt character, the finish is not overly sweet, and has even a bit of a bitter chewy tang.

Bottle.  Poured a dark reddish brown with a moderately sized creamy light tan head that would lace considerably.  A very malty aroma with a touch of rich dark chocolate.  A robust flavor that fills the mouth.  Very malty with a smokey roast finish.  Nice.

Thanks to hopdog for the trade.  Pours a hazy deep reddish brown, with more red coming through when held to the light.  Large frothy light tan head that sustained and left lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, vanilla, oak, caramel, brown sugar, green hops and some berries. Flavor was a little more earthy, light smoke, hints of vanilla and oak, some dark fruits also in there with a sweet toasty maltiness and a great hop spiciness.  Great use of hops in this Scotch Ale.  Another winner for Founders!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2014 A deep red beer with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is sweet alcohol with strong notes of berries, while the flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of berries, combined with lighter notes of alcohol. The sweetness making it a bit sticky.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Unclear. Light brown head. Fruits, caramel and some light sherry notes in the aroma. Flavour is sweet, fruity with notes of caramel, cocoa and light alcohool. Medium bodied. Alcohol and sweetness in the end. Has a sherrytwist to it. Quite good. Thanks to DavidP for the trade.
Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Malty and fruity aroma. Soft and sweet malty and fruity flavour with notes of caramel and some yeast.
Deep brown with a foamy head.  Sweet and malty taste with a strong alcohol finish.  Not as good from the bottle as on tap, but still very good.
A great beer to enjoy- not chug! Highly recomended for the discerning beer buyer

Pours murky brown with a small creamy light brown head.  Aroma is malty and yeasty resin, prunes red wine, smoke and butterscotch.  Flavor is moderatly sweet, and complex with a lightly bitter finish, Medium to full bodied dry and creamy, softly carbonated and a light alcohol finish.
On tap at Curraghs: Great Brew, tastes of chocolate and coffee, real smooth.  Definetly want this one again
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2008 Very complex brew. Nice hop bitterness, but main taste is toasted malt with some sweetness. I prefer IPAs, but this is a great change of pace.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 Not a style I thought I like and I certainly do not like botterscotch which you can taste here, but Dirty Bastard was amazingly good. Creamy mouth feel. Balanced out nicely with hops. Smokey. Great nose. Smooth finish. I  only tried it once but noticed I had an upset stomach later that night-- will  not know if it is related until I give this another go.

A really nice Scotch Ale. In fact its the best Ive had in a while. I can really pin point the smokey trails of the neverending forest of goodness. Its so complexly bitter with such sweet tiggles of refreshing smores from young story telling camp fires.

Pours a murky reddish-brown with a medium beige head. Toffee, chocolate and peat in the nose. Whoah, my kind of Scotch Ale; bold and flavorful with a big helping of bittering hops that balances things out very nicely. Flavor has notes of dark caramel, peat, smoke, chocolate, brown sugar, cherry and dark fruits. Alcohol content very well-hidden. Full, round and creamy on the palate with fine-beaded carbonation. Very good stuff.

12oz bottle. Poured a dark, dark amber or a deeper brownish color with a large sized off white head. Aromas of smoke, peat, toffee, and caramel. Tastes of caramel, chocolate, dark fruits, and roasted malts. Light alcohol in the finish.

A decent scotch ale.  Nice copper hue... smells like a tub of malt extract tastes heavily of malt with a bit of a caramel finish.  Not a bad brew but not necessarily the best scotch ale.  Not much in the way of smokiness...

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2006 Tasted with OhioGuzzler...  Amber borwn, murky.  Very malty aroma
Sweet and malty.  A bit of an alcohol bite, some bitterness toward the end.  More like a strong ale or barley wine and not some much like a scotch ale.  No smoke flavors at all.  12 oz bottle, $1.99 from the Dilly Deli.  UPDATE:  Had this on draught at the "Founders at Dilly Deli" night on 9/21/2006....  It was good, but very much the same as from the bottle.  16 oz draught (8.5% alcohol), $4.00 at Dilly Deli.

appearance: 4  smell: 4.5  taste: 4.5  mouthfeel: 4.5  drinkability: 4

Appearance: Pours an amber caramel color with hints of orange and a decent head.

Smell: Dark fruit, caramel malts and brown sugar.

Taste: A bit of tart cherries, green apple plumb and brown sugar. Then toasty caramel malt molasses and a shot of scotch whiskey dumped in there. 

This one I must get more of!

Mouthfeel: Extremely thick and sticky, very chewy, like a Scotch Ale / Wee Heavy should be. 

Drinkability: I love this style of beer but if you tried to session this your gut may explode =)

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

via trade with OhioDad - Pours a deep copper color with a thin light tan head.  Has a sweet malt aroma.  Flavor is malty sweet with the bitterness to back it.  A liitle dry but smooth.  A medium to full body beer.  A good beer.  Thanks Scott.

smokey, peat, hop bitterness, caramel/toffee, musky sweet -  has syrupy feel to it.   roasted coffee flavor and maltiness.  cloudy reddish brown appearance.  strong hop aroma  Another hit for FOUNDERS.

bottle.  Aroma:  Big maltiness, some dark fruits, light chocolate, and some alcohol. Maybe a whisper of smoke in the aroma?   Big aroma.  Appearance:  Dark brown, with dark red highlights when held to the light.  Light tan head that collapsed quickly.  Some nice lacing.  Flavor:  Malt from the aroma continues in the flavor.  Big roasted malt flavor with large caramel and toffee flavors.  Dark fruits.  Some peatiness also peeking through in the finish.  Hop bitterness is high for the style, but enjoyable.  A nice sweet finish, but isnt sticky at all.  Palate:  Full bodied and slightly chewy.  Medium carbonation.  Alcohol leaves a nice warming on the tongue.  Overall:  A great beer.  Maltiness is king here and it really shines through.  The hopping is right on the money.  Just enough to keep it from getting to sweet, not to much to overshadow the malt.  Definately buying more of this.
Complex malt character, pleasantly sweet but with that little hop kick in there too. Alcohol makes itself known in a nice way. Delicious beer from a brewery I wish I had known about earlier.

Good Scotch Ale, pours a lovely redish brown with small head. 

Not a lasting aftertaste to note, but the ABV packs a velvet punch with the swallow. A nice beer that Ill have to repeat in the Fall.

When poured I was surprised to see a hint of red in the color.  This is mostly brown, with not much head and a slight red tint.  The aroma is what really caught my attention.  A very malty scent, but I caught the faintest bit of fruitiness to it.  The taste is slightly sugary, and has the faintest hint of spice.  It swallows smooth and leaves a short lived aftertaste I enjoy more than the flavor.
Slightly sweet, malty, with some caramel and spice. Zero aftertaste which was strange, but very good flavor while it lasted. ABV is warming all the way down.

This is one fine scotch ale. The pour is dark with a very nice brown head. The aroma is malt with some caramel mixed in. The flavor is very, very nice. The tastes are of a sweet malt, with hints of caramel, and brown sugar. The mouthfeel is thick and pleasing, and this one finishes smooth as silk. Second only to Wee Heavy in my opinion."

Pours out a very dark brown color with a slight tan head.  Aroma is very malty.  The flavor is also very malty and as the discription depicts, hints of smoke.  This is a nice example of a scotch ale.  The one I drank had a little dust on it so I guess it was an Old Dirty Bastard.

Pours a hazy dark brown red with a substantial though thinning tan head.  The nose is particularly noteworthy.  Creamy rich malt lends caramel, toffee, and event hints of chocolate to this ale.  Intermingled with the alcohol are whispers of smoke and light floral hops.  The mouthfeel is unbelievably over the top.  Incredibly luxurious, I would expect this feel much more from an imperial stout than a scotch ale.  The flavors do not disappoint.  Big sweet malt lends a nice backdrop over which the roast and smoke can play.  Theres some definite alcohol in the flavor helping to cut the sweetness as well as a some gentle engish style hops.  I really enjoyed this, and perhaps it should be rated even higher, but compared to the aroma and the mouthfeel, I just couldnt justify bringing the flavor up any.  A delightful brew by any means.

Red colored beer with cloudy brown in the middle and a creamy looking tan head.  The aroma is awesome- malty, chocolate, toffee, sweet.  The flavour has the malty chocolate but also caramel, grapes, and hops, some smoky flavours and bitterness in the finish.  Creamy, smooth, but still soft and flowy in texture.  I would like this beer a lot for the aroma alone, but luckily it has the full package.

Bottle from Tom (oldgrowth) Thanks!  Brown colored pour.  Head is there, then it goes away pretty quick.  Taste is malty and rich, and very smooth.  All these beers that this brewery makes (that I have had) are so smooth, you could drink the entire bottle with one sip.  Very nice, and not really a style that is my favorite, but this one is very nice.
Beer pours dark mahogeny color with an off white head.  Aroma is nicely malty.  Flavor is smoked malt with a bit of smoked peat.  Enjoyable.

Bottle shared by <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank> mds, thanks Mike.  Deep ruby in colour, thin beige head, some lace.  The aroma had some butterscotch, plums, caramel malts and some small amounts of noticable alcohol.  The flavour was a bit smoky, lots of sweet caramel malts, traces of alcohol.  Chewy bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes lingering, nicely bitter, some alcohol warmth.  Not to bad.

"Poured a brown/red color okay head weak lacing. Aroma was like sweet candy like ealge said. Flavor was a little to sweet for my liking but of caramel. I didnt pick up enough smoke and peat. Okay beer could have been better. "
Burgandy pour with fading head.  Nose featured rummy fruits, mainly figs.  Flavour shares the deepness of the fruits, with peaty smoke, and a medicinal undertone.

This one poured a reddish brown color with a nice initial head. Lacing was weak. Aroma was sweet candy (cinnamin also?), some smoke, some caramel. The flavor was a bit too sweet, caramel and some sort of a candy I couldnt place. Hop presence was detectable and the peat smoke flavors light for the style. But, this was still pretty enjoyable.
BOttle. Big sweet malty/hoppy nose. Dark brown body with a film of bubbles. Taste-honey, mildly husky, sweet, medium spicy hops, caramel, very light smoke.
Strong roasted qualities, intense caramel, tootsie roll.  Sour grapes in the flavor, with alcohol.  Thick body and richness.

Dark mahogany in color with a small tan head. Nice bold sweet malt flavor, a little syrupy. A touch of smoke and dark fruit. The hops are more abundant than expected, a nice surprise, I like the hop bitterness. This is a very good bold beer.

Pours nice garnet brown with almost zero head. Aroma is richly caramel and toffee, chewy chocolate with a touch of light hops. The flavor has a nice bitterness to cover the mentioned flavors, and is thick and syrupy in the mouth. Perhaps a little overcarbonated. It still rolls down the throat nice and smooth.
bottle - Warm light mahogany color with light creamy tan head.  Nutty aroma.  Taste is a sweet lightly charred maltiness with dried fruit notes and just enough hop to break the sweetness.

greatalcool caramel aroma, look good with a great hazelnut brown, with a creamy pale brown head and the flavor are a burst of alcool but smoothen fast after to leave the place to some butterscotchand a bit smoky

Pours a very dark amber color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, spices, and a slight hint of alcohol.  Flavor is the same, starts off with the dark fruits then gives way to the spices and then finishes with some smokiness, sweet malts, and a hint of hops.  Decent bitter finish.  Another good brew from Founders.
Thsi beer pours a deep dark red / brown and has a very slight head. Tastes malty with a slight smoke aroma. Good stuff.
Bottle: Rich golden brown color, slight tan head. Excellent blend of complexity in the taste. A slight bite in the finish. Overall excellent beer.

Bottle: Pours a dark ruby color with no head and lacing at all. Aroma is malty with hints of spices, raisins and plums. Mouthfeel is creamy and like a cola body leaving a sticky bitter finish. Alcohol is evident but not powerful in the aroma and finish. Easy drinking and enjoyable.

I thought this was prett good...on tap at brewery.  Poured a dark brown with not head.  Aroma was spicey, malty, and very sweet.  Flavor was a syrupy sweet malt, toffee, and heavy spice.  Mouthfeel was quite light, but also kind of sticky.  Not very much like a scotch ale, but still pretty good.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2006 Bottle. Pours red brown, semi opaque. Very nice diminishing tan head. Aroma of sugary raisens and malt. Initial flavor is very malty with flavors of sweet dark fruits. It quickly kicks you in the taste buds and diminishes to a bitter,sticky, and slightly alcohol finish. The flavors did not seem to transition smoothly, which made this one a little odd. I still enjoyed this beer though. With the exception of the Centennial IPA, Founders has yet to disappoint me.
Robe auburn très claire surmontée dune mousse beige mince. Arômes de caramel, de bois et de scotch. Saveurs de caramel, dérable, de malt chocolat et dalcool. Houblon de soutien.

12 oz. Bottle.  from Dilly Deli.  Bottle Conditioned.  Drank 5/10/06.  Pours clear deep amber / red.  Almost no head  Thick layer of foam that goes away almost immediately to a ring.  Big, chunky sediment, no lacing.  Aroma - sweet malts, raisins, plums, spice.  Maybe a little peat and smoke.  Flavor - really sweet and malty.  A lot of alcohol warmth.  Decent amt. of bitterness, but definitely dominated by sweet malts.  Not as smokey or peaty as traditional scotch ales, but those flavors are present a little.  Sweet and warm finish.  Palate - nice, thick, medium to full body.  Not a high level of carb., but enough to balance the rest of the thickish body.  Overall really good.  Definitely an americanized version of a scotch ale, but really good.  Not surprising from Founders.  Strong and complex, plenty of alcohol and a fair amt. of bitterness.  I like it.

dark amber/ light brown with a small white head that disappears quickly. aroma big sweet roasted caramel malt with a hint of alcohol. flavor sweet roasted malt. caramel slight bread flavor some smokey notes. finish sweet with some warm alcohol. full bodied. very nice creamy mouthfeel. very nice beer.
There is a pleasant malty aroma with an alcohol background.  The color is a deep red with a creamy tan head.  The flavor is malty with an alcohol warming finish.

Purchased in bottle in Menomonee Falls, WI. This was a classic scotch ale, much like McEwans. If there was ever a beer to put hair on ones chest, this is probably it. A deep red color, very malty. This beer tastes like some sort of masculinity that I can only dream of. I had a few beers before this one, but Dirty Bastard is the one I will remember. A fantastic brew, very sweet-tasting and smoky but not overpowering. Dirty Bastard has a very full mouthfeel; one can taste alcohol when you breathe in with a mouthful of this stuff. I would drink this stuff by the gallon if my liver could handle it. Highly recommended.
Good stuff. Had not sampled a Scotch Ale before this one, but get the distinct impression this should be the template for further field research. Bittersweet, molasses subtleties, yummy!

Draught. Pours crystalline cherrywood color with thin khaki head. The aroma is sweet and malty with some caramel and a touch of alcohol. The flavor is malty and earthy with some bitter chocolate and molasses and some caramel in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2006 Ive seen this on various shelves for about 2 years now and have finally picked it up. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thin cream colored head. Smell has a peat and vanilla scent to it. Flavor is well balanced with a nice toasted malt followed by sweet caramel and vanilla. Alcohol is present but not unless you try to taste it. There is a new flavor in it after every sip. Amazing.

draught. A dark red which appears almost black at the thicker regions of the glass and a tan head. The aroma is quite biscuity with a sparkling acidity. The flavor is very bready and sweet with a biting bitterness and subtle citrus notes. Earthy, smokey coffee is hinted at in the finish. The caramel comes through about then as well.  Interesting.

I cant really see what is so beautiful about this beer.  I refuse to finish it.  I had Founders Breakfast Stout and was not impressed with that either.  It pours with a weak off-white head, which is a good indication of too many adjuncts.  The roasted malts made me wonder whether I was drinking a beer or swallowing an ashtray.  Dont waste your money.

bottle smelled a bit like Old Style.  pours an elegent brown, quite small mustard brown head.  ebbs nicely.  not a very powerful aroma, some coffee, quite a bit of raisin. very little hops.  much better than the bottle smell.  wow, that tastes great.  so balanced, and for some reason im surprised how absent the alcohol taste is.  actually, there it is.  its quite nice though.  woody, kinda reminds me of bear republics.  the alcohol is growing stronger and the taste worse as it warms, i dont think i like this beer.

Pour dark brown with off white head - some sediment floating in the beer.  Roasted and lightly burnt malt on the aroma with a light bit of toffee.  Flavor is smooth roasted malt with toffee flavors and a grainy feel.  Finish has a light bit of  hop bitterness, but mainly still the sweet maltiness.  Has almost a butter toffee lingering taste.  Very nice example of the style.

Poured dark amber with practically no head.  There was some lace on the side of the glass but not much else.  Caramel, currant, caramel and chocolate jump out in the aroma.  Smokey taste with really nice chocolate and currant notes.  Palate was pretty full but not perfect.  It was fruity and had a good touch of alcohol.  The finish was quite bitter but it worked well.  The hops were much more present in the finish.  Very good overall but a bit unbalanced at times.

Aromas of are sweet and earthy...  Body is a fairly dark brown with some reddish tones and head is a minimal film.  Flavor is sweet, of caramel and some fruity flavors.  Much thicker mouthfeel than expected from a scotch.  Almost has a brandywine character due to sweet syrupiness.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: a good scotch ale, even made me forget that the hockey team that knocked us out of the playoffs was sponsored by founders and had this as their logo

Dark copper,no head. Malt peat aroma. Other than that this beer is a waste of $$. I think it was the nasty ass hop finish turned tongue scraper finale that killed it. I love hops but this was just unbalanced.

Dark amber. Small, frothy, tan head settles completely. Aroma of roasty malt, subtle, smokey peat, and moderate hop presence. Same flavor, surprisingly well balanced, a bit of alcohol in the finish. Id like more smoke and more peat in a scotch ale. Full, smooth body. Great brew, but needs more scotch.

Pours a deep brownish crimson with a medium-light tan head that turns to a bubbly film. A sweet aroma of caramel malt and rasins fills the nose with the presence of smoke, though not overwhelmingly so. The flavor is also fairly sweet, caramel and  maple followed with a small smokey peat note.  A somewhat bitter alcohol/hop flavor comes out in the finish which feels a bit awkward, though its not really off putting. The beer is both malty and smooth over the tounge...a nice solid body that finishes both dry and a bit bitter. A toasty beer, though I was hoping for a bit more peat to come out and perhaps a tad more smoke. Fairly easy to drink, though I dont think drink more than one or two in a night.  A great cool weather beer to be sure.

Bottle: Poured a dark brown color ale with a small off-white foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of strong malt, caramel and a light touch of smoke. Taste is also dominated by the strong malt presence with sweet caramel with a subtle touch of peat. Body is quite full and carbonation is low. Very interesting take on the style.

Creamy rich and slightly smoky (almost a pepper smoke) taste.  Very nice texture of silk and cream, with a medium dryness in the finish.  Well crafted and very drinkable, really only losing points for a bit of a sikly sweet maple presence that, in my opinion, just doesnt have a place in this beer.

(03.02.06) 12 oz brown bottle purchased from Archor Liquors, Chicago, IL.  Pours clear brown with light syrup-like consistency.  Small black particulates.  No head. Soft-carbonation.   Caramel/toffee/ toasted malt aromas.  Full-bodied Scottish ale that starts with moderate malt sweetness and toffee/toasted malt flavors. Finishes with light bitterness and roasted malt flavor. Smooth and rich. Definite alcoholic warmth.  A delicious malty beer with a memorable toasted malt flavor and dangerous moreish quality..

Bottle shared with tupalev & jerc - courtesy of tupalev. Mahogany colour with a tiny head. Big, sweet aroma with notes of caramel and smokey whiskey. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but OK. Flavour holds a great balance of brown sugar sweetness and earthy peat notes, with a nicely hopped finish. Lots of attempts at this style disappoint me, but I was quite happy with this one.

Pours a dark orangish amber with slightly tan orange head that fades quickly.  Aroma of Chocolate Riesans.  Flavor is bold with a faint sweetness in the up front followed by bits of wasabi on the back of the tongue and finally heat in the throat.  Very well done and a good flagship in my opinion.

Dark red color with a miniscule tan head.  Aroma and flavor of chocolate covered caramel with a little heat on the back of the throat. Very one dimensional, but its a good dimension.  Tastes so much like 3Fs Robert the Bruce its uncanny.

Bottle, shared with Jerc and GregClow.  Decent sweet malt aroma - some caramel and alcohol and a hint of smoke - nice.  Brown in the glass with a small off white head.  Nice warming alcohol, earthy hops, and lots of sweetness in taste - now this is a properly done Scotch ale!! As it warm it becomes very strong and releases a hint pf peat smoke in the taste.  Nothing new here, just a very well done Scotch Ale - one of my new instant favourites in this category.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2012 2012-12-08. Crisp dark red-brown body, modest beige head. 3+ Very sweet malty flaovur has odd sugary fruitiness to it, earthy almost smokey quality that is probably not quite the right descriptor but thats the best I can come up with today. Earthy muted peat in the background. Smooth medium bodied is under carbonated. Too sweet overall. 7/4/6/3/14 On tap at Coles, Buffalo
2006-02-XX. Brown body with a small tan head that fades. Sweet malt aroma with hints of peaty-earthy character that carries over to the flavour profile. Sweet malt base. Medium palate. Earthy character distracts for me personally, but I think I have come to realize that my mental picture of a scotch ale is not necessarily what everyone else pictures. I prefer those that lean away from the peat smoke and more towards the big sweet malts. Regardless, a very nice Scotch Ale! Bottle.  7/3/7/4/14

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2006 Bottle. Pours a dark red with a thin tan head. The aroma is full of malts, with a bit of dried fruit, some caramel, and a little chocolate.  The flavor is initially sweet with a hint of smoke at the end.  Very pleasant.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a reddish hue to the color.  Quickly diminishing tan head.  Sweet malt nose with notes of caramel and raisins, fruit and cocoa.  Great body with a lingering alcohol resinous finish.  Initial taste is sweet caramel malts.  Followed quickly with the alcohol burn.  There is a mild smokiness somewhere in the middle.  First of the night and its gonna be difficult (but enjoyable) to top it this evening.  Still sippin and lovin it!

Brownish barleywine appearance. Aroma whaffing of alcohol, also barleywineish and some spice and roast. Taste well balanced though followed by tongue numbness. Hops at finish with roast. Very well malted, some sweet rather than bitter chocolate, and cinammon, and a touch of smoke. and an easy drink.

Aroma is heavy on caramel, with a bit of alcohol, butterscotch, and light coffee.  body is a nice brown ruby with a very thin tan head.  taste is caramel, dried cherries, with a bit of alcohol and bubblegum.

Aroma:Roast caramel,alcohol...
Appearance:redish-brown,small tan head....
Flavor:Alcohol,caramel,Light chemical flavor.....
I think this beer taste more like a barley wine.....

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  Deep clear mahogany with a small diminishing off-white head.  Thick sweet aroma of rich roast caramel malt, wood, chocolate and hops, nice and boozy - lightly peaty scotch.  Taste of chocolate malt, quite roasty, not as sweet as the aroma, with more prominent alcohol and wood resin - it actually has a fairly bitter finsh - I like the balance, and the peat character is very appealing to me.  Mouthfeel is sharp, alcoholic, fairly thick and sryupy - I really like this, its almost like a light barleywine.

Bottle. Pours a murky brown with red hues and a large somewhat lasting light-brown head. Lovely mild aroma of malt, chocolate, caramel and alcohol (whiskey-ish). Well balanced flavour starts off sweet and malty along with some chocolate and smoke and ends with mild alcohol and citrus hops. The alcohol is well hidden for an 8.3 % beer. Syrupy mouthfeel and medium to full bodied. Pretty good, I enjoyed it quite a bit.
decent ale, if you like the style i thought it was ok but wont be rushing out to get more. poured a dark red with no foam wow! is this stuff beer or whiskey?not for the crud light crowd
Im not crazy about the style of beer.  Deep reddish-brown in color.   Decent taste to it.  This beer has a good kick.
Draft Pours a Deep ruby brown with a creamy off white head. Aromas include malt, carmel and chocolate. Flavors are very well balanced with malt hop and dough in the flavor.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2006 Pours a clear deep reddish brown with a small tan head which quickly disappears.   I now know what people mean by the smell of peat--this beer has it, a very earthy smell along with some alcohol and smokiness.  Also has some chocolate cherry notes. Taste is more of the same.   Not really noticing much bitterness than a slight bitter finish.  Not a bad beer by any means, but I think this may be my first Scotch ale, so Im not a huge fan of the style just yet.  I may rerate once I get to the end up the sixer.

Rerate:  Big, rich malts and piney hops noted, and this is a pretty good beer.  Hops noticeable throughout, and upping the rating from 3.4
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pour is nice warm mahogany brown with a thin very dense tan head...smell is chocolatey with some big hints of smoke and alcohol...taste is sweet with definate strawberry and cherry notes, giving way to strong smokey flavor...alcoholic sweet finish...seems way too hot for 8.3%...

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2007 Cloudy brown pour, small white head. Aroma of crystal malt. Flavor is caramel, light roasted grains and some smoke. Almost a fruity aftertaste with a touch of banana. Sweet but with a light smokey kick. Full mouthfeel and really a good scotch ale.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Bottle from SantaPours a rich mahogany, smells of barleywine.  Nice lacing.  Flavor is cherry, strawberry, and more strawberry.  Interesting beer.  A bit of black cherry seems to be poking in the background.  I detect a bit of peach as well; could it be that Im dreaing of a vacation to the Hill Country?  Good, and very interesting.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: I think EDA gave me this bottle a while ago- just waiting for a cold night to try it. Pours a hazy deep amber/light murky brown with a thin film of a head.  Low carbonation.  Sweet aroma, with dates, raisins, caramel, and brown sugar.  Flavor is also mostly sweet with a wierd lightly bitter smoky finish.  Light tobacco, caramel, molasses and brown sugar in the middle.  Smooth mouthfeel and easy finish.  Great Scotch ale.

12 oz. bottle thanks to My Santa.  Such good stuff.  Dark color with not much head.  I love these Founders lables too.  Aromas were very malty.  Caramel, molassas, brown sugar, raisins.  Flavors were similar with roastiness and burnt matls too.  So good.  A wonderful wee heavy.

This Scotch Ale pours a deep ruby red brown color form a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate with a touch of smoke. A medium bodied scotch ale. Malts are roasty and chocolate. Little bit of smoke, little bit of peat. Very smooth, fairly sweet. Lots of chocolate flavors. Nice balance. Touch of hops at the finish. Hides the alcohol very well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

weird looking clouded pour with a nice grey head. chocolate aroma. smells like cold chocolate chip cookies. lots of chocolate flavor with a doughy taste. damn, this is a liquid chocolate chip cookie. just a nice sweet easy drinking beverage that ius way too high in alcohol  for the taste. this could be dangerous. thanks, santa.
No head.  Strong hoppy aroma.  Dark copper color.  Tastes of hops and roasted malts.  Great taste at the back of the palate.
Thanks to Duane for this one! Sweetness, dark sugar, hit me first, alcohol is there, but not overpowering. Fruity, then sharp as it warms, not bad at all, quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 On tap at Ashelys in Ann Arbor.

Pours an attractive, clear ruby with no head. The aroma is bready raisin and pum; the flavor is wet brown/burnt sugars and dried fruit, delightfully mellow at first but quickly giving way to a late-kicking alcohol burn that is too sharp to be excused even at 8.3%.

This beer has some nice earthy roasted malts hanging on in the middle. A caramel  candy sweetness is also apparent. Ends on a surprising hop note, with hints of smoke in the background.  This beer has some nice depth and is quite tasty.  The noticable thing about this beer is that the hint of cherry in the middle keeps it oh so smooth. This doesnt get bogged down in dry smoky flavors like some other Scotch Ales seem to.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2005 Deep mahogany pour with a rich tan head that quickly disappears...Mainly rich roasted caramel maltiness...but with a surprisingly strong hop bitterness profile... very nice bitter bite in the finish.   Some smoke and peatiness, as expected. Very nice entry by this outstanding brewer...!

Bottle poured a dark brown with a thick, creamy off white head.
Sweet malty, candy like aroma.
Flavor is sweet malts, molasses and fruit with a smooth creamy mouth feel.
light roasty alcohol finish.

This beer is super carbonated; it starts to foam as soon as I pop the cap.  The head on this is easily three-fingers thick and is a light amber-brown color.  The beer is a deep amber color that shows a murky ruby-orange color when held up to the light.  The aroma is pretty darn pronounced with strong notes of maraschino cherry, caramel, sweet toffee and a bit of toasty malt notes at the end.  The aroma definitely has a sharp sweetness to it.  As the beer warms up it picks up a bit of subtle phenolic smokiness and maybe even a hint of some musty-type character.

The beer is quite full on the palate, but the high carbonation makes it seem a bit lighter than it actually is.  A couple of swirls later, I have released the excess carbonation, lets see what the beer is like now.  The beer is fairly sweet, but not as much as the aroma suggested; it is a mix of caramel and toffee sweetness.  There is a bit of that cherry sweetness, but it is much more subdued than the nose.  The finish has notes of roast malt, a hint of coffee and a dry toasty note; plus it also has a hint of alcohol to it.  There is not much in the way of perceptible hop notes here; the malt certainly dominates.  This beer is definitely a sipping beer.

I was a bit worried, because of the high carbonation, that the beer was infected, but I dont get any of that in the taste.  As the beer warms up a bit I get a note reminiscent of rum in the finish (both a bit of alcohol heat and the fermented/ distilled molasses flavor).  This is quit a tasty beer and, unlike some of their other high octane offerings, this one has a nice balance to it, despite being a malt bomb.

Amber brown in color with little head. Aroma is sweet and lightly fruity, caramel. Flavor is moderately sweet with lots of malts. Finish is slightly sweet with a little bitterness. Not bad, but I had hoped for more.

This was funny a visitor from Michigan brings a sixer of this just after I had called someone a dirty bastard earlier that night at work. Mahagony color to the body with thin head cover. I have the aroma and flavor the same for this one. Seemed like a medium bodied sweet porter. Smooth on the palate, good brew.

dark coppery color with a huge caramel malt aroma, along with some chocolate, and a little bourbon.  not much head at all, just some little white bubbles floating around. very sweet and malty flavor, goes  a little bit too hoppy at the end and looses some smoothness.  flavor is mostly caramel and chocolate.  didnt get any of the bourbon or wood that was in the nose, though, that was a bit of a bummer.  still very nice though.

Bottle from CharlesDarwin.  You know, this is pretty much what I expected it to be.  Pours dark red with a small head and a few floaties.  Aroma is a little light, but has good breadth with chocolate, cherry, some peat, maybe a little molasses and a healthy dose of bourbon.  Sharp and tingly but sweet mouthfeel.  Caramel, bourbon, some hops, some rye, chocolate, cherry (and other dark fruits), more bourbon and some butterscotch in the flavor.  Very earthy and smoky finish.  The amount of alcohol knocked it out of balance a little, but its still a very solid brew.  Thanks, Tom!

This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of light brown colored foamy mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a transparent dark caramel brown colored softly carbonated body.  The aroma was mild with brown malt Scottish like notes and the mouth feel was initially tingly followed by a mellow malty finish that was crisp and clean.  The flavor was mild sweet Scottish malts that were sweet and semi-dry.

Chocolate, coffee and rich malt aromas, deep ruby, wears a tiny tan head. Flavours of fine malt, butterscotch and mocha. Medium bodied, well balanced, smooth, mellow and warming. Terrific!

        Thanks radiomgb.

bottle. ruby-brown body with a small short lasting off-white head. caramel and butterscotch sweet malt aroma. its sweet and mildly alcoholic with generally well blended flavours. soft carbonation. warm throughout. good stuff.

Interesting woody, malt aroma. Scotch alcohol present in background. Clear, ruby in appearance. Very smooth , clear velvety ale .  Good work on malt. Interesting accents .gently but not boring nor flat. Alcohol well incorporated. Very nice.

Poured out a very nice dark brown color with not really much head to speak of. The aroma was very earthy. The taste was unlike any other scotch Ive had. Very earthy with notes of pete some fruit and maybe a sweet/roasty finish. Very complex

Being from Iowa, I dont always get to purchase the beers that I would like to.  That being said, when I went to Madison last month I had my choice of a handful of good IPAs (my favorite style) at the local liquor store.  However, when it came time to buy I decided on a six pack of Dirty Bastard, because I had heard such good things about it.  And I have to say that I am not dissappointed.  The appearance of this brew is absolutely perfect (looks of rich mahogany).  Sweet up front with a  nice roasty finish.  A full mouthfeel and it goes down so smooth.  To be honest, I wish this beer had a little more alcohol, but other than that, a truly superb beer.

12 oz bottle, via trade with atpayne.  Poured a very dark mahogany, zero head but a thin ring clinging to rim, and minimal carbonation visible.  Aroma featuring a huge amount of molassas, with dark fruits, soy sauce, peat, and a little alcohol.  Flavor is heavy on the malt with a dominating taste of soy sauce.  Virtually no hop flavor at all.  Finish is alcoholic but very pleasant.  This has a great thick chewy mouthfeel with  minimal carbonation.  Mouth coating but  not cloying.  This delivered much more than expected, a big chewy beer in a style category filled with alot of lame stuff.  In some ways this reminded me of a well aged Old Ale.  This beer is awesome!

Nice dark brown/black color,small tan head that faded quickly leaing just a faint lace behind.Nice malty aroma with some fruit notes and a decent sweetness as well.Malty roasty flavor right away,with a nice hop bite coming on in the middle and end.The alcohol for the most part is well hidden with the exception of a warm feeling going down.Over all its a damn fine brew i think and well worth having some more around.Which i may just have to pick a 6er for the winter.

Maintains a small off-white head after the pour and is a surprisingly light brown-red in color. Nose is strongly sweet which is the case with the flavor as well. Caramel is definitely the overriding taste before it gives way to a subtle hop-infused bitterness. This is an excellent scotch ale that never betrays the high alcohol level.

Draft at FBC. Small tan head that mostly diminished, fine-small sized bubbles, poor lacing, softly carbonated, transparent, and a reddish brown hue. Nose was malty, caramel and sweet. Flavor was caramel, sweet, chocolate, and vinuous but not overly so. Smooth palate. Medium body. Nicely done and very quaffable.

Bottle. Deep brown color, some reddish highlights and a beige head. Full malty aroma, caramelly, molasses, generally sweet, some earthiness. Flavor is caramelly, fairly sweet, touch of smoke, a bit of alcohol. Medium to full bodied, a touch hot, should mellow out nicely. Tasty beer, Ive got more to let em settle out a bit.
Slight taste of fig and raisins. Definitely a burnt caramel aftertaste. Pallate is a little week though.
Great beer. Smells good, tastes better. The amazing thing is this beer starts bitter goes over sweet to sour. just a fantastic beer.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 Pours dark red brown with creamy tan head, mostly diminishing. Aroma is coffee, caramel, toffee, and molasses. Flavor is roasted and sweet. Caramel, chocolate, some coffee, some raisins and figs. Hops come in at the end. Full-bodied, smooth, creamy texture, low carbonation.  Warming alcohol finish.

Poured a dark mahogany with a semi-creamy off-white head.  Sweet somewhat dry aroma of syrup and molasses.  Taste is sweet with hints of caramel, molasses, and a touch of smoke, which does well to offset the sweetness.  Very little alcohol character... I had no idea this was 8%.  Very enjoyable.  Nice body, lightly carbonated and pretty full.  Delicious.

Bottle, dark brown pour.  Roasty aroma with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Nice milk chocolate,  molasses, and hints of chocolate flavors.  More roastiness and a touch of smoke.  Finishes nicely with very good mouthfeel.

Draft - big, sweet malty aroma.  Appearance is almost that of grape juice with a smallish head and next to no retention.  Overly sweet finish, some milder malt before.  I found next to no hops anywhere.  Eh.
from bottle.  dark amber color. smells of roast.  taste of coffee and roasted malts.  full body beer with slight bitter after taste.  smooth and enjoyable

Bottle.  A deep, muddy brown with a very thin dark-khaki head.  Milk chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, malts and some soy sauce in the rich aroma.  Very low level of carbonation.  Smooth and thick.  Tastes like a chocolate candy bar with a caramel center and some raisins.  Some coffee-like bitterness present too.  A little musty.  The slightest hint of smoke.  Good stuff.
Bottle. Deep copper in color with a nice tan head. Fruity and malty aroma. Caramel notes. Malty and hoppy flavor. Light licorice. Full bodied. Finish is malty and hoppy. Nice beer. Enjoyable.
Bottle. Orange, nice tan head. Massive malty fruity aroma, hints of carmel. Huge malty flavors. Carmel. Full body. Malty finish. Real nice.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: cloudy dark rust color, short & quick tan foamy head.  aroma is syrupy malt, some vinuous notes and a little whiskey/licorice.  smells a little like a thin barleywine!  mouthfeel starts thin and hoppy, then gets syrupy malty sweet and some light licorice.  a dash of salt.  biterish hoppy malt finish.  mild "session scotch ale".  thanks Styles for this one!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 The body is brown with ruby highlights, on top of it thrones a thin light brown head. Very good aroma of caramel, smoked and earthy malt and alcohol, very appealing. Excellent flavor of rich smoked and earthy malt, thick caramel and alcohol, the finish is bitter. The body is thick and generous with a silky and creamy texture, the carbonation is low. This scotch ale has a good measure of balance and complexitty, great stuff, Founders is probably my favorite brewery discovered in 2005.

Thanks to JPDIPSO for this one.  Im so tired of seeing "Scottish ales".  It always pleases me to drink a true scotch ale, and this one was great.  Pours muddy dark brown with a medium khaki head.  Aroma of caramel malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit.  The taste is roasty malty, with big chocolate, dark fruit, cognac, and port taste hints.  Dense palate.  This one is 2 parts strong scotch ale and a dash of barleywine thrown in for good measure.

Brownish-red.  Smells quite sweet, maple syrup, toffee, a bit of peatiness.  Lots of sweet caramel and toffee, sugars are very pronounced here.  A mite earthy and peaty, could use some more for more depth.  Raisiny.  Lots of alcohol, the abv is very assertive.  Not particularly scotchy.

Courtesy of Pailhead. Malty and musty with some pastry sweetness. Brown with a red tinge to it. Razor thin head. You can feel the malts in your mouth it is so viscous. Tastes a bit like raisin bread, and toffe mashed up together though there is a disconcerting mustiness (peat malt) that doesnt really compliment anything else the beer has to offer.

Bottle Poures a dark cloudy redish brown.  Lots of suspended "floaties" Small light brown head and only a few wisps of lacing.  Aroma is a tantalizing medly of sweet woody notes and vanilla, caramel and dark fruits.  Flavor was similar but more bitter and woody.  Late sharp bitter aftertaste.  interesting but not quite what I hoped.  Thanks to Pailhead for the bottle

GTM. Sweet, candy like aroma. Somewhat faint. Thick reddish, murky, dark, almost brown body with off-white head. Not much head. Unique flavor. Rich with some hops. Not quite as good as I was expecting, but still very solid.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Pint at Barley Island - Aroma is malty with toffee and caramel.  Pours muddy brown with a small head and good lacing.  Flavor is milk chocolate, caramel, toffee, peat and a hop snap.  Palate is creamy and crisp with a sticky finish.  A tasty brew Im glad I revisited.
 Original rating 6/3/6/4/15=3.4 - 12oz - Malty aroma with carmel, toffee, and raisin.  Poured a deep reddish-brown with a small head and little lacing.  Flavor is sweet malt, carmel, toffee, raisin, and a touch of chocolate.  A bit astringent.  Palate is thick and chewy, not smooth like it should be.  Not a bad scotch ale, but doesnt quite hit the mark.
Dark brown body with no head. Caramel, alcohol, malt, and some more - its strong. Reminds me of a barley wine. Flavor is the same with a high alcohol flavor.

Couleur ambrée aux reflets rouge foncé.  Mousse beige pale et persistante, adhérant aussi à la paroi du verre.  Arômes difficilement perceptible. Malt et sucre semblent être en bon terme, puis arrivent lalcool avec ces réminiscences de raisin sec, passant par le jus de raisin sucré.  Faible réchauffement occasionné par lalcool en finale.  Corps dépaisseur moyenne, texture sirupeuse, faible carbonatation.  Une étrange création.  Servi en fût  Chez Ashsleys, Ann Arbor, Michigan, Juillet 2005.

Pours a dark auburn with a medium light tan head that fades. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, alcohol, slight smoke and leather. Flavor is of caramel, smoke, and a slight peat. Nice and rich but still very well balanced.

picked this bad boy up at Picadillys in Champaign yesterday.  a wonderful aroma of earthy malt and just a tad of alcohol.  pour was a deep ruby red and little head.  this is sticky sweet on the lips and the flavors are of roasty, toasty malt and some smokey characteristics as well.  finish is slightly alcoholic, but I could see knocking down several of these on a cool autumn evening and catching quite a buzz!

Deep ruddy amber body with dense ultra-fine particulates and a uniform, sudsy, light tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, toasted nuts, and a touch of raisin. Sweet flavor like a Werthers Original toffee plus mild smoke. Unmistakably sweet but has a light roasty, phenolic counter-balance and some earthy bitterness. Rich, velvety palate. Quite rich but still dangerously drinkable. Not very complex, but plain delicious. Thanks OhioDad for another tasty brew.
Pretty damn good beer. Im not too familiar with scotch ales, but this is among the best I have had. Great beer to have in a 6-pack

Solid head, dark amber. Aroma is malty, sweet, with hints of alcohol and nuttiness. Great soft, frothy mouthfeel. Taste is buttery, malty, and sweet. Finish becomes bitter, toasted. Very well balanced beer, although maybe not quite to style.

Tap Asheys Ann Arbor:  Loveley red mahagony with nice head. Candy aroma with strong complex palate similar to the red rye. Bold malts come through when finishing. Lovely amount of hops, slightly bitter finish awesome beer.

Perfect mahogny body and cream head.  Sweet chocolate peaty, candy malt aroma.  The flavor is of a strong, sweet candy and highly alcoholic with a tad of a bitter finish.  A barleywine esq, strong scotch ale, that is fit for winter.
Wow!  I wasnt sure if I liked Scotch ales before drinking this.  If all Scotchs taste this amazing, then Im a fan.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2005 I owe many thanks to EDA, I like scotch ales, this is the new #1. Poured a deep chestnut, with nice fizzy head. Nose was powerful,  malty and smoke. Taste was earthy, and a shinning example of the style. Great. Get this guys.
