Bottled. U.S. Beer 21 of 31 for <a href=http://www.americanbeermonth.com>American Beer Month! Rich malty and alcohol smell right off the top. Pour is a deep mahagony under a brownish persistent head with fine bubbles. Fine, sippable taste, more of the same malt richness that reminds me for no particular reason of peated whiskey. Taste is just a touch harsh, but that just adds to its charm. A deep draught of Scots satisfaction.<font color=red> Cmdr. Montgomery Scott, heres to ya!</font>
This is the best Scotch Ale I have ever had.  The commercial description says it all.  Pleny of malt flavor with a nice alcohol finish.  A must have in your list.

Out of a bottle courtesy Ohiodad, a brilliant waffe of smoked barrelled malted goodness.  Encompassed the glass in a flash of dark ruby capped by a tan head.   The flavor is where its friggin at, a mixture of malts, smoking and hops to finish make this so tasty.  Palate was full and smooth. Overall I liked it imensely, its definitely something I could easily drink til Im pickeled.

This scotch ale pours a gorgeous ruby-mahogany with a thick rocky brown head, which recedes with very nice lacing.  Aromas include malt, coffee, dark fruit, earth/peat, alcohol and smoke.  Taste is strongly malt, earth, smoke and yeast, with undertones of herb, alcohol, and maltose.  Although it doesnt show up until late, theres a decent hop finish.  Mouthfeel is good -- not too viscuous and just enough carbonation to make it refreshing.  I enjoy scotch ales and this is a pretty good one.

I was not a huge fan of this beer.  I know that they say that this is their flagship beer, but it is very straight forward with what it is--malty.  It smells of smokey malts and lots of caramel.  I wish that the strong maltiness would have been backed up by a more intense hop attitude.  Drinkability is a real problem with this beer.  I might try this again b/c im a big fan of Founders other products.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2006 Bottle.  Sweet caramel, malty aroma, with some grassy hops in there too to balance it out a bit.  Flavor is rich and sweet,  with some smoked notes, bit of roast, and again, grassy hops.  Fairly bitter finish.  A bit of alcohol does show, but its not distracting.  Quite tasty, better as it warms.   Ill certainly buy this again.  Real nice brew.

Dark purple-ish red in color with lasting, sticky lace - plum, toffee and herbs in the aroma - lots of caramel malt in the flavor, with a touch of peat smoked malt way in the back - a tad sweet with nothing much to balance it, but still very tasty - quite an odd beer to be a flagship product, so I tip my hat to them for that.

Upon first pouring this beer, the head is quite full, but quickly diminishes to a lasing around the sides of the glass.    THe aroma is very mild: full of heather, and earthy, herbal notes.  Mild, yet well-balanced beer.  Cocoa, herbs,  caramel and quite buttery predominate the flavor.  A nice example of the style.  The malts hang on in the finish.  It finishes smooth and creamy.

Sampled from a bottle, it pours to a thick, long lasting creamy/rocky tan head.  The body is  a dark red/brown color.  The aroma reminds me of peat and homemade strawberry fruit rollups after theyve been in the dhydrator for hours and are still warm.  I also get a touch of smoke.  The flavor is peaty, and also reminds me of how really old wood smells.  Sweet, smoky, earthy, woody.  The flavor is simply put... strange.  I love Scotch, but this doesnt remind me much at all of that.  Instead, this is more like being at a campfire with burning sugars, wood, and peat whofting through the air.  Im not big into this style, but I feel that this is a well produced beer.

Nice large long lasting head from a vigorous pour.  Settles slowly.  Wonderful, thick aroma with plenty of malts, caramel, peat and bit of smoke and rotting wood.  Color is a hazy dark magagony brown.  Flavor is rich and sweet but luxurious as it goes down.  Nice alcohol warming.  Plenty of malts again, a bit of roastyness, caramel, molasses, brown sugar, scrumptious.  Finish is creamy and coating.  Lingering tingle form the alcohol.  A top quality scotch ale.  Props go out to RoyalBrown for this one.

Dark brown to reddish and bubbly. Aroma of malt, hint of hops. Impishly sweet , but dont be fooled. This ale is like your sweet, innocent cousin who puts a snake in your sleeping bag. The alcohol in this tasty, easy-sipping ale can bite you.

From a 12-oz. bottle: Pours a deep, clear ruby with a full tan head.  Very pretty. Complex, yeasty aroma.  First taste is a big wallop of caramelly malt, followed by an almost syrupy sweetness.  Very rich mouthfeel.   Not much bittering; this beer is way over on the sweet side of the spectrum (which isnt surprising, considering the high alcohol content). BONUS: two bottles of this will make a bagpipe serenade sound good (though I still couldnt bring myself to dig into a plate of haggis).

bottle...ruby red with a frothy tan head. Malty aroma, also bittering hops in the nose. This smells like something that I will really like. Sweet caramel to start, malts are evident through the middle, with the hops taking over to finish. Alcohol is evident in the finish also. Chewy, sticky and oooh so good. I am hooked.I really liked this beer and it finished nice and warm.

Pours a dark brown color with little head.  Notes of chocolate and roasted malt fill the nose.  Taste is of mild chocolate, hints of smoke, roast, and sweet malt..  Decently hopped, it appears to me, to be a Breakfest Stout with the coffee elements removed from it.  Finishes a bit sweet  Excellent beer!

Pours deep reddish brown without any head to speak of.  Aroma is exceptionally sweet and malty -- hard to get past.  The flavor follows similarly -- the malt is too cloyingly sweet to get past and recognize any of the subtleties behind it.  The finish is drier than the initial flavor, but I still found it to be a fairly inaccessible beer -- I cant taste through the residual sugars.  Great mouthfeel, though; syrupy and rich.

Bottled.  From trade with OhioDad, thank you.  Pours a deep dark ruby garnet color with no haze and no significant head.  Appears minimally carbonated.  Aroma is very malty sweet with caramel and dark dried fruits and a complex ester profile.  A bit of smoke creeps up in the nose as well.  Flavor is very sweet and one dimensional upfront.  However, in the drier finish, more complexities come out: subtle smoke and fruity esters with some dried cherry and raisons. Alcohol and hops are minimally apparent in the flavor though a pleasant moderate bitterness lingers in the finish.  Body is extremely full and silky smooth and the low carbonation goes well in this beer.  I could only drink one of these in a given session due to the sweetness and body but very good nonetheless.

O, aye - methinks malt hath dribbled cross my kilt an spilt on m willies. First sip starts quite sweet and then comes to a screeching halt on the bitter. Best be buckled. Mellows as I sdrink. Very nice, but put up against the fantasticother efforts offered by Founders it falters - if ever so slightly. Nice nevertheless. Hope you dont think me a wee man for saying that.
Very dark red. Very malty with a hoppy bitter finish. Flavor stays for a long time. A great beer.

(draft) This beer knocked me on my ass. Very dark red, nearly black, with a decent head and more lacing than I expected. The flavor was a little intense. I kept wanting to call this a Winter warmer without the Winter part. A beer to celebrate happiness or drown sorrows, not a beer to simply enjoy.

Slightly hazy dark golden brown.  Small white soft foamy head.  Sugary malt aromatics with tinges of peat.  Caramel and specialty malt flavors, wisps of smokiness and a heavy peaty and salty finish.  Mouthfeel is fairly robust.
Dark Brown Coloring with Sandy Skin.  Rich Whisky and Grapey Aroma.  Bourbony...Rich Malt, Heavy Mouthfeel..Not Smooth...Aftertaste Doesnt End as Well as it Starts.

On the malty side, enough hops to make for a bitter, tingly finish.  Very impressive.  Im struck by the lasting, bitter (not in a negative way) finish.  Creamy, off-white lasting head with good lacing.  Never had a Scotch Ale before, but I hope they are all at least this good!

Pours a dark brown/amber color, small offwhite head. Powerful aroma of baked bread, grass, and a little smoked moss to it. Flavor is syrupy, strong kick of alcohol, with scotch, cherries, and caramel. A strong brew with big flavor, the booze is a little overbearing however.
Amazing, complicated smell, great red color, redish brown with a nutty colored head. Great bitterish flavor.  Of the scotch ales i have tried lately, this one is the top for me. Amazing.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 American Beer #1000.  Red color with no head.  Aroma of sweet maple syrup.  Very sugary and sweet taste with malt as the base.  No notes of alcohol, despite not really having anything to cover it up with.  Slightly plumy.
And a dirty bastard it was. nice furniture maroon/stain color to it. Carmel carmel and more carmel over malts. The body was deep and held on for a while, very enjoyable brew.

Thanks to BennyTicklez for this!
This starts with a large, creamy, light brown head over a clear deep brown body.
Light malt aroma that didnt give a clue as to all the falvor that was to follow.
Rich caramel malt, lightly bittered with a long satisfying finish. I Really liked this one.

Thanks to heemer77 for this one.  Wonderful deep red appearance with a creamy, yeasty, lasting head.  Yeast is most prevalant in the nose.  Caramel and hops also noticeable, and a smoky feel like scotch as well.  Good, but not exceptional.

This is a neat beer.  Not sure ive ever had a scotch ale but there is a strong chocolate presence.  Malt dominates, but still some mild hops balancing it all out.   There is a slight alcohol burn but nothing you cant handle.  Brown in color.  Darn good.

Deep red, garnet with thick compact creamy head.  Aroma is a nutty malt with a bit of sweetness and a hop presence.  Flavor is quite malty, both sweet and lightly roasted and a nice dry grapefruit hop finish.  Strong sweetness and a hint of alcohol.

Another great beer from Founders, this one pours an opaque black with tinges of dark bronze capped by a thin layer of dense foam.  The aroma is decidedly malty but hints of hops.  It also has that tasty mustiness you get from other good porters, such as Stone Smoked Porter.  The mouthfeel is heavy and velvety.  Chocolaty hints give way to a tidal wave of sweet maltiness.  The finish is complex, consisting of a backdrop of characteristic Scotch ale alcohol flavor punctuated by modest cherry tones, a more pronounced hop presence, and finally, the gentle sting of carbonation at the back of the throat.

I had this beer on draft at MacNivens, a Scottish-themed restaurant and bar on Massachusetts Avenue in downtown Indy.  MacNivens has an anxious-makingly large selection of interesting beers on draft and in bottles.  But what impresses me most is that *they serve them to you in appropriate glasses.* The Dirty Bastard came in a snifter, but Im sure its the only thing by that name that would smell as sweet.

I guess I think beers look Mahogany, because Im saying thats the color they are more and more.  This is a good looking beer though.  The aroma is light and malty, not really very descript.  The flavor is dominated by caramel maltperiod!  There may be some smokey hints but they are very light.  Creamy medium body.  Overall, I really found this beer enjoyable.  It was what it was, nothing too complex but fulfilling.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2005 Fiery red color, decent lasting head.  Sweet, fruity, toasty aroma.  Big soft sweet palate and tons of caramel flavor.  Some nutty/roasty chocolate malt flavors.  A little bitter and alcoholic in the finish.   I didnt know anything about it and wasnt prepared for such a big beer.  Put a couple away in the cellar, could be interesting in a couple years.

Crimson and browns, huge fluffy light tan head (which didnt seem right).  Nose was decent with notes of musty toasted caramel, toffee, and chocolate, with softer notes of moist cavendish tobacco, and cherry.  Flavor was sweet and malty up front with more cherry, musty caramel, and toffee tones throughout, and only a very light hop bitterness to round it off.  Medium bodied crazy mega-fizzy carbonation, semi-dry, malty finish.  Had to be an old bottle.  Either way, of the Founders brews Ive tried to date, this one was the first swing and a miss....

Deep amber-reddish brown brew with omlya ring of tan bubbles.Rich malts on the nose with a little earthiness along with some dark cherries.Funky in a good way as the earthiness really offsets what I thought was going to be a sweet beer.It is rather thick and has a nice mouthfeel.

Poured a dark brown with a red tint. and a small light tan head.  Malty aroma and a touch of smoke and  peat.  You get alcohol if you breath in deep.  Flavor has a little more smokiness.  Malty and lightly sweet with a bitter finish mixed with some alcohol.  Medium bod and a good bit of chest warming.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber with a smallish head. Aroma of caramel and some dried fruits. The first thing I look for is some sort of peat flavor and you really have to dig to find any. Unfortunatly, there isnt enough for my liking. Thsi is more of a flavorful Amber to me, which is fine. Texture is smooth and creamy. Not bad.

Bottle.   Muddy dark opaque mahogany-brown, opaque with a small tan head.  Aromas are earthy, sweet malts, something burned, and some nice smokiness.  Nice caramel malts in the flavor..peaty..and some nice bitterness toward the end.  I really, really liked this scotch ale.  Smooth and full-bodied..very good.

Not ususally my style so dont judge this particular beer on my comments.  Definately a heavy handed brew.  Taste not much different than drinking a 50/50
blend of scotch and a strong ale.  Im much fonder of their Red Rye.  Apologies  to my two Scot grandfathers.

Poured deep copper with a healthy tan head.  Aroma is mostly hops.  A little perfumy with some rye malts.  Flavor is very alcoholic almost bourbon.  Some smoke hint.  The palate is heavy for an ale smooth body very warming on the finish and somewhat dry.  Good for this style.  I liked it and would drink it again.

Bottle: poured cloudy brown with a very small beige head. Smoky, meaty peat aroma. Ouch! 8.3%?? I had no idea. Big malt flavor, light smoke, light soy sauce. Very rich and full bodied. Very low carbonation. Decent flavor but semiflat.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2005 Slight note on this one - not a rerate.  I have had this one on tap several times and adorn it.  In the bottle, it lags just slightly, but its still a damn good beer.  On tap, Id give it a 4.5, out of the bottle, probably a 4.2.  Nevertheless, the average of 4.4.  To its credit, below is my rating of it on tap...

Safire rose in color.  Thin, creamy, floating head with formidable lacing.  Aroma is - woah! - cherry Dots, red licorice, toasted and rye malts.  This bastards got character.  Rich rye accents, paired with a Kentucky-style bourbon.  Black licorice and charcoal flavoring.  Heavy, thick and smooth bodied.  Great malts-hops combo.  Some small single malt scotch hints, mostly in the finish, which is sweet, warming and dry.  This is a sound brew.
(Bottle)  Pours a mahogany body with a medium-sized beige head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, and toffee.  Flavor of malt, cream, and carmel.
Pours amber with a small white head. Malty aroma. Taste is big malt and hop balanced well. Caramel mixe d in. Decent.

12 oz bottle.  Muddy dark brown, opaque with just a touch of filmy froth...earthy-sweet nose with perhaps a bit of juniper, lots of burnt caramel and a little smoked peat...luscious smoky-woody body, front is rather acerbic and makes you notice it, but quickly settles down into a smooth caramel maltiness with dry bitter herbs touching the background.

A big malty scotch ale that makes you want to wear a kilt and march around town screaming I love my bagpipes. Well maybe not. But anyhow it was a dark amber color. A malty aroma. A complex flavor consisting of chocolate, almonds, oak, and caramel. The alcohol is well hidden but it does provide a warming effect. Good stuff.

Deep cloduy ruddy amber pour, with a very thin light brown head, atop. Quickly diminishing. A very fruity, almost aged malt to this one. Enticing. An extremely rich, creamy smooth malt, boosted by the high alcohol and some nice hops finish. Theres a musty, earthy quality in the background, close to the peat and smoke they describe, but not quite there for me. A nutty, dry smack. Fantastic! The palate sugary coats the mouth and leaves a buttery flavor that stay behind for a long time.

On tap.  It was very dark, dark red with a small white head that thinned out.  Aromas of sweet caramel, sorta earthy.  Sweet flavors of caramel, brown-sugar with an astringent finish.  Long finish with noticeable alcohol.  Somewhat creamy body with a somewhat chalky finish.  I cant drink a lot of this style.

This was pretty freakin awesome.  I had it for breakfast this weekend at the farm courtesy of the boy :)  found it in Ohio.  Much more immense chocolate flavors than I expected.  Oak flavor, carmel, lots of malt, with excellent full mouthfeel.  Nicely done.  Cheers!

Ruby amber hue, with suspended particles.  Roast malt nose, vinous and woody.  Chewy dark caramel, dark roasted malt, medium body, finisihing with perfect bitter hops.  Juicy, soft, salty, wonderfully balaned, and quite quaffable.

Dark ruby is a great way to describe this beers appearance - almost brown.  Lots of sweet malts, sour lemon and rye in the nose.  Smoky, rounded bitter-sweet chocolate taste.  Also dark chocolate and roastiness in the finish.  Arrogant Bastard-esque.  Good!

Rich malty aroma, caramel and toffee, a little alcohol.  Slightly hazy brown with ruby tints, thin beige head.  Flavor matches the aroma, sweet malt, plenty of caramel with some peat and roasted malt coming through, a little hop flavor and bitterness in the finish.  Full body, very drinkable.  Another really nice beer from Founders.

props to growler for this bonus brew.pours a ruby red with a white head.aromas of butterscotch,malts,candy,and more malts.the flavor is sweet and again,full of malts,and a bit of alcohol tward the end.overall this is pretty good stuff.
UPDATED: APR 21, 2005 bottle. Nice dark red color. Slight creamy head. full bodied taste fills the mouth. nice roasted caramel taste. very pleasing beer. definite one to have in stock.

bottle...ruby red with a frothy tan head.  Malty aroma, also bittering hops in the nose.  This smells like something that I will really like.  Sweet caramel to start, malts are evident through the middle, with the hops taking over to finish.  Alcohol is evident in the finish also.  Chewy, sticky and oooh so good.  I am hooked.  If I could drink Reds Rye, Black Rye and Dirty Bastard every night, I would be a very very happy man.  Too bad these beers are not available to me, I had to trade for them, and what a wonderful trade it was.  Many thanks to Styles for these wonderful beers.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2005 Dark Ruby color on the pour with a thick tan head.  Smells of sweet caramel and slight malt.  Flavors starts sweet and thin (like flat coca cola) and moves toward a slight bitterness in the end.  This beer coats the entire mouth and leaves a lasting flavor.  In the end though the alcohol bite takes over and spoils the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2009 Bottle. Pours an almond brownish color with a small off white head. Nose is malty and caramelly sweetness. Palate is full and smooth with a touch of velvet. Flavor if rich malty sweetness with a light hint of alcohol and a heavy filmy finish.

I put this very high on the "drinkability" scale -- just a real pleasure to imbibe.  Smooth, slightly watery, smoky, a little fruity, some alcohol not totally hidden.  Maybe a little bready.  Even some sourness on the finish.  A good beer puts some conflicted feelings in me.  I get hard for great appearance, though appearance wasnt all that on this one.  I havent had a bad Scotch ale yet; thanks to Founders for continuing this small streak.

A very dark brown red amber w/ a thick chewy lasting tan head. The aroma is sweet and malty, hints of a carmel.  The  palate is thick  rich and creamy that  is well carbonated. The flavor has  hints of wine, roasted carmel malts and a little bit of coco.  I like the D.B. and have take it to friends.

12 oz bottle.  Dark amber beer with a very slight tan head.  Aroma is that earthy peat moss. Heavy malt taste with a ton of body.  Thick rich finish.  Not one of my favorites  but definately worth searching for.

Mahogony colored body with a creamy tan head...sweet butterscotch aroma  and subtle hoppiness.  Nice smooth body with a very appealing smokey malt followed by a nicely balance hop bite but finishes a little lacking.
This ale is similar to McEwans scotch ale. Very smoky tasting and good mouthfeel, leading to pleasant after effects. Great with a good cigar.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 a cloudy dark amber w/ a thick long lasting tan head that laced well, aroma is sweet and malty, hints of a smokey scotch.  palate is rich and creamy w/ a nice carbonated kick on the swallow very nice... The flavor is good hints of alcohol nice roasted carmel malts maybe a hint of bitter chocolate.. I really liked this beer and it finished nice and warm.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2005 Bottle courtesy of styles: Appears brown until held up to the light, where it shines deep ruby.  Tiny tan head.  Has a sweet & rich malty nose with notes of caramel, milk chocolate, very mild alcohol, and a surprising fruity hops notes barely discernable in the background.  This fruit scent smells like a combination of pine/banana/cherry/apple/blueberry.  Taste is initially very heavy and malty, followed by a hint of alcohol, berries, pine, chocolate, dense wet earth, apple, chalky dark malt.  Finish is chalky caramel, chocolate, light berries, stale malt (though not in a bad way).  Once again, Founders has a near-perfect palate & carbonation.

Bottle. Another one sent to me by joeybgood. Pours bronze with a small fluffy tan head. Nose is malted milk chocolate blended with light hops and peaty notes. Light caramel as well. Taste is alcohol, more caramel, light smoke, creamy, sweet malts, and light earthiness. Body is medium with mild carbonation and medium alcohol warmth. Finish is more caramel, milk chocolate, alcohol, and light peatiness. Nice beer!
UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 Dark ruby color with no head.  Malty alcohol aroma.  Nice "scotch" aroma.  Smooth mouthfeel.  A little too much alcohol in the aroma for my taste but still pretty nice.
Tap at brewery. Dark red color with medium reddish head. Aroma is mix of malt with smoke. Flavor is very complex and solid. Malt, hops and earth tone. Strong finish.

Clear ruby with a dense light tan head. Nice light fruity sweet caramel and light earthy aroma. Very nice flavor, full fruity with just the right amount of sweetness balanced with an earthy peatness. Full soft body. A very, very nice Scotch Ale.

Dark ruby color with a decent sized, late forming head.  Aroma is hella malty, sweet caramel, hearty earth notes, and very full bodied.  Flavor is on the same par, very sweet and smooth malt complex, low hop action and just all around wonderful to taste.  The taste has a subtle blend of grape, cherry, and all sorts of glorious complex malt flavor.

Rich dark brown color with a frothy light tan head with thin lacing.  Aroma is full of sweet caramel malt, a touch of peat, and a nice hoppy balance.  Body is full and malty with a nice light smokiness and good sweet balance and nice authenticity.  Finishes semi-dry and toasty while hiding the alcohol well.  A nice Scotch ale!

Fruity, dark, malty aroma has a light note of peat malt. Amber-brown with thin but lasting off-white/tan head that recedes to cover.  Alcohol, strong orange/pine earthy resinous hops. Nice supporting malt base and some strong fruity esters.  Medium body is smooth in texture with engaging carbonation.  Sampled at the Extreme Beer Festival 2005.

Draft, EBF: Superb reddish brown. Light lasting off-white head. Strong malty aroma, very peaty, but almost predominantly hoppy as seems to be the standard at Founders. Deep earthiness lets way for lots of fruits (cherries, grapes etc). Orangey hop flavours are a bit too upfront, fighting off the earthy malts. Obvious alcohol presence. Creamy texture, medium body, pleasant mouth presence.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2006 Trying this one again, thanks to iowaherkeye for the bottle. The aroma has some toffee and chocolate with some notes of good tobacco. The taste is very boozy with some hints of burnt walnuts and caramel. There is also some light smoke. Not as sweet as the other samples I tried. There is also some prune taste in the finish. A decent, but not great beer. Original rating follows. Dark brown with some red on the edges with the light. A very thin slightly yellow colored head. The aroma is toffee and caramel. Also some walnuts. The taste has toasted malts and toffee. Hints of mint and some bread crust. A medium nouthfeel with plenty of carbonation. The sweetness of the malt is a little cloying. It gets sweeter as you drink it.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy copper brown with a fizzy tan head that quickly goes to a thin film.

Its aroma is sweet and slightly smokey molasses with some figgy fruitiness and a little chocolate.

The flavor is sweet caramel/toffee malts, a little chocolate, some dark fruits, a touch of smoke, and a dry bitterness at the end.  The mouthfeel is very full, smooth and creamy.

Not my favorite style and a little too sweet for me, but this is a nice, well made beer.

Sample generously provided by the waitstaff at Pizza Man here in Milwaukee.  Clear dark brown body with red highlights.  Thin, small-bubbled white head.  Berry-fruited malt with maple-wood and roasted caramel malt in the aroma.  Big molasses-tinted flavor with chocolate and cherry notes.  Nice malt in the beer, an appreciable combination of caramel and chocolate, the fruit accents are nice too.
malty aroma, malt laced with alcohol and pear taste,not to much bitterness, full taste at firstbut seemed to get lighter as it went along.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Dark mahogany/brown with a decent beige head that fades to film rather quickly. Aroma is malted caramel, tons of smoked peat malt and chocolate. Flavor is smoked peat malt, with caramel/toffee and chocolate through the middle. Finish fresh is a combo of smoke and pine resin/aged all chocolate. Long sweet and smoky aftertaste. Decent overall.

from the bottle poured a nice dark ruby, with a tan head. aroma, malts, caramels, light smoke hints of raisins, and hops, with just a hint of alcohol, enjoyed the aroma of this one. flavor mlats, raisins caramels, chocolte, toffee, and some cheeries. this was a good beer.

Mahogany color with a creamy amber color head. Sweet aromas. Caramel, pears and pineapples all seem to be present. Heavier feel with a nice oily quality. Lots of malt in the flavor, but more fruit seems to be present and distract. The finish does lose its sweetness and the toffee and peat flavors come out and are rather pleasant. A few fewer esters and this would be better IMO.  Actually just did another aroma check and the fruity characters seem to be driven off and  Ill give this an additional point.

Bottle:  Light malty aroma.  Pours a reddish-brown with a pretty insignificant tand had.  Light malt up front with caramel and banana bread in the finish.  Finish of this beer is similar to how a barley wine starts.  Slight sour apple in the finish as well.  Somewhat weak aroma keeps this out of the fours.
Nice deep red brown with a thin lasting head. Slightly smokey smell with a malt character and distinct hops. Taste is the same, and very good. Well-balanced. A nice one!

dark ruby-brownish color.  creamy palate.  no taste of alcohol.  some hop balance which rounds out hte beer quite well.  as of today the second best beer i have had with the word bastard in its name.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 This is good, a rich malty drink.  It pours dark brown with a respectable tan head.  The aroma is seriously malty, sweet with hints of chocolate.  Medium-bodied, the flavor is caramel and chocolate malts, a hint of smokiness with a rouch of dark dried fruits.  Theres a slight hop bitterness right at the end.  It finishes with a lingering malt taste.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Frankfort, IL<font size=-1>

This is a WONDERFUL scotch ale.  Smooth, yet a bit hoppy, and fills the mouth with its goodness.  Pours a nice brown-ale color with a tan-colored head.  This beer fills the palate perfectly and just warms as it goes down.  Not too sweet and not too bitter.  Perfect "flagship beer."

Came is a short 12 oz. brown bottle, with a nice quote on the neck putting me in the mood for the experience.  The beer poured dark red with an inch thick head on top.  Lacing was top notch.  The aroma was malty and dusty with some floral hops peeking through.  The taste was sweet (raisins, cherries, and chocolate), nutty, and smoky.  The bitterness was minimal, and the aftertaste was clean.  The mouthfeel was chewy with a tongue coating stickiness.  A nice soothing beer for a damp and dark winters night.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 rerate:  slightly thinner and more oxidized than previous, but otherwise first rating is accurate.  a bit too cardboardy.

still not entirely sure what a scotch ale really comprises, but ill take this beer for what it is.  dark red, essentially brown.  lots of malt and smoke in the aroma, particularly smoked fish.  very pleasant in the winter.  8.3%?  no alcohol presence, very well masked behind a toasty malt presence and a surprisingly cascade-like hops finish.  pretty good, although founders has better to offer.
This one smells like chocolate milk. Grapefruity hops are buried behind that sweetness.  Flavor is chocolatey nut brown, sweet roasty malts.  Hints of sulfur.  Bitter alcoholic chocolate finish.

Bottle. A nice amber color with tan head, some lacing.  Aromas on the sweet side, with a hint of smoke.  The taste is where its at, with flavors from all over the board.  Caramel, malt, fruit, with a nice warm finish.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2006 Whew...I had no idea of what to expect when I ordered this.  I was thinking that it would be something typical and microbrew-like.  I was wrong.  This beer hits like a hammer.  It certainly starts out sweet and, IMO, has a dark liquor-like finish.  Really unique and worth trying.  Dont expect to drink it quickly or in great quantities.

Pours a light tan, one finger-head that goes slowly leaving a good lace.  Deep amber color.  Light carbonation.  Medium bodied.  Nose is raisiny.  Starts sweet with hops in the background, finishes with some bitterness.  Still easy to drink, alcohol is not noticeable.  $3.75 for a 12oz  bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

Rich roasty malty chewy aroma with hints of coffe and some chocolate.  Also has some vinous notes reminiscent of a barleywine.   Pours a perfect mahogany color that is hazy with a pretty dark tan head that is robust and has nice lacing.  Nice smooth velvety texture.  UNfortunately, this is somewhat one dimensional and bland. There are significant roasted malts in this with a few hints of dark chocolate here and there, but nothing that really makes its mark.
Cloudy brown with a thin tan head, brown sugar with a tinge of smoke in the aroma, full bodied with lively carbonation, starts and ends sweet.

Dark brown with a medium, light-tan head.  Aroma very malty, a touch of caramel, dark fruits.  Flavor also very malty; brown sugar, fruits, and lightly sour; the alcohol adds a very nice touch to this beer.  Thick enough but, as is common, oto syrupy/sticky.  I like this a lot, but it could really stand out a little bit more than it does.
tawny brown color with creamy head...a very impressionable taste (with fruits, caramels, and SPICES)....it has a flowerlike aftertaste with a touch of smokiness....overall a pleasurable scotch ale

Color of light roasted coffee with thin trace of a creamy head.  Aroma of sour cherries and very muted barnyard scents.  Flavor of sweet fig with fruity aftertaste.  Very prominent malt with little to no hop flavor/aroma, but some bitterness.  Very nice Scottish Ale, but mild flavor for the style
Not so great. A bit too far on the sweet side with some odd diacetyl notes. A bit syrupy and low on carbonation. But then Im not a fan of Scotch ales so who knows? You might liike it.

good scotch ale.  keeps me wanting the better stuff though.  like the alesmith wee heavy i got laying around.   but as for this brew, it had a slight caramel notes. as well as malty.   taste was very rich, carmaley, and smokey.  overall not a bad drink at all.

Beautiful tawny brown color, nice, thick, lasting tan head lies on top.
Malt dominates the nose, in abundance, thick, rich, with dark fruits, and spices holding sway...quite, quite nice.
Very plush on the mouthfeel as well, wonderful texture, full and devilish, flowing with uncommon delights, soft, yet sensuous, and very flavorful. Full bodied, long, fruity finish. Huge malt, little hop, but unrelenting in the way of flavor. Gets a bit chocolatey in the middle...the wonders yet unfold...they did themselves proud with this one! Wow...a top-notch Scotch!
Tap.  A red brown color.  Head is tannish and long lasting.  Aroma is almost floral,  sweet with malt and hops.  Taste is rich.  Very malty, nice hop additions balance things out.  Very good beer.

Brilliant reddish brown with thick off-white head. Carmel, roasted notes and hops on the nose to start. Creamy mouthfeel, with a green hop finish. Carmel, Toffee, pIne, and light roasted flaovors dominate. Well balanced brew!
Caramel all over it- color, flavor, and nose. Gets a little sweet and roasty towards the finish

Dark and thick caramel brown color, rusty orange edges, thin sized but thickly set and lumpy tan cap, keeps a skim and collar nearly the whole glass down; lacing moderately coats in strings and graceful sheeting. Aroma is chalked full of some really nice caramel, deep and inviting, nuances of brown sugar, vanilla, earthy roasted malts, smoked husks and hay. Taste is crispy and full, crunchy burntish cookies, maple and brown sugar sweetness with roasted grain, husky toasted edges. Has a caramel loaded middle and finish with a firm hold and feel of caramel malts with a crisp toasted grain dryness creeping around the surface late. Nice creamy body and fullness with just the right amount of roasty crispness and drying toasty grain bitterness. Slight dry hop background appears as it warms and where this beer really comes into its own. Letting this warm up some is ideal. Very approachable, very drinkable, very good stuff! One of the better American brewed Wee heavys Ive encountered.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2005 Dark clear mahogany body. Thin soapy off-white head. Extremely pleasing, but a little too light aroma. Slightly smokey, but mostly sweet-like malts, chocolate, etc. Smokiness picks up in the taste. Nice sweet smoke and caramel toffee with some good hop bitterness to round it out. Full taste and a little oily in the mouth.
Smoky malt dominates.  Im not really a fan of brown ales and though I like McChouffe the smokiness of this beer didnt do it for me.
Scotch malt peatiness and thick sweetness.  Rich and refreshing.  Sweet at the finish.

Never had a scotch ale before this was great. Similer to a stout it did not need to be warmed. Light slightly smokey flavor with a hint of subtle sweetness. Quite a nice strong brew! Not hoppy thankfully.

Murky amber color in my snifter with a small tan head.  Nose of plum and toast with a little alcohol.  Toffee sweetness with faint smoke somewhere in the background.  It seemed a little thin for the style, even with the alcohol burn on the tongue.  I dont like this style, but...

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2005 pours mahogony hue with a faint tan head.  hoppy, sweet, dark fruits, plum, red grapes and lighty roasted notes predominate the aroma.  this beer is much more hoppy than i thought it would be.  big plum, citric hops, roast, lightly chocolate and carmel notes.  this is somewhat reminiscent of bear republics version, but this version leans more towards the scotch ale category.  Nice fruity notes on the finish.  there is that characteristic founders yeast note-dry!  This is another winner from founders.  I think my bottle may have been a little old and its still very good!
Earthen aroma. Foamy head. sweet malty taste. Full bodied flavor with a nice bitter finishing. Founders best offering.
Malt, smoke, peat moss in aroma. Charcoal, chocolate and moist woody notes. Slightly hoppy and sweet finish -- good example of style, one of my favorites.

Bottle pours dark caramel, petite creamy head, with decent lacing.   Caramal, pitted fruit, and malts on the nose.   Certainly smells like a Scotch Ale.   Raisins, figs, plums, nuts, and caramel on the tongue.   Rather good too!   Slight alcohol tinge, but tiz very manageable.   Quite smooth, good body, creamy mouthfeel.   Slightly bitter finish, a bit bready.   Light chocolate notes emerge as the beer warms, as well as sour notes in the finish.   May not be completely true to the style, but I enjoyed this one.   Thanks to hopsrus for the trade!

This beer poured a hazy reddish brown color and formed light tan foamy head that left circular lace as it subsided. A medium amount of carbonation and some sediment is present. A complex aroma of malt, caramel, raisins and other dark fruit. Not as heavy an aroma as others, but more in the mix if you will. The flavor was of malt, caramel, slight bit of chocolate and a hint of raisin. A slightly lighter body than I would expect for this style and slightly sweet finish. The alcohol is well hidden in this one. Also best if had at cellar temp or just slightly cooler to help draw out more of it's character
Cloudy brown with an average head. Aroma is malty, lightly hopped and slightly yeasty. Flavour is slightly sweet, earthy, and moderately acidic. Not malted aggressively enough for a scotch ale.

Pours a cloudy brown with really no head. Aroma is coffee and cherries. Flavor is a malty vanilla.  Goes down velvety and smooth.  Nice texture to a nice nice brew.  The label on the bottle is good for a laugh as well.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie), moderately hoppy (apricot, resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of brown sugar and toffee. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic. Inappropriate hopping for the style (until, of course, we have an "American Scottish Ale" style, sigh...) and clearly too sour for the style...uh, no thanks, this just isn't right.  Neither whiskey-like nor smoky.  A high-alc ("Imperial" if you want to use that overused term) American Brown Ale is what this is, more than a Scottish ale.
no head but beautiful ruddy hugh. very smooth on palate with right amount of carbonation. Taste is a little sweet but very good overall.

Appealing nose of heavy caramel and butterscotch, alcohol and spice.  Pours a dark mahogany with garnet highlights.  A beautiful long cascade greets an aggressive pour.  The thick creamy tan head is mostly lasting with fair lacing.  The bold heavy malt flavor has a warm sweet middle and a lingering spicy finish.  The thick creamy perfect palate is soft and finishes clean.  Bravo.

12 oz [capped bottle, 2001 sampling: Deliahs Chicago (vintage beer tasting, Feb 04)]: Chesnut brown, fairly clear.  Old bitterness is noticeable in the aroma  what once was has melted into sugary caramel and sweet raisins.  Thick mouth feel is nice and helps the flavours cling to the palate: mostly caramel with small dances into cherries and red grapes.  Nice, but perhaps a bit too old.

This beer is a monster.  Pours a deep garnet, slight cloudiness, with lots of tiny bubbles.  Nice fluffy head.  Aroma of burnt cherries.  Sweet cherry malt flavor, milk chocolate, and a dash of nutmeg.  Creamy mouthfeel.  The alcohol only becomes apparent when yu are halfway finished, if you know what I mean.  A very interesting wee heavy, and worth the sample.
UPDATED: APR 4, 2004 Pours a nice deep red with small but decent off-white head. Smells of chocolate, flowers, and malt. Taste good, with a nice blend of malts, spices, maybe caramel? Very good.

Paid $1.50 for a 12-oz single.

Dark mahogony, almost black, with a small, fluffy brown head.

Sweet smelling, wineline scent... I smell grapes or something in there.

Caramels, coffee, grapes, wine, and chocolate make up the complexities of this brew. Lots of flavors meshing together to make a nice taste.

Drinkable, for this glass, but I wouldn't want another right away.

I saw the name on this one and a I couldn't pass it up.  I'm a sucker for offensive marketing I guess.  Pours a reddish-brown color with a moderate brown head and leaves some lacing on the glass.  The aroma was very sweet, a bit of caramel, and alcohol.  The flavor was very sweet, like the aroma, but not too sweet.  The maltiness is present in the flavor as well as the alcohol and a tiny bit of the vanilla.  This was an interesting beer, nice mouthfeel and not too hard to drink.

Red-brown with beige head.
Merengue, chocolate and cloves in the aroma.
Dry, spicy flavor with chocolate and merengue.
Round with little bitterness.

Reddish brown hue with a good off-white head and very good lacing. The nose was smoky, dusty, fruity with additional hints of caramel and spice. The taste was spicy and fruity with the malt as more of an undertone. A smoky. lightly salty and almost acidic character shows on the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is lush for the style and there is a minor alcohol presence detected during the swallow, but not overpowering. A darn nice brew for a cold winters eve. Recommended.
I liked the hops in the nose and the taste.  A toffee, chocolate, and caramel blend was detected.  This is my first Founder's product.  It won't be my last.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Nice!  I really enjoyed this one, it gave a nice hoppy bite with the first sip to the last.  Smooth and some toffee hints were noted.  I look forward to trying more of the Founders products.
Dark, reddish brown body under a tan head.  Complex nose of toffee, fruit, spices, and honey.  Sweet fruity taste with some spices.  A good drink.

Bottle. Dark amber brown. Thin head. Smells like bitter hops. Nice deep flavor. Smooth as silk, leading into the deep bitter finish. Malt in the flavor, very slightly sweet, burnt marshmallow. Nice and distinct. Very nice beer from Founder's. Quite filling.
On draft at brewpub. Dark garnet-brown and clear with a creamy beige head.  Smokey-sweet malt nose.  Rich Malty flavor, smokey and spicy with a hop bite.  Mouthfeel is round, smooth almost syrupy.
GABF '03 Amber in color,weak aroma,nice full body.Wished they would have gone BIG on this beer,as they have with others.

This brew pours with a slightly cloudy amber brown body topped by a thick off white head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, a touch of vanilla and a trace of alcohol.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter and malty with roasty notes, a subtle hint of vanilla, caramel and alcohol.  Full bodied and smooth, yet slightly warming.
Bottled. Mahogany colour. Malty and quite soft. Peaty and roasty with notes of toffee, Firm and rather sweet with salty balanced finish. Good stuff!
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 Darker reddish colour with no head and some lacing on the glass. Kind of weak nose, but still kind of malty. Hops and caramel in the taste
Really dark redish color.  Cherry, malt nose with some mild bitterness.  Thick palate with presence of alcohol.  Caramel, malt and a bit o'hops.  Really fizzy mouthfeel.  Enjoyable.
Some head and lacing.  Cola color with a touch of red to it.  Hoppy and malty, with a touch of bitterness.  Strong, dark ale that fits its name.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 a big strong.  tastes pretty bad.  costs a small fortune.  save your money.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2005 Looks beautiful. Smells a bit off (i guess im a sissy, as the labels description explains...), but it tastes great. Would make a good chaser for rum - ha... Really good beer. UPDATE 4/12/05: updated aroma a couple points. tis excellent: peat, smoke, alchohol, caramel, creamy, smooth, bold, uhm... yeah, awesome.

Deep copper with a small sheet of orange bubbles. Sticky roast aroma, light coffee, light chocolate, yellow cake, fruit, and caramel - could mistake this for a lighter stout or porter on its aroma. Full bodied, sweet with roast on the taste and toast on the finish.

The body is rubied leather topped by a fading crown of buttered straw (brown with ruby highlights and faded khaki with an oddly strongly yellow tint). The aroma is nicely malty, but it hints that this is a bit old. Still a beer this old shouldn't have too much of a problem surviving. The flavor is brown sugar and leaf litter and a surprising amount of hop bitterness for a scotch. Unfortunately, there's a bit of a metallic nature about the hops that I find slightly unpleasant.

tannin and tobacco leaf chestnut roan, nearly clear, head was the light toasted biege color of winter grass, and very jealously protective of the beer beneath it's thin but loyal creamy skin.  nose likewise reflects the well-baked doppel-bock malts with airs of rye bread and plum, carmelized pecans and the puissance of alcohols feeding upon the dark, fruity bounty. 
creamy orange and toffee,  gorgeous bitterness probably goes beyond the call of scotch ale duty,  full of nutty and well-kilned malts, mostly bready. no peat or roasty aspects, alas. reminescent of a great winter ale, like avery's jubilation.  definately one of the premier scotch ales.

This was a wonderful surprise. The golden/yellow color and off white head, did not prepare me for the full body and complex character.  It had a dry roast malt flavor up front, with some nutty malt flavors (subtle) and some hops intertwined.  The alcohol was apparent but just right.  There was a caramel finish, and sure, it was sweet, but not too sweet. There was astringency and some bitterness too.  Definitely a bit of a change from the usual scottish style ale.  Struck me as tending towards a mix between a well balanced EPA and a bock (if that can be imagined) as it was smooth and had more hops than I would expect for this style but was also a bit chewy and sweet with a slightly bitter finish.
All around good beer.  Great balance of hops, sweet malt and roasted/smokey flavor.  Nothing is overpowering in this ale.  Would definitely get this one again.

Body is dark red with a strangely blonde head. Flavor is bold, but smooth...  Like the cross between a Scottish ale, IPA, and a Belgian Strong.  It rocks others like McEwens.  This smarmy little ass-kicker is mean like a Scottsman.

another beer tried at the Old Channel Inn in Montague, MI.... HEAVY and full bodied, sweet, malty, rather nutty and dry as well, nice dark reddish garnet/ruby color to it, small tan head, was rather impressed with this one, especially after having the poor Anglers Ale before hand

A deep ruby color with a medium rocky off-white head.  A sweet vinous aroma with water going over rocks in a fast moving stream.  Slight molasses and earth also.  A sweet caramel malt taste that has a slight bitter finish that evens it out.  Outstanding.
Caramel, butterschotch, alcoholic aroma.  Thick mouthfeel, pounding caramel flavor with a sweet, alcoholic finish.

On draught at Lazy Chameleon in Powell, OH. This beer is a dark brown with a copper hue and a thin light beige head. Very little lacing. Aroma is mostly caramel malt with a little spice thrown in. The flavor was not really reminiscent of other Scotch Ales I have tried. It seemed to be leaning more toward a Brown Ale. Flavors of caramel, malt, molasses and brown sugar are all there, but not in the doses you would expect. Still, it is not a bad beer. The finish is more bitter than most Scotch Ales as well.

Copper body with a light tan head, does not last as long as it should.  Heavy sweet caramel malt aroma w/ a little roastiness and grainy for a Scotch ale.  No smokiness or fruit aromas are detectible, but I'm picking up traces of chocolate malt.  Caramel malt very apparent in the flavor and a little roast, as well as some chocolate and alcohol.  Well balanced, but toward malt, no hop flavor that I noticed.  Alcohol noticeable, but not hot, with a subdued carbonation and medium full M/F.  This one seems a little light for what I expected from a Scotch ale, and it also a little astringent.  Nice attempt at a Scotch, but fall short IMHO.  Better than most, but not as good as some.
(draft @RBSG2003):  Clear red-brown with medium tan head.  Aroma is mild -- sweet and caramel.  Taste is medium sweet, floral, caramel, malty, mild alcohol and minimal bitterness.  Medium/full body.

Bottle: Good nose roasted molasses and some smoke. Nice clear brownish amber color.  Smokey malty with a bitter hops flavor. Creamy with a typical higher abv warmth about it. Lost a few on the nose. Very tasty overall. Love a good scotch style ale
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark ruby color with a tan head. Malt and fruit aroma. Really thick and malty with fruit, toffee, caramel, hops and a little roast.
Liquid bread, the flavor of dark bread with spicy undertones.  Rich and chewy a very good beer with a really nice hop finish.

Aroma of freshly-baked bread drizzled with melted toffee and caramel, with a touch of vinous malt, floral hop spice, pine and a small dosage of yeast esters.  Deep brownish red color, hazed, with a fine, light tan head and a nice bit of lacing.  Fruity, almost candyish sweetness to start, quickly joined by earthy, spicy, Pacific Northwest-style hop flavors and carrying each other throughout.  Becoming bready and slightly roasty, bitter and dry  towards the finish, although all previous aspects of flavor persist.  Smooth, lightly acidic palate, fairly full-bodied.  Very interesting and stronger than it tastes in regards to alcohol level.

Somebody has got to be kidding, I'm with MartinT on this one.  This is one of the best Scottish Ales I've had.  Brown colored with a head that crosses the glass, transluscent.  Aroma of malt very similiar to an ESB.  Carmel flavor with enough bitterness to make it more than one dimensional, but not enough to dominate the malt character.  Bitter, dry finish, excellent beer!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2008 Glorious caramel archers, armed with fruity toffee arrows, transpierce haggard and plentiful berries...Their loyal toasted bows and bitter potions hit the target almost every time...Classy and drinkable, this is a fine sipper of a Scotch Ale...

Poured a dark amber, and developed a thin tan head.  The basic recipe for this one seems to be as follows: take an amber ale, and add twigs, berries, molasses, dark fruits, feces, and smarm.  Top it off with 10%/90% SARS/sorbitol solution and fermented maxi pads.  In other words, if you find a hypodermic needle in your bottle, go back to the establishment you purchased it from and pay them double.  A previous reviewer had it right: the malts leave you feeling violated, filthy, and self-pitying.  Woe to he who dares tame the Dirty Bastard.
5/26/03:  bottle.   red-brown body.  spice and malt aroma and flavor.  some alcohol tastes as the beer warms

Poured a dark ruby brown body under a tan (with a hint of amber) head that settled into a hurricane pattern in my snifter.  Thick malts - not overly sweet (thanks).  I get a lot of rum and cinnamon in this, and in the background, it's cinnamon bread and enough hop to dry it out at the finish.  This is nearly perfectly balanced for my palate (if you got this from the tap, would it, could it, be a tad more hoppy?)

This ribbin' lit'le gent knocked me off me arse. Sweet, sensual and balanced. The hops are light, the malt is thick and heavy and the combined flavor strong, pungent and very much a dirty bastard. Left me feeling cheap, used, confused and ashamed until my scotish blood began to boil and erupt with song. I must have sung ten rounds of "danny boy" while playing the air bagpipes until I collaped in a pool of my own urine, thus fulfilling the prophacy of the "dirty bastard". For he was I and I he. Give it a whorl, you'll like it fine.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2003 This bottle yields a dark reddish brown brew, fairly cloudy, with a decent light tan head.  Aroma is a nice mix of malt, hops, and some spices I just can't place.  A good aroma, though.  The flavor to this one is unlike any flavor I've seen in a Scots Ale.  Almost vineous in the manner of some imperial stouts, though obviously not of the same variety.  Also of note is a light/medium hops bite in the finish, which is stronger than most hops notes in Scots Ales.  I have to say that this beer, to me, seems underrated.  This is a very unique and delicious Scots Ale.  A great brew!

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2014   A very malty beer, dark reddish brown in color. Just loaded with caramel and banana nut flavors. Some notes of dark plummy fruit. Slightly sweet, incredibly smooth finish. Warming and sessionable for the abv.
Dark red/brown in color with a decent brown head.  The aroma shows a nice malt profile.  Sweet fruit, caramel and toffee dominate.  A light hop kick in the finish rounds a decent scottish ale.
Very dark rose color and opaque.  Very sweet taste and you can taste the high alcohol content.  There is some hops flavor but, a very small amount.
Dark red.  Faint nose of fresh fruit.  Thick sweet malty body, alcohol, finishes hoppy.  Unlike any scotch ale I"ve had, aroma is unlively, but the flavors come together well, maybe a little sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2003 Reddish-brown in color, has a huge foamy clingy off white head that leaves a clingy blacing in my glass, has a sweet fruity, bready and citrusy hoppy aromas. Nice sweet fruity cherry flavors balanced with alot of hops, nice bitter finish, medium body with a smooth creamy mouthfeel, pretty damn good.
color is deep amber, no head. aroma is very fruity with underlying hoppiness. bit of smokiness too. flavor is fruity with a lot of cherry character.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006 Bottle... This beer rocks!...Crystal clear, ruby ale. Small, creamy off-white head. Earthy, sweet, peaty, chocolatey, vineous, alcoholic aroma and flavor. In other words, Its as a Scotch ale should be. Full-bodied and oily with mild carbonation. Sweet, malty-as-all-hell, red hot finish.  Terrific! A big THANKS to growler for the bottle!

brown and red take turns in the color as the head dissapears on top and settles to almost nothingness..aroma had notes of cherry toffee and cough syrup..strange malts like melted toffee ontop of unripe cherries...turpintine and scraped whiskey barrels and smoked peat and what not..i started to ponder things and felt myself being trapped in a nutshell, saying to myself this is me in a nutshell..theres a bitterness here that plays of the subtle smoke, cherry, and toffee so amazingly..its superb..its salty..its dirty!

reddish brown color, with minimal head, smoky malt taste, sweet and very smooth, tad bitter in the finish, not bad Re-Rate 12/7/02 This was much better than last time, got some interesting flavors which were hard to finger, malty, and the description of the bottle is well worth reading. Im upping this a few points

UPDATED: APR 3, 2003 Remarkably smooth for such a dark ale, my favorite scotch ale to date.  Be careful though it goes down real smooth, almost too smooth for something at %8.3.  The first time I had this I didn't realize just how high the percentage was until I read the side of the box after my 5th. I think its safe to say that this is my favourite brew from Founders.

Dark mahogany,with a thin,rocky,consistent head.Very pretty lacework.Aromas of alcohol,nuts,and grain.No shortage of hops in the aroma either.Alcohol is quite dominant.Palate is soft but,no lacking.Flavor is more promising than aroma leads to believe.Malty,rummy,brown sugar flavors.Finish is deeply warming with a floral hop tingle and a spicy alcohol wallop. Good,strong,clean tasting beer but a little out of the Scottish style.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2006 The pour yields an impressive rocky, tan, and sticky foam.  Quality nose of dark bread, rum, very grainy malt, pecan, apple, cinnamon, honey, and an unusual-to-the-style faint tropical fruit hop character.  Only a slight phenolic hint lies beneathe this nearly flawless aroma.  Zero trace of peated malt.  A plethora of flavors lay on this silky palate:  extremely warming alcohol, cinnamon toast lingering with cardboardish malt, coconut, pineapple, fig, burnt sugar hint, coarse hop feel, and almost a numbing medicinal malt note that outshines the remainder of the brews flavors.  A quality example, which is very aggressive when found fresh.  Reminds me of a lessened Double Bastard.  Absolutely boastful in the malt and hop department.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: First off, I like going to Founders.  Its one of those places where you can throw your peanut shells on the floor.  It overlooks the Grand River and is in a part of Grand Rapids where theyre starting to redo all the buildings.  Anyway, this was a great dark beer.  Fairly heavy, but not too much so.  I would get this one again.

What a beer!!!  This has to be the best scotch ale Ive ever had.  The waitress at Founders told us it was the best in the world, and we just laughed.  But after drinking it, I think she was right.  Ultra complex, slightly sweet, roasty, nutty, with lots more going on that I cant even identify.  Its very full bodied and quite smooth.  This is an Imperial Scottish Ale as far as Im concerned.  :)

Wow... I cant believe were talking about the same beer here? My god; I mean, taking away the fact that the aroma is fairly non-existant... the flavor and palate is spectacular. Roasted cherries, grapes and some nut, seemed to change consistency in my mouth almost... from a thin start to an instantaneous switch to full bodied, creamy and finishing off by trickling slowly down the throat, revealing the smokey, nut dry finish that was quite nice, this beer had it all... I honestly cant figure out why this beer is rated so low; maybe I was on crack or something, who knows. Perhaps it was the unrelenting flavor...
Very complex with all kinds of different subtle tastes.  Very smooth, long finish, good body.  This is the best Scottish ale Ive had.

Dont know why this beer is taking such a beating here. I found it to be a really pleasant brew with sweet, fruity flavor balanced by a nice hint of smokiness and a good shot of bitterness (Fuggles?).

Absolutely gorgeous garnet color without any head to speak of.  Not much of an aroma, either.  The taste confused me - I was thinking high hops at first before I realized what I was tasting was smoke.  Maybe Id had too many brews.  Anyway, not all that pleasant to me.
burgundy color, smooth, fruity sour then nice and bitter choclate with a slight alcohol bite
Very smooth and creamy. I picked up some smoke and malt. It was pretty good stuff.

Bottle.  A rich scotch ale red color with no head.  Some sweet fruit aromas.  The body is smooth, almost creamy, with a slight grape wine dry bite in the finish.  The aftertaste which is quite nice is better than the flavor.
Only slightly better than a Bud but nowhere near a real scotch ale from Scotland.
Had a cool name.  The beer sure wasnt cool though.  Scotch ale is on my Dont Want list.

very sweet with a winey feel. Hops though not strong or overpowering stand.  I detect too much water and numerous off flavors.  I agree with Hennes, founders is experimenting more but still havent come close to the Dry Hops
A great beer.  The only problem is it tends to disappear far to quickly.
This is some of the best Scotchales around

Whoa - Founders is making some odd brews these days.  The beer is pretty - a deep, deep red, and interestingly round and smooth in the mouth.  The flavour is strange - a hint of toast, but mostly slick, somewhat sweet, molassesy malt.
